**3.8** *Alternating stair tread layout \(Source\: Building Regulation K1 1.10\)*  
Under certain limited domestic circumstances, an alternating stair  
can be used \(Figure 3.8\). In order to save space and increase the  
pitch to well over the standard 42°, these stairs maintain the mini-  
mum going of 220 mm and the maximum rise of 220 mm but only  
for each individual footfall. These stairs require people to walk  
up taking each step alternatively, so someone who may have to  
negotiate one step at a time for both feet would have to zigzag up  
the stair. Equally, turning around halfway up can be problematic,  
requiring both feet on one step to avoid encountering a double rise  
going down.  
# 4.3 Internal stair design  
• **Width\:** Stairs should not be less than 1.2 m wide. \(There is no  
minimum in domestic situations but 850 mm is suggested with  
600 mm when the stair is serving only one room.\)  
• **Treads\:** Treads should be consistent throughout the flight with  
a rise and going as shown in Table I. There should be no open  
risers \(except in domestic situations where they are constructed  
with a minimum 16 mm overhang and a 100 mm diameter sphere  
cannot pass through the risers\). For tapered treads, the standard  
design principles should still be adhered to but with the going  
measured at the middle of the stair, subject to a minimum 50 mm  
tread at the narrow end \(Figure 3.9\).  
• **Landings\:** Stairs should have landings provided not less than  
1.2 m long, for every 16 risers in the case of a utility stair and  
for every 12 risers for general access stairs \(Figure 3.10\). There  
should be at least a 1.2 m level approach at the foot and head of  
the stair with intermediate landings also of 1.2 m \(reduced to  
the stair width with 400 mm unobstructed by door openings for  
domestic situations\).  
• **Handrails\:** Handrails should be provided on both sides \(see  
Figure 3.3\). In the case of general access stairs that are wider  
than the minimum, additional handrails are required to ensure  
that the effective width of access is not less than 1.0 m or more  
than 2.0 m wide.  
• **Headroom\:** A minimum of 2000 mm clear headroom should  
be provided at all landings and access points as well as above  
the pitch line, measured at the outer limit of each going  
\(Figure 3.11\).  
**3.9** *Curved staircase and tapering treads – essential elements*  
*are the going and the minimum tread size \(Source\: Building*  
*Regulation Part K1 1.9\)* **People and movement 3-7**  
# 4.5 Handrails  
The design of handrails needs to take account of the principle that  
all people, regardless of age, gender or ability should be able to use  
them. They could in certain circumstances provide a physical aid to  
assist ambulant disabled in hauling themselves upward and there-  
fore be subject to significant loading. They should also provide a  
distinctive visual contrast to assist in location.  
In most circumstances, handrails should be fixed between 900  
mm and 1100 mm above the floor or pitch line \(see Figure 3.12\)  
and subject to the design requirements set out in Figure 3.13.  
**3.10** *Staircase landings \(Source\: Building Regulation*  
*Part K1 1.7\)*  
**3.11** *Staircase headroom – essential elements are the points at*  
*which it is measured \(Source\: Building Regulation Part K1 1.3\)*  
# 4.4 Staircase handling capacity  
Staircase handling capacity \(Cs\) in people per minute can be cal-  
culated using\:  
Cs = 0.83 \(60 *v D W*\)  
where\: *v* is the average pedestrian speed \(m/s\)  
*D* is the average pedestrian density \(people per m2\)  
*W* is the corridor width \(m\)  
**Free flow design\: D** = **0.6 people per m2 and v** = **0.6 to 0.8 m/s**  
**Full flow design\: D** = **2.0 people per m2 and v** = **0.6 to 0.8 m/s**  
Note\: People tend to walk in an orderly fashion on stairs.  
**3.13** *Handrail design – essential elements are those related to*  
*grip and structural integrity \(Source\: Building Regulation Part*  
*K1 1.13\)*  
# 4.6 Guarding  
Handrails and stair guarding serve distinctly different purposes  
although they can also be combined into one element. Where hand-  
rails, usually wall mounted, are used to assist in negotiating stairs  
as a handhold, stair guarding is there to prevent people falling over  
an exposed edge of the stair; banisters serve both purposes.  
In the case of staircase design, guarding should be provided  
to the same height requirements as the associated handrails when  
there is a drop of more than 600 mm.  
Building Regulation Part K1 requires that in buildings that will  
be used by children under five, additional conditions come into  
force. Inclusive design principles suggest that this should include  
all buildings where children under five may visit, thereby including  
almost all buildings.  
**3.12** *Handrail positioning – essential elements are the dimensions and structural integrity \(Source\: Building Regulation Part K1 1.12\)* **3-8 People and movement**  
These additional yet very sensible requirements suggest that  
guarding should be designed to accomplish the following\:  
• Prevent children being held fast by the guarding  
• Ensure that a 100 mm sphere cannot pass through any openings  
in the guarding  
• Prevent children from readily being able to climb the guarding.  
# 5 MECHANICAL MOVEMENT WITHIN  
# BUILDINGS  
# 5.1 Introduction  
Mechanical devices for moving people around buildings are now  
essential aspects of all large building design and they involve signif-  
icant energy demands and safety backups for when energy supplies  
are restricted. Before reliable and safe systems were produced, the  
effective height of buildings was restricted to the number of sto-  
reys individuals would be happy to walk up. It is worth noting that  
mechanical systems are often found to be a compromise between  
moving small number of people very quickly \(with a low overall  
population movement\) and moving large numbers of people more  
slowly \(with high overall population movement\).  
# 5.2 Escalators  
Escalators are essentially moving staircases but where the people  
on them are expected to remain standing on one step while the step  
itself moves. For this reason, the rise and going are not governed  
by the same criteria as normal stairs. It is also why climbing a static  
escalator is more difficult than conventional stairs.  
• Escalators typically operate at speeds of 0.5 m/s to 0.65 m/s  
\(0.75 m/s in London Underground\).  
• Escalators are normally constructed at 30° incline.  
• People walk up stairs typically at 0.5 m/s.  
• Depending on the design \(speeds and width\), escalators can  
move more than 10000 people per hour.  
The standard shape of an escalator is provided by a steel truss that  
supplies the framework to support the moving staircase between  
storeys \(see Figure 3.14\). The individual steps in an escalator are  
roughly triangular in section and connected to two different guid-  
ing tracks that loop around the system and govern the relative  
position of each step as well as the movement. One track is the  
driving mechanism \(chain\) where the leading edge of the step is  
connected on each side and the step is essentially pulled around  
the loop in this way. The lower edge simply follows with two  
wheels located in a guiding track. This follows the main drive  
chain but by altering the relative position of the track to the drive  
chain, the position of each step is changed. By altering the space  
between the two loops, the steps are kept horizontal through-  
out the journey and as the pitch flattens at the top and bottom,  
they fold onto each other. This process is assisted by a series of  
grooves where each step fits together with the next in a tongue  
and groove alignment.  
The movement of an escalator is powered by an electric motor  
housed within the truss and geared to move the drive chain and the  
handrail as required keeping it aligned with the steps. The handrail  
is simply a synthetic rubber conveyor belt looped around a similar  
path but off set from the main step drive mechanism.  
Design and construction considerations\:  
Clear access areas should be provided equal to twice the escala-  
tor tread width in length and the escalator tread width plus 100  
mm either side in overall width.  
Minimum clear headroom of 2130 mm \(measured vertically from  
the pitch line\) should be maintained across the whole of the system.  
The handrail should have 100 mm clearance horizontally and 25  
mm clearance vertically from any adjacent surfaces.  
All connecting floor surfaces should be continuous with any  
abrupt change in level limited to a maximum of 6 mm.  
\(*Source\: Kone’s Escalators and Autowalks Planning*  
*Guide*, p. 49, Section 6.2, parts A to D\)  
Escalator handling capacity \(Ce\) in people per minute can be  
calculated using\:  
Ce = 60 \(*V k s*\)  
where\: *V* is the speed along the incline \(m/s\)  
*k* is the average density of people \(people per step\)  
*s* is the number of steps per metre \(m\) e.g. for a 400 mm  
step rise, *s* = 2.5  
Step density is theoretically related to escalator width where\:  
600 mm wide *k* = 1.0  
800 mm wide *k* = 1.5  
1000 mm wide *k* = 2.0  
People tend not to fill escalator stairs to capacity, so use half these  
values.  
An example from Table II indicates a 1000 mm wide step at  
0.50 m/s will carry 150 people per minute, in reality this should be  
assumed to be 75 people per minute or 4500 people per hour.

# 5.3 Moving walkways  
Moving walkways \(or a mechanised passenger conveyor system\)  
can be assumed to have the same design and performance char-  
acteristics as escalators, moving similar amounts of people and  
subject to similar speed and operating mechanics \(Figure 3.15\).  
They generally come in two forms. The pallet variety is simply a  
flat escalator with individual steps \(pallets\) running horizontally  
\(or inclined as required\). These do have a potential advantage due  
to the interconnection provided by extended grooves between each **People and movement 3-9**  
**3.15** *A one-speed mechanised passenger conveyor system, may be flat, or up to 12° for prams, shopping trolleys, etc., or up to 15° for*  
*special installations. Other systems available permit ‘valley’ and ‘hill’ longitudinal profiles; also surface laying of conveyor on drive*  
*motor on existing floors. Capacity of system shown is 7200 persons per hour. Systems are available up to 8000 pph. Speed range is*  
*0.45–0.6 m/s. Tread widths, 1000–1400 mm*  
step, allowing the speed to be varied over the journey. The grooves  
close up at lower embarking and disembarking speeds but increase  
during the middle higher speed portion of the journey. The second  
form has a continuous conveyor belt constructed of metal belts or  
rubber walkways running over rollers.  
# 5.4 Lifts  
In most circumstances, a passenger lift is the most suitable method  
of vertical transportation within buildings. Because of their reliance  
on a power source, they should always also have a fire protected  
stair access provided as well. They also come in a wide range of  
sizes from a simple two storey hydraulic lift to the sophisticated  
operating systems needed in 100 storey skyscrapers. A lift car size  
of 2000 mm wide by 1400 mm deep will provide adequate space for  
any wheelchair and a number of other users although Figure 3.16  
illustrates the minimum size required.  
A well-designed passenger lift provision will include most,  
if not all, of the inclusive design principles. However, in certain  
refurbishment situations, a full scale lift provision is not possible  
**3.16** *Lift design – key minimum dimensions Source\:* Building  
Regulation Part M Diagram 11  
and in those cases, specific wheelchair platform stairlift or lifting  
platform may be suitable. Wheelchair platform stairlifts differ from  
lifting platforms in that they take a single wheelchair up a flight of  
stairs by means of a mechanical rail and traction device. Lifting  
platforms by contrast raise a platform that can accommodate a  
wheelchair plus attendant or partially sighted people over a cer-  
tain vertical distance. These can be relatively short distances such  
as negotiating a change in level or more fully enclosed journeys  
between storeys.  
# 5.5 Wheelchair platform stairlifts and lifting platforms  
Where a platform stairlift is installed, the minimum stair widths  
need to be increased to accommodate the extra width required  
by the stairlift \(Figure 3.17\). They also require a platform of 800  
mm wide and 1250 mm deep and are limited to a speed of 0.15  
m/s. In addition, they should also have controls that restrict usage  
to those in need and authorised to do so. These controls should  
include a ‘continuous pressure’ control device where if the pressure  
is released, the lift comes to a halt.  
# 5.6 Lifting platforms  
Lifting platforms, like stairlifts, are not replacements for a good  
passenger lift service and therefore are also not ideal. Both require  
the continuous pressure control device which can be too strenuous  
for some users to maintain. Lifting platforms have the same speed  
restriction and minimum platform size for single wheelchair users.  
In addition, however, they are also restricted to a 2000 mm travel  
if they are not enclosed. Where they are enclosed, the minimum  
dimensions increase to 900 mm wide and 1400 mm deep and if  
the wheelchair user has an attendant, to 1100 mm wide and 1400  
mm deep.  
# 5.7 Hydraulic lifts  
These lifts appear the same as any other standard lift design in  
that the most apparent aspect, the lift car, would not be any dif-  
ferent. The difference lies in the driving mechanism \(Figure 3.18\).  
Hydraulic lifts use a hydraulic ram to move the lift car between sto-  
reys and because it consists of a piston that is forced upwards by a  
fluid pumping system \(usually oil\) they are limited to the structural **3-10 People and movement**  
**3.17** *Details of stair lift for wheelchair, or for seated passenger \(Source\: Gimson Stairlifts Ltd\)*  
and height restrictions of the piston. Some use a hole in the ground  
to house the piston when fully descended, others use telescopic  
pistons. The mechanism is relatively simple in that an electrically  
operated pump forces the fluid from a reservoir into the piston  
to ascend and a valve allows and controls the returning oil when  
descending. Even if the reservoir were to fail, the action of having  
to force the oil back through the system means that hydraulic lifts  
would return to ground level fairly slowly and therefore also safely.  
In action, as the ascending lift car approaches the correct floor, a  
control system gradually reduces the pumping speed. At each floor,  
with the pump off, the oil in the cylinder cannot flow back through  
the pump and, with the valve closed, the car is supported by the  
full piston. To descend, the control system opens the valve so that  
the oil in the cylinder can return to the reservoir. It is the weight  
of the car and contents that push down on the piston driving the oil  
back into the reservoir. To stop the car at a lower floor, the control  
system simply closes the valve.  
Although a very safe mechanism, hydraulic lifts are limited in  
**3.18** *Schematic diagram of a direct-acting hydraulic lift with* scope because of the length of pistons required and also because  
*remote machine room* they are relatively energy intensive when compared with the alternative traction system. In raising a lift car and its contents, a  
hydraulic system has to produce all of the required power via the  
pump to overcome the force of gravity for the full weight of the  
lift car and load. In a traction system, the weight of the lift car is  
balanced by a counterweight so that moving only the difference in  
weights requires power.  
# 5.8 Traction lifts  
The most common design for lifts is the traction variety where the  
lift car is raised and lowered by steel wire ropes attached to the  
car and looped around a sheave. In effect a pulley, the sheave has  
grooves around the edge, designed and shaped to grip the ropes so  
that a rotating sheave moves the ropes simply because of the friction  
between the two. In higher speed lifts, the ropes are wrapped around  
the sheave twice to provide extra friction. A traction lift therefore  
works by an electric motor turning the sheave directly \(or via a gear-  
ing system\), either one way or another to ascend or descend.  
The great advantage of traction lifts is that the ropes are also  
connected to a counterweight on the other side of the sheave. The  
counterweight is normally designed to balance the lift car at 40  
per cent capacity, considered to be the average load in use. When  
loaded equally like this, the sheave motor has little work to do in  
moving the lift up or down. In addition to guide rails in the lift  
shaft, traction lifts usually locate the sheave, motor and control  
system in a machine room above the lift shaft, adding to the over-  
all height required as well as the overall structural loading on the  
building \(Figure 3.19\).  
**3.19** *Schematic diagram of a conventional electric traction lift*  
*with high-level machine room*  
The safety of traction systems depends on two fundamental princi-  
ples. Firstly, the fear that a rope may snap or become disconnected  
is overcome by using multiple ropes; typically, four to eight wound  
steel wire ropes where each rope individually can support the lift  
car. Secondly, they will also use a braking system. Physical braking  
systems typically use a governor and sprung flyweights that acti-  
vate when the lift is travelling too fast and then through linkages  
bring the braking system into operation. Electromagnetic braking  
systems keep the brakes open in normal operation so that a loss of  
power would trigger them. They can also be used as part of the con-  
trol system at each stop. In addition to overrun braking protection  
at the top and bottom of shafts, a heavy-duty piston shock absorber  
system at the bottom will cushion a runaway car’s landing.  
• Gearless traction lifts – the industry standard – typically operate  
at speeds in excess of 2.5 m/s.  
• Geared traction lifts – more efficient – typically operated at  
speeds between 1.75 and 2.5 m/s \(Otis 2011\).  
# People and movement 3-11  
# 5.9 Design of lift systems  
The design of lift systems is a complicated and in most instances,  
a specialist operation. This is because of the very many parameters  
involved including such things as the number of lifts available, the  
populations being served, usage patterns \(peak flows\), number of  
storeys being served and also the quality of the service required,  
to name just a few. Specialist design services will include eval-  
uation of ‘round trip times’, passenger demands, limitations and  
assumptions around peak traffic flows as well as car size, number  
and location, clearly well beyond the scope of this chapter. Yet  
there is some basic information that is useful and can form the basis  
of ongoing design work.  
# 5.10 Handling capacity of lifts  
It is important to recognise that lifts provide a different service to  
that of stairs and escalators discussed previously. Where escala-  
tors can carry large amounts of people relatively slowly, lifts carry  
much smaller amounts much more quickly.  
• A previous example showed a relatively small 1000 mm wide  
escalator at 0.50 m/s carrying 75 people per minute or 4500 peo-  
ple per hour.  
• The most efficient group of 8 lifts serving 14 floors at full 21  
person capacity can only handle 50 people per minute or 3000  
people per hour.  
• Take that down to 3 lifts in 8 storeys at 10-person capacity and  
the figure reduces to 16 people per minute or 960 people per hour.  
# 5.11 Location and number of cars  
The most efficient design layout for lift lobbies is in a cul-de-sac  
layout as indicated in Figures 3.20 and 3.21 as it provides the  
shortest distance from any waiting position; it also provides the  
best view of all lifts in operation and, most importantly, it avoids  
obstruction by passers-by.  
**3.20** *Plan of recessed lobby and machine room for multi-lift*  
*installation – dimensions refer to the values in Table IV*  
**3.21** *Plan of cul-de-sac lobby and machine room – dimensions*  
*refer to the values in Table IV* **3-12 People and movement**  
Lift cars are rated by their load capacity in kilograms and the  
number of people they can carry. The load capacity is defined in  
EN81\(1998\) and must not be exceeded but people capacity ratings  
can be misleading and experience has found that in reality, the fig-  
ure should be adjusted for variations in people size, luggage etc.  
A further reduction comes from statistical analysis of passenger  
behaviour suggesting that a 20 per cent reduction should be applied  
to get the true capacity of individual cars.  
In very tall buildings, where the number of lift cars becomes  
very large to serve all storeys from the access point, ‘sky lobbies’  
provide an intermediate access point where a specific lift will only  
take people to this point for further distribution at higher ‘local’  
levels.

# David Dropkin and Neil Smith  
*David Dropkin and Neil Smith are consultant members of the National Register of Access Consultants and are inclusive design*  
*specialists.*  
*KEY POINT*  
• *Inclusive design goes beyond just making the built environ-*  
*ment accessible – it is about creating environments that allow*  
*everyone the same opportunity of use, enjoyment and experience*  
*without separation*  
# Contents  
1 Inclusive design  
2 People  
3 Mobility equipment  
4 Built environment elements  
5 Sanitary facilities  
6 Bibliography  
Inclusive design is about making places everyone can use.  
The inclusive design process is just as important in the briefing  
and master planning stages as it is in the design of individual  
components/built elements. The built environment should facil-  
itate independence, not only in the built form, but also in green  
space strategies, social infrastructure planning, housing and  
transportation.  
# 1 INCLUSIVE DESIGN  
# 1.1 Scope  
This chapter deals with inclusive and accessible design for  
non-dwellings. For dwellings, refer to Chapter 22 Houses and flats,  
Chapter 23 Housing for older people and Chapter 24 Housing for  
students and young people.  
# 1.2 Design principles  
Good design reflects the diverse nature of people and does not  
impose barriers of any kind, whether physical, cultural or social.  
The design of the built environment can form barriers that are, or  
can become, disabling to all people. Designing inclusively guar-  
antees accessibility to all and considers age, social circumstance,  
gender, disability, sexual orientation and faith.  
The British Standards Institution’s \(BSI\) BS 7000–6\:2005  
*Design management systems* – *Part 6*\: *Managing inclusive design*  
identified that inclusive design recognises diversity by addressing  
the ability and preferences of people, covering elements such as  
age, disability, culture, gender, allergies and cognitive abilities.  
Making environments easy to use for everyone requires consider-  
ation other than just physical factors – it is also about experience.  
How people feel when using a building or space is of equal impor-  
tance to their physical needs.  
The Design Council’s Inclusive Design Hub advises that apply-  
ing the following five principles of inclusive design from the outset  
can help achieve an accessible and inclusive environment\:  
• Place people at the heart of the design process  
• Acknowledge diversity and difference  
• Offer choice where a single design solution cannot accommodate  
all users  
• Provide for flexibility in use  
• Provide buildings and environments that are convenient and  
enjoyable for everyone to use.  
BS 8300–1\:2018 and BS 8300–2\:2018 *Design of an accessible*  
*and inclusive built environment – Code of Practice* \(BS 8300\) set  
out the importance of integrating inclusive design principles into  
the development process in order to achieve the desired outcome of  
inclusive and accessible environments.

# 1.3 Regulations and guidance  
In the United Kingdom, Building Regulations or Technical  
Standards form a starting point in determining minimal spatial cri-  
teria for delivering accessible environments for non-dwellings. In  
England and Wales, these are set out in Approved Documents of  
the Building Regulations Part K and Part M, Technical Booklet  
R in Northern Ireland and the Building Standards Technical  
Handbook in Scotland. However, following building regulation  
provision does not necessarily deliver inclusive projects, as set out  
in the five principles mentioned previously. Here, the goal of cre-  
ating aesthetic and functional environments that provide equity of  
experience for everyone requires a creative and inclusive design  
process that carries through the building design process and deliv-  
ery into day-to-day use and management practice.  
A simple demonstration of this is as follows. The design of a  
new building incorporates steps that conform to the provisions of  
the building regulations. With the inclusion of steps, the design  
team add a ramp that also conforms to regulation, in that it pro-  
vides step-free access. This ‘bolt-on’ solution is ‘accessible’ but  
not ‘inclusive’ as it separates those who can and those who cannot  
use the steps. An inclusive approach, for instance, might challenge  
if the stairs were necessary in the first place and if they could be  
eliminated entirely or ameliorated by changing the approach by  
gently grading the approaches.  
Good practice guidelines such as BS 8300 should be drawn  
upon in order to go beyond minimum requirements if an inclusive  
environment is to be achieved.  
For sport-specific approaches, see Sport England’s Design  
Guidance Note *Accessible sport facilities* with detailed commentary  
and spatial requirements. BS 8300 does not have detailed guidance  
for stadia. For development of stadia and similar venues, the Sports  
Grounds Safety Authority’s \(SGSA\) *Guide to Safety at Sports*  
*Grounds* \(also known as the ‘Green Guide’\) 6th edition should be  
used in conjunction with *Accessible stadia* and *Accessible stadia*  
*supplementary guidance* also published by the SGSA.  
Although withdrawn, the recommendations of Building  
Bulletin 102 *Designing for disabled children and children with*  
*special educational needs* are essential to incorporate early in the  
design process \(it is worth noting that although the areas guidance  
is superseded by Building Bulletin 104, the general guidance is still  
relevant\).  
Additionally, consideration must be given to local planning pol-  
icy and any supplementary guidance or documents. For instance,  
the Greater London Authority set out a comprehensive approach  
to meeting their planning policy requirement for inclusive envi-  
ronments with the publication of *Accessible London\: achieving an*  
*inclusive environment*.  
**4-1** **4-2 Inclusive and accessible design**  
# 1.4 Equality Act 2010 and inclusive design  
The Equality Act 2010 \(the Act\) provides the legal framework in  
Great Britain protecting people from discrimination. It unified a  
range of existing discrimination legislation including supersed-  
ing the Disability Discrimination Acts 1995 and 2005 \(DDA\). It  
is essential in creating and delivering inclusive environments to  
understand the overarching principles of the Act.  
The Act created a piece of anti-discrimination legislation across  
nine ‘protected characteristics’. These are\:  
• Age  
• Disability  
• Gender reassignment  
• Marriage and civil partnership  
• Pregnancy and maternity  
• Race  
• Religion or belief  
• Sex  
• Sexual orientation.  
In taking an inclusive design approach, all protected char-  
acteristics should be considered. Disability is the only protected  
characteristic that has specified duties relating to adjustments to the  
built environment and the need to remove physical barriers, as well  
as providing auxiliary aids and/or auxiliary services.  
The ‘reasonable adjustments’ duty within the Act imposes  
a duty on employers, service providers and public functions to  
make reasonable adjustments to any physical feature which may  
put a disabled person at a substantial disadvantage compared to  
non-disabled people. This is not a minimalist policy of simply  
ensuring that some access is available to disabled people. Instead,  
as far as is reasonably practicable, it approximates the access  
enjoyed by disabled people to that enjoyed by the rest of the public.  
The Equality Act is not a design standard, and does not impose  
design criteria. The Act does not have specific and defined provision  
for the built environment and therefore, physical features cannot  
be ‘compliant’, nor can any product be ‘compliant’. Although the  
Act does not cover physical features or auxiliary aids for protected  
characteristics other than disability, there is a general duty for all  
public bodies under the Public Sector Duty to have due regard to  
the need to advance equality of opportunity for people covered by  
protected characteristics.  
The design of built environment may create barriers to people  
with protected characterises other than disability, and therefore,  
further consideration should be given to delivering inclusion for  
everyone rather than ‘compliance’ with the more narrowly defined  
legal obligation. It is also important to consider the intersectionality  
of the protected characteristics set out in the Act, as a disabled per-  
son might also be protected by one or more of the other protected  
characteristics as well. An example of this would be provision of  
accessible prayer facilities, or access to appropriate sanitary facili-  
ties for people undergoing gender reassignment.  
The Equality Act does not apply to Northern Ireland, where the  
Disability Discrimination Act 1995 and the Special Educational  
Needs and Disability \(NI\) Order 2005 continue to give disabled  
people important rights not to be discriminated against.  
# 1.5 Design process  
In order to deliver inclusive environments, the principles of inclu-  
sive design must be integrated into the design process from the  
outset. Making environments easy to use for everyone requires  
consideration other than just physical factors. These include, but  
are not limited to, signage/way-finding, information systems,  
lighting, visual contrast, controls and door furniture, interactive  
displays and materials.  
Inclusive design relates as much to the design process as to the  
final product, bonding user-experience with professional expertise  
and management practice. The process extends from inception,  
through the planning process, detailed design and construction to  
occupation, management and operation.  
The goal of creating aesthetic and functional environments that  
can be used equally by everyone, irrespective of age, gender, faith  
or disability, requires a creative and inclusive design process work-  
ing towards accommodating a diverse range of users.  
Following the minimum provisions of the building regulations,  
or dimensional criteria within good practice guidance alone, will  
not deliver inclusive projects. For this, the close involvement of  
design team, client, stakeholder groups and end-users are required.  
# 1.6 RIBA Plan of Work  
The RIBA Plan of Work provides a framework for architects to  
use with their clients, bringing greater clarity to the different stages  
of a project. The National Register of Access Consultants set out  
a process for delivering inclusive environments to align with the  
2013 version of the Plan of Work. Table I highlights and explains  
what activity should be undertaken at each RIBA work stage to  
embed the principles of inclusive design from project inception to  
completion. It is important that the inclusive design process should  
be documented, reviewed and monitored throughout the different  
stages of the project. Though now superseded, this is still a useful  
reference to the inclusive design inputs at each stage.  
In 2020, RIBA revised the Plan of Work to address changes in  
the industry such as digital innovation, modern methods of con-  
struction, and changes in project drivers, including delivering best  
value and an increased awareness of ethics. For the first time, the  
Plan of Work now incorporates an inclusive design strategy. RIBA  
acknowledges that accessibility and inclusion for disabled people  
is a firm policy of Government and the aspiration and expectation  
of the general public. The Plan of Work identifies that the inclu-  
sive design strategy should consider all of these and be developed  
at the outset and implemented over the building’s useful life. The  
codes of practice that form the two parts of BS 8300\:2018 provide  
a detailed breakdown of the contents of an inclusive design strategy  
for each stage of a project.  
# 1.7 User engagement  
User consultation and the involvement of local people, including local  
disabled people’s groups, also help to highlight particular, sometimes  
local, access issues that need to be addressed. People are the experts in  
their own lived experience and the barriers they face. Giving excluded  
people the opportunity to bring their personal experiences into the  
design process through co-design enriches design development. This  
was the case with the design of the climbing experience Up at the O2  
in Greenwich, London \(Figure 4.1\), which has been made accessible  
to a wide range of disabled people including wheelchair users.  
# 2 PEOPLE  
# 2.1 Disability  
Under the Equality Act 2010 a person is considered disabled if  
they have a physical or mental impairment that has a ‘substan-  
tial’ and ‘long-term’ negative effect on their ability to do normal  
daily activities. It is estimated that approximately 21 per cent of  
the UK population \(14.1 million people\) are disabled, according to  
the Department for Work and Pension’s *Family resources survey*  
2018/2019.  
While the spatial requirements of people with mobility impair-  
ments, including wheelchair users, are important in terms of  
designing the physical environment, it is necessary to understand  
the barriers experienced by people with a broad range of access  
requirements, which could be sensory, cognitive, physical or relate  
to neurodiversity.  
In general, designing to provide access, whether physical or  
intellectual, will yield results that benefit the community at large.

# 2.3 Neurodiversity  
Neurodiversity is an umbrella term referring to a group of neu-  
rological conditions which share common features, in particular  
differences in how people learn and process information. Definitions  
vary, but the term covers conditions such as dyslexia and dyscalcu-  
lia, dyspraxia and developmental coordination disorder, learning  
disabilities, attention deficit disorders \(ADD/ADHD\), mental health  
diversity and autistic spectrum \(Autism/Asperger’s syndrome\).  
Neurodiversity is a form of human diversity. The idea that there  
is one ‘normal’ or ‘healthy’ type of brain or mind or one ‘right’  
style of neurocognitive functioning is no more valid than the idea  
that there is one ‘normal’ or ‘right’ gender, race or culture. We all  
have differing neurological needs.  
There is very little detailed guidance on the design of the  
built environment and neurodiversity. To address this, the British  
Standards Institute is expected to publish PAS 6463 *Design for the*  
*mind – Neurodiversity and the built environment* in 2022.  
The nature of neurodiversity is that people interact with the  
built environment differently, and on that basis, there may not be  
a single solution. While it is advisable to minimise factors that  
cause difficulties within the environment in general, it may not be  
possible to deliver environments suitable for everyone. A key aim  
should be to create environments in which people are able to either  
adapt a space to suit their needs or find a space in which they can  
manage their needs.  
Sensory overload is a common issue; this could be visual,  
audible, olfactory or spatial. Examples of this may be manifested  
through poor acoustics and overbearing background noise, signif-  
icant reflection or glare, patterned surfaces that do not incorporate  
natural forms, or the lack of personal space or defensible space  
\(that is, quiet space in which people feel secure and gain respite  
from the overstimulation\). The converse may also be true, as there  
are people with hyposensitivity that need the opportunity of gain-  
ing sensory stimulus.  
The availability of calm spaces, logical layouts and defined  
way-finding and orientation are also important factors to be  
addressed, as are the memorability and familiarity of space.  
# 2.4 An ageing population\: the implications for design  
The UK’s population is getting older and, as a result, the pro-  
portion of the population that are aged 65 or over is significantly  
increasing. Age UK’s publication *Later Life in the United Kingdom*  
identified that there are 11.6 million people aged 65 or over in the  
UK, and over a third of the overall population are aged 50 years or  
older. The number of people aged 60 or over is expected to pass the  
20 million mark by 2030. The number of people aged 65 or over is  
projected to rise by over 40 per cent in the next 17 years to over 16  
million; by 2040 it is expected that nearly one in four people will  
be aged 65 or over.  
The Office for National Statistics identified that by 2039 the  
number of people aged 75 and over is projected to rise by 89.3 per  
cent to 9.9 million; more than 1 in 12 of the population is projected  
to be aged 80 or over, while the number of people aged 85 and over  
is projected to more than double, reaching 3.6 million.  
Amongst all people in the United Kingdom, 21 per cent reported  
a disability in 2018/19, an increase from 19 per cent in 2008/09.  
Many older people have, or will have, an impairment of some kind.  
There is a demonstrable correlation between age and disability.  
The *Family resources survey* identified that 8 per cent of children  
were disabled compared to 19 per cent of adults of working age; of  
adults over state pension age 44 per cent were disabled. In addition,  
the average number of years that people survive with a disability or  
long-term illness is increasing.  
People also tend to shrink slightly with age. More significantly,  
the body tends to be less flexible in regard to adapting to dimen-  
sionally unfavourable situations. Older people tend to have more  
than one impairment. It is, therefore, critical that design also allows  
for older people.  
A further consideration is dementia. The Alzheimer’s Society  
estimates that there are approximately 850000 people with dementia  
in the UK, a figure likely to increase to 1.6 million people by 2040.  
# 2.5 Children and adolescents  
Where facilities are to be used solely by small children, specific  
heights should be adjusted to meet their requirements. There are  
approximately four million children aged five or under. Therefore,  
design in general should also consider the needs of younger chil-  
dren, for example, when providing family facilities or sinks at  
lower heights in toilets. There is limited guidance on the design of  
the built environment for disabled children, and consultation with  
stakeholders can provide invaluable information based on practice  
and precedent.  
Disabled children and young people currently face multiple bar-  
riers, making it more difficult for them to achieve their potential, to  
achieve the outcomes their peers expect and to succeed in education.  
Disabled parents and carers of children should also be consid-  
ered at all stages of the design process. Where family facilities  
are provided, for example baby changing rooms, these should be  
accessible to both disabled and non-disabled parents/carers.  
# 2.6 Large people  
Obesity is more common among people from areas of higher depri-  
vation, older age groups, some ethnic minority groups and disabled  
people. The *Health Survey for England* 2019 found that 68 per cent of  
men and 60 per cent of women are overweight \(BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2\) or  
obese \(BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2\). Obesity prevalence rose between 1993 and  
2019 from 13 to 27 per cent for men and from 16 to 29 per cent for  
women. The survey found that one in five children in reception year  
are overweight or obese, rising to one in three children in Year 6.  
Both raised BMI and very high waist circumference are thought  
to be independent predictors of future obesity-related ill health, and  
are considered predictive measures for identifying an individual’s  
risk of obesity-related conditions including high cholesterol, high  
blood pressure, diabetes, bone and joint problems, and breathing  
difficulties – as well as premature adult mortality.  
Pregnant women, like larger people, can also be disadvantaged  
by the design of the environment. Long routes and stairs can be  
very tiring; narrow seats, doors and small toilet cubicles are other  
common barriers.  
In certain buildings such as football stadia, deliberately narrow  
doorways are used to ensure control over entry. In these cases, and  
also where turnstiles are used, additional provision for large people  
should be made.  
Where there is fixed seating, for example in a theatre, there  
should be a number of easily accessed amenity seats, which may **Inclusive and accessible design 4-5**  
have increased width and legroom, have removable arms or fold-  
down arms and may include a space for an assistance dog.  
# 2.7 Mobility ranges  
Many people with a mobility related disability find covering long  
distances a significant barrier. The Department for Transport’s  
*Inclusive Mobility* publication identified that of disabled people  
who were able to walk, approximately 30 per cent could manage no  
more than 50 m without stopping or severe discomfort. A further  
20 per cent could only manage between 50 and 200 m.  
Mobility ranges vary enormously between individuals with age  
and disability, while factors such as weather, topography \(gradi-  
ents\) and obstacles can also affect mobility ranges. In pedestrian  
schemes, extended travel distances should be avoided where rea-  
sonable and practicable. Where gradients exist, the distance people  
can traverse should be reduced. Conversely, the provision of seat-  
ing and resting places can extend the distance people can traverse.  
The recommended maximum distance on level ground between  
resting places should be no more than 50 m.

possible with movement of the torso\). *Inclusive Mobility* gives fig-  
ures for comfortable and extended reach ranges; see Table II and  
Figures 4.2 and 4.3.  
When considering reach ranges, it is important to consider the  
need for appropriate design solutions that provide for people with  
a range of heights \(people of short stature and people above aver-  
age height as well as wheelchair users\). However, it is important  
to remember that designing features that are easily accessible to a  
wheelchair user may exclude other people, for example, an ambu-  
lant disabled person who is unable to bend down easily. More than  
one solution might be required. For instance, if all work surfaces  
are designed for use by wheelchair users, this could have a dispro-  
portionately negative ergonomic impact for people of tall stature.  
Therefore, adjustable height work surfaces or a choice of work sur-  
face heights should be provided, rather than designing one solution  
for all.  
# 2.8 Reach and height  
The distance and angle that an individual can reach is dependent on  
their size, agility, dexterity and whether they are seated or stand-  
ing. The ability of a seated person, for example, in a wheelchair to  
reach forward, sideways, upwards or downwards is different from  
someone standing.  
Reach distance forms an arc, based on shoulder level. Reach

Wheelchair users need quite a lot of space to move comfortably  
and safely. People who walk with two sticks may require a wider  
circulatory route than someone using a wheelchair. It is worth not-  
ing that a double pushchair may be wider than an occupied electric  
wheelchair.  
# 3.2 Wheelchair and scooter users  
The range of wheelchair dimensions is considerable, particularly  
given the overall length and width that an occupied wheelchair may  
extend to. The figures given for the width of a wheelchair user do  
not usually make allowance for their elbows and hands. To propel  
a wheelchair manually, a clearance of not less than 50 mm, prefer-  
ably 100 mm, on both sides is required.  
The maximum length a conventional wheelchair user with  
leg-supports or an electric mobility scooter is likely to occupy is  
1600 mm. Conventionally seated wheelchair users do not usually  
occupy a length of more than approximately 1250 mm. However,  
if a wheelchair user has a companion then the combined length of  
the space they occupy will be typically 1375 mm – design guidance  
allows for 1570 mm.  
The average height of wheelchair users is 1080 mm but can  
range as high as 1535 mm. The average height of a scooter user is  
approximately 1170 mm but can range as high as a maximum of  
1500 mm.  
In designing for wheelchair users, the critical dimensions are\:  
• Eye height, around 120–130 mm below seated height, giving a  
5th–95th per cent range for wheelchair users from 960 to 1250  
mm \(1080–1315 mm for scooter users\)  
• Knee height, 500–690 mm  
• Seat height, 460–490 mm  
• Ankle height, manual wheelchair users, 175–300 mm; electric  
wheelchair users, 380–520 mm  
• Height to bottom of foot support, 60–150 mm.

# 3.7 Space provision for assistance dogs  
Assistance dogs include guide dogs and hearing dogs. While peo-  
ple primarily with sensory related disabilities have an assistance  
dog, people with limited mobility and wheelchair users may also  
have an assistance dog. *Inclusive Mobility* identifies that people  
with assistance dogs require a clear unobstructed width of at least  
1100 mm.  
# 4 BUILT ENVIRONMENT ELEMENTS  
# 4.1 Scope  
Many elements, such as the design of religious facilities, trans-  
port infrastructure, master planning, schools, libraries as well as  
features such as stair design and so forth are detailed in the other  
chapters of the *Metric Handbook*. The following advice supple-  
ments the other chapters and follows the macro to the minutia of  
the design process.  
# 4.2 Inclusive neighbourhoods  
Inclusive neighbourhoods help to build cohesive, successful and  
sustainable communities.  
There is no defined content of an inclusive neighbourhood, but  
it should be recognised that access to good quality accessible and  
inclusive social infrastructure is vital. Social infrastructure covers a  
wide range of facilities such as health provision, educational, com-  
munity, cultural, play, recreation and sports facilities, and green  
infrastructure. Inclusion in the widest sense should be married with  
environmental, economic and social sustainability. As well as look-  
ing at physical factors, this should also address health impacts that  
create unintentional barriers for under-represented groups.  
One underlying concept that supports inclusive neighbourhoods  
is – like that of lifetime homes – making neighbourhoods adaptable  
and addressing peoples’ differing needs over the different stages of  
their lives. An inclusive neighbourhood should be welcoming, easy  
to move around, enjoyable and somewhere they feel secure. There  
should be a focus on the inclusivity of connections and spaces  
between buildings, which are often overlooked.  
The Mayor of London’s *Accessible London* sets out three prin-  
ciples to support this concept. Neighbourhoods should be\:  
• Well connected, walkable and easy to get around  
• Have a choice of homes, accessible infrastructure and services,  
as well as places to spend time in, work in and with a mix of  
accessible and adaptable uses  
• Belong to a cohesive community which fosters diversity, social  
interaction and social capital.  
The London Legacy Development Corporation’s *Inclusive Design*  
*Standards* offer a good practice approach to delivering inclusive  
environments at a neighbourhood scale.  
# 4.3 Public realm  
The design of the external environment and the public realm is  
an essential consideration if an area is to be considered inclusive  
and accessible. Key consideration should be given to the provi-  
sion of a coordinated network of legible, safe and accessible routes.  
Elements to be considered are\:  
• Location and ease of access to public transport  
• Prioritisation of pedestrian movement over vehicles  
• Provision of natural surveillance and perception of safety  
• Easy-going gradients and equity of experience when overcom-  
ing changes in level  
• Quality of the paving/foot paths  
• Legibility of spaces and routes, particularly for people with  
dementia, or who are blind or partially sighted people  
• Lighting.  
A factor often overlooked is the provision of suitable acces-  
sible seating and resting points, which are essential for some  
disabled and older people if they wish to access the environment  
independently. The provision of some seating with armrests and  
backrests will cater for people with reduced mobility who find it  
difficult to raise or lower themselves into a seat. Space between  
seating allows access for wheelchair users to sit alongside their  
families and friends, or for a pushchair or buggy.  
# 4.4 Shared space  
The principles of shared space involve decluttering the streetscape  
by removing unnecessary obstacles and simplifying the area, all  
of which have benefits in terms of access and can add to inclu-  
sive design. However, the removal of kerbs can be problematic, as  
kerbs provide many disabled people with the confidence that they  
are segregated from traffic. Kerbs can provide blind and partially  
sighted people with a ‘shore-line’ to follow, helping them navigate  
an area particularly in the absence of a clear and uncluttered build-  
ing line to follow at the opposite edge of the pavement. Kerbs are  
also important, as they are required for taxi and bus ramps to be  
deployed safely, and for people stepping down from side access  
minibus transport.  
The Department for Transport’s *Cycle Infrastructure Design*  
LTN 1/20 replaces LTN 1/12 *Shared Use Routes for Pedestrians*  
*and Cyclists*. It identifies that a protected space, with appropriate  
physical demarcation, might need to be provided, so that those  
pedestrians who may be unable or unwilling to negotiate priority  
with vehicles can use the street safely and comfortably. Clearly  
defined safe crossing points should also be provided.  
There is a delicate balance between promoting active travel and  
creating schemes that protect pedestrians. LTN 1/20 indicates that  
shared use routes in streets with high pedestrian or cyclist flows  
should not be used. Instead, in these sorts of spaces distinct tracks  
for cyclists should be made, using sloping, pedestrian-friendly kerbs  
and/or different surfacing. Shared use routes away from streets may  
be appropriate in locations such as canal towpaths, paths through  
housing estates, parks and other green spaces, including in cities.  
Where cycle routes use such paths in built-up areas, they should be  
separated from pedestrians, perhaps at different levels or a kerb.  
Where shared space is proposed, early stakeholder engagement  
is a critical part of the design process. It should allow disabled  
and older people and representative organisations to be part of the  
design decision process. LTN 1/20 reaffirms that engaging with  
such groups is an important step towards a scheme meeting the  
local authority’s Public Sector Equality Duty.  
Careful consideration should also be given as to whether the  
area is suitable for such an approach, taking into account the vol-  
ume of pedestrians compared to traffic flows, and types of traffic  
using the area such as bicycles, buses, HGVs and so forth.  
To support independence for more vulnerable pedestrians, con-  
sideration should be given to the incorporation of a ‘safe zone’, to  
delineate optional routes specially for pedestrians only.  
# 4.5 Changes in level  
Changes in level cause problems for many people, particularly peo-  
ple with mobility impairments or people who are blind or partially  
sighted. Even a single step can prevent access for someone with  
mobility impairment and can present a trip hazard for all people.  
Any gradient less steep than 1\:60 can be considered level.  
Where changes in level cannot be avoided, slopes with as shallow  
a gradient as possible \(less steep than 1\:21\) should be provided as  
it is preferable to avoid the use of ramps \(a slope with a gradient of  
1\:20 or steeper\).  
If a ramp cannot be avoided, then it should conform to  
Figure 4.11. The maximum going of a flight must not exceed the  
maximum rise without intermediate landings. Ramps steeper than  
1\:12 should not be used, as they may be unsafe as some wheel-  
chair users may tip over on them. Good practice such as the London **Inclusive and accessible design 4-9**  
**4.11** *Maximum length of ramp at a given gradient \(Source\: From Approved Document K\)*  
Legacy Development Corporation’s *Inclusive Design Standards*  
suggest a ramp no steeper than 1\:15 should be used if a ramp is  
unavoidable.  
Slopes or ramps provide access for people who use wheels, such  
as wheelchair users or parents with pushchairs. However, some peo-  
ple may find it easier to negotiate a flight of steps than a ramp and  
for them, the presence of handrails for support is essential. Stepped  
routes within the public realm can also offer shorter routes and help  
avoid people needing to travel extended distances that they may  
find challenging to walk along if only graded ones are provided.  
However, stairs are not to be dissected by ramps or graded routes  
as to produce feathered/tapered steps. Where a change in level is no  
greater than 300 mm, a ramp may be acceptable as the only means  
of access, avoiding the need for steps. Otherwise, steps would also  
be required.  
It should be noted that if the level change exceeds 2 m, then  
the ramps become very difficult to use for many people including  
wheelchair users. There should be an alternative means of step-free  
access such as a lift. Where lifts are provided, the quality of the  
journey should not feel secondary. Stairs can promote well-being  
and their use should be encouraged. However, lifts should not be  
hidden as a result.  
Lifts should have a minimum car size of 1100 mm wide by 1400  
mm in depth \(classed in BS EN 81-70\:2018 as a Type 2 lift\). While  
complying with the minima set out in the building regulation, the  
use of this car size may preclude at least 5 to 10 per cent of wheel-  
chair users and scooter users because of the length of the car. The  
maximum length of mobility scooters identified in BS 8300 is 1600  
mm. For this reason, it is recommended that a Type 5 lift 2000  
mm by 1400 mm \(minimum\) should be adopted – where space and  
budget will allow.  
The design of suitable stairs will be dependent on a variety of  
factors such as location \(external or internal\), building type, floor-  
to-floor levels and other dimension constraints as well as whether  
they are fire escape stairs.  
Many people find long flights of stairs difficult to use; there-  
fore, the maximum recommended number of steps should be 12  
in a flight and no more than 20 if a suitable going \(300 mm or  
greater\) is provided. If there are successive flights, it is important  
there are resting places, at least 1200 mm long \(preferably 1800  
mm\) across the full width of the stair. There should be an unob-  
structed landing space at the top and bottom of a flight of stairs to  
avoid any collision.  
As a rule of thumb, a comfortable step will have a rise of between  
150 and 170 mm with a going between 300 and 425 mm deep.  
Stair risers should be closed, in part, because it removes the  
possibility of the front of a foot or a walking aide being caught  
underneath a tread during ascent, possible causing a fall, but also  
avoids the feeling of insecurity people get when looking through  
open risers on a stair. This therefore precludes the use of clear  
glazed risers.  
Steps without projecting nosings remove a potential trip hazard.  
If necessary, the projection of a step nosing over the tread should  
be a maximum of 25 mm. All nosings should be made apparent  
through visual contrast on both the riser and tread, which will assist  
people ascending and descending the stair.  
# 4.6 Parking  
Many disabled and older people are reliant on a car for independ-  
ence. Additional space for designated bays for disabled persons is  
vital. The driver of a vehicle or a passenger may be disabled. They  
may need to enter or leave the vehicle using a transfer hoist for  
their wheelchair, or they may require assistance to alight from the  
vehicle first. In some instances, a disabled person may need to drive  
a powered wheelchair or scooter through the rear or side entrance  
of a vehicle. An unobstructed 1.2 m access zone \(minimum\) should  
be provided to the side and rear of a standard bay \(2.4 m wide by  
4.8 m long\). Access to the rear of a vehicle by ramp also requires  
extra space. The provision of a larger designated accessible parking  
space 4.8 m wide by 8 m long benefits people using hoists or ramps  
to access their vehicles, and caters for larger commercial vehicles  
converted for side or rear access using hoists or ramps. In cov-  
ered parking, allowance should be made for high top conversion  
vehicles and vehicles with roof mounted hoists, with a minimum  
clearance of 2.6 m.  
The number of recommended designated bays should be cal-  
culated on the basis of the Table VI, which indicates minimum  
provision and allows for future flexibility if required. The table  
sets out a minimum percentage of bays but also suggests a flexible  
approach to future provision should demand dictate it. **4-10 Inclusive and accessible design**

Location, in addition to size, is critical – bays for disabled per-  
sons should be located as close as possible to the building entrance.  
If further than 50 m, then suitable seating/resting points should be  
provided.  
Even if parking is provided, suitable drop-off facilities should  
also be available as close to the building entrance as possible.  
# 4.7 Inclusive cycling  
An inclusive approach to cycling should accommodate a wide  
range of cycle types and not exclude or disadvantage their riders.  
This includes people with physical, sensory and cognitive impair-  
ments who use handcycles, tricycles \(both upright and recumbent\),  
tandems, solo bikes with or without adaptations to suit the rider’s  
specific needs \(e.g. one-handed brakes, crutch holders and power  
assisted\) and cargo bikes and bikes with trailers used by parents  
with children.  
Cycle infrastructure, such as cycle parking, should accommo-  
date all-ability cycles with cycle parking within buildings accessed  
by step-free routes. Transport for London recommends that at least  
5 per cent of parking spaces should cater for non-standard cycles  
\(using Sheffield style stands rather than stackers\) and that if lift  
access is provided to cycle stores then the lift should have a min-  
imum car size of 1.2 m wide by 2.3 m deep with a 900 mm door  
opening.  
# 4.8 Faith and cultural provision  
Building Regulations do not provide design guidance or consid-  
erations for the different faiths and cultures of building users, and  
there is limited guidance within British Standards. As discussed  
previously, although the Equality Act covers faith, it does not  
specifically require the design of the built environment to con-  
sider faith.  
From an inclusive design perspective, it is important to consider  
this as part of the analysis and response to user need. Depending  
on the nature of the building, the local population and the build-  
ing’s users will dictate how the design should accommodate  
differing faiths. Large-scale shopping facilities, transport hubs,  
civic buildings and educational establishments are likely to have  
large culturally diverse populations and, as such, are likely to have  
a defined need for such facilities. In developing the building brief  
designers should be cognisant of the need to address faith and cul-  
ture within the overall spatial requirements of the building; see  
Figure 4.12.  
Chapter 31 identifies key considerations for places of worship  
and identifies design features, notably for sanitary facilities, that  
should be considered for certain faiths. Where multi-faith rooms  
are provided, they should be provided with adjacent wash \(ablu-  
tion\) facilities and storage facilities.  
**4.12** *The London Legacy Development Corporation’s Inclusive Design Standards address the need to consider the needs of different*  
*faiths and cultures within the design of public buildings and housing. Photo © LLDC* **4.9 Emergency egress**  
Evacuation for disabled people is a combination of physical and  
management procedures plus a liaison between the building man-  
agers and occupants. The evacuation strategy for disabled people  
must include those with sensory and cognitive disabilities and  
should be developed in conjunction with the fire strategy and  
management policies, with reference made to good practice rec-  
ommendations within the BS 9999\:2017 *Code of practice for fire*  
*safety in the design, management and use of buildings*.  
All building users should be able to evacuate from a building  
with dignity and by as independent means as possible. Emergency  
carry up/down devices that rely on manual handling are not con-  
sidered to be appropriate for reasons of dignity and independence.  
The installation of lifts which can be used for evacuation purposes  
provide a dignified and more independent solution and are there-  
fore recommended.  
BS 9999 indicates that the preferred method of evacuation for  
disabled people is by horizontal evacuation to the outside of the  
building, or another fire compartment, or by evacuation lift. If these  
are not available or not in operation, then it might be necessary to  
implement ‘carry up’ or ‘carry down’. This approach has been cod-  
ified in the London Plan Policies *Inclusive Design* and *Fire Safety*.  
These require that in all developments where lifts are installed, as  
a minimum at least one lift per core \(or more subject to capacity  
assessments\) should be a suitably sized fire evacuation lift suitable  
to be used to evacuate people who require level access from the  
building.  
In addition, BS 9999 indicates\:  
• All refuge areas should be fitted with a means of two-way  
communication between the person waiting in the refuge and  
a central, monitored location from where evacuation assistance  
will be coordinated \(note the communication system should be  
accessible to people who are blind and partially sighted as well  
as people who are deaf, deafened or hard of hearing\).  
• Where refuges are provided, the scale of provision should repre-  
sent the expected users of the building and as such more than one  
space per escape core may be required.  
• If appropriately managed, the lobbies may permit more than one  
disabled person to wait safely for assistance, although only one  
official refuge space is indicated.  
• Management strategies can also be set in place to provide  
assisted escape via the steps if required.  
• Staff may need to be suitably trained in evacuation features and  
procedures including ‘carry up’ and ‘carry down’ procedures for  
evacuation of wheelchair users and other disabled people.  
• A Personal Emergency Egress Plan \(PEEP\) should be developed  
by disabled staff members in liaison with their employers.  
# 5 SANITARY FACILITIES  
# 5.1 Introduction  
Chapter 2 People and space addresses many of the key elements  
that need to be considered in the provision of suitable sanitary  
accommodation. There are further considerations that need to be  
factored into an inclusive design approach.  
# 5.2 Public toilets  
The provision of public toilets allows many people to spend more  
time in an area, to dwell and linger and enjoy the space. Toilets  
are not just important for families with small children, for preg-  
nant women, some disabled people and for older people, but for the  
seven million people in the UK who have an over-active bladder.  
# 5.3 Separate sex provision  
Without adequate toilets, many people, especially disabled people,  
are limited in their ability to go out to work, to shop and so forth.  
# Inclusive and accessible design 4-11  
The majority of disabled people do not require the use of unisex  
wheelchair accessible toilets.  
It is important that all toilet facilities are accessible, catering  
for a wide range of people, including older people and children.  
Therefore, elements such as door opening pressures, range of  
heights of sinks and urinals, visual contrast, easy to use door fur-  
niture and tap design are key design factors in making all toilets  
useable.  
The NHS estimates that between 3 and 6 million people in the  
UK have some degree of urinary incontinence. Up to 4 million peo-  
ple, mainly men, are affected by ‘shy bladder syndrome’ \(avoidant  
paruresis\) and therefore the layout of toilets should provide ‘line of  
sight’ privacy, an adequate number of cubicles and privacy screens.  
Another consideration is that women may need to use toilets  
more frequently than men and on average take longer than men  
\(this is particularly true during menstruation or during and after  
pregnancy\). The British Toilet Association recommends that twice  
the number of male cubicles plus number of male urinals is the  
appropriate number of cubicles for women.  
# 5.4 Faith  
Where WCs are provided, they should not be directly adjacent to  
prayer rooms.  
A proportion of WC pans and urinals should not align with  
Mecca. Quibla, the direction of the Kaaba \(the sacred building at  
Mecca\) to which Muslims turn and pray, should be established at  
the earliest RIBA work stage possible to assist with the setting out  
of sanitary facilities.  
# 5.5 Gender-neutral toilets  
There is no UK legislation that enshrines in law that non gendered  
toilets are to be provided. However, on private premises the man-  
ager or licensee has the right to determine entry to the premises and  
the right to decide who uses which toilet and any other gendered  
facilities such as changing rooms etc.  
Emerging good practice is to let people use the facilities appro-  
priate to the way they present and as those who have the protected  
characteristic of gender reassignment should not be discriminated  
against purely because they are transsexual. A proportionate solu-  
tion should be found. The Equality Act 2010 defines a person as  
having the protected characteristic of gender reassignment \(trans-  
sexualism\) if the person is proposing to undergo, is undergoing or  
has undergone a process \(or part of a process\) for the purpose of  
reassigning the person’s sex by changing physiological or other  
attributes of sex.  
Consideration should be given to providing gender-neutral  
toilets that people of any gender or gender identity may use.  
Gender-neutral toilets should preferably be self-contained. Not  
all toilets should be defined as gender-neutral, as this may be  
problematic for certain faith groups who require separate sex  
facilities.  
Wheelchair accessible toilets are unisex; there is nothing that  
precludes them as being assigned as gender-neutral. However, this  
is not recommended in practice as this could make the accessible  
toilets less available to the disabled people that need them.  
# 5.6 Children’s toilets  
Children are often not considered in the design of toilets. Many  
children can be deterred from independent use of toilet facilities  
by poor design and specification. It should also be possible in  
developments that are likely to have many children using them,  
for example leisure facilities, to provide separate children’s toilets.  
These could be provided with associated family facilities, such as  
nappy-changing facilities. Nappy-changing facilities must never be  
situated in accessible toilets, except through exception as indicated  
in BS 8300. It is important that separate wheelchair accessible  
nappy-changing areas are provided. **4-12 Inclusive and accessible design**  
# 5.7 Changing Places facilities  
In larger developments, consideration should also be given to  
Changing Places \(CP\) toilets. Some people, including people  
with profound and multiple disabilities, need to be laid flat to be  
changed within WC accommodation. If CP toilets are not pro-  
vided, people may have to change a person on the floor. This is  
undignified, unhygienic and involves heavy lifting by others, such  
as carers or personal assistants, which could cause serious back  
injuries.  
CP facilities should be provided in buildings and locations  
where large numbers of people may visit, such as major enter-  
tainment venues, as well as places people may visit for several  
hours at a time. The requirement for CP toilets are statutory  
in Scotland under the Town and Country Planning \(Changing  
Places Toilet Facilities\) \(Scotland\) Regulations 2020. The trigger  
points for use-class application, occupancy and size differ from  
the amended requirements of the Approved Document M Vol  
2 Non-dwellings. As of January 2021, there were no statutory  
requirements for CP facilities in Northern Ireland or Wales. The  
Department for Transport also requires CP toilets are provided  
within all Category A railway stations \(stations with at least a  
2 million footfall each year\) when toilet facilities are installed,  
replaced or renewed.  
Based on recommendations by the CP Consortium and BS  
8300, CP toilets should be provided in\:  
• Major transport terminals or interchanges such as airports and  
large railway and bus stations  
• Motorway service stations  
• Sport and leisure facilities, including entertainment arenas, sta-  
dia, large hotels, large theatres and multiplex cinemas  
• Cultural centres such as museums, concert halls and art galleries  
• Shopping centres, large retail developments and Shopmobility  
centres  
• Key public buildings within town centres such as town halls,  
civic centres and principal public libraries  
• Educational establishments, including universities  
• Health facilities such as hospitals, health centres and doctors’  
surgeries  
• Crematoria and cemetery buildings.  
A CP toilet should be at least 3 m wide and 4 m long, and have  
a ceiling height of at least 2.4 m to accommodate the hoist. The  
entrance door should provide an effective clear width of 1000 mm.

# 1 INTRODUCTION  
This chapter examines the relationship between cost and value  
in construction projects, and discusses why architects should pay  
attention to their client’s budgetary constraints. We also describe  
the degree of risk which clients accept when undertaking construc-  
tion projects, and the steps which designers can take to mitigate  
these risks. In describing the estimating and cost planning process,  
we explain the discipline of the cost planning process, and the  
importance of the achievement of an appropriate level of fixity of  
design and specification at the conclusion of each RIBA project  
stage. We also describe the information that is available to cost  
consultants in preparing estimates at different project stages, and  
the degree of certainty that can be attached to these estimates.  
The expenditure on design and construction can have significant  
leverage relative to the costs of occupation. For example, appropri-  
ate investment in design and construction could potentially have a  
significant and valuable impact on the productivity of building occu-  
piers. With many buildings procured by the public sector on the basis  
of design, build and operate arrangements such as LIFT, which is  
used for primary healthcare, whole life costing is today of increas-  
ing importance. The sustainability agenda is of growing significance  
with the drive for net zero development and a rising consideration  
of circular economy principles, which is concerned with managing  
energy consumption, carbon emissions and other environmental  
impacts. As a result, opportunities to invest to save energy and to  
mitigate environmental impacts are taken increasingly seriously.  
# 2 CONSTRUCTION COSTS  
# 2.1 Cost planning  
Cost planning is a key due diligence step in preparing for a construc-  
tion project. Cost planning informs the client and the project team  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-6  
how much a proposed project is likely to cost. Additionally, cost  
planning will tell when the expected expenses will most likely occur\:  
a cash flow programme. This information is critical for obtaining  
project financing and for determining project affordability.  
Very few, if any, clients have the luxury of an unlimited budget,  
and even with generous funding, all clients will want to make sure  
that the proposed design solution represents the best way of meet-  
ing their purpose, and that their investment makes the best use of  
their resources. Financial discipline on a project does not mean  
that budgets must be unrealistically tight. However, it does mean  
that the client’s investment should be managed responsibly by the  
project team to focus on elements which relate specifically to the  
client’s value criteria. Typical value criteria influencing projects  
are discussed later.  
# 2.2 The value agenda  
For many buildings, particularly those constructed for commercial  
markets, the client’s principal measure of worth is the building’s  
exchange value, typically measured by rental or sales revenue.  
Exchange value is used by clients in investment appraisals to deter-  
mine whether projects are financially viable. In effect, exchange  
value determines the ‘bottom line’ of most schemes. Exchange  
value is generally defined by third parties and, particularly in com-  
mercial property markets, it is often difficult to secure a premium  
valuation for innovation. As a result, clients may have surprisingly  
little room for manoeuvre in setting their construction budgets.  
Exchange value issues can affect public sector projects too. Many  
public sector clients operate internal marketplaces where facilities  
are bought – using the volume of demand to establish the size and  
quality of the building that can be afforded.  
Value is of course not just about financial considerations and  
there are many other ways in which buildings are able to contribute  
benefits to their owners, occupiers and neighbours. Some of the  
sources of these are listed here\:  
• *Operational value*. The benefits generated through the occupa-  
tion and use of the building, which might include greater staff  
productivity, or improved educational outcomes associated with  
a new school.  
• *Social value*. The broader benefits to society of a development,  
which might include local residents feeling more secure in their  
neighbourhood following the completion of an urban realm  
improvement project.  
• *Brand/organisation value*. Messages communicated by a build-  
ing derived from its design, and which reflect positively on the  
occupier. For example, a flagship development designed to  
achieve exemplary standards of sustainability and environmen-  
tal performance.  
• *Civic/esteem value*. This is the contribution that a development  
can make to a neighbourhood in terms of physical improve-  
ment to the quality of the building fabric, public realm and so  
on. This benefit is secured by all users of the neighbourhood.  
The reflected prestige that neighbouring buildings can gain from  
proximity to a high-quality development, be it Tate Modern or  
a major redevelopment scheme such as Kings Cross Central in  
**5-1** **5-2 Capital and whole life costs of buildings**  
London, may reflect in an increase in the exchange value of the  
neighbouring buildings.  
Whilst not all sources of value have an immediate financial dimen-  
sion, all require a focused and disciplined approach by the design  
team to concentrate effort and investment on aspects of the design  
which maximise benefits to client, end users and the wider commu-  
nity, without compromising the fundamental financial viability of  
the project.  
# 2.3 Risk and value management  
Risk and value management should be carried out throughout a  
project lifecycle, with early involvement of the entire integrated  
project team to minimise/manage risks. Risk management ensures  
that risks are identified and analysed as early in the project life  
cycle as possible, and that their potential impacts are understood,  
allowed for and where possible minimised. The main emphasis is  
to ensure that they are effectively managed in order to minimise  
negative consequences and maximise opportunities.  
The project team create a risk register and assign a red, amber  
or green ‘traffic light’ system to each risk \(Table I\). Obviously red  
risks need actioning immediately. Rigorous follow up of identified  
risk mitigation actions and regular updates of the risk register are  
essential if the full benefits of risk management are to be realised  
\(Figure 5.1\).
