building. If the straight line passes through a window opening, in  
both plan and section, then the object will normally be visible; if  
not it may be necessary to alter the shape, angle or position of the  
window.  
Consideration for the exact arrangement should be made. For  
example, on challenging facades where heat gain and glare are  
factors, a double skin façade might enable a sunny balcony to be  
installed whilst tempering the light and potential glare entering  
the living spaces, Figure 9.11. The image of the recessed win-  
dow, Figure 9.12, shows how a calculated approach and modified  
# Light 9-9  
geometries can inform the window arrangement to reduce glare,  
with a recessed window an overhang combined with a lateral light  
scoop.  
As occupants move around the interior, the end of the straight  
line moves with them; a good view from the back of a room will be  
harder to achieve \(especially if the windows are vertically narrow\)  
than a view from just within the window area. The choice of desir-  
able objects of regard is usually easier in reality than in theory, but  
it is a choice that needs to be made consciously and deliberately if  
the window is to be optimised. Testing and optimising the views  
and position of apertures should take consideration of the likely  
functions within the space with thought given for how the space  
and occupancy might evolve over time. The setting out of interior  
lighting should also be factored in, as internal reflections of interior  
lighting will detract from the ability to see through the glazing. For  
restaurants where seats are located near windows as a feature, the  
interior lighting needs to be considered carefully so that the views  
are not lost due to interior reflections. There are techniques that  
can be applied to help, such as tilting the glass to move reflections  
away from direct view or the application of anti-reflectance glass  
or films. Alternatively influencing the external brightness levels to  
draw the eye through the glass can help.  
Visibility of the skyline within the interior plays a key role in  
effectiveness of daylight. Ideally, the view of the skyline should  
not be interrupted by the window head. Should this be impractica-  
ble, some direct view of the sky remains desirable, if only to reveal  
the clarity or cloudiness of the local weather.  
But the need for a view interacts with other aspects of the envi-  
ronment. A direct view of the sky can be a source of discomfort  
\(‘glare’\), especially when the patch of sky is close to the direction  
of the sun. On the other hand, the daylight factor at the back of a  
room depends largely on the amount of sky directly visible, see  
Section 2.2. Thus, there is a potential conflict between the imper-  
atives of view, comfort and uniform daylighting. This conflict can  
be resolved only by prioritising. The relative importance of the  
three factors will largely determine the right shape and position for  
each window

# 4 WINDOW DESIGN  
# 4.1 Developing window design  
We return to equation \(4\) for the average daylight factor, in  
Section 3.3\. The expression offers a natural sequence for window  
design decisions.  
*Stage 1*  
The first item to be fixed in the equation is the angle θ defined by  
the position of exterior obstructions. This depends mainly on the  
spacing and massing of surrounding buildings. The block layout  
is effectively fixed quite early in the design process, well before  
fenestration has been thought about. Access, prospect, privacy, site  
utilisation and microclimate are some of the formative factors at  
this stage. Because these will act as constraints on the daylight fac-  
tor, the determination of the angle θ is identified as the first stage  
in window design. Some relevant criteria and design aids are listed  
in Table I.  
*Stage 2*  
A side-lit room may be too deep to be satisfactorily daylit. This out-  
come was discussed in Section 3.1. It occurs when the *no skyline*  
seriously encroaches on the *working plane*, or when equation \(3\)  
indicates that the natural lighting at the back of the room will look  
unacceptably dim.  
If the room is indeed too deep for stand-alone natural lighting,  
the average daylight factor will not be a useful design criterion.  
Instead the windows should be optimised mainly for view and for  
thermal performance and, if daylight-linked controls, as in Section  
6.2, are contemplated, for the dimming and extinction of the row of **9-10 Light**  
luminaires closest to the window wall. Unless the room meets the  
two tests in Stage 2, the designer should proceed straight to Stage  
4, omitting Stage 3 of this window design sequence.  
*Stage 3*  
The window area W is estimated by inverting equation \(4\)\:  
*W = df* × *A\(1 − R*2\)*/\(T* × θ × *M\)*  
At this point, there is the conflict between visual and thermal  
considerations. The average daylight factor *df* is proportional to  
the window area *W*, but so is the winter heat loss through the win-  
dows, and so \(other things being equal\) is the daily mean solar heat  
gain. Passive solar design, harnessing both daylight and solar gain,  
may optimise by reducing heat loss through the glazing. Other  
approaches to design must face and resolve a three-way conflict\:  
daylight versus heat loss and summer heat gain. It is important to  
resolve these pressures on the window area at this stage, before  
proceeding to Stage 4, which is concerned with optimising window  
shape and position for each window.  
*Stage 4*  
By this stage, either the window area is established, and the average  
daylight factor settled in Stage 3, or the room has been identified in  
Stage 2 as too deep for stand-alone natural lighting. In either case,  
the shape and position of the windows have yet to be finalised, but  
the completion of the design is obviously simplified by the prior  
decisions in Stages 2 and 3.  
The competing claims of view, visual comfort and daylight  
uniformity were reviewed in Section 2.4 above. They centred on  
the visibility of the skyline. The avoidance of glare required as  
little visible sky as possible. A good view implied a good sight of  
the skyline itself but no additional access to the sky. Uniform day  
lighting mandated as much sky as possible visible from the depths  
of the room. The conflict must be resolved, in Stage 4 as in Stage 3,  
by identifying and balancing the relevant priorities.  
Also in Stage 4, the possible advantages of multilateral fenes-  
tration may merit review. Windows in more than one wall may  
improve the natural lighting in two respects\: by increasing the area  
of sky seen from the poorly lit parts of the room, and by reducing  
the brightness contrast between the sky and the window walls. In  
a naturally ventilated building gazing from two aspects will also  
promote cross-ventilation, mitigating summertime overheating.  
# 4.2 Applicability  
The above, idealised sequence is remote from the reality of  
window design. The results of applying formula-based design, win-  
dow-by-window would be a chaotic elevation, maybe unbuildable. A  
formal design sequence should provide a safety net for architects in  
trouble. Using calculation and simulation you can retrace your steps  
and recognise false turns if need be. The key to good natural light-  
ing design is to identify significant crunch points\: What is the most  
important or the most demanding room on a given facade? Design its  
windows properly. Repeat variants of the solution up and down the  
elevation. Then the windows will do their job, both as external visual  
elements and as components of the interior environment.  
# 5 INTERIOR LIGHTING DESIGN  
# 5.1 Introduction  
Developing a detailed brief and understanding of a space is essen-  
tial. For the best results, it may be helpful if a specialist lighting  
designer is involved at the early stages. It is then possible to adapt  
structures and spaces to include lighting details as the interior  
scheme develops.  
Lighting possibilities can be explored to address the obvious  
requirements and to identify the less obvious opportunities in a  
project. Lighting consultation will open-up a broad range of con-  
siderations, taking into account the daylight qualities, the sun path  
throughout the year, and how creative added light will transform  
this. Observations about the scale, proportions, materials, use and  
the intended impression or atmosphere are the starting points.  
The art of lighting design is to work closely with the direc-  
tional behaviours of light – its distribution, tone, spectral scatter  
and resulting light characteristics. The careful positioning of a light  
source will play a critical part. For instance, a visually reinforced  
processional route, or ‘rhythm’, can be set up using linear lines, lit  
architectural features or fittings spaced in regular patterns.  
By interrupting these or by setting up opposing junctions/  
angles, the rhythm can be slowed or altered by this intentional  
change in the visual pattern. The lighting can be concealed to be  
discreet, or be highly visible and expressive, or be a balance of  
both. Illuminating a great architectural feature or interior element  
can be more powerful and sensational to the eye than some arbi-  
trary lighting statement or gesture.  
# 5.2 Tone and mood  
If the surfaces of an interior are lit carefully and in good balance,  
the design can bring serenity, delight and inspiration into any space.  
For example, the feeling of well-being and mood can be affected  
by brightness, tone and intensity. Specific colours and tones can  
create feelings of excitement or calm. The application of lighting  
techniques adapted from theatrical applications can be considered,  
where surface texture can be created through light, transforming  
surfaces and forms with a broad range of possibilities.  
Once the interior tones and colours for a space are being  
progressed in a design, it is possible to start to develop an under-  
standing of how a space will feel. If a scheme contains dominant  
colours, rich or absorbing surfaces, carefully selected lighting can  
transform them. Selecting an appropriate light source with the right  
tonal outputs, lighting angles and controls can express or enhance  
the selected tones, colour and surface modelling. All materials con-  
tain pigments or reflective qualities which will visually resonate if  
the right spectral quality and blend of light is selected to achieve  
this. It should be noted that the wrong type of light on a quality  
material can be a detriment.  
With simple or more complicated lighting controls, it is possible  
to bring an impressive range of appearances or presentations of a  
space \(for example, creating five different spaces from one space at  
the touch of a button\). Carefully integrated lighting choices provide  
scope to transform a huge space to look intimate at times or trans-  
form a tiny space to look huge. Light, space and human perception  
can all be adjusted through considered lighting design, accounting  
for the aspect, views, vistas and interior architecture.  
The material tones or colours of adjacent sites and facades can affect  
the tones of natural light being reflected or transmitted into buildings  
and neighbouring spaces. The interior lighting needs to account for  
this, more so in schemes where spaces are densely clustered.  
# 5.3 Comfort  
Creating spaces that are comfortable to the eye is also vital. Comfortable  
spaces are where the eye is not forced to work too hard. If the eye has  
to struggle to reconcile a wide range of brightness and contrast values,  
it will become tired very quickly. The balance of sequential experi-  
ences coupled with a consideration of the range/field of vision should  
be used to set the parameters of light. Ideally, visual brightness differ-  
entials of circa 30 per cent between surfaces and spaces will keep the  
muscles in the eye working at comfortable levels. Stark shifts between  
contrast and brightness will always add drama and excitement, but  
care and attention should be given to the extent and positioning to  
enhance the perception of the space and experience.  
As low light or excessive light makes the eye work hard, it is  
good practice to track the external light levels to create exception-  
ally comfortable environments within the building throughout the  
working day at all times. This approach can be informed by light sensors externally and internally, where daylight within a building  
will bring savings and will alter the sensation of light in a space.  
Impressive energy savings can be achieved through the balancing  
of the intensity of light during the day and into the evening. Almost  
all commercial buildings in the UK will be occupied in the darker  
months of October to March, so if the lighting is programmed to  
account for that, brighter interior levels will create a greater sense  
of well-being in the winter months.  
Less can be more. It is important to consider primary surfaces,  
areas of intensity and the priority spaces, but secondary light or  
reflected light from a lit object or surface is often significant as a  
contribution. By electing what the primary lighting intent is for key  
surfaces and spaces, a selective approach can be taken to ensure  
that the elements of highlighting or drama occur at the right place.  
A totally uniform approach to lighting can be wasteful of energy,  
and potentially creates a bland appearance. It is better therefore to  
select and develop a lighting scheme that can enjoy a range of lev-  
els, but within the boundaries of comfortable brightness.  
Walking into a great space should be as engaging to the eye as  
enjoying a great artwork.  
# 5.4 Light source efficacy  
Energy efficiency for lighting should be carefully examined. Care  
and attention need to be given to the lighting source selection to  
ensure the attributes fit the needs of the project.  
The *efficacy* of an electric light source is defined as its *lumi-*  
*nous flux* \(*lumens*\) divided by the electric power consumed \(watts\).  
Efficacy is expressed in lumens per watt \(lm/W\). Lamp/LED man-  
ufacturers specify the lumen output of a lamp/LED.  
Note that lamp/LED manufacturers normally express lamp/  
LED efficacy as lumens per lamp/LED watt, whereas Part L of the  
Building Regulations specifies lumens per circuit watt including  
power consumed by control gear. Some representative *circuit effi-*  
*cacies* are listed in Table IV.

# 5.5 Luminaires  
The word *luminaire* covers a lighting fitting complete with control  
gear, optics such as reflector, diffuser, lens and suspension where  
applicable. The *light output ratio* \(LOR\) of a luminaire is the pro-  
portion of *luminous flux \(lumens\)* from the lamps which emerges  
from the luminaire. The LOR for a bare lamp would be 1.00. Other  
things being equal, a luminaire having a high LOR is more efficient  
than one with a lower LOR. Typical values are listed in Table V.  
# Table V Light output ratios for typical luminaires  
# Luminaire Light output ratio \(LOR\)  
Bare light source 1.0  
Open reflector 0.8  
Pendent or surface-mounted diffuser 0.65  
Louvered luminaire 0.6  
Recessed diffuser 0.5  
The *luminaire efficacy* is the *luminous flux* output from the lumi-  
naire, divided by the electric power consumed, including losses in  
control gear. Luminaire efficacy, like *lamp efficacy*, is measured in  
lumens per watt \(lm/W\).  
Luminaire efficacy = lamp efficacy × LOR  
The *flux fraction ratio* \(FFR\) of a luminaire is the ratio of the  
flux \(*lumens*\) emerging in directions above the level of the lumi-  
naire, to the flux directed below the level of the luminaire. For a  
downlight, the FFR is zero, for an uplighter, infinity.  
With an FFR greater than 0.8, the ceiling may be more brightly lit  
than the working plane. With an FFR less than 0.1, the ceiling may  
look dark; so low-FFR luminaires work best when the ceiling, floor  
and table top all have a reasonably high *reflectance*. The FFR has a  
significant effect on the character of the lit environment. See Table VI.  
# Table VI Effects of luminaire light distribution on the atmosphere in a room

# 5.6 Building regulations – dwellings  
In new dwellings and in existing dwellings where major refurbish-  
ment is undertaken, at least 75 per cent of luminaires in regularly used  
rooms \(i.e. other than cupboards, wardrobes and storage spaces\) must  
use lamps with a *circuit efficacy* greater than 45 lumens per watt, and  
emitting over 400 lumens. Filament lamps fall well short of the circuit  
efficacy requirement and are being progressively phased out.  
Any fixed lighting must satisfy one or other of the following  
sets of requirements\:  
**Either** *lamp wattage* must not exceed 100 lamp-watts per  
fitting, and must be automatically extinguished if the area  
becomes unoccupied, or when daylight is adequate  
**Or alternatively**, *lamp efficacy* must be greater than 45 lumens  
per circuit watt, luminaires must be controllable manually, and  
automatically extinguished when daylight is adequate.  
The UK building regulations are due to be updated in late  
2021–2022 and it is anticipated that the criteria for minimum  
performance will be more ambitious. **9-12 Light**  
# 5.7 Building regulations\: non-domestic buildings  
The following requirements apply to general lighting in offices,  
industrial or storage spaces, classrooms, seminar rooms and con-  
ference rooms. They apply to new buildings and to buildings where  
substantial refurbishment is undertaken.  
The average initial *luminaire efficacy* must be not less than 60  
luminaire lumens per circuit watt. The circuit wattage for each  
luminaire may be multiplied by the control factors in Table VII.  
To derive the average luminaire efficacy, divide the total luminaire  
output \(lumens\) by the total circuit wattage adjusted by control fac-  
tors.

Electric lighting energy consumption must be metred separately  
from other electrical supplies, either by kWh metres in dedicated  
lighting circuits or in the lighting controls of a lighting or building  
management system, or by automatically logging energy consumed  
by the lighting.  
Lighting controls should be tailored to the nature and use of  
each space.  
# 6 LIGHTING CONTROLS  
Five types of electric lighting controls may be distinguished as fol-  
lows.  
# 6.1 Constant illuminance control  
Dimmable LED’s or high-frequency fluorescent *luminaires* can be  
linked to indoor photocells set to sustain a fixed target *illuminance*.  
Lighting schemes should factor in lumen degradation \(which  
occurs over time due and will reduce output\). Typically, 30% loss  
of output is not uncommon. It is possible to set the target light level  
criteria and then use a combination of light sensors and controls to  
balance the light levels.  
In practice, the lighting scheme would be designed to overa-  
chieve the target performance. The lighting control system would  
be set up to under-run the fixtures to attain the designed levels.  
Over time as the lighting output starts to depreciate naturally, the  
photocells will compensate for this by increasing the voltage and  
current to the fixtures to sustain a consistent output.  
This approach has an additional advantage in that when the  
room changes from one use to another, the setting can be adjusted  
to maintain the reduced lighting level.  
There are a range of lighting control systems and protocols to  
achieve this intent, and care and attention is needed to ensure the  
level of control is right for the project. Some controls are able to  
provide exacting levels while others might have limitations with  
regard to dimming speed, feedback and monitoring.  
# 6.2 Daylight linking  
One or more rows of luminaires along a window wall may be linked  
to either interior or exterior photocells, which monitor day light  
levels and adjust the electric lighting accordingly, preferably by  
top-up \(dimming\) rather than by automatic daylight-linked on-off  
switching. The latter may be resented by occupants unless they  
understand and fully accept the purpose and value of the provision.  
Note that high-intensity discharge lamps, and some compact fluo-  
rescent lamps, are unsuitable for dimming. Control zones should  
be parallel to the main windows. Daylight linking can be combined  
with the occupancy detection system, Section 5.5.  
# 6.3 Manual switching  
Manual switches should be close to the luminaires they control.  
A row of unlabelled switches invites indiscriminate switching.  
A lighting control system can be introduced to simplify lighting  
controls where standard switches or retractable switches can con-  
trol scenes or specific switching arrangements. Options include  
low-voltage switching, pull-cords, remote ‘wireless’ switches,  
radio-based controls, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth or infrared. A lighting con-  
trol system can be linked to an energy-management system and can  
provide data for optimisation and energy savings.  
Manual switching with absence detection is particularly suitable  
for a cellular office or consulting room, or for workstations which  
are occupied only intermittently. A lighting control system based on  
DALI or other protocols can offer flexibility for future adaptation.  
# 6.4 Timed switching and dimming  
Electric lighting can be switched off or dimmed automatically via  
a time clock/control panel at the same time each day \(or specific  
days\), perhaps to coincide with work breaks, for example, at mid-  
day. Controlled lighting can be staged in a sequence, for example  
switching or dimming half the lights off at first, with further var-  
iations later. A manual override then permits users to redeploy  
the lights they still need. This system shares the responsibility for  
energy saving with the occupants, whose understanding and coop-  
eration should be assured in advance.  
There are several alternative methods for implementing a syn-  
chronised or staggered switch-off\:  
• Digitally Addressable Lighting Interface \(DALI\)  
• IP Addressed fixtures  
• Bluetooth devices  
• Low-voltage wiring to a relay/dimming control module in each  
lighting circuit  
• A mains-borne signalling system.  
In each case, other manual overrides should be provided, for occu-  
pants to switch lighting straight back on if needed.  
Time switching or scene setting is particularly suitable for a  
hotel lounge, a restaurant, a shop, a corridor or an atrium.  
# 6.5 Occupancy-absence linked switching  
The aim of occupancy-linked lighting controls \(presence detectors/  
absence detectors\) is to operate the lighting when, but only when,  
somebody is there to make use of it or to extinguish the lights when  
not needed. Some units flash a warning signal just before lights  
are turned off, so that an undetected occupant can wave an arm  
and avoid being left in the dark. Occupancy-linked discharge lamps  
with long restrike times should be supplemented by separate back-  
ground lighting.  
Occupancy detectors are suited to daylit spaces, and can be  
combined with daylight sensors, Section 6.2. Presence detec-  
tors can double as part of a security system or part of a Building  
Management System \(BMS\) to control heating and cooling. At  
night or at weekends they can activate an alarm instead of working  
the lights. They can also assist security patrols at night.  
Occupancy detectors may be triggered by air movement, by a  
flapping curtain or by events in a corridor outside the monitored  
space. Ultrasonic detectors seem more prone than passive infrared  
detectors or microwave detectors to these extraneous stimuli. The  
sensitivity of some units can be adjusted to minimise such fail-  
ings, at the price of their effective surveillance area. But the best  
arrangement is always to include manual-on/automatic-off occu-  
pancy controls with a manual override. The best applications for Passive Infrared \(PIR\) detection is  
where occupancy is infrequent or unpredictable, e.g. private offices,  
conference rooms, lecture rooms, toilets, warehouse storage aisles,  
photocopy rooms and archive or bookcase lighting in libraries.  
# 7 SIZING AN OVERALL LIGHTING  
# INSTALLATION  
The sizing of overall lighting installations for working interiors and  
for floodlighting is often left to computer simulations. However,  
the choice of target lighting levels remains in the hands of the  
designer or client. The Building Regulations \(Part L\) do not man-  
date target lighting levels. Wise choices may offer opportunities for  
appreciable savings in energy and in costs. Table VIII lists some  
recommendations from the Lighting Code of the Society of Light  
and Lighting \(SLL\), and other references.  
In many cases, especially in residential or public areas, a critical  
visual task is hard to identify, and the *illuminance* should be cho-  
sen to provide the right atmosphere for meeting, socialising or for  
relaxing. Especially where this is the case, listed values of standard  
maintained illuminance should be treated as a point of departure,  
not as a target. If a designer seeks a subdued atmosphere, a lower  
value would be right; if a livelier ambience is envisaged, a higher  
illuminance would be justified.

# Light 9-13  
aiming more difficult, and spotlights might remain unadjusted if  
the displays are moved out of the lit positions. There are motorised  
lighting solutions that can assist with flexibility and aiming angles.  
Effective display lighting depends as much on darkness as on  
illumination. Objects will stand out only if they look significantly  
brighter than their surroundings. Brightness has two aspects\:  
• *Illuminance\:* to appear noticeably brighter the illuminance on  
a surface should be at least three times the background illumi-  
nance; to stand out strongly would require a ratio of 10\:1 or  
more.  
• *Reflectance\:* if an object has a lower reflectance than its back-  
ground it will respond much less to an increase in illuminance;  
spotlighting may well be inappropriate, or the profile of the beam  
may need careful trimming to the profile of the target.  
The overall pattern of light and shade deserves careful consid-  
eration. To pick out a single focus of attention is simple and always  
effective. To highlight two objects risks an impression of disunity.  
To spotlight more than three requires skill and invites confusion.  
Aim for a simple and clear hierarchy of illuminance.  
The lighting of paintings, notice-boards, white boards and areas  
in the near of display screens, etc. must address two constraints\:  
• The lighting must not produce shiny reflections, which reduce  
legibility  
• The lighting should provide reasonably even illumination over  
the target surface.  
In Figure 9.13, the closest distance from which an observer can  
comfortably regard the picture as a whole is equal to the length of  
the picture’s corner-to-corner diagonal. This fixes the distance D,  
which shows the best position for a luminaire. If it were mounted  
closer to the target surface, the foot of the target would look dimly  
lit compared with the top. If it were further back, a visitor would  
see shiny reflections.  
In conclusion, a golden rule for successful spotlighting is ‘light  
the objects, not the people’. The positioning of luminaires should  
# 8 DISPLAY LIGHTING  
The effectiveness of display lighting depends as much on the skill  
of the person responsible for aiming it as on the good intentions  
of the specifier. A key consideration is to identify who is likely to  
take responsibility for the lighting once installed. It may well be a  
caretaker, a shop assistant or a clerk of works, with no training in  
display lighting techniques. If so, any track or adjustable lighting  
is likely to become poorly positioned and wrongly aimed. Fixed  
lighting, perhaps above louvers, may well be preferable in cer-  
tain environments. The following guidance relate mainly to track/  
adjustable spot lighting, but the same principles apply to fixed  
lighting.  
In a space where visitors are free to move around, there is  
a skill in lighting vertical surfaces without shining light straight  
into somebody’s eyes. To achieve this, start from the principal  
entrance and consider the routes through the exhibits and dis-  
plays. Run lighting track in strategic arrangements to provide  
low glare and discreet lighting. Arrange spotlights to shine over  
the shoulders of visitors following the preferred route. At each  
point along the route, make sure that the next stopping point is  
attractively lit, to encourage circulation in optimal directions.  
Visitors moving the opposite way will potentially face darker  
surfaces – by walking the course, it is possible to fine tune the  
lighting arrangements to optimise the look, drama and comfort of  
the space for all visitors.  
Track lighting and adjustable spotlights should preferably be  
2.5 to 3 m high. Lower mounting may cause glare, invite tam-  
pering, discomfort from heat radiated from the fixtures, and the  
shadows of visitors thrown on exhibits. Higher mounting will make

*picture frame, H = eye level of short adult, say 1.5 m* **9-14 Light**  
be constrained as much by the need to avoid glare and distraction  
as by the need to reveal an illuminated object. In an environment  
where the architecture and interior qualities are to be celebrated, a  
lighting strategy should be developed to establish the balance of  
lighting to optimise the potential of an environment.  
# 9 PROJECTION SCREENS AND REFLECTIONS  
The front surface of a display, white board or projection screen vis-  
ibility can be impaired when shiny reflections approach or exceed  
the brightness of the luminous pixels. Side windows present a dou-  
ble problem. If for example a laptop user faces a window, they may  
be distracted because the outside scene is brighter than the screen.  
The face of the screen should ideally be at right angles to the face  
of the window. If there are windows on two adjacent walls, this  
remedy may fail, and partitions or blinds might be considered.  
To optimise any environment, lighting design should be  
explored fully. There are opportunities to add visual delight to  
a space through blending the natural attributes of daylight and  
sunlight with artificial lighting, efficiency and drama. Additional  
functionality can be brought to an environment through strategic  
lighting design.  
# 10 EMERGENCY LIGHTING AND ESCAPE  
# LIGHTING  
Emergency lighting and escape lighting should be considered in the  
early stages of the design to avoid it appearing as a bolted-on after-  
thought. There are a number of elements that need to be examined  
in detail which include type of building, fire strategy, emergency  
lighting rationale and overall holistic design intent.  
Many types of general lighting can be adapted to work in emer-  
gency functions. This is useful as it can contribute to the look and  
feel of an architecturally developed scheme.  
Emergency lighting will require some form of battery back-up  
to drive the fixtures in the event of a power outage. Consideration  
needs to be given to\:  
• Required duration of the lighting to be operative in an emer-  
gency situation  
• Required output  
• Required light distribution  
• Relevant lighting codes  
• The requirements of the fire strategy consultant.  
Generally, lighting of principle routes need to be clearly defined  
and a low base-line level of light should be provided in all large  
occupied areas. The exact criteria for the lighting will be deter-  
mined by the project type. Certain types of buildings such as  
cinemas, places of public entertainment and visitor attractions will  
have project specific considerations to account for.  
# 11 GLOSSARY  
# Altitude  
An angle in a vertical plane, measured upward in degrees from the  
horizontal. The solar altitude is the altitude of the sun above the  
horizon.  
# Azimuth  
An angle in plan, also called the bearing. The solar azimuth is usu-  
ally measured from due north.  
# Circuit efficacy  
The *luminous flux \(lumens\)* emitted by a lamp or *luminaire*, divided  
by the *circuit wattage*. See also *lamp efficacy* and *luminaire effi-*  
*cacy*.  
# Circuit wattage  
The power consumed by the fixture and light source in an electric  
lighting system, considering their control gear, and with associated  
equipment for power factor correction.  
# Daylight factor  
Equal to the *illuminance* \(lux\) at a point indoors, expressed as a  
percentage of the simultaneous horizontal illuminance under an  
unobstructed overcast sky outside, see Section 3.1.  
# Direct-indirect lighting  
Provided by a luminaire designed to combine the lighting charac-  
teristics of an uplighter and a downlight. It provides upward and  
downward illumination, sometimes in variable proportions, but lit-  
tle or no light sideways.  
# Efficacy  
*Luminous flux* output \(lumens\), divided by the electric power con-  
sumed \(watts\). See also *lamp efficacy* and *luminaire efficacy*.  
# Flux  
See *luminous flux*.  
# Flux fraction ratio  
Equal to the upward *luminous flux* from a *luminaire*, divided by the  
downward flux.  
# Heliodon  
Figures 9.8, 9.9. A physical simulation of the changing geometrical  
relation between the earth and the sun. The heliodon incorporates  
seasonal and hourly changes. A model of a building is mounted on  
a rotating platform whose tilt from the vertical corresponds to the  
geographical latitude of the building’s location.  
# Illuminance \(E\)  
The degree of concentration of light, in *lumens* per square meter  
\(lux\), striking a surface. Illuminance is measured by a special light  
metre – an illumination photometer; photographic light meters are  
mostly unsuitable.  
# Lamp efficacy  
The *efficacy* of an electric light fixture, i.e. the *luminous flux*  
*\(lumens\)* emitted by an electric light source, divided by the wattage  
consumed, It is known as the lamp circuit efficacy if all the power  
consumed by the electric circuit is included.  
# Light Output Ratio \(LOR\)  
The *luminous flux \(lumens\)* emitted by a *luminaire*, expressed as a  
fraction of the flux emitted by the light source\(s\) inside the lumi-  
naire. The LOR is sometimes known as the ‘luminaire efficiency’.  
# Lumen  
See *luminous flux*.  
# Luminaire  
A lighting fitting complete with control gear and suspension where  
applicable. In North America but not usually in the UK the term  
includes the associated light source.  
# Luminaire efficacy  
The *efficacy* of a luminaire, i.e. the *luminous flux \(lumens\)* emit-  
ted by a *luminaire*, divided by the wattage consumed by the light  
source\(s\) in the luminaire. It is known as the luminaire circuit effi-  
cacy if power consumed by the electric circuit is included.  
# Luminous flux \(φ\)  
The rate in lumens at which light energy is emitted from a  
source or received by a surface. For a given illuminance *E* lux, the flux striking a surface will be proportional to the area  
*A* \(m2\)\:  
φ *= E × A* lumens \(5\)  
Hence 1 lux = 1 lumen per square metre.  
# Lux  
See *illuminance*.  
# Maintenance Factor \(MF\)  
The ratio of the *illuminance \(lux\)* of a lighting system, or, in the  
case of natural lighting, the *daylight factor*, after a given interval,  
expressed as a fraction of the illuminance or daylight factor when  
the same installation was clean and newly commissioned. See  
Table III for maintenance factors for natural lighting.  
# No-sky line  
The dividing line, Figure 9.2, in a room between the area which is  
exposed to a direct view of the sky, and the area which receives no  
direct daylight at all.  
# Probable sunlight hours  
The long-term average number of hours per year when direct sun-  
light is visible from a given point. Long-term weather conditions  
are taken into account.  
# Reflectance \(R\)  
The proportion of incident light which a surface reflects. A pure  
white surface would have a reflectance of 1.00, a perfectly black  
surface would have zero reflectance. Most paints and surface mate-  
rials will have a reflectance value that can be obtained; these values  
have a profound influence on the resulting light. Table IX provides  
some approximate values for typical surfaces.  
**Table IX** **Reflectance of some familiar surfaces**  
# Surface Reflectance  
White emulsion paint on plaster 0.80  
Pink plaster 0.65  
Cork tiles 0.20  
Red quarry tiles 0.10  
Black chalkboard 0.05  
# Painted surfaces, \(with BS 4800 colour code\)  
White 00 E 55 0.85  
Light grey 00 A 01 Mid grey 00 A 05 Dark grey 10 A 11 0.68  
0.45  
0.14  
Black 00 E 53 0.05  
Note\: Some paints/surfaces have been developed to provide specific reflectance values.  
# Sky factor  
The horizontal *illuminance* \(lux\) at a given point due to light  
received directly through an unglazed window opening from a sky  
of uniform brightness, expressed as a percentage of the horizon-  
tal illuminance under an unobstructed vault of the same sky. See  
Section 2.5. Zero *reflectance* is ascribed to interior and exterior  
surfaces.  
# Skylight indicator  
Figure 9.4, for checking the daylight potential of new buildings  
and daylight protection for existing buildings. It provides an esti-  
mate of *the vertical sky component* on a built-up site. The centre  
of the semi-circular indicator corresponds to the position in plan  
of the reference point. Its base should run along the plane of the  
window wall. Radial distances correspond to the ratio \(distance of  
obstruction on plan\)/\(height of obstruction above *reference* point\).  
Each little cross stands for a vertical sky component of 0.5 per cent.  
# Light 9-15  
Count how many crosses fall within the outline of the sky. Divide  
by 2. The answer equals the vertical sky component, expressed as  
a percentage.  
# Solar declination  
At any one moment, the sun is precisely overhead at some point  
on the earth’s surface. The latitude of this point depends on the  
season, and is known as the solar declination. Some values of solar  
declination are shown in Table II.  
# Sunlight availability indicator  
Figure 9.5, for checking sunlight protection for existing buildings  
and sunlight potential for new buildings. It provides a measure of  
the *probable sunlight hours* on a built-up site. The centre of the  
indicator corresponds to the position in plan of the reference point.  
Radial distances correspond to the ratio \(distance of obstruction  
on plan\)/\(height of obstruction above reference point\). Align the  
south point of the indicator with the south point of the site plan.  
Each of the 100 dots on the indicator stands for 1 per cent of the  
annual probable hours of sunlight. Choose the indicator whose  
stated latitude \(51.5°, 53.5° or 56°\) is closest to the geographical  
latitude of the site. If a dot is closer to the centre than any obstruc-  
tion in that direction, then sunlight from that dot is unobstructed  
\(unless, of course, it comes from behind the facade\). Count the  
unobstructed dots. The total is the percentage of probable sunlight  
hours. Littlefair \(2011\) recommends an annual exposure to at least  
25 unobstructed dots, including at least five from beyond the equi-  
nox line.  
# Sun-on-ground indicator  
See Figure 9.6, designed for site planning, showing the length  
and direction of shadows at the equinox. The Building Research  
Establishment has issued indicators for the following latitudes  
– 51.5°, 53.5° and 56° – each at scales of 1\:100, 1\:200, 1\:500  
and 1\:1250. Place the point P of the indicator over a reference  
point at ground level on plan. Line the south point of the indi-  
cator with the south point on the plan. Parallel east – west lines  
on the indicator show the heights of obstructions which would  
just intercept direct sunlight at the time indicated. Hence, one  
can estimate the hours of potential sunlight reaching any point  
on the ground at the equinox. Sunlight less than 10° above the  
horizon is ignored.  
# Sun path indicator  
See Figure 9.7, for checking times and seasons when direct  
sunlight strikes a given reference point on a built-up site. It is  
aligned and scaled in the same way as the *sunlight availabil-*  
*ity indicator*. Choose the indicator whose stated latitude \(51.5°,  
53.5° or 56°\) is closest to the geographical latitude of the site.  
If a point on one of the sun path lines is closer to the centre  
than any obstruction in that direction, then the sunlight at that  
moment is unobstructed \(unless, of course, it comes from behind  
the facade\).  
# Transmittance \(T\)  
The proportion of *luminous flux* in lumens striking the upper sur-  
face of a transparent or translucent sheet which emerges from the  
lower surface. The transmittance of clear single layer of window  
glass for reference is taken as 0.82; double glazing 0.70.  
*Note\: These values refer to diffuse incidence. Figures from*  
*glass manufacturers usually refer to normal incidence, and are*  
*correspondingly higher*.  
# Vertical Sky Component \(SCv\)  
The *illuminance* in lux on a vertical element at a point due to direct  
light from the overcast sky vault, expressed as a percentage of the  
simultaneous horizontal illuminance under the whole unobstructed  
sky vault. **9-16 Light**  
# Working plane  
The flat plane on which the visual task is located. In a corridor, this  
would be at floor level. In a shop, at counter height. In an office –  
average desk height 0.7 m, a factory or kitchen 0.85 m above floor  
level. Unless otherwise stated the working plane is assumed to be  
horizontal.

# 2 FUNDAMENTALS OF ACOUSTICS  
# 2.1 Creating sound  
Consider a tuning fork \(Figure 10.1\). When the fork is struck,  
the prongs vibrate. As the prongs vibrate, the air particles around  
the prongs are pushed away. These air particles in turn push the  
air particles next to them and so on, thereby creating a pressure  
wave through the air. This forced wave motion is what our senses  
interpret as sound in the inner ear. In all instances, we will have a  
vibrating source \(e.g. the tuning fork\), a path \(the air\) and a receiver  
\(normally a person\).  
# 1 INTRODUCTION  
There are three main areas for consideration when designing build-  
ings for good acoustics.  
1 The control of sound break-in from external noise sources; most  
commonly from transportation, industrial and/or commercial  
\(pubs, clubs, etc.\) activities  
2 The control of sound transmission through a building; most  
commonly from building users \(voices, TV, stereo, footfall,  
living activities\) but can also include control of sound from  
building services \(fixed plant, ventilation systems\)  
3 The acoustic quality of a room; most commonly the level of  
reverberation \(echo\) in a room effective for a given function  
\(speech clarity, music\).  
Consideration of acoustic design during the early stages of a  
project can substantially reduce the potential for costly remedial  
# 2.2 Sound transmission  
Forced particle motion forms wave patterns and so allows sound  
to travel within air. As the particles form waves, they propagate,  
diffract and curve like other wave forms, which is why sound can  
be heard round corners or through small gaps in a structure.  
We can reduce a sound by controlling the noise at source,  
altering the transmission path or by changing the acoustics of the  
listeners’ location.  
Controlling the noise at source is not always possible for most  
sources affecting a building, as they are outside the designer’s  
control \(motorway traffic, the activities of a neighbour etc.\). The  
exception to this would be noise from sources associated with the  
design of a new building \(ventilation plant, services\). Here, the  
selection of suitable equipment and plant will reduce the likelihood  
of noise complaint.  
The second option, altering the sound transmission path, is  
the most readily used method of reducing sound from a source.  
This can be seen in the use of heavy, double-glazed windows to  
lower road traffic noise, or the construction of a twin stud partition  
instead of a single stud partition to separate dwellings.  
**10.1** *How sound is created*  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-12 **10-1** **10-2 Sound**  
By changing the materials and properties of a façade, floor or  
wall we can alter the sound path and the way that sound is trans-  
mitted \(Figure 10.2\).  
The third option is to alter the acoustics of the space or room in  
which the receiver is situated. While this will have a limited effect  
on the annoyance of noise from external sources, it can improve  
the acoustic environment within a room. This is important when  
considering things such as speech intelligibility or suitable listen-  
ing environments.  
**10.2** *Source – path receiver*  
In most rooms, the RT will be a product of the room volume and  
material finishes. The larger a room volume, the longer it will take  
sound to reach and interact \(i.e. be reflected or absorbed\) with the  
material finishes.  
Other factors influencing RT include room shape and surface  
diffusion, both linked to the spread of sound within the space.  
A key means of controlling the RT within a space is to introduce  
acoustically absorbent finishes. Materials can be classified by their  
acoustic absorption in line with the guidance given in BS EN ISO  
11654\:1997; Acoustics – Sound absorbers for use in Buildings –  
Rating of Sound Absorption. This allows the designer to specify  
a classification of material rather than being forced into giving a  
prescriptive specification.  
Figure 10.3 details the absorption classifications that are nor-  
mally associated with absorbent materials specified in the UK.  
They run from Class A materials \(those with the highest levels of  
acoustic absorption\) to Class E materials \(those with the lowest  
levels of acoustic absorption\)  
Classification of a material against the absorption coefficient  
graph shown in Figure 10.3 may not be suitable for all material  
types e.g. panel absorbers tend to provide high performance only at  
a narrow frequency band.  
BS EN ISO 11654 also allows for the average absorption coef-  
ficient of a material to be used as a method of defining is absorption  
classification. This is detailed in Table I where άw is the average  
acoustic absorption of the material.  
# 2.3 Reverberation time  
Acoustic absorption occurs when sound comes into contact with  
an acoustically porous material. In a bedroom, the carpet, curtains,  
bed and bedding are all acoustically absorbent and so have the  
effect of reducing the reverberation time \(RT, echo\) within a space.  
This can make a sound quieter than in a ‘live’ room or a room with  
lots of hard reflective surfaces, such as a bathroom. Hard smooth  
surfaces within a room will increase the RT \(echo\) within a space.  
The size or volume of a space will also have an effect on the RT.  
We can measure this effect in a room by creating an impulsive  
sound \(a sudden bang or burst of noise\) and measuring the time it  
takes this noise level to fall by 60 decibels \(dB\).

# 3 REDUCING SOUND TRANSMISSION FROM  
# EXTERNAL SOURCES  
# 3.1 Guidance  
In the UK, the level of noise at which disturbance from particu-  
lar noise sources is likely to occur within a dwelling can be found  
in planning guidance such as\: ProPG – Planning and Noise and  
Technical Advice Note – Assessment of Noise. In addition to the  
planning guidelines, other guidance documents can be used to  
assess noise within non-domestic builds. In most instances, we are  
concerned with the level of noise break-in from external sources  
which are outside the control of the building owner or occupier.  
**LDEN.** This is a compounded noise level based on the Leq parameter  
but defined over all days, evenings and nights in a year, and con-  
tains a 10 dB\(A\) penalty for the night-time period \(23.00–07.00\)  
and a further 5 dB\(A\) penalty for evening noise \(19.00–23.00\). It  
is commonly used in environmental noise surveys to account for  
typical human sensitivity to noise, particularly for traffic noise  
sources and is a primary parameter for noise mapping.  
For most transportation sources, it is suggested that external aver-  
age noise level of below LAeq\(16hours\) 55 dB during the daytime and  
LAeq\(8hours\) 45 dB during the night-time are likely to be an indication  
of low risk of disturbance. For comparison, Table II lists likely noise  
levels for a variety of typical urban and suburban areas.  
# 3.3 Control of external noise levels  
The permissible level of noise outside a building can differ greatly  
dependant on the source of noise, nature of the development or  
even the policy of the local authority.  
The World Health Organization suggests external free-field  
levels of below LAeq \(16hours\) 50–55 dB as suitable to avoid serious  
disturbance or annoyance during the daytime. European guidance  
suggesting maximum external free-field levels outside a dwelling  
of LAeq \(8hours\) 40 dB as being suitable to avoid noise disturbance at  
night. In many instances \(city centre, some urban and suburban  
areas\), a different approach may be suitable.  
Table III defines some of the standard noise criteria. External  
noise is normally considered an issue for residential properties but  
can be a requirement for outdoor workspaces or education spaces.  
The requirements of different local authorities can vary greatly and  
so consultation with planning and environmental health depart-  
ments should always be sought when designing for the control of  
external noise levels. The criteria in Table III are based on relevant  
standards and experience of local authority expectations.  
# Table II Likely external ambient noise levels  
# 3.2 Defining levels  
Noise levels are usually not simply defined as decibels. A measure-  
ment parameter is also defined which details the type of noise level  
considered, often as an A-weighted decibel level, measured as an  
average, time fraction or maximum level, as outlined in the following.  
**LAeq**\: The average measured noise level over a defined period of  
time \(LAeq \(16hours\), LAeq \(8hours\), etc.\). The ‘A’ in the LAeq parameter  
means that the noise level has been weighted so that it is akin to  
the subjective noise level that the average person would hear.  
**LAmax**\: The highest single noise event for a given measurement  
duration, such as would be associated with a sudden increase in  
noise such as a train pass by.  
**LA90**\: This is the underlying noise level or the average noise level  
which is exceeded for 90 per cent of the measurement period.  
This is often referred to as the background noise level represent-  
ing quiet periods or lulls in the average noise level. Noise control  
to the background reduces risk of disturbance, that is, during the  
periods between vehicles passing a dwelling where industrial or  
commercial noise may be audible and cause disturbance.

Noise from entertainment sources \(bars, clubs, pubs\) are not normally  
required to be controlled outside the nearest residential property, as in  
most cases noise from these sources is associated with night-time use  
and sleep disturbance within a property. Control levels for such noise  
will differ from one Local Authority to another, and so they should  
always be consulted either when building dwellings next to an entertain-  
ment source or when introducing a new source of entertainment noise.  
‘Agent of Change’ principals, being incorporated into planning  
guidance, place the onus onto the developer to mitigate noise. This  
prevents new residential developments from burdening existing  
entertainment venues with mitigation obligations or threatening  
their operations. In some areas, these principals are being extended  
to other commercial operations.  
# 3.4 Distance attenuation  
The more distant a receiver is from a noise source, the quieter the  
level of noise. With environmental noise sources, the rate of atten-  
uation will depend upon whether the noise source propagates as a  
*point source*, or as a *line source*. If a house were located 20 m from  
a road, this would be considered a line source, and so the level of  
noise would reduce by 13 dB. If the house were 20 m from a point  
source \(an air conditioning unit\) the level would be reduced by  
26 dB relative to the measured noise level at the source.  
As a general rule of thumb, the difference between line source  
and point source attenuation is\:  
• 3 dB reduction in noise level for each doubling of distance from  
a line source  
• 6 dB reduction in noise level for each doubling of distance from  
a point source.  
# 3.5 Acoustic barriers  
Noise can be reduced by the construction of an acoustic barrier.  
An acoustic barrier can be as simple as a close-boarded fence,  
earth bund, or combination of both. By breaking the direct line of  
sight between a noise source and the receiver, we reduce the level  
of sound because we are increasing the distance the sound has to  
travel \(i.e. the sound has to go over the top of the barrier\).  
The level of attenuation for an acoustic barrier will be depend-  
ent on the following factors\:  
• The height and length of the barrier – the higher the barrier, the  
greater its expected performance, however the length should  
ensure that height is the critical factor.  
• The shape of the top of the barrier can increase the effective  
height/path difference.  
• The type of noise source – barriers are more effective for station-  
ary noise sources such as fixed plant than for a moving source  
such as vehicles.  
• The height of the noise source – the higher the source, the higher  
the barrier will have to be to break the line of sight.  
• The height of the receiver – the higher the receiver, the higher  
the barrier will have to be to break the line of sight.  
• The distance between the source and the barrier – it is always  
preferable to place the barrier as close to the source as possible.  
• Where the aforementioned cannot be achieved, the next best  
option is to position the barrier as close to the receiver as possible.  
• The worst position for a barrier is half way between the source  
and the receiver.  
• The mass of the barrier – generally the minimum surface mass of  
any acoustic barrier should not be less than 15 kg/m2.  
• Gaps, cracks, and damage are all critical factors to reduced perfor-  
mance and therefore good materials, design and durability are key.  
# Table IV Basic sound reduction levels from acoustic barriers  
Full barrier \(full break in line of sight from source to receiver\) −10 dB  
Partial barrier \(partial break in line of sight from source to receiver\) −5 dB  
The calculation of the attenuation offered by an acoustic barrier can  
be complicated, but a good rule of thumb is to assume a 5 dB reduc-  
tion for a partial barrier effect and 10 dB for a full barrier effect,  
see Table IV. For example, a 2 m barrier is likely to provide 10 dB  
reduction from road traffic at ground floor level and 5 dB reduction  
at first floor level.  
Higher levels of acoustic insulation can be provided by increas-  
ing barrier height, but this can become impractical and expensive.  
Barriers with a sound absorbing face to the source side may provide  
additional performance in some enclosed scenarios.  
The insulation performance of a barrier should be defined with  
the parameter *DL*R dB and may be categorised by performance  
from B0 to B4, as defined within BS EN 1793–2. Typically, B2 or  
B3 barriers shall provide performances of *DL*R 15 to \>24 dB how-  
ever it is useful to seek an end-of-life performance guarantee given  
that in-situ timber barrier performance has been found to drop by  
4–7 dB in the first 5 years of use due to poor design/damage.  
# 3.6 Angle of view  
The orientation of a building or a noise sensitive room away from a  
noise source can also reduce the level of noise disturbance experi-  
enced. If the room is at an angle to the source \(i.e. not at 90 degrees\)  
then there is typically a reduction in noise relative to the angle of view.  
Table V outlines the expected reductions in sound levels at 500 Hz  
and 1000 Hz dependant on the angle of view from source to receiver.

# 3.7 Façade attenuation  
Building façade specification provides an opportunity to attenu-  
ate external noise sources. It is commonly accepted that for some  
noise sources such as commercial noise and industrial noise, inter-  
nal noise levels within an affected building should be calculated  
in relation to an open window. In many other instances such as  
transportation noise in particular, the assessment of internal noise  
levels can be calculated with closed windows. If we take the glaz-  
ing element to be the dictating factor in the acoustic insulation of a  
façade, it can be used as the means by which façade insulation can  
be specified.  
A wide range of acoustic performance data is published by most  
glazing manufacturers and will normally detail frequency perfor-  
mance levels along with average or single figure values. When  
assessing the acoustic performance of a glazing unit for road traf-  
fic noise protection, it is best to base an assessment on the RTRA  
criteria. This is the reduction \(R\) in noise level provided by the  
glazing unit when adjusted for a road traffic noise spectrum \(TRA\).

# 5.3 Isolation of a structure  
Separating \(or isolating\) the different elements of a structure using  
an air cavity can break the sound transmission paths, like a break  
in a circuit board. The deeper the isolating cavity, the greater the  
isolation. In narrow cavities, the air can act as a tie between two  
independent leaves. Isolation is particularly important for light-  
weight wall constructions and impact sound insulation.  
Impact resistant mats, isolated floor battens and floating floor  
systems all help to isolate a structure from impact sound. Isolation  
will also reduce airborne sound transmission through twin stud  
wall systems and independent ceiling or wall linings.  
# 5.4 Mass of a structure  
The more mass a material or structure has, the more difficult it will  
be for a sound pressure wave to force it to vibrate. For most mate-  
rials, mass is the defining factor in acoustic performance. For every  
doubling of mass in a structure or material, we should see a 6 dB  
improvement in acoustic insulation. This will only be noticed at  
the mass-controlled frequencies. This normally occurs at the mid  
range of frequencies.  
# 5.5 Absorption within a structure  
By adding absorbent materials to cavities within a partition, we reduce  
the reverberant sound therein and the transmitted sound energy. This  
is normally achieved by adding acoustically porous materials such as  
mineral fibre quilt. The inclusion of such materials can improve the  
acoustic insulation of a partition by between 3 to 6 dB.  
# 5.6 Flanking sound affecting a structure  
Sound always takes the path of least resistance. Flanking sound  
transmission relates to noise that does not come directly through  
the separating construction and can include airborne \(interconnect-  
ing spaces\) and structural paths \(common structural elements\). It  
is possible for there to be at least 12 flanking transmission paths  
between two rooms other than directly through a separating con-  
struction such as flanking via wall, floor and ceiling elements.  
Flanking transmission can be a particular problem with masonry-  
supported timber separating floors, where there is a strong structural  
connection between flats due to continuous masonry walls running  
up through a building, Figure 10.4.  
# 4 REDUCING SOUND TRANSMISSION THROUGH  
# LAYOUT AND DESIGN  
The layout of a building interior can either enhance or reduce its  
suitability in controlling noise. It is good practice to locate noise  
sensitive activities away from noisy activities. Early consideration  
of noise can provide economical design solutions.  
In domestic buildings, an increase in single living and shift  
working, coupled with the ability of homeowners to generate  
high levels of base intensive noise, have increased the likelihood  
for noise issues to arise between neighbours. In civic buildings,  
it is often possible to put ancillary storage cupboards as buffers  
between opposing room uses. Aligned room use is recommended.  
The following should be considered in order to reduce noise  
issues from building users\:  
• Avoid placing noise sensitive activities next to rooms with  
higher levels of noise.  
• Avoid detailing services \(such as soil vent pipe or heating, venti-  
lation and air conditioning\) through noise sensitive spaces.  
• Avoid placing rooms with heavy service demands or high activ-  
ity above quiet rooms \(e.g. kitchens above sleeping areas\).  
• Locate external bin areas away from noise sensitive rooms.  
• Avoid locating lift shafts in areas where they directly back onto  
noise sensitive rooms.  
• Place plant rooms and building services in as remote a location  
as practical from a noise sensitive area.  
• Fire doors in communal corridors should be located away from  
the entrance doors to dwellings or noise sensitive rooms.  
• Avoid locating rooms with high occupancy at the end of cor-  
ridors where there is greater potential to cause disturbance to  
adjacent noise sensitive rooms.  
# 5 REDUCING SOUND TRANSMISSION THROUGH  
# A STRUCTURE  
# 5.1 Principle  
Airborne sound transmission through a structure is the passage of  
the sound pressure wave from the air, into the structure, through the  
structure and then out the other side. Low frequency noise pushes  
the whole structure causing the sound pressure wave to be transmit-  
ted by the surface of the wall or floor. As we move up the frequency  
range, the wavelength of the sound gets shorter and so instead of  
being able to force the whole partition into motion the sound finds  
paths through the structure. Sound will also find ways of transmit-  
ting through small gaps or voids within the structure or through  
weaker flanking elements such as adjoining walls or service runs.  
There are six key factors in the reduction of sound through a  
building structure. By taking cognisance of these six issues when  
specifying a partition, be it a floor, wall, roof or external cladding  
**10.4** *Flanking paths through separating wall* **10-6 Sound**  
# 5.5 Completeness of a structure  
Without a complete structure, sound can leak through any gaps or  
holes in the same way that water would leak through the cracks  
in a dam. In addition to gaps or holes, incompleteness will have a  
similar effect. In some instances, this can be a result of poor work-  
manship such as badly finished joints, but it can be attributed to  
poor detailing such as wall head details or detailing of service pen-  
etrations.  
# 6 PERMISSIBLE NOISE LEVELS WITHIN  
# A BUILDING  
# 6.1 Defining levels  
It often falls to the lead designer on a project to outline suitable  
performance parameters and criteria for permissible noise levels  
within a building. The required levels will depend upon the client’s  
requirement, the expected use of the building and the types of room  
within a building. Defining the most suitable parameter to use is  
the first task of any design process. There are two main perfor-  
mance parameters that should normally be applied\: The Ambient  
Noise \(LAeq\), outlined in Section 3, and/or the Noise Rating \(NR\)  
parameter. In addition, the maximum noise level \(LAmax\), outlined  
in Section 3, is often applied.  
# 6.2 Noise rating curves  
NR is the Noise Rating Curve. This is commonly applied to steady  
or tonal noise sources \(e.g. fixed plant and equipment\). The NR  
criteria sets a maximum noise limit for each frequency band rather  
than setting a maximum average noise level as is the case with the  
LAeq parameter. Fixed noise sources such as plant and machinery  
are known for having high levels of noise at a particular frequency  
and so it is important to have a performance parameter that sets a  
maximum level at each frequency band. If an average noise level  
were set, such as the LAeq criteria, then it could be possible for noise  
from a fan to meet an LAeq criteria but still be perceived as disturb-  
ing due to a tonal emission at a particular frequency. Figure 10.5  
details the NR curves.  
# 6.3 Guidance on performance criteria by room type  
Table VII details suitable ambient noise levels and suitable NR lev-  
els for a range of building and room types.  
The guidance given in the table is an amalgamation of current  
performance criteria from the most relevant guidance documents  
\(Building Bulletin 93, HTM08–01, BS8233, CSDG2007. CTDG  
2019\. BCO Guidance 2011&2014\).  
# 6.4 Maximum or impulsive noise levels  
The control of impulsive noise events is also worthy of consid-  
eration in building design as such noises can be distracting and  
interrupt activities including sleep. This is normally described by  
the parameter LAmax, the A-weighted maximum noise level recorded  
during a measurement period although the LA1,30min parameter is  
used for schools. These parameters should be considered when  
assessing noise sources which may include a sudden short duration  
noise or individual high noise events. Examples of this would be  
trains passing by or bangs from industrial sources. These param-  
eters are not normally used in isolation but in conjunction with  
the LAeq or even the NR criteria. It is generally only reasonable  
to enforce maximum parameters in situations where sudden noise  
events occur regularly and during the night-time periods \(11pm to  
7am\), although there are some exceptions. ‘Regularly’ is normally  
taken to mean more than twice in any single hour \(daytime\) or  
more than 10 times during the night-time period. Table VIII defines  
some appropriate LAmax and LA1,30min performance criteria to avoid  
disturbance.

# 7 SOUND INSULATION PERFORMANCE  
# PARAMETERS  
Detailing the correct performance parameter for separating partitions  
has become a more complex task since the advent of guidance doc-  
uments such as Approved Document E, Building Bulletin 93 and  
Health Technical Memorandum 08–01. This is because different  
terms are used to define acoustic insulation. For example, airborne  
laboratory tests on a sample partition are normally defined as the  
Rw value \(the weighted sound reduction\) while testing on site in  
Scotland the DnT,w term is used \(difference in transmitted sound\) and  
in England and Wales the DnT,w + Ctr term is used \(the difference in  
transmitted sound adjusted using a Ctr traffic noise weighted adapta-  
tion term\).  
It is also important to know whether airborne sound insulation  
or impact sound has been measured. As a general rule, any param-  
eter which starts with ‘D’ or ‘R’ \(Dn,Tw, R’w, Dw etc.\) will be an  
airborne sound test while any parameter which starts with an ‘L’  
\(Ln’T,w, L’nw, ΔLw\) will be an impact sound test.  
Simply stating a dB requirement for the acoustic insulation of a  
partition can cause confusion as it does not describe the method by  
which the partition is to be assessed \(e.g. the difference in on site  
performance between specifying a partition with a DnTw of 50 dB  
compared to a partition with a DnT,w+Ctr of 50 dB can be more than  
10 dB\). Therefore it is necessary to state the performance param-  
eter \(Dn,Tw, R’w, etc.\) as well as the performance criteria \(45 dB,  
50 dB etc\).  
The most commonly used parameters are listed in Table IX out-  
lining what they mean and where they are used.  
# 8 SOUND INSULATION PERFORMANCE  
# CRITERIA  
# 8.1 Airborne and impact sound transmission  
The level of insulation required is set as a performance criterion  
and stated in dB. For example, if we were undertaking sound insu-  
lation testing in England and Wales we know that the performance  
parameter is DnT’w  
+Ctr but if we were testing in Northern Ireland  
the performance parameter is DnT,w. As these parameters determine  
the way in which the result is calculated, the resultant dB level is  
likely to be different. For example, if we test a blockwork wall and  
calculate the insulation value using the DnT,w  
+Ctr parameter, we may  
get a dB level of 45. But if it were to calculate the result using the  
DnT,w parameter we may get a dB level of 52 dB.  
Because airborne and impact sound measurements are con-  
ducted differently, there is a difference in how we determine what  
is a good result for airborne sound insulation than for impact sound  
insulation\:  
• Airborne sound insulation values are always set as **minimum**  
performance levels \(a measurement of level difference\)  
• Impact sound insulation values are always set as **maximum** per-  
formance levels \(a measurement of the resultant level\).  
Therefore for airborne sound insulation, the higher the result the bet-  
ter. But for impact sound insulation, the lower the result the better.

# 8.3 Acoustic lining systems performance  
When selecting suitable acoustic lining systems, such as bonded  
resilient coverings, floating floor treatments \(batten, cradle or  
deck overlay systems\) or resilient ceiling bar systems in domestic  
buildings manufactures should prove that their systems can meet  
minimum standards based on laboratory data.  
In this instance, the ΔLw or ΔRw parameters are used. This is the  
level of improvement a system has achieved when tested on a base  
timber or concrete floor under laboratory conditions. Regardless of  
whether it is an impact \(ΔLw\) or airborne \(ΔRw\) result the Δ character

# 8.5 School performance criteria  
The guidance offered in this section is based on the performance  
criteria set out in Building Bulletin 93. Table XIII details the DnT,w  
airborne sound insulation requirements for school developments.  
Table XIV details the impact sound insulation requirements for  
schools. The impact requirement for each room would be for the  
floor above the room in question so that the room is protected from  
impact sound to the prescribed level.  
Note\: An adjustment is made to the T0 \(reference RT\) to the  
design RT parameter \(Tmf,max\) of a space for both airborne and  
impact sound insulation.

doors or glazing in them, would not be testable on site. Therefore,  
a performance criterion based on laboratory performance is pro-  
vided. Laboratory test data provides the bases of evidence that a  
partition specification is suitable for use.

# 8.7 Hospital performance criteria  
The guidance offered in this section is based on the performance  
criteria set out in Health Technical Memorandum 08–01.  
*Impact sound insulation* – Guidance for impact insulation given  
in HTM08–01 is limited and recommends that the aim should be  
to avoid locating heavy traffic areas above sensitive spaces such  
as wards. The performance requirement set is a maximum L’nT,w  
of 65 dB.  
*Airborne sound insulation* – Table XV details the DnTw airborne  
sound insulation requirements for hospital developments.  
Locating rooms adjacent to one another, which will result in a  
partition that requires a DnT,w of 57 dB, should be avoided but where  
# Sound 10-11  
unavoidable should be achieved as a minimum. Where it is not pos-  
sible to meet the minimum acoustic absorption requirements within  
a receiver room \(set out in Section 10\) then the level of insulation  
for the partitions in these areas should be increased by 3 dB.  
# 8.8 Hospital performance criteria – corridor/circulation  
# space walls  
The level of sound insulation for corridor walls separating rooms  
from circulation spaces which have doors or glazing in them would  
not be testable on site. Therefore, a performance criterion based  
on laboratory performance should be set. Laboratory test data can  
be used as evidence that a partition specification is suitable for  
use. For all rooms to circulation spaces the minimum requirement  
would be Rw 40–45 dB for the wall and Rw 30–35 dB for the door  
set respectively.  
# 8.9 Performance criteria for civic buildings  
Guidance for many civic buildings may be ad hoc, however guid-  
ance for sound insulation is provided in the Courts Standards and  
Design Guide 2007 \(CSDG\) document which outlines reasonable  
performance specifications for airborne and impact sound insula-  
tion. Table XVI details the airborne insulation requirements while  
Table XVII details the impact requirements.  
# 8.10 Performance criteria for other building types  
Sound insulation in other building types is often disregarded until  
there is an issue. Nevertheless, it remains important in offices,  
cinemas and other building types, for their intended function.  
Table XVIII outlines good practice for airborne sound insulation  
in a variety of building types. Performance standards given for  
office accommodation are taken from the BCO Guide to Fit Out  
2011.  
# 8.11 Broadcasting  
The guidance requirements for commercial recording studios and  
television broadcast studios is considered a highly specialised area  
and should be considered the remit of acoustic consultant or spe-  
cialist design consultant. Further guidance can be found in BBC  
Engineering’s ‘Guide to Acoustic Practice’.  
# 9 SPECIFYING AIRBORNE AND IMPACT INSULA-  
# TION FROM LABORATORY TEST DATA  
# 9.1 Laboratory to site  
It can often be difficult to find site performance data for a parti-  
tion, and so a designer may have to rely on test data gathered from  
laboratory testing. In most instances, airborne and impact sound  
insulation is measured in a suppressed flanking laboratory. This  
type of laboratory reduces the effects of the other sound paths  
between the two test rooms \(see Section 5\) so that only the perfor-  
mance of the specimen partition is tested.  
In order to assess if the laboratory performance of a partition  
is good enough to be used on site it is necessary to adjust the lab-  
oratory result. The level of adjustment required is partly based on  
the performance parameter that is used on site \(DnT,w, DnT,w+Ctr etc\)  
and the anticipated effects of flanking. For these estimations to be  
meaningful it is assumed that the partition specification used on  
site is identical to that tested in the laboratory and that there are no  
workmanship variances on site.  
# 9.2 Domestic performance conversions  
The following rules of thumb are normally applied when converting  
site performance requirements to laboratory performance levels\:  
Site DnT,w = Lab Rw +5 dB for masonry partitions  
Site DnT,w = Lab R +7 dB for light weight partitions  
w  
Site DnT,w+Ctr = Lab Rw +Ctr + 10 dB for masonry partitions  
Site DnT,w+Ctr = Lab Rw +Ctr + 15 dB for lightweight partitions. **10-12 Sound**

# 9.3 Hospital performance conversions  
# \(laboratory to site\)  
For hospitals, the HTM08–01 document suggests that additional  
care be taken when specifying partitions with relevance to room  
volume. Plasterboard and blockwork suppliers normally give  
performance results in Rw \(laboratory tests\). To determine the cor-  
respondent DnT,w value \(site performance\) a conversion must be  
made.  
The minimum that should be added is +5 dB for heavy con-  
structions and +7 dB for lightweight constructions however, as the  
room width reduces the level of insulation that a wall would have  
to provide under laboratory conditions increases in order to provide  
the required level of insulation on site.  
For standard cuboid receiving rooms, the following equations  
are used to convert DnT,w to R values\: w  
• Lightweight walls/floors\:  
*R*w ≡ *D*nT,w−10 log *d* + 14  
• Masonry walls/floors\:  
*R* w ≡ *D*nT,w−10 log *d* + 11.  
Where d is the dimension of the receiving room perpendicular  
to the separating partition.  
# 9.4 School performance conversions  
For schools projects, the DnT,w parameter discussed in 9.02 and  
9.03 is normalised \(T0, reference RT\) to the design RT parameter  
\(Tmf,max\) of a space. The Tmf,max parameter sets a maximum RT to  
be used in the calculation of the result \(i.e. substituting T0 = 0.5  
seconds\). If the correct RT within a room is not achieved it will  
have an effect on the overall sound insulation performance of the  
partition. **10-14 Sound**  
While it is suitable to use the rules of thumb outlined in Sections  
9.02 \(+5 and +7 dB added to the Rw value depending upon the  
partition type\) this will only be credible if the correct RT in the  
receiving room is also achieved \(see Section 10\).

# 10 REVERBERATION CRITERIA  
# 10.1 Parameters  
Two performance parameters are normally set when considering  
RT in a room. Either the room must not exceed a maximum RT  
or a minimum area of acoustically absorbent material should be  
specified within the room. For the second parameter described, it  
is also normal to dictate the minimum level of absorption offered  
by the material.  
# 10.2 Reverberation times  
For rooms intended for speech, the RT, given in seconds, can  
be considered as the average RT for the octave frequency bands  
500 Hz, 1000 Hz and 2000 Hz or an average of 400–2500 kHz  
one-third results.  
Table XX details the required maximum RTs for a range of  
rooms. Instances where an alternative frequency range should be  
used are noted in the table.

# 10.3 Optimum reverberation times in performance spaces  
For performance spaces including churches, the optimum RT will  
differ dependent upon the type of performance, \(speech, music\) the  
type of building and the volume of the space. Figure 10.6 gives  
guidance values for RTs in some common performance spaces  
\(William Cavanaugh et al, BS 8233, Ballou\).  
These guidance levels show the optimum RT dependant on  
room volume at the 500 Hz frequency bandwidth. Achieving these  
RTs will be dependent on specialist acoustic design. General guid-  
ance on this subject is given in Section 11.  
# 10.4 Minimum area of absorption  
The other performance parameter commonly used is to define the  
minimum area of absorption required for a space, and to define the  
absorption classification of the material. This is used in hospital  
developments or in circulation spaces \(e.g. in schools or stairwells  
in domestic developments\). **10.6** *Reverberation vs volume criteria in performance spaces*  
*\(500 Hz\)*  
The absorption classification of a material is defined in BS EN  
ISO 11654 at each frequency as the άs and as a single figure value  
as the άw. From this, the classification of a material is rated from  
A-E, with Class A absorbent material being the highest classifi-  
cation with the most absorption, and Class E materials being the  
lowest classification with the least absorption.
