# 11 GENERAL GUIDANCE ON THE ACOUSTICS OF  
# PERFORMANCE SPACES  
When designing performance spaces such as auditoria and theatre,  
it is always advisable to involve a specialist in building acoustics.  
However, there are some basic guidance rules that the non-special-  
ist designer should be aware of to allow them to begin the initial  
design\:  
• Halls for music performance require a minimum of 8 m3 per  
audience member.  
• Halls for theatres or cinemas require a minimum of 4 m3 per  
audience member.  
• Rectangular shaped halls with high ceilings are normally pref-  
erable; fan shaped halls normally provide poor acoustics for  
musical performances.  
• Domes and barrel vaults can cause focusing and should be  
avoided or treated with additional absorption.  
• Acoustic scattering treatments are recommended for side walls.  
Side wall diffusion will increase the musical clarity.  
• A proscenium stage enclosure will benefit the balance and  
ensemble of orchestrations.  
• Large overhangs or balconies will reduce the quality of sound  
reaching those seated below. The depth of an overhang should  
not exceed the height between the floor and the underside of the  
overhang.  
• Shallow pitched roofs can cause flutter effects.  
• Seating should be arranged to allow for a clear line of site to the  
performance space for acoustic as well as visual reasons. This  
should help to ensure the same acoustics each seat.  
• Steeply raked seating should be avoided particularly for musical  
performance spaces.  
• The walls, floor and ceiling around the performance space should  
preferably be acoustically reflective. Acoustic absorption in this  
area should be avoided.  
• For music performance spaces, the acoustic absorption provided  
by unoccupied seating should be as similar as possible to when  
the seats are occupied. Upholstered seating is best. Where tip-up  
seating is used, it is preferable to upholster the underside of the  
seat.  
• Background noise levels should be kept to a minimum. The  
acoustic performance of the building envelope is important when  
designing in noisy \(city centre\) areas.  
• Plant and machinery should be as quiet as possible.

# Beryl Menzies  
*Beryl Menzies is a consultant in fire safety.*  
*KEY POINTS*  
• *Most buildings have a statutory requirement to provide a mini-*  
*mum level of life safety in the event of a fire*  
• *Insurers may require specific fire safety measures*  
• *Most building owners wish to include a level of fire safety, be it*  
*for life or property protection*

# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 General principles  
When designing a building with fire safety in mind, particularly  
means of escape, it is important not to forget usability and security  
needs. The fire strategy should be practical in use, reasonable and  
manageable. If the fire measures are seen to be too onerous \(for  
example, a multiplicity of fire doors\), they will be circumvented  
and their purpose will be frustrated. Fire and security need not con-  
flict, and every effort should be made to design out any conflict.  
Buildings should be accessible to all persons. It is therefore  
necessary to ensure that adequate measures are incorporated to  
facilitate the aided or unaided escape of persons who find steps a  
barrier, or who will find evacuation during a fire difficult or impos-  
sible without assistance.  
# 1.2 Legislation and guidance review  
While the contents of this chapter are correct at the time of going to  
press, it should be noted that all fire safety legislation and guidance is  
under review in response to the Grenfell Tower fire of June 14, 2017.  
The initial review was detailed in the Hackitt Report published  
May 2018. The Building Regulations and Approved Document B  
were subsequently amended and a draft Fire Safety Bill has been  
issued. At the time of writing, both this bill and the draft Building  
Safety Bill, were progressing through Parliament. Both bills are sub-  
ject to amendment. The Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local  
Government \(MHCLG\) and the Home Office websites and \(www.  
parliament.uk\) should be checked for their progress and outcome.  
# 2 COMPONENTS OF FIRE  
# 2.1 Combustion  
Fire is combustion producing heat and light. Combustion will  
occur and continue if three factors are present\: oxygen, heat and  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-13  
# CI/Sfb \(K\)  
fuel. These are generally referred to as the combustion triangle,  
Figure 11.1.  
**11.1** *Combustion triangle*  
# 2.2 Extinguishment  
Fire can be extinguished by removing one component of the com-  
bustion triangle\:  
• Starve or limit the fuel by removing it  
• Extinguish by limiting or stopping the further supply of oxygen  
• Remove or stop the heat source; cool by dissipating the heat  
faster than it is generated.  
# 2.3 Heat source  
A source of heat comes into contact with a combustible material \(the  
fuel\) which ignites and supports combustion while oxygen is present.  
The heat sources within a building are many, for example, cooking,  
smoking, heating equipment, overheating/faulty equipment.  
# 2.4 Fuel  
This can take many forms\:  
• Combustible materials that will support burning following igni-  
tion \(e.g. timber, certain insulation materials, plastics\)  
• Flammable liquids  
• Flammable gases given off from substances when at ambient  
temperature or when heated.  
The fuel may be present in the building structure, fittings and/or  
contents and can be in the form of solids, liquids or gases. Most  
organic materials will burn. Certain materials spontaneously com-  
bust under specific environmental conditions and care is required  
in their storage, for example, linseed oil, certain chemicals, grains,  
waste materials. Certain industrial processes involving high levels  
of dust, for example, printing or flour mills, can result in flash fires.  
Specialist advice should be sought in respect of these matters.  
# 2.5 Risk of fire  
Risk results from the presence of a hazard. While it is virtually impos-  
sible to remove all hazards from a building, they can be significantly  
reduced by careful choice of materials and management control.  
The hazard can result from\:  
• The use to which the building is put  
• The materials it is constructed from in relation to its use  
**11-1** **11-2 Fire safety**  
• The way the building is laid out/subdivided  
• Possibly its location – remote from emergency assistance and an  
adequate water supply.  
It should be noted that electricity in itself will not cause fire\: it  
needs to cause heat and be in contact with a combustible material,  
for example, combustible insulation or cable, or to produce a spark  
or arcing that comes into contact with combustible material.  
# 2.6 Smoke  
This is formed when heated organic materials decompose, giving  
off tar-like and sooty materials. It is likely that most smoke will  
be generated by the building contents. Again, the risk of smoke to  
people \(including firefighters\) and damage/contamination of a build-  
ing’s contents can be significantly reduced. The latter is of particular  
concern where the contents are valuable, rare or sensitive to envi-  
ronmental change/pollution, for example, data centres, galleries and  
museums. See BS EN 16893 *Conservation of Cultural Heritage –*  
*Specifications for location, construction and modification of buildings*  
*or rooms intended for the storage or use of heritage collections*.  
# 2.7 Heat  
This can be transmitted in three forms\:  
• *Conduction* – heat energy is passed from one molecule to the  
next. The conductivity of a material \(which varies with the mate-  
rial\) may affect the fire resistance of a component or structure. A  
steel member in contact with combustible materials may trans-  
fer the heat generating a fire or damage away from the original  
source.  
• *Radiation* – heat is transmitted in straight lines without any  
contact between the radiating material and the target that may  
absorb or reflect the heat. The intensity reduces inversely as the  
square of the distance from the source of radiation. Combustible  
materials placed in close proximity to a radiant fire will ignite.  
• *Convection* – only occurs in liquids and gases. The heated com-  
bustion gases become buoyant and rise through voids and shafts  
with the potential to cause ignition in other areas of a building.  
# 3 PRINCIPLES OF FIRE PROTECTION  
# 3.1 Potential problems  
• Unrestricted growth and spread of a fire within a building that  
will affect life safety, cause extensive damage and may result in  
its collapse  
• Rapid spread of fire across surfaces within the building and igni-  
tion of adjacent fuels may result in the means of escape being  
prejudiced  
• Spread of fire, smoke and hot gases in a building through ducts,  
voids and shafts affecting the means of escape, access for fire-  
fighters and causing extensive damage to decorations and  
property  
• Spread of fire to adjacent buildings affecting life safety and  
property  
• Loss of contents, disruption of work, loss of trade/production.  
# 3.2 Fire precautions  
The aim of fire precautions within a building is to inhibit/restrict  
the growth and spread of any fire. The influencing factors are\:  
• Size of building – area, height, volume  
• Layout, configuration and complexity within the building  
• Uses accommodated, and the requirements of the occupants  
• Construction materials, linings and claddings  
• Type of construction  
• Services installed  
• Furniture.  
Appropriate precautions include\:  
• Protection of the loadbearing structure to prevent untimely col-  
lapse; limitation of combustibility of key structural elements  
• Automatic and manual fire alarms to give warning of fire  
• Adequate and appropriate provisions for means of escape  
• Access for firefighters up to and through the building to reach the  
seat of the fire and promptly extinguish it  
• Compartmentation and separation to restrict spread of fire; main-  
tenance of these by the protection of openings, fire stopping and  
cavity barriers within concealed spaces  
• Safe installation and maintenance of services, heat-producing  
equipment and user equipment  
• Separation of different uses to protect, for example, a risk to  
sleepers from commercial uses  
• Enclosure of high risks with fire-resisting construction to protect  
adjacent areas  
• Active fire suppression installations to detect and/or contain fire  
in its early stages and restrict its spread and growth  
• Limitation of flame spread by selective use of materials  
• Fire-resisting external walls and/or space separation to prevent  
spread of fire to adjacent properties; protection of openings in  
external walls; limited flame spread across external walls and  
roofs; use of insulation with limited combustibility to restrict  
ignition and spread  
• Smoke extraction and/or smoke control measures to facilitate  
means of escape and firefighting  
• Management training and procedures for evacuation, mainte-  
nance of fire precautions, risk analysis, management policy.  
# 3.3 Fire load and ignitability  
The majority of a fire load within a building will be its contents, over  
which a designer may have no influence. Some types of occupan-  
cies have controls relating to the ignitability of furniture \(domestic  
and assembly buildings under furniture safety regulations, hospi-  
tals and prisons under Government directives\). See Table I for the  
various occupancies addressed under the Building Regulations.  
Electricity, often cited as the cause of fires, presents a potential  
hazard when brought into contact with combustible material. All  
new electrical installations should be installed in accordance with  
the current edition of the regulations of the Institution of Electrical  
Engineers and existing installations periodically examined and  
tested for potential risks.  
# 3.4 Smoke  
The limitation of smoke spread is considered mainly as an aspect  
of safe means of escape. Specific limitations of smoke production  
are not, to date, generally specified. There is no generally accepted  
test related to smoke emission. The production of toxic gases that  
accompanies all fires would be very difficult to specify.  
Smoke also presents a significant issue for firefighters during  
firefighting and rescue operations, particularly in tall, complex  
and high-risk buildings. Smoke spread may be limited by sepa-  
ration \(fire resistant smoke retardant construction\), or by natural  
or mechanical ventilation with safeguards for high temperature  
smoke.  
# 3.5 Combustibility  
While it would be possible to construct a totally non-combustible  
building, it is not practical and not required by legislation, although  
some codes do relate means of escape to a classification based  
on the ‘combustibility’ of a building. Non-combustible materi-  
als should be used where hazardous conditions are anticipated or  
where there is a need to maintain the integrity of a structure for the  
maximum time, for example, a compartment wall or floor, or an  
escape stair in a high building.  
The 2018 amendments \(England\) to Building Regulation 7 –  
Materials and Workmanship, required that the external walls of **Fire safety 11-3**  
“relevant buildings” and “specified attachment” thereto must be  
European classification A2-s1, d0 or A1, \(limited combustibil-  
ity or non-combustible respectively\), in accordance with BS EN  
13501\:2007 as amended *Fire classification of construction prod-*  
*ucts and building elements*.  
# 3.6 Fire resistance  
The need for a degree of fire resistance within a structure may be  
dictated by Building Regulations, insurance or damage-limitation  
requirements. The prevention of untimely collapse allows evacu-  
ation, containment of a fire and therefore protection of adjacent  
areas, and access for firefighters. This is essential in high-rise  
buildings. Factors relating to the need for fire resistance are build-  
ing height and size, occupancy type and anticipated fire severity.  
While a period of fire resistance may be specified and an element  
constructed accordingly, it should not be assumed that the period  
will be attained. It may be longer or shorter due to, among other  
factors, interaction with other elements or non-maintenance, or  
more severe fire conditions than those anticipated in the test.  
# 3.7 Fire compartments \(compartmentation\)  
The term fire compartment is widely used, and sometimes incor-  
rectly, to describe any area enclosed by fire-resisting construction.  
In terms of Building Regulations, it has a specific definition as set  
out in Approved Document B\: *A building or part of a building,*  
*comprising one or more rooms, spaces, or storeys, constructed to*  
*prevent the spread of fire to or from another part of the same build-*  
*ing, or an adjoining building. \(A roof space above the storey of*  
*a compartment is included in that compartment.\)* Maximum sizes  
of compartment and which walls and floors should be designed as  
compartment walls and floors are set out in current guidance \(see  
Approved Document B, and BS 9991 and BS 9999\). The construc-  
tion of a compartment wall is specified within guidance in terms  
that include the minimising of deflection and the protection of  
openings.  
Compartmentation divides an area into a size in which it is  
considered a fire could be contained and dealt with by firefighters,  
thereby protecting adjacent areas. The addition of automatic fire  
suppression such as sprinklers to contain and control the growth of  
a fire allows larger compartments or, in some cases, their omission.  
If the only consideration is life safety, it can be argued that if all  
persons can safely escape there is no need for compartmentation,  
and the potential exists for reduced fire resistance. This principle is  
often adopted in low-rise or single storey buildings. However, in  
the case of blocks of flats/maisonettes, high-rise buildings or those  
with phased or staged evacuation, compartmentation is an essential  
part of the safety package.  
Flats and maisonettes are constructed such that every unit is a  
compartment. In the event of a fire, it is only necessary initially to  
evacuate the unit on fire.  
Effective compartmentation requires attention to detail.  
Openings, including those for ventilation and services, must be  
protected. Where shafts perforate compartment floors, ‘protected  
shafts’ should be detailed, see Table III.

Approved Document B \(England\) throughout, as this guidance is  
simple to follow and addresses most uses of buildings. However,  
more specific and detailed technical detail can be found in BS 9999  
on a number of the same issues.

*British Standards 9991 Fire safety in the design, management and*  
*use of residential buildings – Code of practice and BS 9999 Code*  
*of practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of*  
*buildings*  
Together, these provide recommendations for all the main types of  
buildings, referring users to other guidance for buildings of spe-  
cific or specialist use. For example, the guidance for hospitals and  
similar health care premises can be found in the Health Technical  
Memorandum 05–02\: *Firecode Guidance in support of functional*  
*provisions \(Fire safety in the design of healthcare premises\)* issued  
by the Department of Health.  
BS 9991 makes recommendations for residential buildings that  
are\:  
• Single family houses, self-contained flats or maisonettes  
• Residential blocks, students/hospital staff with individual bed-  
rooms and kitchen/sanitary within an individual single fire  
compartment  
• Specialised housing, for example, sheltered housing.  
It does not address hotels, mobile homes, residential care premises,  
hostels or prisons.  
Now under review, BS 9991 was last revised in 2015 and  
incorporates recommendations for open-plan apartments, which  
Approved Document B does not recommend as acceptable in all  
circumstances. There are also some differences between BS 9991  
and Approved Document B relating to the travel distances and  
smoke control measures for common areas.  
BS 9999 addresses the majority of all other buildings. Unlike  
Approved Document B, the level of protection recommended is  
dependent on the use risk profile and building height, the type of  
fire alarm, and any suppression installations to contain and reduce  
fire spread. Uses involving a sleeping risk generally require a  
higher standard of protection. Every building adopting the recom-  
mendations of BS 9999 must incorporate the outlined minimum  
level of protection. Where additional fire protection measures are  
incorporated \(e.g. automatic fire suppression and/or a fire alarm  
incorporating voice messages\), it is possible to vary/reduce \(within  
specific limits\) door and stair widths and increase travel distances.  
BS 9999 was published in 2017. It includes\:  
• A flowchart of sequential steps to aid design  
• Management levels  
• Water mist suppression  
• Recommendations for smoke and heat control  
• Recommendations for mechanical ventilation and air condition-  
ing systems  
• Recommendations for shopping complexes  
• Recommendations for atria.  
BS 9999 does not specifically address fire engineering – for this  
see BS 7974. However, BS 9999 is useful for complex and unusual  
buildings and can support a fire engineering package. **11-6 Fire safety**  
Any guidance or code should be used in its entirety – sections  
should not be ‘cherry picked’ to gain advantage. All the recom-  
mendations are interrelated and interdependent\: adequate structural  
fire resistance allows time for occupants to escape, undertake fire-  
fighting and if necessary search and rescue by the Fire and Rescue  
Service \(FRS\); warning informs of a fire and prompts people to  
evacuate; control of linings deters fire spread allowing time to  
reach an exit, as do cavity barriers by protecting against unseen  
spread of fire within the structure; adequate space separation deters  
fire spread between buildings; and Fire Service access facilitates  
firefighting.  
*Fire engineering*  
In its simplest form, fire engineering is a holistic overview of the  
risks and measures proposed to minimise such risk and where var-  
ious aspects complement each other. A solution may be complex  
and require specialist advice. However, an innovative or complex  
development may not require a complex fire-engineered solution.  
Adequate fire precautions do not need to inhibit innovation or  
design; but the cost or practicalities of the solution may be pro-  
hibitive.  
Approved Document B 2019 sets out the recommendations for  
surface spread of flame for internal linings, Table IV and Table V.  
The limitation on flame spread of linings is by reference to BS EN  
13501–1 classifications and should be read in conjunction with

Approved Document B under the Building Regulations \(not a  
British Standard\).  
The spread of flame across the face of an external wall is  
addressed in Section 10 of Approved Document B Volume 1 and  
# 3.9 Fire spread  
Limiting the spread of fire within the main structural elements is  
generally relatively easy by choosing appropriate materials, pro-  
vided that they do not contain large voids. The addition of linings  
and claddings can facilitate the rapid spread of fire beyond its area  
of origin. This was spectacularly illustrated by the Grenfell Tower  
fire. Flame can spread quickly in all directions and fixings are  
important. It has been found by experiment that the better the mate-  
rial is as an insulator, the greater the likelihood that flame spread  
will be more rapid and extensive.

# 3.11 Ventilation  
Ventilation to release heat and control and/or dispel smoke from a  
fire can protect an escape route and allow easier and rapid access  
by firefighters to extinguish a fire or rescue people. Its relationship  
to means of escape is outlined elsewhere.  
Smoke ventilation is required in\:  
• The common parts of residential accommodation to protect  
escape routes and firefighters  
• Certain lobbies to provide additional protection to escape routes  
• Firefighting shafts  
• Basements  
• Enclosed car parks  
• Possibly as part of a fire-engineered solution  
• Where smoke ventilation is a compensatory feature for a varia-  
tion from guidance.  
Ventilation can be natural or mechanical. The latter is prefera-  
ble as it is controllable, can be activated automatically and, when  
designed correctly, not influenced by wind, internal layout and con-  
figurations, outside temperature or stack effect. It does, however,  
add considerable cost, as it is necessary to safeguard its operation  
by using fans tolerant of high temperatures, protected wiring, fire  
and smoke dampers, automatic detection, secondary power sup-  
plies and monitoring. It may require sophisticated computerised  
controls. It will require ongoing maintenance.  
# 3.12 Mechanical smoke extract systems  
It is necessary to determine if the system is for smoke extraction  
\(usually to facilitate firefighting\) or smoke control \(to assist means  
of escape\). Comprehensive guidance can be found in BS 9999  
Section 27 *Heat and smoke control*. Pressure differential systems  
are addressed in BS EN 12101–6 *Smoke and heat control systems.*  
*Specification for pressure differential systems. Kits*. Currently,  
draft document BS EN 12101 Smoke and heat control systems.  
Part 13\: Pressure differential systems \(PDS\) – Design and calcu-  
lation methods, installation, acceptance testing, routine testing and  
maintenance, is under consideration. This draft document gives  
guidance and requirements for the design and calculation methods,  
installation, acceptance testing, routine testing and maintenance for  
pressure differential systems.  
Specific guidance on accepted forms of smoke control in res-  
idential accommodation \(based on current guidance in Approved  
Document B and BS 9991\) can be found in the document produced  
by the Smoke Control Association *Guidance on smoke control to*  
*common escape routes in apartment buildings \(flats and maison-*  
*ettes\) \(Revision 3.1, July 13, 2020\)*.  
For all but the simplest of code compliant systems, specialist  
advice should be sought.  
# 3.13 Natural ventilation  
Natural ventilation by the provision of open, openable or breakable  
vents is usually intended for operation by firefighters who will take  
into consideration aspects of wind etc. If vents are not accessible,  
they should be permanent, open automatically or open by remote  
control.  
# 3.14 Smoke control in large open areas  
Smoke control in large open areas such as atria, single storey facto-  
ries, auditoria, exhibition halls, shopping malls and the like may be  
required to facilitate escape and/or firefighting.  
BS 9999 contains general recommendations for the majority of  
uses, including atria. See also BRE publications Digest 260, *Smoke*  
# Fire safety 11-7  
*control in buildings\: design principles* and BR 186 *Design princi-*  
*ples for smoke ventilation in enclosed shopping centres*.  
Such smoke control measures may require specialist advice due  
to their complexity, and their complex control equipment.  
# 3.15 Access for fire fighters up to, into and through a  
# building  
Specific access for firefighters will allow their prompt action.  
Access is required up to, into and through a building. Various  
dimensional information is given in Tables VI and VII and Figures  
11.2–11.5, but it should be remembered that fire equipment is not  
standardised; it is constantly changing, giving variations in sizes  
and weights.  
If a building is provided with a fire main \(see Section 8.10\),  
access is required to within 18 m of the inlet to a dry riser or the  
access to a firefighting shaft containing a wet riser. The setdown  
point for the FRS appliance should be within sight of the dry riser  
inlet or shaft access.

# 3.18 Fire spread beyond a site boundary  
The spread of fire to adjacent sites can be prevented by\:  
• Clear space  
• Fire-resisting walls  
• External walls of limited combustibility and limited surface  
spread of flame, and/or  
• Roof coverings resistant to penetration of fire.  
If precautions are taken within a building to limit a fire’s growth  
and spread, it can be assumed that its effects on an adjacent building  
are reduced. Openings in an external wall or walls having no fire  
resistance present weaknesses to an adjoining building by radiation  
and convection. If property protection in addition to life safety is a  
consideration, then all buildings should be considered as being of  
equal risk.  
External walls within 1000 mm from a relevant boundary \(as  
defined in Approved Document B\) should be fire resistant from  
both sides \(with the exception of small openings as set out in  
Approved Document B\). Walls more than 1000 mm from a rele-  
vant boundary but within the calculated required space separation  
distance should be fire resistant from the inside or have the open-  
ings protected against fire spread to the boundary.  
If life safety is the only factor, then residential, assembly and  
recreational uses are at greater risk from external fire sources and  
warrant additional safeguards. Such uses in themselves have a  
higher level of compartmentation and the risk from such uses is  
reduced. **Fire safety 11-11**

# 3.21 Roof coverings  
Roof coverings \(not structures\) in close proximity to boundaries  
should have limited flame spread and penetration to fire. Burning  
brands from a fire landing on an adjacent roof should not readily  
cause another fire.  
The recommended standards and limitations for roof cover-  
ings, including those relating to rooflights, are set out in Approved  
Document B Volume 1\: Dwellings, Section 2 and Approved  
Document B Volume 2\: Buildings other than dwellings Section  
14\. The classification relates to the resistance of a roof to exter-  
nal penetration by fire – through the roof construction and the  
spread of flame over the roof surface – in accordance with BS EN  
13501–5 *Fire classification of construction products and building*  
*elements. Classification using data from external fire exposure to*  
*roof tests*.  
Where green roofs are to be used, their composition should fol-  
low the guidance within the document Fire Performance of *Green*  
*Roofs and Walls*, published by the MHCLG, 2013.  
Approved Document B sets out specific classification recom-  
mendations relating to distances from the boundary, see Tables XII  
for dwellings & XIII for non-dwellings. together with recommen-  
dations for plastic rooflights, Figure 11.12.

# 4 MEANS OF ESCAPE  
# 4.1 General  
In general terms, means of escape is the provision of safe routes for  
persons to travel from any point in a building to a place of safety.  
The place of safety is normally outside the building but can, in  
some circumstances, be to a separate compartment.  
# 4.2 Guidance  
There are three main guidance documents for means of escape\:  
• Approved Document B, Volumes 1 and 2  
• BS 9991 for residential buildings – houses, flats, maisonettes and  
other residential blocks  
# Fire safety 11-17  
• BS 9999 – generally applicable to buildings other than those res-  
idential buildings addressed in BS 9991.  
Whatever guidance is adopted, the means of escape must be  
tailored to the individual occupancy and building. Where a project  
is speculative, a judgement must be made as to the necessary pro-  
visions for means of escape. To assume the worst case may not be  
feasible, although it will result in a level of provision acceptable for  
the majority of occupancies.  
# 4.3 Basic principles  
The aim is to make provision such that escape can take place  
unaided. The occupants of some buildings, however, will not be  
able to achieve this and special measures are required.  
Certain basic principles and provisions are accepted as the min-  
imum necessary. These are\:  
• A means of raising the alarm and advising occupants of a fire  
• Exits and escape routes of adequate number and width within a  
reasonable distance of all points in the building  
• An alternative means of escape \(in the majority of cases\)  
• Protected escape routes where necessary  
• Lighting and directional signage  
• Readily openable exit doors  
• Smoke control \(if required\) to safeguard escape routes  
• Separation of high or special risks  
• Access for fire brigade to attack the seat of a fire swiftly for pro-  
tection of life  
• Portable hand fire appliances for use by trained personnel  
• Instruction of action to be taken in the event of a fire and evac-  
uation procedure  
• In all but the simplest of buildings, a management strategy to  
safeguard and maintain these measures.  
# 4.4 Residential  
Recommendations for safe escape from residential accommoda-  
tion may be found in Approved Document B Volume 1, BS 9991  
\(houses, flats and maisonettes\) and BS 9999 together with spe-  
cialist codes for residential care premises in the *Health Technical*  
*Memoranda* issued by the Department for Health.  
Guidance in relation to houses, flats and maisonettes is high-  
lighted in what follows \(Approved Document B and BS 9991\).  
All residential accommodation requires automatic fire and  
smoke detection in accordance with the relevant sections of BS  
5839 Part 1 and BS 5839 Part 6 \(for the common areas\). Detection  
will afford early warning to residents and staff, instigating escape  
in the early stages of a fire when escape routes are relatively free  
of smoke.  
*4.4.1 Single- and two-storey houses*  
• Escape may be via the entrance hall or through suitable escape  
windows from each room.  
• No habitable room should be an inner room \(i.e. a room from  
which escape is possible only through another room which may  
contain the fire\), see Approved Document B Volume 1, para-  
graph 2.11.  
• An escape window should have an unobstructed openable area  
of 0.33 m2 at least 450 mm high and 450 mm wide. The bottom  
of the openable area should be no more than 1100 mm above the  
floor. The window should enable escape to a place free from fire.  
The window should remain in the open position without needing  
to be held open by an escaping person.  
Figures 11.13–11.14 show means of escape from the ground and  
upper levels of a house. Escape from levels a maximum of 4.5 m  
above ground level and inner rooms at ground level can utilise  
escape windows rather than protected escape routes in the circum-  
stances shown in Figure 11.13. **11-18 Fire safety**

*4.4.2 Flats and maisonettes*  
There are some differences between the recommendations of  
Approved Document B and BS 9991 for flats and maisonettes.  
Designers should refer to the full, adopted guidance as it is impos-  
sible to replicate all recommendations and restrictions for the  
various common layouts. The principles within the codes may be  
applied successfully to innovative layouts when supported by spe-  
cialist advice.  
The concept for escape from flats and maisonettes differs from  
that of other uses. It is a stay in place \(also known as defend in  
place\) strategy – initially only the apartment of fire origin evacuates  
and all others stay in place while it is safe to do so. This is based  
on the high standard of compartmentation and separation recom-  
mended in both Approved Document B, B3 *Internal fire spread*  
*\(structure\)* and BS 9991. From within each apartment, the residents  
should be able to escape unaided.  
The use of a stay in place policy has been questioned since the  
Grenfell Tower fire. The 2019 revision of Approved Document B  
retained the concept based on adequate compartmentation.

*4.4.3 Residential containment of fire by compartmentation*  
Each residential unit is a separate fire compartment. This  
should have a minimum of 60 minutes fire resistance but where  
**11.15** *Alternative arrangements for final exits. Source\: from Approved Document B Volume 1 2019, Diagram 2.2*  
**11.16** *Fire separation in houses with two or more storeys more than 4.5 m above ground level. Source\: from Approved Document B*  
*Volume 1 2019, Diagram 2.4* **11-20 Fire safety**  
**11.17** *Ground or basement storey exit into an enclosed space. Source\: from Approved Document B Volume 1 2019, Diagram 2.5*  
compartmentation is coincidental with structural fire resistance,  
a higher standard may be required. The fire should be contained  
within the compartment and it is considered only necessary ini-  
tially to evacuate the unit \(compartment\) on fire. Consequently,  
the necessary width of escape exits and routes may be min-  
imalised. The travel distance, any alternative means of escape  
and the apartment layout dictate the level of internal protection  
necessary, which in turn influences the protection to common  
areas, see Approved Document B Volume 1 Section 3 – Means  
of escape flats.  
The common and ancillary areas in each block are separated  
from the accommodation by 60-minute compartment walls and  
floors. The common areas are provided with a form of smoke  
control to deter smoke from entering the stair and to dissipate  
smoke that enters the common escape route while the occupants  
of the fire apartment escape. Generally, an integral part of the  
smoke control is the automatically openable vent at the top of  
the stair that allows inlet air to support the smoke control within  
the common lobby/corridor and vents any smoke within the stair  
during the escape or firefighting phases. The flow of smoke into  
the corridor/lobby will stop or be minimised when the apart-  
ment entrance door \(self-closing\) closes after the occupants have  
escaped the fire apartment.  
The common stair should not connect with a basement car park  
and only connect with a covered car park at ground level and above  
if the car park has natural smoke vents or is mechanically venti-  
lated and is separated by a protected ventilated lobby. The stair  
should not serve ancillary accommodation unless it is separated by  
a protected lobby or corridor provided with a 0.4 m2 smoke vent or  
mechanical smoke extract.  
The stair should have either\:  
• A high level openable vent at each floor level within the stair  
\(1.0 m2 minimum free area\) or  
• A single openable vent \(1.0 m2 minimum free area\) that can be  
remotely operated from the Fire Service access level, should be  
provided at the head of the stair or  
• An automatic opening vent \(1.0 m2 minimum free area\) should  
be provided at the head of the stair.  
Detailed guidance on smoke control to common areas in apartments  
can be found in the Smoke Control Association *Guidance on smoke*  
*control to common escape routes in apartment buildings \(flats and*  
*maisonettes\)* Revision 3.1\: July 13, 2020, available to download  
from the Smoke Control Association website at www.feta.co.uk/  
associations/hevac/specialist-groups/smoke-control-association.  
# 4.5 Non-residential uses  
Guidance can be found in both Approved Document B Volume 2  
and BS 9999.  
Generally, BS 9999 addresses all such uses other than hospitals,  
schools and certain licensed premises but is a good source of gen-  
eral information.  
For hospitals – refer to the Technical Health Memoranda issued  
by the Department for Health.  
For schools – refer to Building Bulletin 100 \(BB100 Revised\)  
issued by the Department for Education.  
*4.5.1 Number of exits and escape routes*  
In order to determine the number of exits from a room or storey,  
their occupancy must be established. This may be known, or it can  
be assessed by the use of recognised space factors for specific uses.  
These are only indicators and can be varied. These numbers will also  
affect the width of escape routes. In existing buildings, the width of  
doors, stairways, passages, etc., if not to be altered, will dictate the  
numbers of people that can be accommodated, see Table XIV.  
*4.5.2 Occupancy*  
Once the occupancy factor for an area is known, the number of  
exits must equate to the necessary total width of escape required,  
although a minimum number of exits is specified within Approved  
Document B and BS 9999. Not less than two exits should be pro-  
vided, except in the case of an occupancy of less than 60, or a  
limited travel distance \(‘dead-end’\).  
*4.5.3 Capacities*  
The capacities of exits are given in tables within both Approved  
Document B Volume 2 and BS 9999. While not all exits need be of  
equal width, they should be evenly distributed to provide alterna-  
tives. Where there are two or more exits, it is assumed that fire may  
affect one of them, therefore the largest exit should be discounted.  
Hence the total number of exits = calculated number + 1.  
*4.5.4 Travel distances*  
The number of exits may result from compliance with the recom-  
mended travel distances, that is, the actual distance to be travelled to  
the nearest exit, having regard to obstructions such as partitions. The  
distances are not sacrosanct, but should be shorter rather than longer.  
Extension of travel distances may be justified where compensatory  
factors such as smoke control systems or early warning of fire are pro-  
vided. Only one exit need be within the travel distance; alternatives  
may be at any distance. BS 9999 allows extension of travel distances  
subject to certain conditions – see Section 3.8 in this chapter. **Fire safety 11-21**

*4.5.5 Alternative means of escape*  
A person should be able in most circumstances to turn their back  
on a fire and walk to an alternative exit. If escape is in one direction  
only, an exit or alternative escape route should be near enough for  
people to reach it before being affected by heat and smoke.  
For escape routes or exits to be ‘alternative’ they must be  
separated from each other by direction, space or fire-resisting con-  
struction. If one exit is affected by fire, the other\(s\) should not. See  
Figure 11.18.  
The Scottish Building Standards recommend that the angle of  
divergence should be not less than 45° plus 2 1/2° for every metre  
travelled in one direction.  
*4.5.7 Measuring width*  
There are several important widths\:  
• Door opening – the clear width, see Figure 11.19  
• Stair width – the clear width between the walls or balustrades or  
wall and balustrade. Handrails and strings that project into this  
width by no more than 100 mm may be ignored  
• Escape route width – the width at 1500 mm above floor level  
between any fixed obstructions. Handrails and strings that pro-  
ject into this width by no more than 100 mm may be ignored.  
*4.5.6 Width of escape routes and exits*  
An escape route should be as wide or wider than an exit leading to  
it, and should be of uniform width. The width of a final exit should  
equate to the route or routes it serves. This may comprise the total  
The safe and rapid use of a stair is dependent on all persons  
being within reach of a handrail, therefore no staircase should  
exceed 1.4 m in width unless additional central handrails are  
provided.

*4.5.8 Merging flows at a ground floor final exit*  
A final exit from a ground floor to outside a building may need  
to accommodate people from the ground floor and a stair – the  
flows of people will merge into the final exit, which must be of  
adequate width to the flow from the storey exit and stair combined,  
Figure 11.20\. See Approved Document B 2019 Volume 2 para-

*4.5.9 Evacuation protocol*  
The capacity and therefore the width of a stair differ from that of a  
horizontal escape route as they are influenced by the rate of descent  
and the standing position on the stairs. The width necessary is also  
influenced by the type of evacuation – total or phased – the stair having  
to accommodate only the population of a phase in the latter instance.  
TOTAL EVACUATION  
On the raising of the alarm the total population moves to evacuate  
the whole of the building in a single phase.  
STAGED/PHASED EVACUATION  
On the discovery of a fire the alarm is given in the following manner.  
The fire floor and the floor above are given the signal to evacuate  
immediately; all other floors are given the alert signal to stand by to  
evacuate. If the fire is extinguished, no further evacuation is neces-  
sary; if not, the next two floors immediately above the initial phase  
are evacuated; and so progressively in separate phases of two floors  
up the building to the top. Evacuation then proceeds down the build-  
ing, starting with the floors nearest the fire, until it is complete or the  
fire extinguished. As the population of only two floors are evacuated  
at a time, the stair width dimensions can be decreased.  
ADDITIONAL MEASURES FOR PHASED EVACUATION  
As people remain in the building during the fire, phased evacuation  
can take place only if additional protective measures are incorporated\:  
• All floors constructed as compartment floors with openings  
through them protected to maintain compartmentation  
• All stairs protected by lobbies or corridors of fire-resisting con-  
struction, except on a top storey  
• All lifts approached through a protected lobby  
• A fire alarm system \(conforming to at least an L3 standard in  
accordance with BS 5839–1\) incorporating a personal address/  
communication system operated from a central control point  
from where a fire warden can be instructed from a control point  
at the Fire Rescue Service access level and orderly evacuation  
directed  
• An automatic sprinkler installation throughout a building with a  
floor exceeding 30 m above ground level.  
Phased evacuation is not generally accepted for any basements,  
assembly, hotel, recreational and similar buildings, and, to date,  
the majority of shops. However, in the case of mixed user and large  
complexes, total evacuation may not be necessary or prudent and  
enforcing authorities should be consulted at an early stage.  
Phased evacuation for buildings exceeding 30.0 m in height should  
be agreed with the Fire Rescue Service at the design stage as evacuation  
may impede fire fighters entering and operating within the building.  
*4.5.10 Stairs*  
Where two or more stairs are provided, it is reasonable to assume  
that one will not be available for use due to fire or smoke unless  
a sufficiently high degree of protection is afforded. If a stair is  
approached through a lobby, or protected by a pressure differential  
smoke control system, it can be assumed that it will be available.  
Where such protection is not provided, a stair should be dis-  
counted \(number of stairs required = calculated number plus 1\).  
Each stair should be discounted in turn, to ensure that the capacity  
of the remaining stairs in total is adequate, see Tables XV–XVII.  
As an alternative to using Table XVII, the capacity of stairs  
1100 mm or wider \(for simultaneous evacuation\) can be derived  
from the formula that follows as set out in Approved Document B,  
Volume 2, 3.18 along with worked examples.  
• P = 200 W + 50\(W − 0.3\)\(N − 1\), or  
•  
where\:  
P is the number of people that can be served; W is the width of  
the stair, in metres; and N is the number of storeys served.  
Note 1\: Stairs with a rise of more than 30 m should not be wider  
than 1400 mm unless provided with a central handrail \(see par-  
agraph 4.15\).  
Note 2\: Separate calculations should be made for stairs/flights  
serving basement storeys and those serving upper storeys.  
Note 3\: The population ‘P’ should be divided by the number of  
available stairs.  
Note 4\: The formula is particularly useful when determining the  
width of stairs serving a building \(or part of a building\) where  
the occupants are not distributed evenly – either within a storey  
or between storeys. Note 5\: In the formula, the first part \(200 w\) represents the number  
of persons estimated to have left the stair after 2.5 minutes of evac-  
uation. The second part \[50\(w − 0.3\)\(n − 1\)\] represents the number  
of persons estimated to be accommodated on the stair after this time.  
*4.5.11 Stair design*  
Stair design should accord with Approved Document K or BS  
5395, *Stairs, ladders and walkways*. Where phased evacuation is  
envisaged, the minimum widths in Table XVIII may be adopted.  
For small premises see Approved Document B Volume 2  
Section 4. Small buildings occupied by a limited number of persons  
and satisfying the criteria for use, travel distance and a single exit  
can have a single stairway, see Figures 11.21–11.23.

*4.5.12 Varying population*  
The recommended widths assume a uniform distribution of pop-  
ulation. If any floor within a building has a higher population, for  
example, a conference room or restaurant, any extra or wider stairs  
necessary to accommodate the increased population should extend  
down to final exit level.  
*4.5.13 Independent escape for different/mixed uses*  
Separate stairs should be provided for use by residential or assem-  
bly occupancies independent of any other use. Where a totally  
independent escape can be provided from these higher risk uses,  
for example, using an access deck or walkway, it is reasonable that  
some stairs may be shared.  
*4.5.14 External stairs*  
The use of external stairs should be avoided if possible, due to  
the psychological effect of using unfamiliar external stairs at  
high levels and the effects of bad weather. The width and design  
of external stairs is the same as for internal ones. External stairs  
are not considered suitable for use by the general public in an  
assembly or recreational use, nor for hospital, institutional or  
similar uses except for office or residential staff accommodation.  
They should only be used where there is at least one internal  
escape stair.  
Where used, external stairs should be protected in accordance  
with Figure 11.24. **11-26 Fire safety**

ENCLOSURE OF ESCAPE ROUTES  
Escape routes do not necessarily have to be enclosed. In some  
situations, this would create great problems – open-plan offices,  
exhibition halls, warehouses and factories.  
Where a corridor is not fire protected but is enclosed by parti-  
tions, such partitions should extend to a structural floor above or  
a suspended ceiling and doors should be provided in the corridor  
# Fire safety 11-27  
openings. This is to deter smoke from spreading during the early  
stages of a fire when escape is taking place.  
DEAD-END CORRIDORS  
Where a corridor dead-end situation exists, the escape route must  
be protected against fire, heat and smoke by fire-resisting construc-  
tion, as it may be necessary to pass the room on fire to reach the  
exit. See Figure 11.25.

against the ingress of smoke. To be effective, the construction  
should be from structural floor to structural floor or an imperforate

suspended ceiling. The corridors should also be subdivided by  
cross-corridor doors to inhibit the progress of smoke. These doors  
do not necessarily require fire resistance. Their purpose is to make  
it possible to take an alternative means of escape, not to subdivide  
the corridor at given intervals. Corridors exceeding 12 m should  
be subdivided \(not subdivided at 12 m intervals\) See Approved  
Document B Volume 2 paragraph 2.5 and Diagram 2.9.  
# 4.6 Lighting of escape routes  
General \(primary\) artificial lighting should be provided for persons  
to move about a building effectively and safely.  
Emergency \(escape\) lighting should be provided in those areas  
necessary for escape purposes in case the artificial lighting fails. It may  
be a maintained system \(continuously illuminated in conjunction with  
the general lighting\) or be non-maintained, only coming into operation  
on the failure of the general lighting. Maintained systems are usually  
provided in areas with large numbers of the public unfamiliar with  
their surroundings, and where darkened situations may be common.  
Escape lighting designed and installed in accordance with BS  
5266–1 should be as per Table XIX.

# 4.7 Signs  
*The Health and Safety \(Safety Signs and Signals\) Regulations 1996*  
sets out the requirements for safety signs at a place of work; this  
includes fire safety signs. Guidance on such requirements can be  
found in the Health and Safety Executive Document *Safety signs*  
*and signals. The Health and Safety \(Safety Signs and Signals\)*  
*Guidance on Regulations* at the HSE website.  
Signs are required to indicate the way to exits, and the exits them-  
selves, fire doors \(other than to and within flats/maisonettes\), fire  
alarm call points, portable firefighting equipment and the floor level  
and residential unit number required to assist firefighters. Preferred  
colours, sizes, typeface and graphics are set out in BS 5499. The  
criterion is that signs should be distinguishable against their back-  
ground and surroundings and be of a size that can be read at the  
required distance. If the use of the building warrants it, the signs may  
have to be in more than one language. In public assembly areas, signs  
are usually internally illuminated; elsewhere it is normally sufficient  
for escape lights to be positioned so as to illuminate a sign.  
# 4.8 Fastenings  
Fastenings on exit doors should allow exit without the use of a key  
or other device. Unless careful consideration is given to fastenings,  
security may be undermined. The degree of security required will  
depend on the use of the building and user requirements. Access  
into a building is not required for escape purposes\: re-entry into a  
floor area is neither necessary nor desirable. Fastenings that prevent  
a person entering a floor area from a staircase are acceptable. This is  
often a necessity to prevent theft in offices, factories and hotels and  
the like. The use of electronic fastenings and the use of card systems  
or similar to gain entry are acceptable provided that on the raising of  
the fire alarm or failure of the electrical system all locks ‘fail-safe’ in  
the unlocked position. An override facility to open a secured door is  
also normally required. Guidance can be found in BS 7273–4 *Code*  
*of practice for the operation of fire protection measures – part 4*  
*Actuation of release mechanisms for doors*. However, consideration  
should also be given to the possibility of criminals setting off a false  
fire alarm in order to circumvent security arrangements.  
Consideration should be given to the ability of the Fire Service  
to quickly access a building with residential accommodation that  
has no full time management presence to facilitate access into the  
building. Delay in gaining access for rescue purposes will be life  
threatening.  
Panic bolts and latches are most suitable where there are large  
numbers of persons. Turnbuckle locks with lever handles are com-  
monly used where no public is involved. These may not be suitable  
in some institutional buildings, or places used predominantly by  
the elderly or disabled who may find a small turnbuckle difficult  
to operate. Appropriate door ironmongery should be fitted in these  
circumstances.  
Guidance onhardware for fire and escape doors is published  
by the Door and Hardware Federation and Guild of Architectural  
Ironmongers at www.firecode.org.uk.  
# 4.9 Smoke control  
If a smoke control system is for life safety purposes, it is essential  
that its initiation is automatic on the detection of smoke; and if  
mechanical, that it remains operational at all times by the use of  
duplicate equipment and secondary power supplies etc. Specialist  
advice should be sought regarding the type, design and installation  
of a life safety system.  
Guidance on smoke control measures can be found in BS  
9999\:2017.  
The measures required to protect a means of escape from the  
effects of smoke will depend on the escape protocol adopted.  
Where escape is over a reasonable travel distance, the enclosure  
of the routes by partitions constructed to resist smoke, that is, to  
maintain their integrity, should be adequate. Some smoke will enter  
escape routes, but should not reach a level to make their use unten-  
able in the time it takes to reach an exit.  
As described earlier, the addition of lobbies will retard the  
entry of smoke. Ventilating the lobbies will further dilute the  
smoke and hopefully direct it away from the escape route. It is  
also possible to protect escape routes from the ingress of smoke  
by the use of pressure differentials to retard the movement of  
smoke whereby fans, ducts and vents are used to create different  
pressures between the fire and protected area. Specialist advice  
should be sought.  
# 4.10 Mechanical environmental ventilation  
These systems should not adversely affect a means of escape by perfo-  
ration of enclosures \(fire resistant or not\) without adequate protection,  
or by directing smoke into escape routes. Systems should have regard  
to BS 9999\:2017 \(Clauses 15.9 and 32.5\); Approved Document B  
Volume 1 Dwellings \(paragraph 9.6\) and Approved Document B  
Volume 2 Buildings other than dwellings \(paragraph 10.6\).  
# 4.11 Ancillary accommodation  
Ancillary accommodation \(see Table XVIII\) can present a risk  
to escape routes and evacuation and should be enclosed by a  
minimum of 30-minute fire-resisting construction. Such accommo-  
dation includes\:  
• Chemical stores  
• Cleaners stores  
• Bulk clothes storage  
• Day rooms in residential care premises \(including sheltered  
housing\)  
• Smoking rooms  
• Refuse stores  
• Plant rooms  
• Linen stores  
• Laundry rooms  
• Commercial kitchens  
• Kitchens in non-residential accommodation \(not necessarily tea  
making areas\)  
• Staff changing and locker rooms  
• Store rooms.  
# 4.12 Escape for people who find stairs a barrier or with

a building and its facilities regardless of people’s age, gender or

escape. While some references to escape can be found in BS 8300 *Design of buildings and their approaches to meet the needs of dis- abled people. # 5 FIRE STOPPING, FIRE BARRIERS AND CAVITY  
# BARRIERS  
# 5.1 Definitions  
The unseen spread of fire and smoke can undermine fire safety by  
bypassing lines of fire resistance and smoke control. Notes\:  
1 Any metal \(such as cast iron, copper or steel\) which, if exposed to a temperature of  
800°C, will not soften or fracture to the extent that flame or hot gas will pass through  
the wall of the pipe.  
2 uPVC pipes that comply with either **BS 4514** or **BS 5255**.  
Source\: from Approved Document B 2019 Volume 2, Table 10.1  
**11.26** *Pipes penetrating structure. Source\: from Approved Document B 2019 Volume 2, Diagram 10.1* **11-30 Fire safety**  
# 5.3 Fire barriers/protection of openings  
• The protection of an opening in a fire separating element  
• Fire doors and fire dampers to protect designed openings  
• A fire barrier /seal.  
Fire doors and shutters/curtains can be used to protect openings  
in lines of fire resistance/compartmentation. Generally shutters/  
curtains operated automatically be smoke detection should not be  
used across escape routes. See Approved Document B Volume 2  
Appendix C *fire door sets*.  
Ventilation ducts can be protected by\:  
• Fire dampers  
• Fire-resisting enclosures  
• The use of fire-resisting ductwork.  
Fire dampers should not be used within kitchen extract systems as  
grease and dirt will readily accumulate and present a fire risk. For  
further advice, see Section 10 of Approved Document B Volume 2  
and Clause 32.5 of BS 9999.  
Fire barriers/seals used to maintain lines of compartmentation  
should have the same fire resistance as the compartment line.  
# 5.4 Cavity barriers  
Cavity barriers are necessary to subdivide cavities/spaces and their  
edges that would form an unseen path for the spread of fire and  
smoke, Figure 11.27.  
Compartment walls should extend between floors. It is not  
acceptable to use a cavity barrier to complete a line of compart-  
mentation, for example, within a roof or false ceiling.  
**11.27** *Provisions for cavity barriers. Source\: from Approved Document B, Volume 2, Diagram 9.1* **Fire safety 11-31**  
**11.28** *Fire-resisting ceiling below cavity. Source\: from Approved Document B, Volume 2, Diagram 9.3*  
Lines of fire-resisting construction protecting escape routes  
should be extended between floors wherever possible but otherwise  
provided with cavity barriers on the line of the protected route or  
the partitions should extend to a fire-resisting ceiling, Figure 11.28.  
The extent of undivided cavities is set out in Approved  
Document B Volume 2 paragraph 9.9 and Table 9.1 and Section 33  
of BS 9999. See also Table XXI.

# 6 FIRE SAFETY MANAGEMENT  
# 6.1 Requirements  
Fire safety management includes fire prevention and the mainte-  
nance of fire safety facilities. The understanding and maintenance  
of all fire safety measures is essential, particularly in a large or  
complex building; therefore, the occupier/management should have  
a full understanding of the safety measures incorporated into the  
design of the building. This means that the designer must supply all  
relevant information in a fire safety manual. Details of the matters  
that should be included in the manual can be found in Section 19  
*Fire safety information* of Approved Document B Volume 2, which  
also addresses the requirement of Regulation 38 of the Building  
Regulations 2010 as amended. Extensive guidance on fire safety  
management and a fire manual is also given in BS 9999.  
# 6.2 Regulation 38  
Regulation 38 of the Building Regulations states\:  
• The person carrying out the work shall give fire safety infor-  
mation to the responsible person not later than the date of  
completion of the work, or the date of occupation . . . whichever  
is earlier.  
Regulation 38 requires the person carrying out the fire safety works  
to pass all relevant fire safety information to the person designated  
# 7 MATERIALS AND STRUCTURE  
# 7.1 General  
The materials forming a building should be chosen having regard  
to the safety of the structure and occupants. The adequacy of their  
resistance, or their ability to sustain load for any particular period  
when subjected to fire, may necessitate their protection to prevent  
the premature failure of the structure by collapse, or failure of load-  
bearing capacity. Additional resistance may be achieved by the use  
of protective coverings, casings or membranes.  
# 7.2 Form of construction  
Fire resistance relates to the form of construction rather than the  
material, and is stated in terms of performance in relation to British  
Standards methods of test or European classification of test results.  
These tests include/relate to\:  
• Loadbearing capacity \(resistance to collapse\)  
• Integrity \(resistance to fire penetration\)  
• Insulation \(resistance to transfer of excessive heat\).  
This is expressed as REI in the relevant European standards\:  
R – loadbearing capacity  
E – integrity  
I – insulation  
# 7.3 Loadbearing capacity/fire resistance  
For detailed information, refer to *Appendix B\: Performance of*  
*materials, products and* structures of Approved Document B  
Volumes 1 and 2. **11-32 Fire safety**  
It should be noted that the 2019 edition of Approved Document  
B uses the European classification for fire resistance as set out in BS  
EN 13501–2 to 4, adding that there may be some products lawfully  
on the market using the classification system set out in previous  
editions, In such situations, the equivalent classification given in  
Table B1 of Approved Document B Volumes 1 and 2 may be used.  
Consideration can be given to the use of products or systems  
having an Agrément Certificate issued by the British Board of  
Agrément or a product complying with a European Technical  
Approval \(refer to the EEC Construction Products Directive\).  
In considering the use of a system or component that has a cer-  
tificate attesting conformity, all aspects of the certificate should be  
taken into consideration and attention paid to any caveats relat-  
ing to its use in particular circumstances or other limitation taken  
into consideration. Such a caveat may render the system/compo-  
nent unacceptable in certain circumstances. The limitation may  
be embedded in the circumstances of the original test data, which  
should be obtained and scrutinised.  
# 7.4 CE marking  
The CE marking of components covered by European Technical  
standards was mandatory until December 31, 2020. Refer to *Using*  
*the UKCA mark from January 1, 2021*, which advises UK marking  
will apply to most goods subject to the CE marking. CE marking  
can be used until January 1, 2022 in most cases.  
# 7.5 Suitability  
Regard should be given to the suitability of materials adopted, the  
ease of acquiring the required fire protection, ease of construction  
and durability. Although the last is not required under the Building  
Regulations, a material should be ‘fit for the purpose’ – Building  
Regulation 7 as amended. There are several terms used in Approved  
Document B issued in support of the Building Regulations specifi-  
cally relevant to materials and their choice.  
# 7.6 Surface spread of flame  
Restriction of the spread of flame across the surface of a material  
is an important factor of fire safety, as it affects fire growth and  
spread, and means of escape. The term is used in the 2019 edi-  
tion of Approved Document B Volumes 1 and 2, particularly in  
relation to both means of escape B1, and external fire spread B4,  
by reference to fire performance as classified in BS EN 13501  
\(parts as appropriate\) adding that there may be some products  
lawfully on the market using the classification system set out in  
previous editions, and in such situations the equivalent classifi-  
cation given in Table B1 of Approved Document B Volumes 1  
and 2 may be used.  
It should be noted that neither *surface spread of flame* or *class*  
*0* are defined in Approved Document B 2019. See Approved  
Document B 2019 edition Appendix B National Classifications for  
reaction to fire paragraph B10 and Table B1 plus footnotes.  
Materials chosen for low spread of flame properties may later  
be compromised by inappropriate maintenance/decorative finishes.  
Guidance also recommends restrictions on the use of thermo-  
plastic materials used for glazing \(windows and internal\), rooflights  
and lighting diffusers, and suspended or stretched skin membranes.  
Reference should be made to Approved Document B 2019 edition,  
and/or BS 9999.  
# 7.7 Steel  
Exposed steel can lose strength very quickly when exposed to fire,  
buckling and collapsing in as little as 10 to 15 minutes. The actual  
temperature at which it starts to lose strength depends on the type  
of steel, whether it is in tension or compression, and its restraint  
if any. Encasing the steel insulates it against temperature rise.  
Protection can be in the form of concrete, fire-retardant boards,  
fibrous sprayed or intumescent coatings, or suspended ceilings.  
Water cooling has been used to protect columns.  
A useful reference is the ASFP Yellow Book\: Fire protection  
for structural steel in buildings, 5th Edition, \(Volume 1 of 2\),  
# 7.8 Aluminium  
Some forms fail structurally at quite low temperatures, but it has  
good properties for low flame spread.  
# 7.9 Concrete  
This loses its crushing strength in fire. The heat of the fire also  
affects the strength of steel reinforcement. Adequate concrete cover  
is essential and may require the addition of mesh reinforcement to  
restrict spalling; this is caused by the reinforcement expanding with  
heating.  
# 7.10 Clay masonry, brickwork  
As a form of ceramic, clay performs well at high temperatures  
albeit some expansion may take place. Any steel in clay can expand  
causing failure and should be protected.  
# 7.11 Timber  
This performs better than steel in a fire. It is a low conductor of  
heat; it progressively chars, protecting itself with a charcoal layer.  
The charring rate can be assessed and the ability of the residual tim-  
ber to sustain the required loads calculated. See BS EN 1995–1–1  
*Eurocode 5 and the UK National Annex to Eurocode 5 Design of*  
*timber structures Part 1–2 general – structural fire design*.  
Timber studwork with plasterboard can easily achieve 30 min-  
utes’ fire resistance; 60 minutes with additional protection. Existing  
timber floors can be upgraded to improve their fire resistance by the  
addition of soffit protection and insulation – see BRE Digest 208,  
*Increasing the fire resistance of existing timber floors*.  
# 7.12 Asbestos  
This is no longer used for health reasons. It may be found as fire  
protection in existing buildings.  
A useful reference is the Health and Safety Executive website  
\(hse.gov.uk\) for information relating to the retention or removal of  
asbestos, which may require a licence.  
# 7.13 Protective boards \(plasterboard, mineral fibre  
# boards, cementitious\)  
These are used to protect structural members and form fire-resist-  
ing enclosures on suitable frames. Some forms of construction and  
systems can achieve in excess of two hours’ fire resistance when  
constructed correctly. Construction systems used should be tested  
\(have been tested\) to indicate the required fire performance can  
be achieved. Boards should be used in accordance with the tested  
specification for the appropriate level of fire resistance.  
Service penetrations through boards should be installed in  
accordance with the fire tested specification.  
# 7.14 Glass  
Plain glass \(depending on whether it is toughened or laminated\)  
offers negligible fire resistance. Wired glass can achieve a 60 min-  
utes standard of fire resistance in terms of integrity but with little  
insulation, although this is not generally used as it is dangerous if  
broken – the exposed wires presenting an additional risk.  
Insulating fire-resisting glazing can achieve in excess of two  
hours; the size of glazing panels may be restricted.  
Fire-resisting glass, whether providing insulation or not, should  
be used only in accordance with tested assembly specifications.  
A useful reference is *A guide to best practice in the specification*  
*and use of fire – resistant glazed systems* published by the Glass  
and Glazing Federation.  
# 7.15 Plastics  
Thermosetting plastics harden when heated, and thermoplastics  
soften on heating. Plastics often fall from their supports, making an assessment of  
their action in fire difficult under test conditions. The material may  
not burn, but can drip flaming droplets and spread fire.  
See Approved Document B regarding the acceptable use of  
thermoplastic materials for ceilings, rooflights and lighting diffus-  
ers, and plastics used for insulation in external and internal walls.  
# 7.16 Doors and shutters  
These can be wooden, glass, metal or composite, see Table XXII.  
Some can achieve a fire resistance in excess of four hours.  
# Fire safety 11-33  
Doors and shutters are tested as an assembly and should be pur-  
chased and installed as such. Fire shutters/curtains are generally  
held open and close on the actuation of a fusible link, or automat-  
ically following detection of heat or smoke. Doors are designated  
according to their performance in minutes in terms of their integ-  
rity. Doors forming part of a protected enclosure \(stair, lobby or  
corridor\) for means of escape should have not less than a 30-minute  
standard of fire resistance. Additionally, these doors should be able  
to resist the passage of smoke at ambient temperatures; these are  
generally denoted by the suffix ‘S’, that is, FD30s.
