# 3.19 Sightlines across lateral gangways  
Lateral gangways can be problematic because of how they interrupt  
the continuous line of the auditorium rake. With lateral gangways,  
the line of the auditorium rake must continue so that the audience  
can see the performance area over the gangway as if part of a con-  
tinuous sightline gradient. Stepped rows require a handrail to the  
upper side of the gangway and, if a steep rake, a handrail to the  
lower side; see Figure 15.11.  
# 3.20 The view between heads  
If a balcony or balconies are introduced, the rake of the lower bank  
of seats can be reduced, assuming vision to be every other row  
allowing for point P being seen between heads in the row in front.  
To reduce the degree of rake in the stalls seating, the vertical dis-  
tance between eye point to top of head \(TH\) can be reduced to  
65 mm for calculation purposes if seats are staggered.  
When working with between-heads sightline criteria, it should  
be on the basis that the seating is staggered. This is normally calcu-  
lated on the centre line, but as rows extend sideways, particularly  
with curved rows, seats will invariably coincide partially blocking  
the between view. However, seats located towards the sides of the  
auditorium tend to have a more diagonal view of the stage, which  
can alleviate this condition.  
The view between heads is particularly applicable with the  
design of a large auditorium where the aim is to maximise the seat-  
ing capacity within the visual and aural limitations. This implies a  
balance between sightlines, height of the auditorium and seating  
capacity. Reducing the height of the lower level of seating in the  
auditorium allows more space to accommodate upper balconies.  
Refining the sightlines in this manner illustrates the balancing of  
requirements necessary in the development of larger auditoria.  
# 3.21 Upper tiers or balconies  
The principles for establishing sightlines in the upper seating levels  
are fundamentally the same as for the stalls. Allied to the vertical  
downward sightline is the upper sightline, particularly in prosce-  
nium-framed auditoria where upward sightlines from rear rows of  
seats in stalls and balconies have an uninterrupted view of the top  
of the proscenium.  
*Point of sight \(P2\)*  
As with point ‘P’, point ‘P2’ is the lowest and nearest point that an  
audience member seated in the balcony needs to be able to see. This  
can be the same as for the stalls position, but it can also be different  
from the stalls, such as for a forestage extension or a view of the  
conductor in an orchestra pit.  
*Depth of the stage \(DP\)*  
This is the working depth of the stage or acting area.  
*Highest point visible at the back of the stage \(HP\)*  
This is the clear visible height at the back of the stage or performing  
area. It is important for the audience to not only be able to see the  
backdrop, but where for example a set design may have an upper  
tier or balcony, a raised choir or backing musicians on the stage or  
even aerial props, devices or flown performers.  
*Proscenium height \(PH\)*  
This is the height of the proscenium opening or the upper defined  
limit of an open stage, such as the underside of a lighting bridge,  
lighting bar or pelmet. The panel above the proscenium opening  
may be used to provide subtitles during a performance.  
*Balcony front height \(BF\)*  
For the benefit of the calculation, the balcony may be assumed to  
be 790 mm while recognising that this will need to be at 1100 mm  
for raised rails at the end of aisles. The design of the balcony front  
is a critical item as the shape and form of the balcony riser and top  
rail can impede downward views if its impact on sightlines is not  
considered, particularly from oblique or side views.  
*Distance to front row \(D\)*  
In this case, this is the distance from the front row of the balcony  
to point ‘P2’.  
# 3.22 Horizontal sightlines  
Horizontal sightlines are relevant to proscenium and end stage  
auditoria spaces particularly for dance, where a frontal view of the  
whole stage area is critical. They are also relevant to platforms for  
classical music where acoustic considerations may also apply.  
A frontal viewpoint is also important for film, video and slide  
projection.  
Given a particular stage, platform or performance area defined  
by the proscenium opening, horizontal sightline constraints limit  
the width of the seating area in the auditorium. The view of the  
proscenium opening cannot be too oblique otherwise audience  
members will not be able to see much of the stage area masked by  
the proscenium frame.  
**15.11** *Sightlines at transverse gangway; the angle of the rake line is constant* **3.23 Side seats**  
Side seats can create a more engaging and cohesive ambiance in a  
multi-tiered auditorium and have the benefit of bringing audience  
members closer to the action on the stage or platform, but they can  
also be problematic requiring careful consideration. The amount of  
side seating needs to be balanced as part of the overall provision.  
Where the seat is focused away from the platform or stage, such  
as with side galleries requiring the head to be turned sideways, it  
is debatable how far it remains comfortable for extended periods.  
Without head movement, the arc to view the whole platform or  
stage on plan is 40° from the eye; see Figure 15.12.  
Turning the seat to face towards the stage or platform is some-  
times a solution, but this can take more space while the diagonal  
sightline is extended; see Figure 15.13a–b.  
The horizontal sightline of the performer may also need consid-  
eration; see Figure 15.14.

**15.13a** *The maximum comfortable amount the head can be turned*  
*from the seat centreline is 30°*  
**15.13b** *If the head angle were to exceed 30°, the seats may be*  
*angled within the row*  
# Auditoria 15-9  
**15.14** *Horizontal sightlines of the performer \(also referred to as*  
*‘point of command of performer’, the range of audience an actor*  
*can take in from a single vantage point\)*  
# 3.24 Wheelchair locations  
Locating wheelchair user positions seamlessly and effectively  
into an auditorium landscape can present a key challenge in  
the design of auditoria spaces while taking account of all other  
auditorium design considerations. Positions of wheelchair users  
should therefore be considered at the outset and not added as an  
afterthought, with wheelchair spaces provided in various parts  
of the auditorium to allow different vantage points. Care is  
needed in the design and location of wheelchair spaces so that  
all visitors can enjoy the ambiance of the event. A designated  
wheelchair area in a lecture theatre is shown in Figure 15.15 and  
possible locations of wheelchair spaces in front of a rear aisle in  
Figure 15.16.  
Wheelchair users and those with sensory or mobility impair-  
ment may need to view or listen from a particular side or sit  
in the front for lip reading or to read sign interpreters. Some  
people have difficulties looking up or down or from one side  
or another, so choice of positions is as important as choice in  
response to ticket price. They should be provided with spaces  
into which they can manoeuvre easily and which will offer a  
clear view of an event, while also ensuring they are not segre-  
gated into detached areas.  
A wheelchair user should be able to sit with a party of friends  
not in wheelchairs, or with friends also using wheelchairs. The  
location of wheelchair users as discrete areas can be at the rear,  
front, side or within the body of the seating.  
Wheelchair users and people who have difficulty in using seats  
with fixed arms as well as those with assistance dogs should also  
have the choice of sitting next to conventionally seated person  
or a companion wheelchair user. Consideration should also be  
given to providing an area next to certain seats for an assistance  
dog to rest.  
By having some removable seating at the front and at the back  
of blocks of seats, greater flexibility in location can be achieved  
and a greater number of wheelchair users than the minimum provi-  
sion shown in Document M of the Building Regulations.  
Greater spacing between rows of seats or at the end of rows  
may provide extra legroom for people of large stature. With several  
seats removed, these locations may also be suitable for wheelchair  
users.  
All users of the auditorium should be able to move safely and  
easily to and from seating areas to ancillary facilities, such as  
WCs.  
When it comes to building accessibility guidelines, there are  
two main standards that should be worked to – Document M \(Part  
M Vol 2 of the Building Regulations, Approved Document M1  
Section 4 – Access and use of buildings other than dwellings\) and  
BS 8300 \(BS 8300–2\: 2018 \(Part 2\: Buildings – Code of Practice\)  
*Designing of an Accessible and Inclusive Built Environment*\).  
The ABTT Technical Standards for Places of Entertainment  
makes a clear distinction between conference or lecture theatre  
auditoria and ‘theatrical’ entertainment auditoria. In facilities for  
entertainment, such as theatres, it is normal for seating to be more  
closely packed than in other types of spectator facilities.  
There is currently a divergence in the standards set by Approved  
Document Part M and BS 8300–2, which sets out a higher stand-  
ard for auditoria spaces, such as lecture theatres and conference  
centres. The BS 8300 standards were developed by the British **15-10 Auditoria**  
**15.15** *Wheelchair spaces in a lecture theatre \(from Part M\)*  
Standards Institute \(BSI\) and defines the best practices for design-  
ing accessible and inclusive environments, whereas Document M  
applies only to England and is a legal requirement. The updated BS  
8300 standards are focused on maximising inclusivity and strive to  
incorporate accessible design into mainstream design, rather than  
having specific features and facilities designated as ‘accessible’. In  
Scotland, BS 8300–2 is set out as the reference standard, but is not  
mandatory.  
The ABTT Technical Standard states that the recommenda-  
tions given in BS 8300–2 are unlikely to be suitable for closely  
seated, managed auditoria as found in places of entertainment. The  
ABTT’s guidance is focused on meeting the legal requirements  
for theatres or places of entertainment in England as stated in  
Approved Document Part M but refers to the aspirations set out in  
BS 8300–2 for lecture theatre and conference auditoria.  
Regulations require a minimum of six places for wheelchair  
users, or 1/100th of the audience capacity, whichever is the greater.  
Tables IV and V set out the standards expected by both authorities.

• The provision of wheelchair spaces in audience seating should

The same layout principles apply in BS 8300–2, but increase

Sightlines of wheelchair users should be checked, as there  
can be some variation in eye height and type of wheelchair used.  
See also Chapter 4, Inclusive and accessible design The sight-  
lines of audience members located behind wheelchair positions  
must also be checked as the head of wheelchair users can also  
be higher than audience members seated in standard auditorium  
seats.  
An issue can arise where a level resting position for wheel-  
chair user conflicts with raked seating areas. The designer needs  
to consider how this might be managed without creating trip  
hazards between the rake and the edge of level seating areas.  
Locating wheelchair places on the level at the rear, at the front  
or the level from a cross aisle can provide effective ways of  
addressing this issue proving adjacent seating spaces are also on  
the level.  
Where backing into wheelchair seating positions is required,  
generally at the end of a row, access into the row behind for other  
audience members can be blocked, requiring the wheelchair person  
to move to allow access or require additional seats to be removed  
to allow clear access. Rear access into wheelchair positions, such  
as auditoria spaces with tiers or balconies tend to be more easily  
accommodated into auditoria spaces and allow for users to exit  
more discretely if required during a performance.  
# 3.25 Circulation  
While gangway lengths and widths are calculated as part of the fire  
escape route, they also provide the circulation through the audito-  
rium, with possible additional gangways from the audience entry  
points to individual rows and seats.  
# 3.26 Entry points  
The entry points into the auditorium need to connect directly with  
the gangways and will also be determined by the maximum travel  
distance from rows of fixed seats for means of escape purposes \(see  
3.28, Means of Escape\). The audience can enter from the rear of the  
auditorium, at the sides or in auditorium with in-the-round or thrust  
stage configurations through vomitory entrances.  
The areas around auditorium entrances also serve as useful  
locations for selling programmes, as well as for ticket checks and  
space for audience members to orientate themselves.  
Entrances and exits located near to the stage area will be  
required to have illuminated emergency exit signs. While the  
visibility of exit signs is important in case of emergency, poorly  
located exits can detract from the performance if within competing  
audience sightlines.  
Vomitory entrances can occupy a considerable number of good  
seating positions, so their locations need to be carefully consid-  
ered, while sight lines around the vomitories need careful attention.  
When vomitories are also used as entrances and exits for perform-  
ers, their location relative to the stage or performing area also needs  
careful planning so that extended distances do not detract from the  
element of surprise of performers arriving or exiting the perfor-  
mance area; see Figure 15.17.  
# 3.27 Doors and lobbies  
Observation doors in auditorium entrance areas can cause oper-  
ational problems in entertainment venues because of the need to  
exclude light and sound from darkened auditorium spaces. Curtains  
are not acceptable but management solutions where attendants sta-  
tioned by the entrances and exits can hold open or close doors as  
necessary to help people in and out of the auditorium. Doors must  
open in the direction of escape. Further guidance can be found in  
the ABTT Technical Regulations.  
Lobbies may be provided for heat insulation, sound or light  
reduction and/or fire protection. They must be designed so that  
users are not likely to be trapped or impeded by the doors.  
See Figure 15.18 taken from ABTT Technical Regulations for  
minimum lobby sizes and layouts.  
# 3.28 Fire safety  
Fundamentally, there are two alternative approaches to fire safety  
design although the principles for each will be similar\:  
• Code-based design, which satisfies the standards set out in the  
local building codes  
• Fire-engineering design, which develops a project specific fire  
safety strategy that may offer more flexible solutions, particu-  
larly for complex buildings like theatres, including the removal  
of the traditional fire safety curtain.  
For further detail and legislation, see also Chapter 11, Fire  
safety, this volume. Specific guidance on fire safety matters in  
theatres is provided in The Technical Standards for Places of  
Entertainment, 2015 \(sometimes referred to as ‘The Yellow Book’\)  
published by the Association of British Theatre Technicians, the  
Chartered Institute of Environmental Health, the District Surveyors  
Association and the Institute of Licensing.  
# 3.29 Means of escape  
The aim is for all in the auditorium to be able to escape to a  
place of safety within a set period of time. The escape route is  
from the seat, along the clearway and gangway, and through exit  
doors immediately, or through an enclosed corridor, to a place  
of safety. UK guidance on the distance from a seat to a place of  
safety for means of escape is set out in British Standard BS 9999\:  
*Code of Practice for Fire Safety in the Design, Management and*  
*Use of Buildings*. See also Technical Standards for Places of  
Entertainment 2015. **Auditoria 15-13**  
**15.17** *Performers’ vomitory\: access to the stage through a block of seating, usually in an open stage or theatre-in-the-round format. a\)*  
*Section; b\) Section showing removable seating in place when vomitory not required*  
**15.18** *Minimum lobby sizes and layouts. Source\: ‘Figure F\: Lobbies’ from Technical Standards for Places of Entertainment published*  
*June 2015; reprinted with revisions July 1, 2020 © Association of British Theatre Technicians et al.* **15-14 Auditoria**  
*Travel distance*  
In auditoria with fixed seated rows, a maximum travel distance of  
15 m in one direction is permissible, with 32 m as a limit when  
escape is possible in two directions \(of which only 15 m can be in  
any one direction\). In open floor areas, a maximum travel distance  
of 18 m in one direction is permissible, with 45 m as a limit when  
escape is possible in two directions.  
*Capacity of exits*  
The recommended maximum capacity of means of escape is shown  
in Table VI.  
The aggregate capacity of the means of escape or several exits is  
calculated by adding together the maximum number of people who  
can safely use each exit to escape – and not by adding together the  
widths of the various exits. For example, the capacity of three exits  
each 800 mm wide is \(3 × 60 people\) = 180 and not the capacity of  
a single exit 2400 mm wide.  
Each exit from the auditorium must lead directly to a place of  
safety.  
# 3.30 Width of escape routes  
Escape routes should be uniform in width and no less than the  
width of the exit, but may widen in the direction of escape. The  
clear width is measured at its minimum point, which is often a door  
set, not the corridor. They need to be wide enough to allow peo-  
ple to move quickly to escape from the premises. Corridors and  
passageways should allow for the manoeuvre of wheelchairs and  
permit other people to pass. There must be no bottlenecks and all  
doors within the route must open in the direction of escape.  
Routes within the building should have fire-resistant enclo-  
sures. There are special requirements for all doors opening onto  
fire escape routes.  
The clear width is dictated by the numbers of people exiting  
and as outlined in Table VI. Generally, exit doors should be no less  
than 1050 mm and means of escape routes no less than 1200 mm  
\(but within existing buildings may reduce to 800 mm for exit doors  
and 1000 mm for means of escape\). See also British Standard BS  
9999\: *Code of Practice for Fire Safety in the Design, Management*  
*and Use of Buildings*. Also refer to BS 8300\:2018 *Designing of an*  
*Accessible and Inclusive Built Environment*.  
# 3.31 Stairs  
The width of the stairs is the clear width between the walls or balus-  
trades. Handrails \(including any handrails and subdividing barriers  
on wide stairs\) may be ignored as long as each does not project  
more 100 mm into the escape route. Any additional projection  
should be treated as a reduction in the clear width of the stair.  
Stairs wider than 1800 mm should be subdivided into widths  
not less than 1100 mm wide. This means that stairs wider than  
1800 mm should be at least 2200 mm wide.  
The aggregate capacity of any stairs forming part of the means  
of escape from any floor should equal or exceed the accommoda-  
tion limit for that floor. Where a stair serves more than one floor,  
the capacity of the stair should equal or exceed the aggregate  
capacity of the exits opening onto it.  
Recommended maximum capacity of stairs is shown in  
Table VII.  
# 3.32 Steps treads and risers  
Best practice is set out in the following list\:  
• Flights of stairs should have no fewer than three steps  
• Any landings between flights should be at least as long as the  
width of the stairs  
• The rise of a flight between landings should not exceed 1800 mm  
• There should be not more than two successive flights without  
a turn \(this does not apply, however, to auditoria with stepped  
gangways, which should not be regarded as stairs\)  
• The pitch of any stair should be uniform throughout

# 3.33 Refuges  
Refuges should be provided in accordance with BS 9999. A ref-  
uge is a location of relative safety where people whose abilities or  
impairments might cause delayed evacuation can wait for assis-  
tance with the next part of their escape. However, it is not to be  
used as a place to leave disabled people for rescue by the fire ser-  
vice. Consideration should be given to the likely number and size  
of refuges and allow for bigger powered wheelchairs  
Refuges should be\:  
• Accessed in the direction of escape  
• Located in a protected corridor, protected lobby or a protected  
room adjacent to a protected stair  
• Accessible to the mobility-impaired person and provided with a  
communication system  
• Include a number of wheelchair spaces in refuges that equals  
or exceeds the provision of wheelchair spaces accessible to the  
refuges  
• A single wheelchair refuge should be at least 900 mm by  
1400 mm and clear of the prescribed escape passage  
• Have corridors 1200 mm wide to allow turning through  
180 degrees.  
# 3.34 Ramps and slopes  
Guidance for ramps in theatre buildings is provided in the ABTT  
Technical Regulations, which are also consistent with Approved  
Document Part M. BS 8300 also provides guidance on ramps for all  
new buildings, which may be difficult to achieve in many existing  
theatres and entertainments buildings.  
Wheelchair users should be provided with flat or ramped escape  
routes, which may be separate from other routes. Where there is  
need for a small change in level, such as for one or two steps, a  
ramp should be provided.  
Any ramp should be\:  
• No steeper than 1\:12 \(5°\) and no longer than 2 m between land-  
ings or  
• No steeper than 1\:15 \(4°\) and no longer than 5 m between land-  
ings or  
• No steeper than 1\:20 \(2.9°\) and no longer than 10 m between  
landings  
• Have at least 2.1 m headroom above the ramp  
• At least 1.2 m wide at floor level \(1.5 m wide in public spaces\)  
and at least 1.0 m wide measured at 1.5 m from floor level.  
Any ramp should also have\:  
• A level landing at the top and bottom of the same width as that  
of the ramp and at least 1.2 m long  
• Any intermediate landing of the same width as that of the ramp  
and at least 1.5 m long; landings should be clear of any door  
swinging onto it  
• Handrails on both sides of the ramp  
• Any open side of a ramp or landing should have a 100 mm high  
kerb.  
In theatres and entertainments buildings, gradients for sloping  
floors in the auditorium are generally governed by the need to pro-  
vide good sightlines to the stage or performance areas. In many  
historic theatres, the gradient of stalls floors may be as steep or in  
a few cases even steeper than 1\:9 \(or just over 6 degrees\), while  
the gradient in many will be around 1\:12 \(or 4.9 degrees\). See also  
Section 3.12 Gangways. These floor gradients were sometimes  
matched with raked stage floors, which further improved sightlines.  
The trend for flattening stage floors to make the technical oper-  
ation of theatre spaces less complicated has placed more emphasis  
on achieving good sightlines within the auditorium. To address  
these issues, the designer has to determine whether it is better to  
substitute shallow, elongated steps in the auditorium or provide  
gradients which are steeper than acceptable for ramped passages  
and escape routes.  
The key is to address the needs of disabled people in the audi-  
torium \(as described in Section 3.8 and 3.24\) and for the venue to  
put in place management policies which provide for their needs.  
All these issues will need to be considered in the round in order to  
come up with appropriate strategies and acceptable solutions.  
# 3.35 Handrails, barriers and guarding  
Entertainment venues often have many levels to which the public  
has access. Lighting levels may be low and some audience mem-  
bers have had something to drink, while children can be excited and  
not always effectively watched over. Particular care is needed to  
ensure that edges of all stairs, ramps, balconies and other changes  
of level are guarded effectively to avoid accidents. Backstage areas  
also need to be addressed with equal care and where often for pro-  
duction purposes spaces are dark.  
Any handrail should give firm support and allow a firm grip. A  
handrail can form the top of a barrier if the height can be matched  
and meet the requirements of the barrier. Steeply raked seating \(in  
excess of 25°\) should have hooped rails or similar supports at the  
end of rows with gangways; see Figure 15.19. Generally, loop rails  
should relate to any change in level over one riser as this better  
meets the standards for universal access than basic building reg-  
ulations.  
Barriers should generally be designed so that a 100 mm diame-  
ter sphere cannot pass through, unless it can be shown that children  
will not be admitted to the premises.  
Handrails, barriers and guarding are governed by legislation and  
should be provided to all stairs, ramps, landings, balconies, galleries  
and other changes in level exceeding 380 mm \(see Table VIII\).  
# 3.36 Balcony fronts  
The front of the balcony in auditoria can be set at 800 mm provided  
the front row of seating is not more than 530 mm. The height of the  
balcony front guarding in front rows of seats can be further reduced **15-16 Auditoria**  
**15.19** *Loop guardrail at the end of a row where the rake is steep*  
to 750 mm to facilitate sightlines provided the width of the barrier  
is also at least 225 mm, so that the aggregate of height plus width  
is never less than 975 mm.  
Where a stepped gangway leads to a balcony front \(and where  
there are no fixed seats\), the guarding must be raised to the full  
guardrail height of 1100 mm for the full width of the gangway; see  
Figure 15.20.  
The top element of a balcony front is sometimes referred to as a  
‘rester rail’. This is a misnomer as balcony fronts should be designed  
such that resting drinks, programmes and other items are not at risk  
of being knocked and falling on people below. The added depth of  
some balcony fronts can be useful for running theatrical communi-  
cations systems and containment for theatrical lighting sometimes  
positioned on balcony fronts to provide front lighting of the stage.  
The narrower, higher guarding of say, a 50 mm diameter rail  
can also be brought closer to the seated audience members in the  
front row to reduce sight line obstructions and avoid audience  
members leaning forward. It is also desirable to allow a toe recess  
for audience members in the front row.

# 3.37 Latecomers  
These should be provided with a waiting area at the rear of the  
auditorium either within the auditorium or in a separate enclosed  
space with viewing panel and sound show relay, or elsewhere with  
a closed-circuit television monitor.  
# 3.38 Attendants  
Legislation dictates the number of attendants present at public  
events, each requiring a seat in the auditorium.  
# 3.39 Adaptability, flexibility and variable formats  
Adaptability can range from modest flexibility in one area to  
wholesale reconfiguration of the space.  
*Orchestra pit and forestage*  
Adapting the orchestra pit and forestage is one of the more com-  
mon forms of adaptability associated with proscenium or end stage  
formats. It can be achieved through mechanised forestage/orchestra  
pit elevators or in the smaller and more economically operated ven-  
ues by the use of movable rostra, from simple demountable systems  
to gas- or spring-loaded units; see Figure 15.21.  
**15.20** *The minimum balcony handrail height is set by legislation at 800* *mm in front of fixed seating and 1100* *mm at the ends of*  
*gangways. Balcony fronts are used to support performance lighting and need socket outlets connected to stage lighting controls\: a\)*  
*Traditional balcony front incorporating shelf below handrail and adequate legroom; b\) Simpler front for side galleries with minimum*  
*clearway allowing the audience to lean on the handrail. The 300 mm clearance should be from the front of the armrest rather than the*  
*base of the tipped-up seat as shown.* **Auditoria 15-17**  
**15.21** *Orchestra pit lifts*  
*Adjustable proscenium*  
To accommodate smaller-scale productions, adjustable prosce-  
nium can be made of non-structural materials to vary the widths  
and heights of the proscenium openings. Sightlines, particularly  
the lateral ones, will need to be checked to the smaller proscenium  
opening.  
*Variable audience capacity*  
Larger venues may need to be able to vary the audience capacity to  
suit different scales of production and where audience demand for  
the show can vary. The simplest way of achieving this may be by  
closing upper tiers or levels through the use of house lighting, using  
curtains and drapes, or more complex solutions such as the lower-  
ing of the ceiling area to fully close off upper levels both visually  
and acoustically. Such arrangements need proper advanced plan-  
ning, including the impact on entrances and exits, through to means  
of escape and impact on front-of-house areas including foyers.  
*Adjustable acoustics*  
The acoustic considerations of spaces for drama use differ consid-  
erably from those used for a natural music acoustic. The spatial  
volume for an auditorium in the order of 10 m3 per seat for sym-  
phonic music drops for musical theatre, amplified music and  
speech. In smaller-scale venues of around 300 seats, such adapt-  
ability is relatively easy to achieve.  
The use of curtains, banners or drapes can assist significantly in  
reducing the reverberation time and also, when required, transform  
the visual outlook of the space. In larger spaces, this can become  
more challenging and require more significant adaptation, such as  
the use of movable ceilings or extensive use of acoustics banners or  
drapes. These can also be masked by screens or located in the space  
above lighting bridges and open ceilings.  
In spaces for drama or where a dry acoustic is required and  
the volume of the space cannot be easily enlarged, an alternative  
approach can be adopted through the use of electronically assisted  
resonance systems which can be integrated into the technical infra-  
structure of the venue to create a longer reverberation time.  
*Variable formats*  
A relatively straightforward example of a variable format may be a  
space where there is a simple need to be able to clear the auditorium  
of seating to provide an open, flat floor space. Layout formats can  
vary, for example, to present different stage and seating relation-  
ships in a drama theatre, which may adapt from an end stage to a  
thrust stage or traverse or even stage in-the-round seating format.  
These variable arrangements tend to suit smaller-scale venues  
where the alternative layouts are carefully planned and associated  
adjustments clearly understood. They may affect the whole or part  
of the auditorium space where, for example, the balconies or upper  
tiers are left unchanged.  
Format change may also refer to larger venues where, for exam-  
ple, a change is required to transform an auditorium from a lyric  
theatre space to a space for music presentation by opening up the  
stage or platform area. These format changes tend to be limited to  
quite specific transformations requiring bespoke solutions.  
# 3.40 Key components of adaptable auditoria  
There are a number of standard component types that enable  
adaptable auditoria spaces apart from the bespoke systems, such  
as movable ceiling systems. These technologies can be separately  
applied or, in some cases, combined to provide effective, transfor-  
mational mechanisms, for example the use of seating wagons and  
elevators to transform seating arrangements in an auditorium.  
A key consideration in making auditoria spaces adaptable is the  
amount of time and workforce required to effect the change against  
the capital cost and flexibility of the mechanisms proposed. Each  
separate seating configuration or room layout will need to comply  
with all safety legislation as if the layout were a permanent fixture.  
Inspections are likely to be undertaken from time to time to ensure  
that all safety procedures are being properly complied with.  
*Loose seating*  
Loose seating arranged on a flat floor is perhaps the simplest way to  
provide flexibility between seating configurations and a cleared flat  
floor. Sightlines will require a higher raised stage area than normal  
and seats will need to be linked in rows or fixed in position. This  
arrangement is relatively labour intensive, while lightweight seats  
which are easy to move and stack are generally less comfortable;  
see Figure 15.22.  
*Retractable seating units*  
Retractable seating units are ideal for spaces where flat floor use is  
required for alternative functions or as movable units for alterna-  
tive seating configurations; see Figure 15.23.  
Sometimes also known as bleacher seating, retractable seating  
units are raked seating systems where each row folds back in on **15-18 Auditoria**  
**15.22** *Loose seating, capable of removal. May or may not have*  
*arms, and be stackable. Needs to be firmly fixed down when in*  
*public use*  
**15.23** *a\) Bleacher seating\: one of a number of proprietary*  
*systems of permanently installed retractable systems. The length*  
*of seating in a single unit is limited to 6 m. For tip-up seats with*  
*arms, the minimum riser height is 250 mm. b\) Bleacher seating*  
*retracted*  
itself like a chest of drawers to create a compact unit to a depth not  
much greater than the depth of a single row and the height of the  
highest row. For units with tip-up seats with arms, the minimum  
riser height is 250 mm to accommodate the seat when folded flat in  
storage mode. More recent developments have now created units  
with gently curving rows.  
Units can be manually or electronically operated and turna-  
round time can be achieved in a matter of minutes.  
*Rostra*  
These are generally made up of demountable, framed structures  
\(not unlike scaffolding systems\) to form floor units that can be  
configured to create raked seating tiers \(where seats are separately  
mounted\), raised stage areas or platforms; see Figures 15.24 and  
15.25\. They are manufactured in steel or lighter weight alumin-  
ium sections. They are highly flexible and can be broken down into  
smaller components for storage, but are labour intensive to set up.  
*Seating wagons*  
These are more complete mobile seating units that can be moved  
around on roller castors or, more efficiently, on air castors to  
form different seating arrangements; see Figure 15.26. They  
require a level, flat and generally well-sealed floor to manoeu-  
vre. Seating wagons allow large seating blocks to be moved out  
of the auditorium, either to an adjacent store, or often to a fore-  
stage elevator to be delivered to dedicated stores below the stalls  
\(see Figure 15.21 earlier\). Seating wagons can also accommo-  
date the same quality, fixed seating as fixed seating in other areas  
of the auditorium.  
*Mobile towers*  
Mobile towers are bespoke, multi-tiered architectural elements  
which contain seating and which can be arranged to suit different  
auditorium formats and dramatically alter the architectural outlook  
and character of the space. Their considerable weight generally  
means that they are moved on air castors or floor tracks.  
**15.24** *Rostra\: a set of metal or timber units built up to form a*  
*stepped floor on a flat base. Seats are secured onto floor or riser.*  
*Each rostrum unit collapsible for storage*  
**15.25** *Proprietary scaffolding-type system*  
**15.26** *Large units on brakeable castors or air cushions*  
*Lifts*  
These are not unlike forestage elevators but extend over a wider  
area of the auditorium floor to provide clear flat floor areas or raised  
seating tiers. These can range from modular floor sections, see  
Figure 15.27, which can be individually or collectively raised using  
scissor lift mechanisms, to large floor plates that can be raised or  
lowered by the use of specialist lift mechanisms, such as screw  
jacks, scissor lifts, chain lifts or spiral lifts. The seating still needs  
to be positioned on top and guardrails applied where changes in  
level are exposed.  
# 3.41 Sound insulation from outside noise sources  
These standards are expressed as Noise Rating \(NR\). To achieve  
the appropriate rating auditorium design may require\:  
• Isolation of the auditorium structurally  
• Sound locks to all doors at point of entry  
• Services acoustically sealed  
• Noise reduction to air conditioning/heating/ventilation system. **15.27** *Floor sections that can be raised and lowered by power*  
*operated systems*  
# 3.42 Ventilation, heating, cooling and air conditioning  
The advent of the Coronavirus epidemic in 2020 and much greater  
environmental and sustainability concerns has led to consider-  
able reappraisal of the most appropriate forms of ventilation for  
large volume spaces, such as an auditorium where relatively large  
numbers of people congregate. New build projects will be able to  
address these issues more directly, but the adaptation of systems in  
historic or existing buildings could be more challenging depend-  
ent on existing ventilation systems, space and the structure of the  
building. Auditoria spaces will typically require large ducts or air  
passages to introduce air into the auditorium and this will occupy  
space that needs to be allowed for. For acoustic and comfort rea-  
sons, the air within the ducts or air passages should typically flow  
at a low velocity.  
The movement of air within auditoria will also need to take  
account of smoke ventilation and containment in the event of fire.  
Please refer to the ABTT Technical Standards \(E3 Smoke ventila-  
tion and containment\) for further guidance.  
The design depends on the internal standards required in the  
auditorium, the thermal insulation of the enclosure and on the  
external climatic conditions. In the UK, an internal design temper-  
ature of 22°C, with a relative humidity of 50 per cent \(RH\) would  
be regarded as an acceptable standard.  
*Cooling*  
Cooling may need to be considered in auditoria spaces that may  
suffer from humidity during warmer months. Air conditioning is  
often misunderstood as a term for providing cooling in an audito-  
rium space. Comfort cooling is a term simply used for cooling the  
incoming air by refrigeration or other means such as thermal mass  
during warm sticky conditions in the summer. In warmer climates,  
pre-cooling may be adopted as a strategy for tempering the internal  
environment before the audience arrives.  
*Ventilation*  
Ventilation needs to provide fresh air at a rate of change to achieve  
comfortable conditions. Statutory regulations set high standards for  
air changes within the auditorium with a minimum air supply per  
occupant of 8 litres per second.  
For reasons of sustainability, this might best be arranged as nat-  
ural or lightly assisted ventilation. It is generally referred to as air  
displacement. The air is introduced at around a couple of degrees  
less than room design temperature of, say 22°C under the seats  
through a grille in the floor under the seat, in the riser of a tier or  
through the seat base. It is introduced at low velocity to avoid drafts  
and air noise and where it is comfortable for audience members and  
then risers to be evacuated at high level.  
# Auditoria 15-19  
Air mixing in an auditorium, which was commonly used as a  
means to stabilise air temperature in high-level forced air ventilation  
systems is not good in respect of infectious disease transmission.  
For this reason, high-level or top air supply and top exhaust extrac-  
tion should now be regarded an unacceptable ventilation solution  
in any theatre or auditorium.  
*Tempered fresh air*  
The advent of the Coronavirus outbreak, as well as seasonal infec-  
tions such as flu or influenza has led to much greater concerns  
about the levels of ventilation in auditoria spaces, such that the  
preference is now towards introducing tempered fresh air rather  
than recirculating air systems. The preferred method is now by the  
supply of tempered air from under the floor and seat using the nat-  
ural buoyancy of air warmed by audience members and rising for  
extraction at high level.  
Acoustic criteria mean that large volumes of air need to be  
delivered at low velocity requiring ducts that have large cross-sec-  
tional area. Integrating these within the auditoria surroundings will  
require careful planning from the outset and can be particularly  
challenging to integrate when upgrading historic venues.  
*Air filtration*  
Improved air filtration systems can render incoming air lower risk  
to infections but will require more fan power to drive the air than  
less effective filters. In new build projects, larger filter areas can  
be arranged, but in existing buildings, increased fan power and  
consequent noise generation may be the only way of reducing the  
possibility to virus intake. It should, however, be noted that as  
external air is sanitised by sunlight the risk level of external air can  
be quite low.  
*Building management systems*  
Heating, cooling and venting for large volume auditoria spaces is  
costly during times when the auditorium is closed and not occupied  
by audiences, for example, during rehearsals or technical fit-ups.  
Control systems such as Building Management Systems \(BMS\)  
and air quality sensors can be used to reduce energy consumption  
to levels appropriate to the occupancy.  
# 3.43 Lighting systems  
Lighting design in auditoria is a highly specialised discipline and  
varies for different auditoria typologies and presentational and  
performance types. Theatre lighting technology is developing and  
expert advice from suitable theatre or performance lighting con-  
sultants should be sought.  
Lighting infrastructure needs to be planned from the outset\:  
where the main electrical supply comes in; the location of distribu-  
tion boards; dimmer rooms for performance lighting; the location  
of control rooms; and the distribution and infrastructure for the per-  
formance lighting in the auditorium and stage house or stage area.  
Digital technology is having a marked impact on the control and  
operation of lighting systems. While technological improvements and  
lifespan of the equipment may last no more than 10 years, the distri-  
bution and wiring infrastructure may be expected to last three times  
as long and, therefore, needs to be carefully considered at the outset.  
Broadly, there are six different requirements for auditorium  
lighting\:  
*Performance lighting*  
This is an integral part of the staging of productions, with lighting  
positions not only on the stage but also within the auditorium at  
ceiling level, on side and rear walls and balcony fronts. Further  
details are given in Section 6.  
For classical music and serious jazz, sufficient lighting for  
the performers to see their music and the conductor \(if any\), and  
for them to be seen by the audience is usually all that is required.  
Similar lighting is required for the platform at conferences. **15-20 Auditoria**  
Pop music requires as complex lighting as for drama and  
opera – although highly sophisticated stage lighting effects have  
become an increasing part of the overall presentation.  
*House lighting before and after performance and during*  
*intervals*  
Illumination is needed to enable the audience to move around,  
find their seats and read programmes with decorative lighting to  
enhance architectural features and shape the overall ambiance of  
the space. Electronic, pre-set scene setting of different lighting lev-  
els, sequences and emphasis allows the house lighting to match the  
mood of the production.  
House lighting for conferences needs to allow for networking  
and reading of notes and programmes.  
*House lighting during performance*  
For cinema, lighting during performance is for exit signs and  
escape routes. For the former, illuminated green legends on a  
black background in a black fitting minimises distraction during  
screenings. For the latter, low-level lights, for example LED lights  
incorporated in the vertical face of step nosings, have advantages in  
not presenting distraction in the line of vision of the screen. A low  
level of illumination is also required within the auditorium to avoid  
the need for the audience to adjust their vision in the event of mains  
failure and a switch to emergency lighting.  
For theatre, a slightly higher level of illumination may be used,  
particularly if the performance demands a contrast with a period of  
almost total darkness. For classical music, it is now usual to have  
sufficient lighting for near-normal vision and following scores.  
Pop music may require house lighting as sophisticated as per-  
formance lighting, with strobe, moving and laser light facilities.  
Certain minimal levels of lighting are required during perfor-  
mances to ensure safety in emergency, particularly along the exit  
routes. Other lighting may be required to come on automatically  
in emergency situations; this may work off a separate protected  
supply. Alternatively, each light fitting can incorporate a battery  
and be programmed to come on when a failure in the mains supply  
is triggered.  
*Working lighting at other times*  
The seating area will also require a brighter working level of light-  
ing for cleaning, maintenance and probably during rehearsals and  
auditions.  
*Front-of-house lighting*  
Escape routes have to be adequately lit at all times during, as well  
as before and after, performances. Foyers, bars and ticket offices  
require creative lighting design to enhance their appeal.  
*Backstage lighting*  
Backstage corridors are often also escape routes for the perform-  
ers and service staff and must be kept illuminated whenever the  
building is occupied. Dressing rooms and workshops will have nor-  
mal lighting for such facilities, and may be fitted with proximity  
detectors to ensure that lights are not left on when the rooms are  
unoccupied. Doors leading to the stage may require special low-  
level blue lighting elements to avoid trip hazards and so that light  
does not spill into the stage area during a performance.

# 4 SEATING  
# 4.1 Introduction  
The aim is to provide an appropriate standard of comfort. While  
the range of human body dimensions is wide, in most auditoria a  
single size of seat is provided in dimensions to suit the average per-  
son; see Figure 15.28 and Table IX. Tolerance levels vary – young  
people can tolerate simple seating found less comfortable by older  
people. Those attending concerts of classical music expect more  
comfort than those watching drama. The best able to be achieved  
is in the order of 90 per cent of the audience within an acceptable  
range of comfort.  
# 4.2 Working dimensions  
• *Seat width* – legislation minimum 500 mm \(with arms\) or  
450 mm \(without\). For seats with arms a width of 525 mm is the  
least for reasonable comfort.  
• *Seat height* – 430–460 mm predominates.  
• *Back inclination* – 10 degrees for upper balconies; 18 degrees  
for stalls.  
• *Seat inclination* – an angle to the horizontal of 7–9°.  
• *Back height* – 800–850 mm above floor level \(may be increased  
for acoustic reasons\).  
• *Back inclination* – angle to the vertical of 15–20°.  
• *Seat depth* – 600–720 mm for seat and back depth overall, reduc-  
ing to 425–500 mm when the seat is tipped up. Depth varies and  
depends on thickness of upholstery and backing and if the rear  
of the seat contains the air conditioning. For a modest seat with  
arms, the dimensions can be as low as 520 mm deep, 340 mm  
when tipped up. The ability of the seat to tip up, activated silently  
by weight when not occupied, allows a clearway \(which is a crit- ical dimension\) to pass along a row while limiting row-to-row  
distance. Where space is severely limited such as in studio thea-  
tres, an especially slim seat, see Figure 15.29, can be used.  
• *Arm rests* – 50 mm minimum width, with the length coinciding  
with the tipped seat to avoid obstructing the clearway. Height  
is about 600 mm above floor level. The upper surface may be  
sloped or not.  
The requirements for cinema seats, including recliner seats and  
sofas in cinemas, can be found in Section 10.4.  
# 4.3 Supports  
The permanent fixing of a seat can be\:  
• Side supports shared by adjacent seats; see Figure 15.30  
• A pedestal or single vertical support; see Figure 15.31  
• Cantilevered brackets fixed to riser \(if of sufficient height\) and  
shared by adjacent seats; see Figure 15.32  
• A bar supporting a group of seats with leg or bracket support;  
see Figure 15.33.  
# 4.4 Other factors  
• *Acoustics* – upholstery should satisfy acoustic requirements,  
usually the level of absorbency when unoccupied, especially the  
case with music; see Figure 15.34.  
• *Ventilation and heating* – for air supply under a seat, allow space  
in floor or riser to receive grille; see Figure 15.35. A plenum  
chamber to deliver low velocity air under the seat is now more  
widely used than direct air ducts if space permits.  
• *Comfort* – upholstery padding should provide comfort and avoid  
fatigue but not encourage excessive relaxation.  
• *Fire* – padding and finish must satisfy fire regulations.  
• *Ease of cleaning* – an important factor in the selection of seat  
fixing details.

# 4.5 Writing surface  
Conference use may require a writing surface for note taking. The  
writing surface may be a\:  
• Tablet fixed to each seat; see Figure 15.36  
• Removable tablet  
• Tablet pivoted to slide away vertically; see Figure 15.37

in position, hinged or retractable; see Figure 15.38  
• Fixed table with loose seat  
• Fixed table with fixed pivoting or sliding seat; see Figure 15.39.  
Table seating has the advantage that delegates can pass behind the  
row of seats, and assistants can sit behind the delegates.  
In a theatre or concert hall where there is occasional conference  
use, every other row of seats can be used with temporary tables;  
see Figure 15.40.

# 5 THEATRES  
# 5.1 Range  
Theatre covers productions of drama, opera, ballet/dance, musi-  
cals, variety and pantomime; see Figure 15.42.  
# 5.2 Types  
Theatre design has developed over many generations in a quest to  
enhance the presentational relationship between the performance  
and the audience. From the traditional proscenium theatre formats  
that dominated theatre design from the seventeenth century until its  
heyday in the latter part of the nineteenth and early twentieth centu-  
ries, there has since been a gradual erosion of the division between **Auditoria 15-23**  
**15.42** *Relationship diagrams for buildings for opera, musicals, dance and drama. If for drama only, the orchestra pit and musicians’*  
*spaces may not be required\: a\) Where the building serves only touring companies \(a ‘receiving theatre’\) or with a resident company*  
*whose production facilities are elsewhere; b\) Where production facilities are needed \(a ‘producing theatre’\)* **15-24 Auditoria**  
**15.43** *Auditorium formats for opera, dance, and musicals on*  
*proscenium stages\: a\) Horseshoe form, shallow rear and side*  
*balconies; b\) Fan shape with 90° arc, with or without rear*  
*balcony; c\) Shallow rear and side balconies*  
the stage house set behind the proscenium frame to explorations of  
more open formats where the stage occupies the same space as the  
audience.  
The result is a wide variety of theatre forms and presentational  
formats. This has not been a linear development and the traditional  
form of the proscenium stage theatre is still relevant and remains  
the primary format for the presentation of large-scale and elaborate  
scenic effects, such as opera, ballet, music theatre, variety and pan-  
tomime. Figure 15.43 shows various proscenium stage formats for  
such productions.  
# 5.3 Proscenium stage  
*Stage house*  
In proscenium stage theatres, the stage house is separated from the  
auditorium by the proscenium frame opening. The stage house con-  
tains the stage area and the technical machinery for manipulating  
the scenery and stage lighting, while the audience in the auditorium  
views the action on the stage through the frame of the stage open-  
ing. Arranging good sightlines through the proscenium opening  
has determined the arrangement of seating within the auditorium,  
which is essentially end-on, but which has also been developed to  
form more multi-layered arrangements with tiers or boxes further  
wrapping around the auditorium to ‘dress’ or ‘populate’ the side  
elevations of the auditorium.  
The width and dimensions of the proscenium opening are  
important for a number of reasons. The proportion of the framed  
view is somewhat akin to a picture frame, affecting how much of  
the stage area can be seen by the audience. The width and the height  
of the opening also relate to the type and scale of production that  
can be staged \(see Section 7, Table X, which gives an indication of  
the stage size and proscenium openings for different scale theatres\).  
*Orchestra pit*  
The traditional position for the orchestra is located in a pit between  
audience and stage, with the conductor located in a pivotable posi-  
tion controlling the orchestra and singers, while also being able to  
judge the timing or pace of the production on the stage.  
*Forestage and apron stage*  
The proscenium opening is traditionally a structurally framed open-  
ing that is used as the point for separating the fire zones between  
the stage house and auditorium and, where required as part of the  
fire strategy, a large smoke curtain or fire shutter closes the opening  
when not in performance mode. The fire curtain is located imme-  
diately behind the proscenium wall. The back or ‘upstage’ side of  
the fire curtain is also defined as the ‘setting line’ from where the  
layout of stage sets or scenery is set. Forward, or ‘downstage’ of  
this line, any scenery or props would foul the safety curtain.  
The stage area in front or ‘downstage’ of the safety curtain is  
known as the apron stage. Where this stage area is extended to over-  
lap the realms of the stage with the auditorium, this is known as the  
forestage and allows for a more intimate relationship between an  
actor coming downstage into this area and the audience.  
The forestage may also overlap or overhang the orchestra pit  
and is often used for announcers coming in front of the house cur-  
tain to make an announcement.  
# 5.4 End stage  
The end stage is an evolution of the proscenium format but with-  
out the architectural opening, with the audience orientated end-on  
directly in front of the stage, placing the audience and performance  
in the same space. A characteristic of this format is that all four  
corners of the stage can be seen by the audience. It is therefore well  
suited to contemporary dance and forms of physical theatre.  
The stage may or may not have a stage riser and tend to have  
more limited flying facilities for stage scenery, while the audience  
as a unified body generally sits between parallel walls fronting  
the stage. A ‘soft’ or removable proscenium frame can sometimes  
be dropped in where this arrangement is desired for certain produc-  
tions, such as dance, music theatre or opera.  
For dance and opera, the minimum performance area would be  
10 × 10 m \(excluding wings, stage cross over, etc., while for drama  
the stage depth could reduce to 10 × 8 m. Modest wings would be at  
least 3 m deep on either side with masking for storage and scenery  
as well as performers’ entrances and exits \(see Figure 15.56\). In  
medium and larger-scale touring venues, a performance area of 12  
× 12 m would be expected while for large-scale opera and ballet a  
performance area of 15 × 15 m \(see Table X\).  
# 5.5 Open stage formats  
For drama, the initial distinction in formats is between the pro-  
scenium format \(Section 5.3\) and open stage forms. There are a  
number of variations of open stage formats, as shown in Figure  
15.44.  
In certain open stage formats, such as in-the-round or on a thrust  
stage and where there is little possibility of space for scenery or  
sets, the stage floor forms an important part of the stage production.  
It is essential that access can be made to the underside of the stage  
floor and that it be constructed in such a manner that it can be read-  
ily adapted to suit different stage productions. The whole or part  
of the performance area can receive traps as previously described,  
with one ‘grave’ trap 1200 × 2400 mm as a minimum. If there are  
traps, a basement will be needed with access for the performers and  
minimum ceiling height of 4.4 m.  
The stage itself is usually not raised much above the audito-  
rium floor, but can be between 300–750 mm with 600 mm being  
**15.44** *Auditorium formats for drama on open stages\: a\) End*  
*stage; b\) Fan shape, 90° arc with or without rear balcony;*  
*c\) Thrust stage, 180° + arc, with or without rear balcony; d\)*  
*Theatre-in-the-round; e\) Transverse\: audience on sides of stage* **Auditoria 15-25**  
a commonly used level. The minimum clear height over the stage  
including scenery suspension grid and stage lighting is 6.5 m.  
An important consideration for open stage formats is how  
performers get onto and off the stage because of the extended  
distance from wings or backstage areas. Typically, in thrust stage  
configurations, the performers might access the stage through the  
audience or by means of vomitory entrances \(see Section 3.26 and  
Figure 15.17\).  
# 5.6 Corner stage \(90° arc\)  
Setting the stage in the corner of the auditorium space creates a  
broadly 90° arc. This arrangement sits somewhere between an end  
stage and amphitheatre with an enhanced degree of encirclement of  
the stage by the audience, allowing the performers to come forward  
for a more engaged relationship with the audience, the walls form-  
ing the back corner of the stage, or with some freestanding scenery  
to create the scenic backdrop to the performance.  
Dimensions for the stage area vary, based on a circle or faceted  
circle, with diameters ranging from 8 to 11 m; see Figure 15.45.  
# 5.7 The wide fan  
Extending the encirclement of the stage by the audience to around  
130° brings forward the concept of the actor’s ‘point of com-  
mand’ \(see Figure 15.14 earlier\), where an actor can command  
the attention of the entire audience arranged in the auditorium in  
front without having to turn his or her head. However, the increas-  
ing degree of encirclement of the stage area, while increasing the  
sense of visual immediacy, can in practice mean the actor’s head is  
sometimes facing away from parts of the audience making it more  
difficult to hear or see the actor’s expression, while sightlines to  
the stage set from the extreme side of the auditorium become more  
challenging.  
# 5.8 Amphitheatres  
The Ancient Greek amphitheatre wrapped the audience around a  
central stage with a 220° encirclement. The steeply raked seating  
was carved into an open-air landscape and focused the seating on  
the open stage ‘orchestra’, while the action took place on a linear  
strip of stage running across the back of the orchestra called the  
‘proscenium’. The backdrop was a permanent, multi-storey, archi-  
tecturally structured, stone façade. Roman arenas fully encircled  
the central stage, but their amphitheatres were semi-circular giv-  
ing a 180° encirclement. Today, amphitheatre is a generically used  
term for outdoor performance spaces.  
# 5.9 Thrust stages  
Thrust stages take the degree of encirclement around three sides  
of an exposed stage area in order to provide a high degree of inti-  
macy between actor and audience. In this case, the audience on  
one side has the audience on the other as part of the backdrop,  
so any scenic devices on the stage are reduced to a few minimal  
props, costumes and the actors themselves. The scenic backdrop  
is otherwise restricted to the fourth side where the audience is not  
seated. Entrances and exits for the actors onto the stage area are  
normally from the scenic fourth side, but as the element of surprise  
can be lost by the distance the actor must travel to the front of the  
stage, alternative entry points through the audience are arranged,  
and in the case of steeply raked seating, may be through vomitory  
entrances.  
For an example of a thrust stage, see Figure 15.46.  
# 5.10 Theatre-in-the-round  
As the name implies, the audience wraps 360° around the stage  
area. It is sometimes also referred to as an arena stage and  
addresses the exposed stage issues associated with thrust stages  
in an even more comprehensive manner. Entrances and exits for  
actors are through the audience, while there is little or no place for  
scenic setting \(save perhaps for the stage floor itself\), which would  
otherwise block the view of audience members on the other side.  
This form of auditoria space is also associated with circus perfor-  
mance, where much of the activity may also be aerial and not just  
on the ground plane.

The performance area can be circular, square, polygon, rectan-  
gular or elliptical; see Figure 15.47. The performers’ entry can be  
combined or separate from the public access.  
# 5.11 Courtyard theatre  
The precedent for these theatre spaces originates from Elizabethan  
theatre spaces where the stage is generally surrounded on three  
sides, not unlike a thrust stage, but where the seating is generally  
raised up on a series of relatively shallow tiers to provide a mul-  
ti-layered auditorium space. In early Shakespearean theatres, such  
as the Rose Theatre or Globe, these spaces were outdoors and open  
to the elements. Audience members stood in the pit around the  
stage, while those in the raised tiers were roofed over to provide  
a greater level of comfort. The close proximity between stage and  
audience provides an intense audience actor relationship.  
The contemporary form of this theatre, which derives from the  
eighteenth-century playhouse in more rectangular-shaped spaces  
and with gently raked seating in the stalls area, has now been  
adopted for a variety of contemporary theatre spaces including The  
Dorfman at the National Theatre in London, the Swan and Royal  
Shakespeare Theatre at Stratford-upon-Avon. This form also lends  
itself to a range of adaptable theatre spaces.  
# 5.12 Traverse stage  
The traverse stage format arranges the stage as a linear perfor-  
mance platform through the centre of the auditorium and may be  
arranged along either a long or short axis. These arrangements are  
rarely permanently fixed and can be formed as part of an alternative  
staging format in flexible theatre spaces.  
# 5.13 Promenade  
This is not so much a theatre format as a staging configuration  
where the actors are in amongst the audience in a continually  
changing relationship with the audience where the audience is not  
seated but follows the performance through and around the space  
as in site-specific events.  
# 5.14 Multi-purpose and adaptable auditoria spaces  
Adaptable or flexible spaces are not a particular form of theatre,  
but rather those spaces that can be adapted or changed to allow dif-  
ferent performance types or staging configurations. An example of  
a multi-purpose auditorium space, see Figure 15.48, covers a sin-  
gle form with a modest level of flexibility while combining opera,  
dance, musicals and drama, as well as concerts, conference and  
film shows. This is a multi-purpose proscenium stage with flytower  
and a flexible proscenium zone; the seating in the auditorium can  
remain constant. However, problems can arise in combining differ-  
ent types of production in a single auditorium.  
As seen in Section 3.4, the reverberation times for speech and  
music are different and will need addressing between one perfor-  
mance mode and another, as well as adjustments to the performance  
lighting and technical systems.  
Adaptable auditoria spaces might be used for single perfor-  
mance types, such as drama, which can take the form of a courtyard  
theatre or even flat floor space. These are spaces that can be adapted  
to allow thrust stage, end stage, proscenium stage, in-the-round,  
traverse stages or even a catwalk. Each configuration needs to be  
carefully planned and the means by which stage platforms or seat-  
ing areas are formed and arranged must be carefully designed to  
meet all the auditorium design and safety criteria as if the format  
were a set piece. While in theory well-designed spaces can adopt  
multiple staging and seating configurations, in practice, these audi-  
toria spaces are likely to require a large technical crew to effect the  
change, time to carry out the change and a significant storage space  
to accept the various parts to enable each configuration to work  
safely and effectively.  
# 5.15 Studio theatres  
Studio theatres, sometimes referred to as ‘black box’ theatres, by  
definition do not contain moving stage machinery. They usually  
have some form of mobile or movable seating either to provide  
for different layouts or to clear the space for other uses at different  
times.  
There are a number of well-developed, flexible seating systems  
offering great variety and compliance with normal seating regu-  
lations, with a foldaway and mobile facility. However, bleacher  
seating systems demand a dedicated space into which the seating  
can be concertinaed when not in use. There is a significant point  
load factor under the supporting wheels. Bleacher seating arrange-  
ments do not offer flexible seating layout possibilities.  
*Access*  
Studio theatres should have different access points for entries and  
exits, allowing flexibility for both the audience and performer.  
A passage around the outside of the studio allows performers to  
access any entrance. In all cases, it is assumed that audience circu-  
lation and amenities are located adjacent to designated exits, which  
should have immediate access to further doors on the outer side of  
the passage leading to a place of safety. Provision for drapes to be  
hung and moved around the walls offers the potential for varying  
the acoustic as well as the outlook of the space. Traditionally, these  
spaces had black walls and drapes to determine the ‘neutrality’ of  
the space, but this does not need to be a given.  
Height is a key factor.  
*Lighting grid*  
One of the great selling points for the studio theatre is the speed  
and ease with which one can move from one production to  
another. Frequently this is serviced by having a grid made up of  
50 mm outside diameter tubing over the whole space from which  
performance light fittings can be hung in any location. If space and  
cost allow, it is a considerable advantage if this can be arranged  
in such a way that there are technical gantries that allow access  
to lighting bars to effect all the lighting changes without the use  
of access equipment and ladders, thereby allowing for completely  
different functions to be carried out at floor level simultaneously.  
An alternative is a tension wire grid, which allows full, safe access  
to performance lighting over the whole area. If a technical gan-  
try is not possible then it is essential that the lighting grid can be **Auditoria 15-27**  
**15.48a–f** *Multi-use stage with flytower and flexible proscenium*  
accessed from below by a mobile access system. From a theatre  
lighting perspective, the head of the lantern should not be less than  
4 m above floor level.  
# 6 LIGHTING AND SOUND  
# 6.1 Introduction  
Auditorium lighting and sound will have a considerable impact  
on the design of the auditorium space and therefore needs to be  
considered at an early stage in the planning process. If good and  
workable positions for rigging sound and lighting equipment are  
not considered part of the auditorium design, theatre technicians  
will in due course rig their own positions, which could well look  
unsightly. Integration of technical equipment can be relatively  
straightforward in an open stage or studio space where the equip-  
ment and technical infrastructure form part of the auditorium  
aesthetic. Where this is not the case, greater care will be needed to  
conceal equipment in the appropriate positions. **15-28 Auditoria**  
Lighting requirements within the auditorium include side light-  
ing positions, the advance bar or lighting bridge, lighting bridges,  
tension wire grids, slips or side bridges and follow spot platforms.  
These are all located at high level within the auditorium. At lower  
level within the auditorium, front lighting of the stage is often  
required and hung on lighting bars located on the circle front or  
bars positioned discreetly under tiers.  
Rigging for sound systems within the auditorium may include  
vertically mounted booms each side of the proscenium or a central  
cluster of speakers over the stage in front of the proscenium and  
delay speakers under the balcony.  
# 6.2 Positioning of performance lighting and sound  
The position of technical equipment is governed by ease of access.  
In intensively used auditoria, staff will require almost daily access  
to lighting and equipment and safe access must be provided in order  
for them to carry out their functions. Access needs to be to the rear  
of the lantern with ample room for the staff to reach around to the  
front of the fitting and also sufficient free space for the equipment  
to be readily demountable should repair be required.  
Over a third of the total number of theatre lighting instru-  
ments in a modern rig are likely to be located in the auditorium  
area \(front-of-house\); see Figure 15.49. Lighting the actor’s face  
at around 45° above the horizontal is essential to avoid unflattering  
shadows, while a lower angle may cast unwanted shadows on the  
set. Stage lighting needs to be considered in 3D as spotlights are  
rarely directed straight at an actor’s face and more normally by  
means of cross lighting. This means that lighting angles may be set  
at 55° in order to achieve 45° when crossed.  
Depending on auditorium design, lanterns are either housed on  
bridges, which reach across the auditorium, see Figure 15.50, or are  
attached to the auditorium structure itself. Lighting bridges require  
thoughtful integration into the ceiling design of the auditorium,  
especially where the layout of the bridges needs to be integrated  
with the ceiling design.

side of the proscenium opening mounted on vertically arranged

the performance without undue glare falling in the eyes of the audi-  
ence opposite; see Figure 15.51.  
*Follow spots*  
Follow spots form an integral part of much musical, ballet and operatic  
work. Traditionally, a follow spot operator directs a narrowly focused,  
movable beam onto one or more performers during the course of the  
performance following the performer as required see Figure 15.52.  
**15.51** *On thrust and theatre-in-the-round stages virtually all the*  
*lighting comes from overhead to avoid glare in the eyes of the*  
*audience\: a\) Plan; b\) Section*  
**15.52** *Follow spot, minimum size for equipment and operator*  
*1.5 × 2 m*  
# Auditoria 15-29  
Typically, follow spots are large and require in the order of 2 m2  
of space for the lantern and operator located high up behind or over  
the audience seating. The follow spot positions should therefore  
allow for lanterns to swing and the operator to stand either behind  
or beside the instrument.  
Account should be taken of the considerable weight of moving  
follow spot lanterns into position and the need access to the lens for  
cleaning. Sometimes, these positions may be located amongst the  
rear audience seating where areas are sectioned off to accommo-  
date the follow spot for productions where they are needed. Current  
technology now allows more remote control of follow spots to  
overcome some of the constraints of positioning follow spot in dif-  
ficult or inaccessible locations.  
The angle of the position to the stage should be around 45° or  
more, because the whole point of follow spotting is to isolate what is  
being lit in this way. Normally, a pair of follow spots is located in a  
high central position to allow individual operators easy contact with  
each other, especially if they are separated by glass from the audito-  
rium area. Provision should be considered for two further spotlight  
positions, either side of the auditorium, at a similarly high angle. The  
follow spots should be able to cover the whole of the performing area.  
# 6.3 Spaces associated with the audience area  
*Lighting control position*  
The lighting control position or room is ideally situated on the centre  
line of the auditorium, fully enclosed and soundproofed with a win-  
dow and space for the lighting control console and for the operator  
who needs a clear view over the console to the performance with an  
unrestricted view of the stage; see Figure 15.53. The control room  
window should be openable and non-reflective, with sightlines over  
the audience seating and where someone standing in front of the  
control room will not obstruct views. There should also be space for  
an assistant and a worktop for plans and scripts. The advent of digi-  
tal technology has meant that lighting control systems are becoming  
ever smaller and can now be controlled from a laptop in smaller  
venues. A minimum recommended size for a lighting control room  
would be 3 m wide, 3.5 m deep and 2.5 m high.  
*Dimmer rooms*  
Space is required for the dimmer racks, which are the direct means  
of control for all of the stage lighting equipment. The racks also  
contain the individual fusing for each stage lighting circuit. Mains  
cabling runs from the dimmer room to all outlets of the stage light-  
ing installation, and also to the house lights, but the connection  
between the dimmer racks and the lighting control itself is not a  
mains voltage line.  
The dimmer room should be placed so that quick access may  
be achieved either from the lighting control position or from the  
stage area. The dimmer room will also normally contain the mains  
isolation for the stage lighting system. In large venues which have a  
three-phase supply, each single-phase installation should be phys-  
ically separated.  
*Audiovisual \(AV\) rack room*  
Space will also be required for the AV racks, either as a stand-alone  
facility or combined within the dimmer room.  
*Sound control positions*  
The sound control room needs to be centrally located within the  
auditorium in an open enclosure, where the operator has an unin-  
terrupted view of the performance area as well as being able to  
hear the performance. The room contains a control desk, equipment  
racks, monitor loudspeakers and worktop for scripts. The minimum  
size is 3 m wide, 4.4 m deep and 3 m high.  
*Auditorium sound-mixing position*  
This is for the mixing of amplified sound from the stage by an  
operator who needs to hear the same sound as the audience. The **15-30 Auditoria**  
**15.53** *Control room with direct view of the stage\: a\) Section; b\) Vertical sightlines*  
area needs to be flat and set within the seating area\: minimum area  
of 2 × 2 m, but may be significantly larger, to accommodate the  
sound-mixing desk and protective surrounding barriers. In a tour-  
ing venue/receiving house, the large and heavy mixing desk and  
other equipment may be changed over with each visiting show, so  
access to these positions will need some thought. Fixed seats can  
get damaged when the equipment is carried over them; removable  
seats need time to detach, remove and replace again \(as well as  
needing space for the storage of removed seats\).  
*TV, radio and recording control room*  
This is a separate soundproof control room, with a viewing window  
into the auditorium and clear view of the stage. It will accommo-  
date announcers and staff for balancing and directing transmissions  
and recording. A minimum area of 2 × 2 m is required, but should  
be larger.  
*Observation room*  
Those associated with production may need to check the show  
being performed on the stage from a room at the rear of the audi-  
torium, with a clear view of the stage through an observation  
window, minimum area, 2 × 2 m.  
# 7 STAGE HOUSE  
# 7.1 Introduction  
The stage house is a highly technical area of the theatre that has been  
transformed in recent years by digital technology and sophisticated  
communication and control systems. Continuing technological  
development and improved safe working practices mean that the  
input of suitably qualified theatre consultants to advise on the  
design and operation of these areas is essential.  
The stage house refers to\:  
• The main performance area  
• Flytower  
• Wings on each side of the stage  
• Side and rear stages \(if provided\).  
The stage house of a proscenium stage theatre is about the set-  
ting up and changing of scenery and lighting and must be made as  
easy and as flexible as possible. Scenery may be moved during a  
performance to make way for a new production. The movement  
of sets or scenery and lighting can be horizontal into the wings on  
either side or into a rear stage. It can also be vertical up into the  
flytower or vertical down into a stage basement. **Auditoria 15-31**  
Space at stage level and in and around the surrounding areas  
is at a premium, so very careful planning is needed to ensure the  
whole area is as operationally efficient as possible.
