# 7.2 Proscenium stage without flytower  
For smaller auditorium spaces without a flytower, simpler sus-  
pension systems for the suspension of scenery, curtains, pelmets,  
borders and lighting barrels above the stage, see Figure 15.54, will  
be required. Suspension lines can be fitted to pulleys or blocks  
mounted in a limited height grid, which enables certain forms of  
flying from a side gallery above the stage or from the stage level.  
Side stages are required for stacking spaces for flats, properties and  
rostra, as well as circulation routes within the stage area, particu-  
larly for use as a stage crossover at the rear of the stage.  
*Raised stage*  
The height of the stage can be between 600 mm and 1100 mm with  
a straight, angled or curved front edge to the stage. The floor to the  
performance area, in part or total, may be constructed as a series of  
modular traps, typically in 1200 mm square panels, which can be  
removed selectively.  
# 7.3 Proscenium stage with flytower  
The dimensions and shape of the performance area are deter-  
mined by the recommended proscenium opening as in Table X.  
A wider opening can be reduced by soft masking or curtains, so  
that an all-purpose stage should be sized for the largest production.  
Ideally, the depth of the performance area from front to rear should  
be equal to the proscenium opening.  
*Side and rear stages*  
The side and rear stage areas should relate to the size of the per-  
formance area. These areas may need to hold sets of the same size  
and scale as used in the performance area, with clear circulation  
space all round. The clear height of side and rear stage areas should  
be as high as the highest scenery that might be needed plus 1 m  
clearance.

*Stage basement*  
The space under the stage should be fully accessible with a mini-

*Safety curtain*  
Historically, the stage area has been regarded as a high fire risk  
area and the practice of separating the stage house from the rest  
of the theatre by use of a fire safety curtain has been a strategy  
that is becoming less relevant today dependent on the fire strategy  
adopted for the venue. The normal form of a fire safety curtain  
is a rigid fire resisting shutter suspended immediately behind the  
proscenium opening and dropping on the stage from the flytower;  
see Figure 15.55. The fire seal must continue below stage level and  
around the overlap with the orchestra pit.  
Examples of existing flytower stages are shown in Figures  
15.56, 15.57, 15.58.  
# 7.4 Stage machinery  
Large dedicated buildings such as opera houses are equipped with  
highly engineered and sophisticated stage machinery to facilitate  
the manipulation of a wide variety of scenic effects.  
*Bridges*  
These are long lifts which span the width of the proscenium  
opening, giving a rise and fall facility over the main acting area.  
Typically, they are driven by screw jacks, scissor lifts, spiral lifts,  
chain hoists, hydraulic systems or other heavy lifting equipment.  
*Revolving stages*  
These need to be set into the stage floor to provide a flush sur-  
face with the surrounding stage floor, but this can sometimes be  
arranged to coincide with the system of lifts and bridges.  
*Wagon stages*  
These are large pallets capable of taking an entire stage set, which  
may be moved into place behind the proscenium fully constructed,  
thereby saving time and labour during the performance turnaround  
period. If wagon stages are used, sound generated in off-stage areas  
needs to be isolated from the main stage area. Depending on the  
flying configuration, up to three stage wagon positions \(left, right  
and upstage\) may be held in off-stage areas for immediate deploy-  
ment. It is also possible to mount revolves into wagon stages to be  
brought into use when required for particular productions. Much  
larger theatrical installations have even extended the wagon princi-  
ple so that they are used as a system of gigantic palletised storage to  
store up to a dozen or more sets fully erected in large spaces below  
the stage, with provision being made to have them lowered below  
the stage surface on large stage elevators.

# 7.5 Flytower  
The flytower allows full height stage scenery and lighting bars to  
be raised or ‘flown’ out of view into the tower above the stage.  
With traditional rope sets or winches operated by hand from a gal-  
lery well above the stage level, the load of the scenery is directly  
suspended and so there is no reason for counterweights to obstruct  
the full width of the wings. In counterweight systems, the load of  
the scenery is counterbalanced by weights to relieve the direct load  
needed to move scenery and lights up and down.  
It is essential that the means of suspension can be lowered to the  
stage floor. Depending on the frequency of usage, this suspension  
system can either be winched, or in smaller installations be operated  
using rope hand lines. In the theatre, all items suspended overhead  
are ‘flown’. The space above the stage is referred to as the ‘flies’.  
The greater the height over the stage is usually considered better,  
offering greater flexibility for designers both of scenic and lighting  
disciplines. Where the scenic suspension system is raised consider-  
ably above the stage, it can then be described as a flytower.  
Conventionally, the clear height of the flytower was 2½ times  
the proscenium height. Nowadays greater heights are usually  
demanded, with a minimum of 2½ times the proscenium height to  
the underside of the grid and a clear 2 m above the grid.  
There are two main means of suspension – counterweight and  
powered systems.  
*Counterweight systems*  
Counterweight flying systems have largely replaced ropes and hand  
winches in larger theatres. The load on a flying bar is counterbal-  
anced by weights located in a cradle running vertically in guides  
on the side wall of the stage house. It is usual to only install cradles  
on one side of the stage, thereby freeing up the other side for stage-  
level access.  
There are two types of counterweight system\:  
• Single-purchase counterweights where the travel distance is  
equal to the height of the grid above the stage\: a continuous ver- tical wall running higher than the grid is required for the guides;  
see Figure 15.59.  
• Double-purchase counterweights where the distance travelled by  
the counterweights is halved in relation to the distance of the  
suspension; see Figure 15.60. This allows the operation to occur  
from a gallery above the stage level\: an extra loading gallery  
is necessary between the flying gallery and grid. In mechanical  
terms, double-purchase systems are less efficient than sin-  
gle-purchase, but allow wing space at stage level to be clear of  
the counterweight systems.  
*Power flying systems*  
These are becoming increasingly affordable in the modern theatre  
and obviate the need for space for the cradles at stage level by con-  
taining the entire system at the very highest point in the building,  
opening up the possibility of side stages on either side.  
It is important to locate flyfloors either side of the flytower to  
provide horizontal access above the nominal height of the scen-  
ery. These are used by technicians to locate and control horizontal  
movement of vertically suspended components. If the building is  
likely to have dedicated usage by a single-occupancy user, then  
certain suspension positions may be dedicated for lighting systems,  
**15.59** *Section through flytower showing single-purchase flying*  
*system permitting only one side stage*  
**15.60** *Section showing double-purchase flying system and side*  
*stages*  
# Auditoria 15-33  
**15.61** *Cross-section showing rear stage*  
in which case a special provision may be made for horizontal access  
by personnel to reach these positions as well as their lowering and  
raising facilities. It will also be possible to feed the necessary elec-  
trical supply from directly above the position in a self-monitoring  
system, which caters for the vertical movement. Figure 15.61  
shows a flytower stage with a rear stage.  
The grid above the stage from where the suspensions come  
should provide clear walking space above for personnel to move  
about over the floor area. The received wisdom is to place the pul-  
leys supporting the suspension bridge at the high point with the  
walking grid space below it. The key to overhead suspension is the  
load and the frequency of suspension points. Multi-use, intensively  
used venues will have bars suspended every 200 mm with load  
capacity up to 500 kgf per bar. Less intensively used installations  
may have bars 300 mm apart and, depending on the nature of the  
performance to be given, the load capacity may come down to 350  
kgf per bar.  
An automatic smoke vent is required at the top of the flytower\:  
regulations require the cross-sectional area of the vent to be a par-  
ticular proportion of the stage – usually 10 per cent. Alternatively,  
fire-rated mechanical ventilation can also be used.  
# 7.6 Orchestra pit  
A basic requirement of the orchestra pit is the ability of the con-  
ductor to be seen both by the singers and dancers on the stage, and  
by the musicians in the pit. In turn, the conductor needs to be able  
to judge the timing of the production on the stage in order to pace  
the musical accompaniment, so his or her eye level should be no  
lower than the stage floor. For the audience, the requirement is for a  
balanced sound level from the orchestra to match the performance  
on the stage.  
An orchestra pit for a large opera house may need to accom-  
modate up to 120 musicians, while pits in historic theatres may  
accommodate in the order of 60–70 players. In contemporary the-  
atres designed, for example, for musical theatre or contemporary  
dance, the need may be to accommodate no more than 10–12 people.  
Sound levels for musicians playing within an orchestra pit can  
be extremely high and in excess of 80 dBs, so there is concern over  
preventing hearing damage. Spatial standards and the design of  
orchestra pits need to balance the often limited space available with  
the need for musicians to be able to perform effectively. There are  
many factors that conflict\: increasing space between musicians and  
sound screens versus close proximity needed for ensemble play-  
ing; more musicians forward of the stage front versus their sound  
swamping the singers on the stage; greater depth under the stage for  
sound dissipation versus sightlines to the conductor. It is no longer  
acceptable to leave the design of the pit to chance. As a general  
guide, an allowance of 1.7 m2 should be provided for musicians in **15-34 Auditoria**  
open space and up to 2.8 m2 in enclosed areas, 5 m2 for a piano and  
up to 10 m2 for tympani and percussion. Around 4 m2 should be  
allowed for the conductor. To minimise the gulf between stage and  
audience, the pit can extend under the stage front for a distance that  
is ideally no greater than 2 m.  
In opera houses, the pit is generally a fixed feature. In other the-  
atres, where drama and other performance types are programmed,  
the pit can act as a gulf breaking down the actor – audience rela-  
tionship, so there is benefit in having some form of adaptability  
in the pit zone. Such adaptability can be arranged through the use  
of forestage elevators or more rudimentary means where elevators  
cannot be afforded. See *Orchestra pit and forestage*, section 3.39  
These can provide\:  
• A fore stage when elevated  
• Two or three extra rows of seating when level with the audito-  
rium floor  
• An orchestra pit when in the down position.  
See also Figure 15.21 earlier.  
*Stage manager’s desk*  
This is traditionally located stage left \(facing the audience\) and is pro-  
vided as a communications and control position for the stage manager,  
which includes public address, safety curtain and/or drencher release,  
flytower vent release and communication with lighting and sound  
technicians, fly gallery, conductor, etc. as well as cueing performers.  
*Stage manager’s office*  
The stage manager needs a small office in the immediate vicinity of  
the stage where he or she can manage the technical administration  
of the theatre.  
# 7.8 Spaces for actors, singers and dancers  
• *Dressing rooms*\: arrangements are illustrated in Figures 15.62 to  
15.70 covering single shared and communal occupancy rooms  
• *Green room with kitchen and server*\: 3.4 m2 per occupant  
• *Laundry for repair and maintenance of costumes*\: 20 m2 minimum  
• *Costume store, including skips and rails*  
• *Costume delivery*  
• *Specialist make-up room*\: 10 m2 minimum per person  
• *Pre-performance practice room\(s\) \(singers\)*\: 15 m2 minimum  
• *Pre-performance dance studio \(dancers\)*\: 1000 m2 minimum  
• *Physiotherapy room \(dancers\)*\: 15 m2 minimum  
• *Wig store and hairdresser’s room*\: 5–10 m2  
• *Waiting area* for visitors and dressers  
• *Offices*\: children’s supervisor, company manager, touring man-  
ager, etc. 10 m2 minimum per office  
• *Toilets*  
• *Performers’ assembly areas*\: at points of entry to stage.  
# 7.7 Stage-related spaces  
*Quick change*  
Separate rooms immediately off the stage may be required, each  
with two make-up positions and hanging rails. Where this is not  
possible, separate temporary cubicles may be set up in the wings or  
an alternative space used for quick changes.  
*Properties room*  
This is a store room, opening directly off a side stage for properties  
for use during a performance. It requires a sink with hot and cold  
running water.  
*Scene dock*  
This should be at the same level as the stage for storage of scenery.  
*Loading bay or get-in*  
A loading bay or *get-in* is needed for the delivery of scenery and  
properties into the scene dock. Allow for more than one pantechni-  
con to reverse up to the loading. A weather cover can be desirable  
during inclement weather, while some means of preventing the  
warmth from the stage area escaping to the outside during winter  
months should also be considered.  
In city centre locations, the loading bay may need to be fully  
enclosed with sound insulation, as get-ins and get-outs can take  
place during unsocial hours. However, this is often difficult to  
incorporate with turning circles for large vehicles and operating  
space to the sides for opening truck or container doors.  
*Scenery*  
A repair and maintenance area for scenery located near the stage  
is desirable to maintain scenery and properties in use on the stage.  
*Piano store*  
Grand pianos are delicate instruments, which should be provided  
with a suitable store when not in use. A separate room kept at a  
temperature similar to stage conditions should be provided – a min-  
imum area 4.5 × 3.5 m is required.  
*Lighting and electrical equipment store*  
An electrical equipment store is required with direct access off the  
wing space for the storing of lanterns, leads and electrical equip-  
ment. Lanterns can sometimes be stored at high level in areas off  
the lighting bridges.  
*Sound equipment*  
Storage and maintenance space is required for such items as micro-  
phones, speakers, stands, etc.  
# 7.9 Spaces for musicians  
• *Changing rooms*\: at least two rooms  
• *Musical instruments store*\: large instruments and their cases  
• *Pre-performance practice room\(s\)*  
• *Musicians’ common room*\: 3.4 m2 per occupant  
• *Conductor’s room*  
• *Offices\: orchestra manager, tour manager, etc*.  
• *Musicians’ assembly area*\: at point of entry to orchestra pit.

# 8 CONCERT HALLS  
# 8.1 Introduction  
Concert halls provide an auditoria space specifically for practice  
and performance of classical music including symphonic concerts,  
chamber music and recitals. Most concert halls also accommodate  
a wider range of amplified and contemporary music. Concert halls  
typically seat audiences of 1500 to 2000. Audience size is at an  
optimum at around 1800 seats, beyond which acoustic excellence  
becomes more difficult to achieve. Recital halls are used for  
smaller-scale performance of classical music, typically to audi-  
ences of 200 to 600.  
There are two broad approaches to the design of concert halls  
and include the shoebox form and the vineyard form. The vine-  
yard form is typified by the Berlin Philharmonie, designed by Hans  
Scharoun and completed in 1963. The shoebox form is the more  
widely adopted. The double cube proportion of the space provides  
good lateral surfaces for strong sound reflection and spatial artic-  
ulation of the musical instruments, which enhances the listening  
experience.  
# 8.2 Layout  
The general layout configurations are shown in Figure 15.71. For  
orchestral and choral classical music in concert hall or recital room  
there are three broad categories of relationships between audience  
and platform; see Figure 15.72a–c\:  
• Audience focused towards the orchestra and choir on the plat-  
form, with or without choir stalls, in a single direction; see  
Figure 15.72a  
**15.71** *Relationship diagram for buildings for orchestral and choral classical music with choir stalls, and for jazz and pop/rock music*  
*without choir stalls* • Audience on three sides semi-surrounding the platform; see  
Figure 15.72b  
• Audience surrounding the platform; see Figure 15.72c.  
Types of single-direction relationship include the rectangular box  
as in the diagrams shown and variations on the rectangular box.  
The rectangular box is a simple well-established form. It allows full  
cross-reflection of audience, is central to the platform and receives  
a good sound balance. The fan-shaped auditorium is a particular  
variation on the rectangular box but suffers from the lack of side-  
and cross-reflection. Other shapes include elliptical spaces. These  
should be avoided, as concave shapes within the auditorium tend  
to focus sound creating unbalanced and unwanted concentrations  
of sound.  
# 8.3 Acoustic design considerations  
It is important that every member of the audience hears the per-  
formance clearly without colouration and that the performers can  
hear each other to enable them to play as an ensemble. The acous-  
tic dimension of a space is determined by the relative differences  
between the direct sound path and reflected sound. Acoustically  
reflective surfaces in the appropriate locations and distances from  
both musicians and audience are necessary to disperse and generate  
the sound heard.  
The volume of the room has a direct bearing on the reverbera-  
tion time and it is important that this is established at the outset with  
suitably qualified acoustic consultants. For music, the reverbera-  
tion time should be in the order of two seconds. Clarity of sound  
needed for speech intelligibility is less important than reverberance  
and envelopment of sound. As an initial guide, the volume of the  
room should be in the order of 10 m3 per audience member.  
# 8.4 Seating arrangements  
While it is important that members of the audience can see the  
musicians on the platform, in contrast to seating for drama, steeper  
rakes tend to absorb too much sound energy. Shallow rakes that  
allow the sound path to graze the heads of the audience tend to  
provide a better result in auditoria for music. Auditorium spaces  
for music, in contrast to drama theatres, should enjoy a sense of  
space, openness and even natural daylight illuminating the space.  
This can also be helped by the use of more comfortable seating,  
which should be as acoustically neutral as possible whether occu-  
pied or not and more space allowed between the front row and the  
platform.  
# 8.5 Platform design  
The music components include orchestra platform, choir stalls and  
organ; see Figure 15.73.  
Platform design relates to orchestra size\:  
• Symphony orchestra and choir  
• Symphony orchestra, 80–120 musicians  
• Chamber orchestra, 40–50 musicians  
• Small ensemble.  
**15.72** *Relationships between audience and platform in various*  
*rectangular formats\: a\) Single direction; b\) Audience partially*  
*surrounding the platform; c\) Audience surrounding the platform.*  
*With or without rear and side balconies*  
# Auditoria 15-37  
**15.73** *Components of the platform for classical music*  
The traditional layout of the orchestra prescribes a broadly  
semi-circular form with, facing the audience, the violins, violas and  
smaller stringed instrument sections arranged on the left, the larger  
stringed sections comprising cellos and bass on the right and the  
woodwind section located mid-centre. Progressing towards the rear  
are the brass sections and then percussion and timpani at the back,  
the strength of sound from each section determining their position  
on the platform.  
For larger orchestras, a series of tiered steps at the rear of the  
platform raises the rear sections of the orchestra to increase visibil-  
ity and sound projection. When the orchestra with all its members is  
laid out in plan, the width of the orchestra is the critical dimension  
that must be provided to accommodate the orchestra on the plat-  
form, while the depth might be around one-half times the radius.  
Thus, larger orchestras will require a proportionately wider plat-  
form, which can be up 18 m for a full-scale symphonic orchestra  
of 120 players.  
By following the accepted principle for laying out an orchestra  
and the number of musicians to be included, this will determine the  
width of the platform and hence the minimum width of the audi-  
torium.  
For a chamber orchestra, the platform can be 8 m deep, 12 m  
wide; for a full orchestra an area of 18 × 12 m. Various configura-  
tions are shown in Figure 15.74 and a section in Figure 15.75.  
# 8.6 Areas for individual musicians  
• Violin players and small wind instruments\: 1200 × 750 mm  
• Cellos and bass\: 1500 × 1000 mm  
• Horns and bassoons\: 1000 × 800 mm  
• Trombones and large brass instruments\: 1350 × 1000 mm.  
These dimensions include music stands, but on a tiered riser, addi-  
tional space should be allowed for to provide a safe margin\:  
• Strings, brass, and woodwind players, including cellos and dou-  
ble base\: 1500 mm tiers  
• Percussion\: up to 2 m tiers  
• Concert grand piano\: 2.75 × 1.6 m tiers  
• Choir\: 0.38 m2 minimum per singer in choir stalls with bench  
seats, although when not used by the choir, these seats may be  
sold as audience seats and more space should be allowed. The  
longitudinal section can be flat and stepped transversely, rising  
from the conductor’s rostrum. **15-38 Auditoria**

# 9.1 Introduction  
The conference industry is adapting to a world of ever-greater con-  
nectivity and technological facility. Branding and more individual  
presentational styles are playing increasingly significant roles, and  
the ability of the venue to be able to present itself accordingly for  
each event is becoming more important, particularly in the com-  
mercial sector.  
Front-of-house areas need to be able to greet conference mem-  
bers and delegates, have space for registration and badging, issue  
programmes and conference packs, have space for exhibitions  
and presentational material of sponsors and promoters, be able to  
deposit coats and bags, to use the toilets, provide refreshment and  
circulation areas for members to be able to assemble and network,  
all before going into the conference hall.  
Conferences are often broken into a series of sessions inter-  
spersed throughout a day with more refreshment during breaks, as  
well as meals during lunch breaks. The duration of conferences  
generally extends over a longer time period during the day \(and  
evenings\) and may need to accommodate people coming and going  
throughout the period. Breakout spaces for separate sessions and  
smaller group meetings are often also needed. Staff areas will  
need to be equipped with space for laptops or computers, print-  
ers, telephones, etc., while filming or recording and transmitting  
of conference events is becoming a more common part of many  
larger-scale events.  
# 9.2 Formats  
Conference halls are designed for speech where audience members  
are also able to communicate openly with speakers or presenters on  
the platform. Speech and communication are generally supported  
by amplified sound and AV aids, with presentation from a laptop or  
tablet computer. The platform on which speakers are located gener-  
ally shares the same space as the audience, although other auditoria  
spaces may be adapted to suit.  
Formats depend on use\:  
• *Traditional lecture theatre formats*\: The audience is focused  
towards a platform on which there is provision for a speaker  
or speakers, possibly served by a range of AV aids; see Figure  
15.76\. The speaker is the controlling point with the audience  
in a receptive role. Video projection, white boards and other  
presentation/communication formats tend to limit the extent of  
encirclement of the platform, although multiple screens angled  
towards all parts of the audience can compensate.  
• *Debating formats*\: Participation by each member of the audi-  
ence suggests the debating formats of semi-circle, U*-*shape and  
circle, controlled by a chairperson, see Figure 15.77. Video  
recording and live projection of speakers and participants onto  
large screens or monitors is increasingly used to allow partic-  
ipants to be viewed in greater detail to a wider audience. The  
need for equal distribution and viewing of all delegates’ facial  
expressions is important, particularly in political formats, so  
that delegates can be aware of the spoken contribution of each.  
Public viewing galleries for non-participants can be provided.  
**15.76** *Conference hall formats for lectures requiring projection*  
*facilities\: a\) Rectangular with or without rear balcony; b\) 60° fan*  
*with or without rear balcony*  
# Auditoria 15-39  
**15.77** *Conference hall formats for debating\: a\) Fan with 180°*  
*arc \(US Senate\); b\) Audience in two facing banks \(House of*  
*Commons\)*  
The plan shape of the conference hall can be\:  
• Rectangular  
• Fan-shaped, with angles of 135°, 90° or 60° \(the last is best for  
screening\)  
• Hexagonal  
• Circular  
• Oval  
• Coffin.  
# 9.3 Functional requirements  
With the lecture format, functional requirements include\:  
• The audience needs to see and hear the speaker, chairperson and  
panel of speakers in the various positions on the platform  
• They need a clear view of screens and other visual displays  
• Acoustic clarity of sound listening to speaker and reproduced  
through speaker systems  
• Ability to view presentations and any demonstrations.  
Debating format functional requirements include\:  
• Awareness of the whole audience by every member  
• The audience able to hear all speakers and chairperson  
• A clear view of the chairperson and, ideally, to be able to see  
each member speaking, which can be assisted by AV means  
• An example of a facility used only for lecturing is shown in  
Figure 15.78.  
# 9.4 Seating design  
Seating design for conference use is covered in Section 4, Seating.  
# 9.5 Technical requirements  
The technical infrastructure needs to be able to accommodate the  
regular updates in the technology used in the presentation of con-  
ferences, lectures and events. Satellite communication systems and  
live digital broadcasting, for example, is becoming an important  
part of major events.  
To take advantage of lucrative commercial opportunities, the  
following services must be available.  
*Adjustable lighting*  
In conferences and events, good lighting levels are needed so that  
delegates and users can read conference material as well as being  
able to see conference participants and projection screens. Users  
should have control over lighting levels and the ability to focus  
lights in individual areas. For certain presentations, there may also  
be a benefit in providing the capability of a colour wash, for exam-  
ple by using LEDs to provide red, green, blue, yellow, etc.  
*AV capabilities*  
The majority of conferences and events rely heavily on AV equip-  
ment. To support this, there may be a need for a control room or  
position for technical staff to control the AV systems. **15-40 Auditoria**  
**15.78** *Lady Mitchell Hall, Cambridge. A large lecture theatre for 450 students. Architects\: Casson, Conder and Partners\: a\)*  
*Longitudinal section; b\) Plan of auditorium*  
In fully equipped conference halls, each person in the audience  
may be provided with\:  
• Voting buttons\: yes, no and abstain  
• Simultaneous translation headphones  
• Headphones for the hard of hearing  
• Illumination to read.  
The following is normally provided to be shared by two adja-  
cent participants\:  
• Microphone controlled by the chairperson from the platform  
• Button for ‘request-to-speak’.  
In less sophisticated or smaller-scale venues, AV facilities,  
including sound reinforcement, can provide the base technical  
requirements, while interactive participation might be managed  
with roaming microphones.  
*Internet and wireless access*  
Most people expect some form of connectivity, but participants  
and organisers may need to connect to the internet to retrieve  
important files and documents for their presentations. Adequate  
power points should be available for the speakers to plug in their  
laptops.  
Multi-national organisations may want to conduct live link-ups  
during the conference. Good quality internet is also needed to ena-  
ble the audience to use the internet and stream content.  
# 9.6 Platform  
The size and shape will depend on the extent of AV aids, lectern,  
demonstration table, panel table and other equipment as well as  
sightlines and size and shape of auditorium.  
The platform may need to accommodate only a single speaker at  
one time, with AV, white board and electronic display systems. In  
other cases, it will need to allow for scientific demonstrations, a panel  
of speakers with or without a lectern, or major presentations as with  
commercial, political and institutional organisations. For major politi-  
cal conferences, there can be as many as 50 people to accommodate on  
the platform. Means of access onto the platform from the auditorium  
will be required for speakers or panellists seated in the auditorium.  
The setting about the platform can be an architectural setting  
common to all types of presentations or a shell in which complete  
new settings can be constructed for each conference.  
# 9.7 Lectern  
This is the normal position for the speaker. The design of the lec-  
tern, see Figure 15.79, may vary to suit the interior design, but the  
ergonomic requirements are generally consistent. While the techni-  
cal capability of the venue may be sophisticated, controls should be  
clear and simple to enable the speaker to focus on the presentation  
and not be distracted by complexity.  
# 9.8 Other platform facilities  
*Demonstration bench*  
A ‘laboratory’ fully-serviced bench on the platform for the scien-  
tific demonstrations, with the supply of electricity, gas, water and **Auditoria 15-41**  
**15.79** *Lectern\: a\) Section; b\) Plan*  
drainage. The bench should be able to be wheeled off the platform  
if it is to be used for non-demonstration presentations, with plug-in  
services. The bench can be stored in the adjacent side preparation  
room.  
*Panel table*  
For discussion and presentations by a panel of speakers and a chair-  
person, a long table, parallel to the front edge of the platform, is a  
recognised format, with a chair and microphone for each panellist,  
and possibly simultaneous translation earphones. The table should  
be at least 750 mm deep, allowing 1 m length for each person. The  
name and details of each panellist may be mounted on the front  
edge of the table or on a stand in front of each. The lectern may or  
may not be used.  
*Platform setting*  
This may be a permanent enclosure with curtains, masking or slid-  
ing panels incorporated to mask sections of the side and rear walls.  
Alternatively, there may be a shell with rear and side walls and  
equipment constructed for a particular conference. This is similar  
to theatre open stage with suspension over the platform for setting  
and lighting. Coloured lighting or projections of images or logos  
may be used to enhance the scene setting for conference or pres-  
entation.  
*Signing*  
Signing can be undertaken by a signer in a prominent and clearly  
visible place on the platform to translate the speaker’s words into  
sign language, or through words projected onto a digital screen  
located on or around the platform.  
# 9.9 Translators’ booths  
Conferences with international audiences will probably require  
simultaneous interpretation by translators in booths of those speak-  
ing in various languages.  
Booths need to be located at the rear or perhaps the side of  
the auditorium with an unobstructed view by the translator of the  
speaker, chairperson, projection screens and chalkboards as well as  
any visual display. The booths are soundproofed, with the transla-  
tor listening to the speech on headphones.  
Booths should be located side by side with acoustic isolation  
and small connecting windows. They should open off a corridor  
giving discrete but secure access from the public areas. Booth inte-  
rior should have absorbent material to walls, floor and ceiling, in  
dark matt colours.  
Each booth needs to be able to accommodate two or three seated  
persons, minimum size 6.5 m wide and 6.4 m deep. The soundproof  
observation window can be the full width of the booth, 800 mm  
high, and may be inclined to avoid acoustic reflections on either  
side. The translators need a clear working surface 500 mm wide in  
front of the window for scripts, notes, microphone, channel-selec-  
tion buttons, indicator lights, etc.  
*Simultaneous translation systems in the auditorium*  
Available methods are\:  
• Induction loop\: magnetic field transmission generated by a con-  
ductor looped around the auditorium; conference delegates have  
portable receivers  
• Infra-red\: modulated light signals radiated from a number of  
sources; delegates have portable receivers  
• Hard-wired\: cable within underfloor trunking connected to pan-  
els in armrest or back of each seat for heavily used conference  
facilities.  
# 9.10 Audiovisual facilities  
*Control room*  
This is a limited requirement for conferences, but lighting control  
could be incorporated into a projection room at the rear of the audi-  
torium, minimum size 2 × 3.5 m. In some cases, a dimmer room  
may be needed \(see Section 6.3\).  
*Sound control room*  
In this case, an open room preferably at the rear of the auditorium  
adjacent to the lighting control room, minimum size 2 × 3.5 m.  
Here the amplified sound from one or more speakers can be mixed  
and balanced. The sound control desk may alternatively be situated  
within the auditorium.  
*Screens and projectors*  
Projectors are usually mounted at high level in the auditorium, on  
stands or behind the screen, Close-range projectors can produce  
pictures up to 3 m high; they should be 3.5 to 3.6 times the picture  
width from the screen.  
There are special projectors which can be much closer to screens  
nowadays. These include short throw and ultra short throw projec-  
tors that allow users to create big pictures in tight spaces without  
concerns about shadows obstructing the image or light shining in  
the presenter’s face.  
These projectors have very short throw ratios – the distance  
from projector to screen compared to the screen size. While a reg-  
ular projector with a 1.5\:1 throw ratio would have to be 7.5 feet  
back to project a 60-inch wide image, a short throw projector with  
a throw ratio of 0.6\:1 can project the same image when placed less  
than 3 feet away from the screen. An ultra short throw projector  
with a 0.37\:1 throw ratio can project the same image from just 1.85  
feet away.  
For a large screen, a long-range projector can be used to pro-  
duce a picture up to 7.5 m high. It should be housed in a projection **15-42 Auditoria**  
**15.80** *Video projector mounted at high level in auditorium. More*  
*recent projectors are likely to be of different dimensions. Noise*  
*generated by the projector must also be checked*  
room because of background noise levels generated by the equip-  
ment. For less powerful equipment and a shorter projection throw,  
a projector can be mounted or suspended from the ceiling; see  
Figure 15.80\. For small conference and seminar rooms, digital  
monitors can be used.  
Where films are screened, digital projection predominates.  
A facility for 35 mm film projection may be retained in auditoria  
screening archive material. Film projection in 16 mm and 8 mm is  
now uncommon, as video has taken its place in the majority of cases.  
*Television and digital film recording*  
Conferences are frequently televised and recorded. Speakers and  
demonstrations are often projected on large screens both within  
the main conference hall and in overflow venues. Digital cam-  
era recorders are now very compact and lightweight and usually  
mobile, but require suitable floor surfaces for tripods in low light.  
A room may be required for recording and editing purposes, but  
this may not need direct vision of the conference and could in fact  
be a remote studio.  
*Voting panel*  
This is a panel indicating electronically the numbers voting by  
pressing buttons at each seat, mounted above the platform and con-  
trolled by the chairperson.  
# 9.11 Platform\: associated spaces  
• Ante-room\: reception and waiting areas for conference chairper-  
son and speakers, with lounge, changing facilities and toilets;  
sound and light lobby onto platform; access for guests from pub-  
lic areas  
• Preparation room\: preparation of scientific and other demonstra-  
tions in room immediately off the platform  
• Studios\: television, film and still photography preparation  
• Recording room\: separate facility linked to the auditorium and  
platform sound system for the recording of the conference pro-  
ceedings.  
# 9.12 Conference organisation offices  
• Offices with desks and chairs  
• General office, with desks and chairs, telephones, photocopier,  
computers, good internet connection and space for administra-  
tive work.  
# 9.13 Press room  
• General room\: desks and chairs, telephones, good internet con-  
nection  
• Television and radio interview rooms.  
# 10 CINEMAS  
# 10.1 Types of film and method of projection  
Cinema projection was traditionally film-based but has now been  
replaced by high definition, digital projection technologies in most  
cinemas with a few retaining 35 mm/70 mm projectors alongside  
digital projectors. There has been an overall shift to digital cinema  
as the standard, with film formats relegated to secondary impor-  
tance except for specialist venues. The shift to digital projection  
has led to a surge in neighbourhood cinemas and the creative adap-  
tation of existing buildings for cinema use.  
The majority of films are now screened in Flat screen format or  
in Scope format with very few films released in the old Academy  
format.  
Film projection in cinemas normally uses 35 mm film but can  
also use 70 mm or 16 mm \(generally for smaller or specialised  
cinemas\). Large formats such as IMAX use special 15 perforation  
70 mm film projection systems to produce very wide and tall screen  
images. Both film and digital projection systems can be adapted to  
produce 3D images. The various film and digital projection types  
are shown in Table XI.  
# 10.2 Methods of projection  
There are five methods of cinema projection\:  
• Direct projection from the rear of the auditorium onto the screen  
from a projection or control room. This is the most common  
method by far.  
• Direct projection from the centre or rear of the auditorium onto  
the screen, from an acoustically isolated and ventilated pod  
mounted from the ceiling or rear wall of the auditorium. There  
are new models of digital projector that can be mounted in an  
auditorium without the need for enclosing them in a pod.  
• Indirect film projection, where the projection requires one or  
more mirrors. This method is used where lack of space or struc-  
tural difficulties make direct projection difficult to achieve.  
Mirror projection requires a powerful light source and the  
screen cannot be wider than 9m. This method is not recom-  
mended.  
• Rear projection. This is not possible with a curved screen, but  
may be applicable for a smaller auditorium. For this method, the  
picture needs to be reversed, for which mirrors can be an eco-  
nomic solution when film projection is used. Digital projection  
can reverse an image, so there is no need for mirrors.  
• Direct view screens such as Samsung Onyx. Issues to note are  
the high capital cost, the weight of the screen installation and the  
high heat output. There is an option not to darken the auditorium  
when it is being used for conference use.  
# 10.3 Auditorium design  
Functional requirements include\:  
• Every member of the audience requires an unobstructed view of  
the whole picture area on the screen, without visual and physical  
discomfort or picture distortion.  
• Picture sharpness and luminance should be uniform and at a  
satisfactory level of brightness. Sound reproduction should be  
distortion free.  
• Integration of seating for members of the audience with mobility  
disabilities.  
• Cinema with Premium Large Format \(PLF\) auditoria, such as  
IMAX and Dolby Cinema, have particular requirements for  
projection, sound, seating and auditorium design, which are  
specified by the relevant equipment supplier or cinema opera-  
tor. These types of format could be just a standard large screen  
along with Dolby ATMOS/DTS to immersive formats such as  
4DX with motion seats. Screen X270 degree viewing needs  
additional projectors and surfaces on the side walls that work  
as screens. **Auditoria 15-43**

# 10.4 Viewing conditions  
Viewing criteria are shown in plan, see Figure 15.81a–c; and sec-  
tion, see Figure 15.82b. The size and shape of the screen must be  
related to the shape and rake of the auditorium floor. Seating rake  
is less critical than for concert halls and theatres as the screen can  
be elevated, and sound comes from speakers set behind the screen  
surface.  
*Seating arrangements*  
Few new auditoria are designed with galleries or balconies \(unless  
the auditorium is required for other forms of performance\). Steeply  
tiered stadia seating offers an opportunity for good sightlines onto  
a large screen relative to audience numbers.  
In small auditoria, stadia seating may be arranged in a single  
tier to optimise seating capacity. To provide a choice of seating for  
members of the audience with mobility disabilities, access should  
be provided for wheelchair users to the front and rear rows.  
In larger auditoria, access may be provided onto a cross aisle  
with steeply tiered stadia seating to the rear of the cross aisle and a  
gentle rake to the front rows. A choice of seating position for mem-  
bers of the audience with mobility disabilities can be on the cross  
aisle or in the front row.  
*Seating types*  
A variety of types of seating are now being used. Recliners are  
increasingly being used in multiplexes. Sofas and armchair seats  
are commonly used in boutique cinemas. Dine-in cinemas require  
adequately sized tables at each seat and a kitchen facility to service  
the food offer in the auditoria.  
Expectations of comfort evolve over time. Until recently,  
550 mm seat centres and 1100 mm seat tier widths was considered  
an acceptable benchmark for fixed seating. Currently, 600 mm seat  
centres and 1200 mm seat tier widths are more prevalent as a min-  
imum, with an increasing number of cinemas being fitted out with  
seats at 650 mm centres and 1300 mm seat tier widths.  
Seat tier widths are governed not only by expectations of com-  
fort, but by choice of seat type and statutory requirements for  
minimum clear seatways. Comfortable, fixed seats rather than tip-  
out seats are now prevalent in cinema fit-outs. Sofa seats, either  
combined with fixed seats or used throughout an auditorium, are  
also common.  
To accommodate ‘premium’ armchair or sofa seats offer-  
ing extra comfort, tables and at-seat service, seat tiers of up to  
1500 mm wide may be required. A requirement to accommodate  
cup holders, bottle holders or small tables will influence the choice  
of seat, seat centres and seat tier widths. To accommodate recliner  
seats and seats with small tables for food/drinks, 900 mm seat cen-  
tres and 2000 mm seat tier widths should be anticipated with exact  
dimensions dependant on the choice of seat.  
In multi-use auditoria with a flat floor regularly used for cinema  
screenings, retractable seating systems with straight and curved  
rows, and comfortable cinema style seats are available.  
*Aisle arrangements*  
The maximum number of seats permitted in a row is not only gov-  
erned by viewing criteria but statutory requirements. The aisle  
arrangement and clear seatway are critical factors. The maximum  
number of seats permitted in a row with a single aisle is 12, irre-  
spective of the seatway width. **15-44 Auditoria**  
**15.81** *Projection and viewing criteria for various formats\: a\) 16* *mm film; b\) 35* *mm film; c\) 70 mm film in specialist cinemas* **Auditoria 15-45**  
**15.82** *Projection criteria and vertical sightlines\: a\) 16* *mm and 35* *mm film \(specialist cinemas\); b\) 70 mm film \(specialist cinemas\); c\)*  
*tiered seating with cross aisle \(specialist and digital cinemas\); Projection criteria and vertical sightlines\: d\) stadia seating \(specialist*  
*and digital cinemas\) and projection criteria \(digital cinemas\)* **15-46 Auditoria**  
A single centre aisle is not favoured as it occupies seat posi-  
tions with the best viewing conditions, as well as splitting the  
audience. An offset single aisle provides a more cohesive seating  
arrangement for the audience as a whole and provides an oppor-  
tunity to accommodate seats for couples in the shorter row. The  
provision of two side aisles enables the numbers in a single row  
to be increased.  
It is good practice to avoid entrances at the screen end of the  
cinema, in order to prevent disturbance by latecomers.  
# 10.5 Acoustics for films  
The sound track is an integral part of the audience experience.  
The quality of sound reproduction has vastly improved in recent  
decades, and cinemas are now equipped with many channel sound  
systems which require acoustically dead auditoria – the ideal is a  
zero reverberation time. Hence all finishes – floor, walls, ceiling  
and seats – need to be sound absorbent. Side walls should ideally  
not be parallel, and rear walls should not be curved unless treated  
with absorbent material. The auditorium should be acoustically  
isolated from external noise and structure borne noise. A suitable  
ambient noise standard for cinemas is NR25 to NR30. Air volumes  
will be dependent on occupancy levels in the auditoria.  
# 10.6 Access  
The design of the auditoria should optimise the experience of going  
to the cinema for all members of the audience.  
*Mobility disabilities*  
A choice of position for wheelchair users should be provided. This  
should be integrated within the main body of seating. Suitable posi-  
tions on a level surface may include the front row, cross aisle or  
back row. It should be possible for a wheelchair user to sit next to  
a companion, whether another wheelchair user or not. Wheelchair  
positions should not be limited to the front row, where viewing  
angles are most acute.  
*Visual impairment*  
Space should be provided for a guide dog at the end of a row.  
Facilities for screening films with audio description are based on  
visually impaired audience members collecting headsets before  
entering the auditorium. The headsets operate from one of the  
channels on the infrared or wireless \(RF\) system.  
Low-level lighting on stepped or raking aisles, with the light  
source located out of the line of vision of the screen, is an aid to all  
members of the audience.  
*Aural impairment*  
Facilities may include permanently installed, inductive loop  
systems and/or infra-red/wireless \(RF\) systems. A system of  
superimposing a subtitle \(soft title\) image is also available for the  
profoundly deaf. This system is incorporated into the digital cin-  
ema projector and does not require an additional projection system.  
# 10.7 Lighting  
Auditorium systems such as lighting and curtains activated to start  
and finish a show are usually automated. The automation system  
will also turn off the projector and raise the emergency lights when  
and if required. These services are integrated with the cinema film  
server.  
The different types of lighting which need to be provided within  
a cinema auditorium are\:  
• *House lights*\: Decorative lights which set the ambiance of the  
auditorium when the audience enters and are gradually dimmed  
before the screening.  
• *Curtain lights*\: Highlight the screen curtains/screen surface prior  
to the screening. Colours are usually generated by LED light  
sources.  
• *Primary lighting*\: Powered from the mains supply, this provides  
a low level of lighting during screenings equivalent to the level  
of lighting provided by the secondary emergency lighting in the  
event of mains failure. It is essential that this is no brighter than  
required to meet statutory requirements to avoid distraction dur-  
ing screenings.  
• *Secondary \(emergency\) lighting*\: Powered by a central battery  
or local battery packs this provides a low level of illumination in  
the event of mains failure.  
• *Illuminated emergency exit signs*\: These are dual-fed \(mains  
powered and powered by a central battery or local battery packs\),  
and remain illuminated during screenings and in the event of  
mains failure and an emergency. It is bad practice to locate exits  
and hence illuminated emergency exit signs within the same  
plane or in close proximity to the screen. Illuminated exit signs  
should be selected to minimise disturbance through light spill-  
age during screenings. Preferred models have green legends on a  
black background in a matt black casing. In some cases, the exit  
signs may be dimmable during the main show and come to full  
brightness in case of an emergency or at the end of the show.  
• *Cleaners’ lights*\: House lights that are energy efficient may dou-  
ble up as cleaners’ lights. Alternatively, separate cleaners’ lights  
are installed. These need to be controllable from the projection  
room and/or the usher’s position in the event of an emergency  
\(other than mains failure\), for example a medical emergency.  
• *Speakers’ lights*\: In auditoria, these are used for awards cere-  
monies and panel discussions before or after screenings, or for  
conference use.  
Regard needs to be given to lamp life and ease of changing the  
bulbs when considering the location and specification of all light  
fittings within a cinema auditorium.  
# 10.8 Interiors  
It is good practice for the lighting design and colour scheme on the  
approaches to the auditorium to assist members of the audience to  
adjust to lighting levels within the auditorium. It is also advisable  
to avoid light colours and reflective surfaces within a cinema audi-  
torium, to avoid distraction during screenings. Dark wall coverings  
and seats are ideal to minimise light reflections.  
# 10.9 Screens  
*Shape*  
Film and digital projectors may be required to project material in a  
variety of width-to-height ratios. Digital projection in commercial  
cinemas normally uses two ratios\: Flat 1\:1.85 and Scope 1\:2.39  
Film projection picture formats varied throughout the history of  
cinema but the most frequently encountered are 1\:1.33 \(described  
as 4\:3 in video terminology\) 1\:1.66, 1\:1.85 and 1\:2.39. High defini-  
tion television normally uses a 1\:1.78 ratio \(16\:9 for video\).  
*Size*  
The largest 35 mm screens will usually be less than 18 m in width.  
Digital cinema projectors can now illuminate a picture size in  
excess of 40 m if not larger.  
*Curvature*  
For uniform focus, a large screen should be curved to keep its sur-  
face equidistant from the centre of the lens and improves viewing  
for 3D formats.  
*Luminance*  
Screens may have a matt white surface or a special high reflectivity  
surface \(high gain screens\) that is particularly suitable for larger  
screens where the luminance needs to be enhanced. 3D projection  
systems which rely on polarised spectacles for viewers require a  
high reflectivity surface to maintain the polarised light, although  
these may be less satisfactory for conventional 2D projection. *Position*  
seating.  
The centre of screen should be on the central axis of the auditorium  
*Masking*  
Mechanically adjustable black masking to the sides and top of the  
screen is often provided to contain the picture surface and obtain  
maximum apparent screen brightness. The masking is usually wool  
serge on metal rails, and the motorised pulley system should be  
fixed at floor level for ease of maintenance. Movement is remotely  
controlled from the projection room. It is becoming more of a  
standard to use ‘floating screen frames’ with no masking; the frame  
is dressed in black serge including the bottom picture line. No mov-  
ing masking is used with these type of frames.  
*Unmasked screens*  
Unmasked \(floating frames\) screens are used in many multiplex  
cinemas and some specialised cinemas. They are most suitable  
when used with digital projection systems which can produce a  
‘clean’ picture edge.  
Edge/halo lighting is sometimes used with unmasked screens as  
part of the decorative lighting scheme.  
*Construction*  
Screen material is either PVC or metalised fabric, held by cord lac-  
ing to hooks on a metal lattice frame. Generally, cinema screens  
are perforated to allow high quality sound reproduction from the  
speakers positioned behind the screen. Different sized perforations  
are available. Digital cinema projection and small auditoria usu-  
ally require smaller size perforations. Unperforated screens may  
be used in specific circumstances such as lecture halls. In these  
circumstances, loudspeakers cannot be placed behind the screen  
surface.  
*Temporary screens*  
In some multi-use auditoria, screens may need to be easily and  
conveniently removed. A flat screen up to 10 m wide can be incor-  
porated into a proscenium stage of a theatre and either housed,  
when rolled, above the stage or flown in the flytower. Curved  
screens could be flown, but take up much valuable space in the  
flytower; or they could be stored at the rear of the stage if fitted  
with rollers or castors for ease of movement. Roller screens are not  
recommended for metalised fabric screens \(3D\).  
*Speaker installation*  
The speakers need to be located behind the screen, firmly fixed  
to the platform or screen frame. One speaker is needed for mono-  
phonic sound \(not often used nowadays\). For multi-channel and  
stereophonic sound, three speaker units are necessary – one cen-  
trally placed and the others equidistant from it to the left and right.  
Sound production in 70 mm requires five units symmetrically  
placed about the horizontal axis of the central speaker and the same  
would be said for digital immersive sound systems depending on  
the specifications of said system.  
A sub-woofer low-frequency speaker is usually located cen-  
trally behind the cinema screen. Depending on the installation,  
there could be more than a single sub-woofer. Surround sound sys-  
tems are widely used in cinemas and require a number of small or  
mid-size wall-mounted units on the left, right and rear auditorium  
walls.  
Surround speakers are placed on side and rear walls of audi-  
toria. Immersive sound systems such as Dolby ATMOS/DTS and  
Barco Auro also include speakers in the ceiling directly above the  
audience. These immersive sound systems may have more than 60  
speaker positions located behind the screen, around the walls and  
across the ceiling. Structural support for the array of loud speak-  
ers mounted across the auditorium ceiling will be required. These  
speakers can be embedded within the ceiling but provision must  
# Auditoria 15-47  
be made for the speakers to be angled appropriately. The manu-  
facturer and service company will provide a detailed layout of all  
the speaker positions. This may affect other service provision and  
consultation with the provider should be taken at an early stage.  
*Platform*  
The entire wall surface behind the screen should be covered with  
black tissue-faced insulation. The screen can be set over a platform  
with a forestage, carpeted with black carpet to prevent reflection  
of sound and light. The forestage edge can be vertical, splayed or  
stepped. Some theatres now build baffle walls behind the screen  
that incorporate the theatre stage loudspeakers.  
*Stage for speakers and small-scale performance*  
In cinemas used for speeches or panel discussions before or after  
screenings, awards ceremonies or occasional lecture or confer-  
ences, it should be possible for all audience members to have a  
clear view of the participants’ faces.  
Usually this will require the provision of a raised stage in front  
of the screen, although with steeply tiered stadia seating this may  
not be necessary.  
AV and IT provision at the speaker’s position, linked back to  
the projection room, needs to be considered. On a new installation,  
tie lines should be installed as the norm including Ethernet cables.  
Access to the stage for speakers or panel members with mobil-  
ity disabilities needs to be considered.  
In cinemas seeking to attract young audiences, there is an  
increasing interest in small-scale live performance in conjunction  
with film exhibition.  
*Internet provision*  
Provision should be made for large bandwidth 30/100 mbs internet  
provision for downloading content to the film/library server. High-  
speed fibre lines would be of benefit if available.  
# 10.10 Projection suite  
A projection suite provides space for all the image projection and  
sound reproduction equipment in a cinema. Contemporary cinema  
design aims for a single projection suite to cover all the audito-  
ria. Most cinemas provide automated systems that allow complete  
performances to be screened with minimal staff input. Specialised  
cinemas and lecture halls rely less on automated systems.  
Digital cinema projectors can be installed in a conventional  
projection suite or, especially for smaller auditoria, in an acous-  
tically insulated and ventilated enclosure or pod. Pods for digital  
projectors, other than other than laser projectors also require cool-  
ing. There is a range of proprietary pods available that can either  
be ceiling mounted or mounted on the rear wall of the auditorium.  
There are new smaller models of digital projector which can be  
mounted in the auditorium without an enclosure or pod. Digital  
film storage and playback along with audio equipment can be  
located in the projection suite or in a nearby location such as an  
office or equipment room with appropriate temperature and venti-  
lation control.  
Projection suites and equipment rooms should be secure from  
access by the general public.  
*Digital projection*  
Digital cinema projectors have approximately the same footprint  
as 35 mm projectors, although smaller models are now available.  
2 K and 4 K projectors can achieve image widths up of 40 m or  
more nowadays. 6 P digital laser projectors can achieve 60 m plus  
picture size. There is a cooling requirement for the racks of lasers  
that supply the projector.  
A single projector can be used for 3D projection, but has to  
produce approximately twice the light output as that used for  
2D projection. Two projectors can be used to increase the lumi-  
nance in larger theatres. Some 3D equipment is fitted in front of **15-48 Auditoria**  
the projector lens assembly and requires approximately 500 mm  
from the projection lens to the porthole glass for installation and  
removal.  
There are two types of 3D glasses in use, the disposable and  
reusable. It should be taken into account that glasses should be  
easy to distribute and to collect. The reusable glasses are more  
expensive, and because they have to be handed back to the cinema  
after the screening, anti-theft issues should be taken into account.  
Facilities will be required to clean and store the glasses.  
A typical digital projection system is comprised of\:  
• A projector head, lamphouse and lamp power supply. These are  
usually housed together in a single module.  
• Digital cinema film server and storage system can be rack  
mounted along with the theatre’s sound processor and  
amplification system, or in some cases under the projector’s  
lamphouse. Many digital projectors are supplied with an inte-  
grated media server \(IMS\) which does not require a separate  
media server in most cases, just a network link to a theatre  
management system \(TMS\). Sometimes network storage  
\(NAS\) is added to the IMS if extra storage for more films is  
required.  
• In many cinemas, there is a requirement to play live relays or  
recorded performances of opera, concerts, theatre and dance per-  
formances, gallery and museum tours and other events. Other  
non-cinema uses may comprise of corporate slide presentations  
or video gaming.  
Additional equipment may include\:  
• Multimedia playback box, digital to analogue sound inter-  
face, audio delay, DVD/Blu-Ray playback, satellite dish and  
transcoder for live events and downloading digital cinema and  
live relay content \(‘event cinema’\), space for HD disc player/VR  
playback, monitor and fibre optic cabling.  
Digital cinema projectors require venting at approximately  
600/650 cfm. Projection rooms and projector pods should be  
cooled to approximately 21°C.  
# 11 SUPPORT FACILITIES  
# 11.1 Introduction  
This section covers the front-of-house or publicly accessible areas  
where the audience arrives and assembles before entering the audi-  
torium. It also deals with the facilities that support or enhance the  
public areas and the management of the venue, as well as the back-  
of-house or backstage areas that support the shows and productions  
that are presented in the venue.  
Front-of-house areas need to present a welcoming and enjoya-  
ble place to visit, as well as serving to attract new people. Foyers  
do far more than acting as an area to muster and process audiences  
before entering the auditorium. Increasingly, the whole operation  
of the venue needs to be run like a business in order to sustain  
itself, not only in the evenings prior to a performance, but by pro-  
gramming events throughout the day. In this way, the venue can  
make use of facilities that might otherwise stand idle and can raise  
additional revenue to support the venue.  
In the backstage areas, the cost of mounting shows is also  
an important consideration. Increasingly, more theatre venues  
are unable to support the range of workshop, storage and pro-  
duction areas needed to mount a show. They therefore become  
‘receiving houses’ which rely on outside specialist workshops  
or producing theatres to make the scenery, or otherwise receive  
product or shows created elsewhere. In contrast to ‘receiv-  
ing houses’, ‘producing houses’ are venues for opera, dance,  
musical theatre and drama companies, which initiate their own  
productions.  
# 11.2 Entrance doors and lobbies  
These require\:  
• Arrival and drop-off  
• Ease of access from car parking and public transport  
• Prominent venue signage  
• Easily accessible approach with clearly identifiable entrance  
• Canopy to provide shelter at entrance  
• Provision for posters and other promotional information  
• Welcoming and inviting aspect  
• Draught lobby  
• Automatic sliding doors.  
It is recommended to follow the guidance set out in British Standard  
BS 8300–2\:2018 *Designing of an Accessible and Inclusive Built*  
*Environment* for information needed to create an inclusive environ-  
ment to all areas of the building outside of the auditorium.  
# 11.3 Entrance foyer  
Foyers and facilities within them need to be adaptable to meet dif-  
ferent needs to suit different programming.  
• Foyers, open-plan circulation, routes and stairs\: these should  
avoid bottlenecks, cramped areas and cross-flow of audiences  
queuing for the box office, bar, toilets, cloakrooms or even the  
auditorium at peak times  
• Lifts, for access to upper or lower levels  
• Box office counters may now be combined with general recep-  
tion desks including office spaces and stage door, while ticket  
machines are increasingly used as a means of buying and col-  
lecting tickets  
• Registration \(conference hall\)\: counter or table  
• Reception and information\: counter  
• Cloakroom \(not usual in cinema\)\: attended or unattended  
• Creche\: at least 6.5 m2 per child  
• First-aid room\: bed, wash-hand basin  
• Toilets\: see Chapter 2, People and space  
• Lounge areas\: standing height shelves for drinks where space  
limited, tables, chairs, display stands, lounge seating  
• Performance area\: within foyer or separate area  
• Education and community events\: studio or suite of spaces for  
such events  
• Space and display for exhibitions\: see Chapter 28, Museums, art  
galleries and temporary exhibition spaces  
• Auditorium lobbies\: barriers to sound and light at entry points  
into the auditorium; the level of lighting should assist adap-  
tation to and from the dark auditorium and the brighter foyer  
lighting.  
# 11.4 Places to eat and drink  
Noise from these areas needs to be carefully managed to avoid  
affecting performances in the auditorium. These may include\:  
• Coffee bar  
• Licensed bar \(often referred to as the ‘crush bar’ because of peak  
periods before a show or during short intervals\)  
• Self-service food counter  
• Restaurant  
• Banquet room  
• Private room  
• Associated spaces \(bar store, cellar, kitchen, storage, staff rooms,  
manager’s offices, delivery, refuse\).  
# 11.5 Sales  
These may include\:  
• Shops and merchandise outlets\: display cases, shelving, office,  
storage, security; see Chapter 34, Retail shops and stores • Kiosk and other food counters\: display cases, shelving, micro-  
wave oven, stockroom \(confectionery, drinks, etc.\) with possible  
refrigerator and freezers for ice creams; security.  
# 11.6 Meeting rooms  
Breakout rooms, sponsors’ rooms; equipped for receptions, and  
small group lectures, discussions and workshops.  
# 11.7 Important guests, VIPs and sponsors rooms  
Reception rooms or separately defined spaces for distinguished vis-  
itors or sponsors, with attendant lounge and toilets.  
# 11.8 Exhibition hall  
Displays including trade exhibitions; storage, deliveries, possible  
separate public entrance; see Chapter 28, Museums, art galleries  
and temporary exhibition spaces.  
# 11.9 Art gallery  
Permanent and/or temporary exhibitions; see Chapter 28, Museums,  
art galleries and temporary exhibition spaces.  
# 11.10 Office services  
Conference halls\: access by delegates to the internet, telephones,  
photocopiers, translators, secretarial work, see Chapter 29, Offices.  
# 11.11 Outdoor areas  
Gathering area at front doors; associated with foyer and places to  
eat and drink as external terraces; store for outdoor furniture; land-  
scaping.  
# 11.12 Signage  
This includes\:  
• *External*\: name of venue, current and future events  
• *Internal*\: direction signs to the various public attractions.  
# 11.13 Managerial and maintenance spaces  
These include\:  
• *Administrative offices*\: functions may include policy, house  
management, accounts, personnel, marketing, press and pub-  
licity, development and community programmes, clerical work.  
Associated spaces may include boardroom, storage, strong room,  
office services and equipment, entrance and reception, toilets.  
• *Box office*\: room for postal and telephone bookings, storage of  
sales records and accounts; access to changing, relaxation and  
toilet facilities.  
• *Men’s and women’s staff rest rooms*\: lockers, lounge chairs,  
refreshments and toilets.  
• *Sales and trays store*\: refrigerator for ice cream, shelves for  
confectionery, programmes, documents and other items for sale  
or distribution; storage of sales trays; table; washhand basin;  
located directly off the public areas.  
• *Maintenance workshop, office and, in larger venues, store*.  
• *Cleaners’ stores*\: central storage of materials and equipment;  
cupboards with sink, cleaning materials and equipment through-  
out building.  
• *Security control room*\: surveillance monitors, fire-detection sys-  
tems, alarms, service monitors, paging systems, locking devices.  
• *Refuse*\: external provision for dustbins, well ventilated and eas-  
ily cleaned.  
• *Catering facilities*\: the scale of the operation may justify the  
inclusion of catering facilities for all staff, typically in a facility  
known as the ‘Green Room’.  
# 11.14 Get-in \(receiving theatres\)  
The get-in is one of the most important considerations in the design  
and arrangement of a theatre venue. It is where visiting companies,  
# Auditoria 15-49  
productions or sets are delivered. Large vehicles may need to  
deliver to the scene dock, sometimes during inclement weather.  
This also needs to facilitate the get-out, often late at night after a  
show has finished and when the crew may be tired.  
Delivery vehicles should be parked on the level, so that carrying  
or wheeling large and heavy items from the back of the vehicle into  
the scene dock can be done without pushing up a slope or restrain-  
ing down an incline. Long items, typically at least 6 m long and  
up to 4 m high need to be manoeuvred through to the stage area,  
platform or scene store. During winter months, heat from the stage  
area and auditorium can escape to the outside and so arrangements  
need to be made to protect this.  
Delivery vehicles need to be parked somewhere within the site  
curtilage when not in use with sufficient turning and reversing  
space allowed.  
# 11.15 Other spaces  
• A small office for a tour manager equipped with a desk, tele-  
phone and internet connection  
• Green Room facilities by way of a staff canteen or kitchen area  
and some comfortable chairs or sofas as part of the venue’s back-  
stage provision is normally appreciated by touring performers  
• Rehearsal space and repair workshop for repairs and main-  
tenance of sets and production equipment, such as lanterns,  
electrical leads, sound systems, etc.  
• Space to repair and clean costumes may also be a requirement.  
# 11.16 Production spaces  
Producing theatres typically require the following spaces\:  
• Offices for the functions of artistic policy, direction, production  
development, instruction, design, production organisation, busi-  
ness management, development programmes and clerical work  
• Associated spaces may include boardroom, library, music room,  
audition room, working conference room, model-making facil-  
ities, dark room, general storage, office services, refreshment  
areas, toilets, entrance and reception.  
# 11.17 Rehearsal spaces  
A relationship diagram for a rehearsal suite is shown in Figure  
15.83\. Long hours can be spent in these areas and it is therefore  
desirable that they should provide daylight and privacy. The suite  
may include\:  
• Rehearsal room or rehearsal studio able to accommodate the  
largest performing area on the stage, which is plotted out in the  
rehearsal studio, plus 2 m on three sides and 3 m on one long side  
as a minimum for circulation space around the performing area.  
• Practice studios for individual or small group practice, for exam-  
ple for dancers who need mirrors along one wall that can be  
curtained off; see Figure 15.84.  
• Associated spaces may include lounge, changing rooms, toilets,  
storage of equipment.  
# 11.18 Scenery workshops  
The substantial facilities required where the manufacture and main-  
tenance of scenery is involved is well illustrated in Figure 15.85.  
These include\:  
*Offices*  
For head of carpentry workshop, head of paint shop and head of  
property department.  
*Carpentry workshop*  
For the construction of scenery; power operated tools \(such as  
woodworking machine, mortise, circular and bandsaws, and  
lathes\); benches for carpentry, assembly and canvassing; storage  
of raw materials such as timber, sheet materials, rolls of materials, **15-50 Auditoria**  
**15.83** *Relationship diagram for a rehearsal room or studio*  
**15.85** *Plan of workshops in the Leeds Playhouse, Leeds*  
**15.84** *Section through wall barres in rehearsal studio for dance*  
*practice*  
nails and screws and so on, including polystyrene sheets which  
may require a separate fire-resistant enclosure.  
*Paint shop*  
For the painting of scenery, accommodating various methods of  
painting backcloths and flats \(flat on the floor, on mobile frame or  
fixed frame and gantry\), and 3D pieces; benches for mixing paints  
and other preparation and cleaning brushes; storage requirements  
for raw materials such as paints and fire-proofing, and equipment  
such as brushes and spray equipment. Paints may need to be stored  
in a fire-proof enclosure.  
*Metalwork shop*  
For the use of metal in the preparation of scenery; provision for  
welding, cutting and fabricating metalwork items; benches, weld-  
ing screens and bending machinery; storage of raw materials such  
as sheets, tubes and bars, bolts, nuts and screws.  
*Trial assembly area*  
Area for the erection of a trial assembly of the set under construc-  
tion, the size of the performing area of the stage. *Property department*  
For worktops and storage of raw materials. Separate workshops  
may be required for work with associated fire-resistant require-  
ments and extraction of toxic gases and another for work with other  
materials.  
*Delivery and storage*  
For raw materials being delivered to the carpentry workshop,  
paint shop, metalwork shop and property department, including  
unloading bay and parking of delivery vans and lorries. There may  
also be requirements for the storage of scenery and properties for  
re-use.  
# 11.19 Layout of workshops  
A level floor is required through unloading bays, workshops, scen-  
ery store and stage, giving a clear, broad passage of movement of  
scenery onto the stage. Where a change of level is unavoidable, a  
lift will be inevitable but is not recommended. The passage from  
the unloading bay to the stage for touring companies should be  
direct without interfering with the workshops.  
The paint frame and backcloth storage should be placed so that  
the rolled backcloths can be moved horizontally into position under  
the flytower or grid with the painted surface facing the audience.  
The large doors or roller shutters required for the movement of  
scenery should not also be used for people. The minimum dimen-  
sions of the openings should be determined by the maximum size  
of scenery expected.  
The carpentry shop should be isolated from the paint shop to  
avoid noise and sawdust penetration, and both areas should be  
acoustically insulated from the stage. Scenery storage located  
between workshops and stage acts as a sound barrier.  
# Auditoria 15-51  
# 11.20 Wardrobe space  
Wardrobe space is required for\:  
• Making and fitting of performers’ costumes  
• Making and fitting associated items such as wigs  
• Storing, repairing and cleaning costumes  
• Making millinery and accessories  
• Dyeing cloth and spraying materials  
• Storing rolls of cloth and pattern paper  
• Storing small items such as sewing materials, dyestuffs  
• Delivery of raw materials including unloading bay and parking  
of delivery vans  
• Office for costume supervisor.  
Performers require easy access to the wardrobe for fitting cos-  
tumes, while the distribution of finished costumes for, and their  
cleaning during, a production suggests a location close to the dress-  
ing rooms.  
# 11.21 Digital suite  
For sound effects and music. This requires an isolated space where  
digital editing can be undertaken. Associated areas may include a  
library of digital recordings, entry lounge and lobby.  
# 11.22 Common facilities  
Provision for resting, changing, refreshment \(Green Room\), toilets  
and showers.  
# 11.23 Transport  
Van or vans for the collections and delivery of goods, with parking  
spaces within the curtilage of the site. **16 Civic buildings**
