# 1 TOWN HALLS  
# 1.1 Introduction  
The concept of the town hall as a local civic and community focus  
has a continuing importance for communities. Local authorities  
are, however, significantly reviewing their modus operandi and the  
physical needs of their buildings.  
A developing direction in the design of town halls is towards a  
flexible, modern facility that delivers high quality services to the  
public. Local authorities are consolidating their property portfolios  
in order to achieve greater efficiencies operationally and in terms  
of building stock. The name civic centre is considered as a more  
appropriate description or title, and even more fashionable expres-  
sions such as ‘The Hub’ or ‘The Cube’ have been adopted where  
the association with an outdated concept of local authority admin-  
istration is no longer desired.  
Although many of the key spatial requirements are similar to  
the traditional town hall model the emphasis has changed from the  
corridors of power to a building that provides services and facilities  
for the community, see Figure 16.1. The nature of the spaces has  
arguably become more demanding in terms of flexibility and there-  
fore more generic rather than bespoke to a location.  
Although local authorities may have different requirements, the  
new town hall or civic centre is likely to require the following prin-  
cipal components\:  
• Members’ accommodation  
• Council chamber  
• Community hall  
• Committee rooms and meeting rooms  
• Offices  
• Reception  
• Customer services  
• Library  
• Events spaces.  
**16.1** *Relationship diagram for civic centre functions \(Hopkins Architects\)*  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-19 **16-1** **16-2 Civic buildings**  
# 1.2 Members’ accommodation  
Traditionally, the town hall was a place where the facilities  
accorded to the decision-making role of elected councillors were  
celebrated by a very high quality of traditional finishes setting  
those areas above others in terms of importance and status.  
More recently, however, where members’ facilities are pro-  
vided in new accommodation, the standard of finishes and furniture  
is required to match that of the council’s offices or administration  
areas in order that members are not seen to have a higher standard  
of finishes or be enjoying lavish benefits associated with their  
elected position. Instead, members’ offices are modern, flexible  
and deliberately non-specific to party colours.  
# 1.2 Council chamber  
The function of the council chamber as a space for council meetings  
continues and is likely to continue as long as the current format for  
local democracy exists. Their traditional forms are mostly segmen-  
tal or horseshoe, see Figures 16.2 and 16.3.  
**16.2** *Hammersmith Town Hall’s Council Chamber suite is an example of a triple-tiered horseshoe configuration*  
**16.3** *Council chamber, various layout types \(1= mayor, 2 = ordinary members, 3 = officers, 4 = committee clerks, 5 = press and*  
*public\)* Council meetings are held on a monthly basis and may be  
supplemented by youth parliament and other quasi-democratic  
meetings or presentations. For the remainder of the year, the cham-  
ber is available for other potential uses, most of which would not  
require the tiered seating \(see Figure 16.4\) and public galleries  
so common in historic town halls. Rather it favours a flat-floored  
space with flexible furniture, which can then be used for various  
functions or conferences that can be a source of potential revenue  
to the council.  
The character of the civic chamber as a traditional oak-panelled  
room with all the allusions of grandeur attributed to outdated civic  
notions is not something that is prized by forward-looking councils.  
However, allusion to the civic nature of the room can be accommo-  
dated by a modern system of panelling utilised also for its acoustic  
# Civic buildings 16-3  
performance. This space may be renamed. At Brent, for example,  
the civic chamber and its associated meeting and committee rooms  
are known as Conference Hall and Board Rooms.  
**16.4** *Council chamber seating*  
# 1.3 Civic suite  
In support of the civic functions of the council, meeting spaces and  
committee rooms are required in proximity to the civic chamber.  
These are to provide spaces serviced with audio-visual and cater-  
ing for the needs of the council in conducting its business through  
committees. When not required for this use they can be let for com-  
munity/private/corporate use.  
# 1.4 Committee rooms  
Local government business is conducted principally through  
numerous committees and sub-committees. Meeting rooms of  
various sizes are required; these \(including the council chamber\)  
are often available for letting by outside organisations, producing  
useful additional revenue for the council. For this reason, if for no  
other, they should be well designed and fitted out.  
# 1.5 Community hall  
A central feature of the community function of the town hall/civic  
centre is the community hall. This is a space essentially for the use  
of the community but also for corporate events. It might accom-  
modate large-scale weddings, concerts, pantomimes, plays, dances  
and banquets.  
# 1.6 Offices  
These can account for the bulk of accommodation within the town  
hall/civic centre as local authorities consolidate resources and  
departments in order to better deliver public services ‘under one  
roof’. This breaks down the traditional ‘silo’ thinking of separate  
departments to encourage integrated delivery.  
Administration areas within local authorities are now recog-  
nised as being as demanding as commercial office requirements  
\(see Chapter 29\). Smart desking and new ways of working are  
becoming accepted and have benefits in terms of space utilisation  
and efficiency. A ratio of 10 employees per 8 or even 7 desks is  
not unusual.  
Flexible open plan areas with fixed island desking are punc-  
tuated with quiet rooms, breakout spaces, staff storage lockers,  
business support units for printing, recycling, storage and wet sup-  
port areas for tea points.  
# 1.7 Public reception and information  
A large entrance or atrium space is required for the public to  
arrive and orientate. People will be met by ‘meeters and greeters’,  
who will answer any immediate questions and give directions to  
departments as appropriate. A large reception desk is required  
with space for several receptionists, some potentially in wheel-  
chairs, who will receive the public, provide information or  
coordinate meetings.  
# 1.8 Customer services  
Also known in some local authorities as a ‘one-stop shop’, this is  
a large space consisting of a seating/waiting area, queuing system  
and large number of desks manned by council staff to answer que-  
ries and provide information to the public on all matters \(planning,  
building control, council tax, education, social services, leisure\).  
Additionally, a series of rooms for confidential consultations are  
required with alternative staff exits if necessary for security and  
escape reasons.  
# 1.9 Cash facility  
The need for cash transactions is diminishing as more and more  
are dealt with online. Dedicated cashier stations are generally no  
longer required. **16-4 Civic buildings**  
# 1.10 Library  
Public libraries \(Chapter 26\) are often incorporated into town halls/  
civic centres in order to benefit from the proximity with other ser-  
vices and facilities \(Figure 16.5\).  
The nature of the public library has changed to more of an inter-  
net café and indeed many have informal seating and a café facility.  
Books are displayed face-on rather than end-on and study tables  
with Wi-Fi are mixed in. Children’s book areas are linked and not  
separated.  
# 1.11 Events spaces  
With a growing emphasis on mixing up civic and community func-  
tions, the scope for impromptu or even scheduled performance  
events in visible areas within the town hall suggests that reception  
and circulation spaces can double-function as ‘given’ or ‘found’  
spaces for such uses thereby animating the potentially otherwise  
institutional character of this area.  
# 1.12 Case study – Brent Civic Centre  
*Introduction*  
London Borough of Brent commissioned Hopkins Architects to  
design a multi-purpose civic centre on a site close to Wembley  
Stadium. The aim was to house civic, public and administrative  
facilities within one building including office space for 2000 staff.  
It was also conceived as a new community hub for the public to  
meet within the newly landscaped Arena Square. There is also a  
wedding garden for guests attending wedding parties in the com-  
munity hall.  
*Size*  
Brent Civic Centre totals 39683 sqm. Of this, 14154 sqm is public/  
civic space, 18073 sqm administrative and 7456 sqm basement.  
*Layout*  
The building’s spaces are arranged around a 31 m high, natu-  
rally lit foyer and atrium \(Figure 16.6\). This houses a large public  
amphitheatre and wide civic steps as well as the circular civic drum  
containing a multi-purpose, a library \(1211 sqm\), customer services  
centre \(768 sqm\) and 26 m diameter community hall \(1177 sqm\)  
\(Figure 16.7\).  
The chamber \(284 sqm\), on level three, can be reconfigured to  
suit a variety of civic and public uses \(Figure 16.8 a, b, c\). There is  
also an atrium foyer and civic hall lobby \(473 sqm\) and committee  
rooms \(407 sqm\).  
Two glazed office wings provide open plan and flexible admin-  
istrative space to the rear of the site, included at a ratio of 7 seats to  
every 10 staff to reflect anticipated occupancy levels.  
*Building performance*  
Brent Civic Centre has a BREEAM ‘Outstanding’ rating and  
was the first of its building type to have achieved this. As such, it  
attained a 33 per cent reduction in carbon emissions due to a com-  
bination of solar shading, natural ventilation, high-performance  
façade and combined cooling, heating and power.  
**16.5** *Axonometric of the CUBE civic centre in Corby, designed*  
*by Hawkins Brown. Key\: 1\) entrance foyer information desk; 2\)*  
*library ramp; 3\) theatre auditorium; 4\) council chamber; 5\) roof*  
*terrace and restaurant*  
# 2 LAW COURTS  
# 2.1 Background  
The judicial system of England and Wales is in direct line of  
descent from that established by William I nearly a thousand  
years ago, subsequently modified by Magna Carta and many other  
reforms. Courthouses are the visible manifestation of one of the  
most fundamental sets of principles upon which our society is  
based.  
How this is to be expressed in architectural terms is the particu-  
lar challenge facing the designer of a courthouse. He or she will  
have to consider the contextual and environmental constraints that  
apply to any urban structure, especially those on prominent sites  
in town centres. Planning problems posed by the specific require-  
ments for a courthouse must also be addressed, such as the four  
segregated circulation routes \(for judge, jury, defendant in custody  
and public\), the servicing of the many and varied spaces within a  
complex layout and the need for flexibility to accommodate future  
developments in information technology. Although courtrooms  
built 200 years ago are still able to cope, the law is constantly  
evolving and both the courtrooms and the ancillaries need to be  
receptive to inevitable change. **Civic buildings 16-5**  
**16.6** *Section looking north of Brent Civic Centre in north London, designed by Hopkins Architects*  
**16.7** *Community hall, designed to be configured for a variety of uses including boxing matches, as shown here* **16-6 Civic buildings** **Civic buildings 16-7**  
**16.8a–c** *Brent Civic Centre civic chamber, shown configured for, a\) council meetings; b\) conference use; c\) as a cinema*  
# 2.2 Court system  
HMCS \(Her Majesty’s Court Service\) has existed in various forms  
for over 900 years. Following the Courts Act 1971, it was given the  
task of running a new system covering all courts above the level of  
Magistrates’ Courts. It is directly responsible for\:  
• Court of Appeal  
• Royal Courts of Justice  
• High Court  
• Crown Court  
• County Court.  
The Crown Court is a national court which sits at different cen-  
tres. Practically all its work is concerned with cases committed for  
trial or sentence from the Magistrates’ Courts, or appeals against  
their decisions. Cases for trial are heard before a judge and jury.  
Centres are classified as first, second or third tier according to the  
nature and complexity of the court business.  
Magistrates’ Courts were traditionally local courts but are  
increasingly organised regionally. Some are part of larger com-  
bined courts such as Newport Law Court, which combines County  
and Magistrates Courts \(Figure 16.9\).  
# 2.3 The courtroom  
The Crown Court sits in a courtroom, the design of which will  
always be subject to the continuous adjustments dictated by  
changes in attitudes to child witnesses, the need to protect wit-  
nesses and jurors from possible intimidation and developments in  
technology.  
The courtroom is the primary workspace and focal point in  
a courthouse, which is developed around it. It is the only place  
where all parties in a case are likely to meet. Of paramount  
importance is the need to segregate judge, jury, defend-  
ant and others in the courtroom and within the courthouse.  
Segregated circulation routes are provided so that the judge,  
jury and defendants \(if in custody\) make their way to the court-  
room without meeting each other or any other users such as  
members of the public.  
The exception is the Magistrates Court in which there is no jury,  
so therefore no need to provide space for jury seating or circulation  
\(see case study in Section 2.15\).  
In all other courts, dedicated entrances are provided for\:  
• Judge  
• Jury  
• Defendants in custody  
• Public, witnesses and defendants on bail.  
Some prosecution witnesses have to be protected from intimida-  
tion; a separate secure waiting room for them is often situated with  
its entrance off the vestibule provided between the public entrance  
and the courtroom itself. An alternative arrangement has a separate  
access from the secure waiting area into the courtroom adjacent to  
the witness box.  
The public enter the court behind or to the side of the public  
seating at the rear of the courtroom; neither public nor witnesses  
pass areas dedicated to other participants \(e.g. jury or defendants in  
custody\) on entering or leaving the courtroom.  
# 2.4 Relationships within the courtroom  
Courtroom layout incorporates specific and well-defined rela-  
tionships between the various participants by means of carefully **16-8 Civic buildings**  
**16.9** *Newport Law Court, in South Wales, designed by Feilden + Mawson, with clear delineation of public, court and court ancillary*  
*zones. Gross internal area\: 9100 m2*  
arranged sightlines, distances and levels. There are four main ele-  
ments in Crown Court cases\:  
• Judge  
• Jury  
• Witness  
• Counsel \(barristers and solicitors\).  
Defendants do not take part except as witnesses. Each element  
must be closely related, and be able to see and hear each other  
clearly at all times without mechanical or electrical aids, and with-  
out excessive turning from side to side. The basic positioning of the  
occupants is shown in Figure 16.10.  
The theory behind these relationships can be summarised as  
follows\:  
• *The judge or magistrate*. Presides over the courtroom, should be  
able to observe the whole of it, to see clearly the principal par-  
ticipants as well as the defendant in the dock and, when called,  
the antecedents and probation officers. The judge or magistrates’  
bench is always elevated, usually by 450 mm \(Figure 16.11\).  
• *The court clerk*. Administers the case and needs to keep a watch-  
ing eye over the court. He or she often advises the judge and  
should be able to stand up and speak to the judge without being  
overheard.  
• *The exhibit table*. This is in front of the counsel benches for the  
display of exhibits put forward for evidence.  
• *Counsel*. These are barristers and solicitors who represent the  
defendant or prosecution. They need to be able to see the jury,  
judge and witness to whom they address their remarks. The bar-  
rister at each end of the front bench should be able to keep every  
jury member and the witness on the stand within about a 90°  
angle to obviate too much turning to ensure that the judge, the  
other main party, shall have at least a part face view. The counsel  
benches are wide enough to hold the large, and numerous, docu-  
ments and books that are often in use.  
• *The defendant*. The defendant is assumed to be innocent until  
proved guilty and current practice is to reduce any prison-like  
appearance of the dock by lowering the barriers enclosing it as  
much as possible compatible with security. Defendants sit in sep-  
arate fixed seats and if they are thought to be a security risk may  
sit in an enclosed glazed cubicle within the court. The dock is con-  
trolled by a dock officer and situated at the back of the courtroom.  
• *The jury*. This comprises 12 members of the public whose duty  
it is to reach a verdict based on the evidence presented. The  
jury sits opposite the witness stand and must be able to see the  
defendant in the dock, as well as the judge and counsel. Jurors  
must have a writing surface and a place to put documents.  
• *The witness*. The witness waits outside the courtroom and when  
called gives evidence from the witness stand near to the judge’s  
bench. They stand facing the jury who must be able to observe his  
or her face. The witness is questioned by the barristers and occa-  
sionally by the judge. If the judge directs that a witness should be  
retained, he or she can wait seated within the courtroom. **Civic buildings 16-9**  
**16.10** *Standard Crown Courtroom*  
**16.11** *Judge’s bench*  
*Source*\: Court Standards Design Guide, Ministry of Justice **16-10 Civic buildings**  
• *The shorthand writer*. This official keeps a transcript of the trial  
and consequently must be able to see and hear everyone who  
speaks.  
• *Probation and antecedents officers*. These give evidence from  
their seats after the jury has reached a verdict. This evidence is  
used to assist the judge in passing sentence.  
• *The press*. These are not party to the proceedings, but they  
should be able to see the participants.  
• *The public*. These are in court to see that ‘justice is done’.  
They are placed at the near end of the courtroom and have  
a general view of the proceedings, but with the minimum  
possible direct eye contact with the jury to reduce the risk  
of intimidation. A public gallery over the jurors is the most  
effective method of eliminating possible intimidation; but  
access to such a gallery and the increase in height of the  
courtroom has to be considered. The glass screen between the  
public and the dock is partially obscured to prevent members  
of the public from seeing the defendant\(s\) \(and vice versa\)  
while seated.  
# 2.5 The courtroom environment  
The design of Crown Court rooms should reflect the quiet dignity  
of the law rather than its power. Guidance was published by the  
Ministry16 of Justice \(Court Standards Design Guide\) in 2010  
and by HM Courts & Tribunals Service in 2019. A fully acces-  
sible \(Figures 16.12, 16.13\), well-detailed, comfortable and quiet  
**16.12** *DDA compliant standard criminal court, 14.4 m × 13.5 m, 172 m2. Source\: Court Standards Design Guide, Ministry of Justice* courtroom with efficient and simply managed ventilation, lighting  
and acoustics is the ideal.  
• *Youth court*. Magistrates’ Courts often contain a court appro-  
priate for juveniles, where magistrates and defendants and legal  
teams can sit around the same table. These courts should have  
their own circulation routes, which can be kept separate to that of  
any other\) courts operational that day in the building.  
• *Ventilation*. Well-balanced environmental conditions within  
the courtroom are essential to the smooth running of the  
court. They keep the participants comfortable and interested,  
and avoid distractions. The current trend, supported by most  
users, is for natural ventilation with openable windows. This  
will subject the courtroom to wider temperature fluctuations;  
but this can be minimised by integrated automatic control  
systems.  
• *Mechanical assistance* \(or in extreme cases full air condition-  
ing\) will be necessary where there would be unacceptable noise  
intrusion; or where the courtroom cannot have the height to  
induce air flow by the natural stack effect. It is normally more  
economical and energy-efficient to have separate air handling  
# Civic buildings 16-11  
units for each courtroom, managed by time switches and occu-  
pancy sensors.  
• *Lighting*. Daylight is provided if possible; but direct sunlight  
must be controlled and security risks avoided. The controlled  
use of daylight alone improves environmental comfort, but when  
it becomes for any reason insufficient, artificial lighting will be  
required. A combination of uplighters and downlighters reduces  
glare and contrast, and enhances the character of the courtroom.  
Lighting levels and colour should ensure correct colour render-  
ing, and that all participants, exhibits and written evidence can  
be clearly seen without strain or dazzle.  
• *Acoustics*. The acoustics and noise levels should ensure that  
the proceedings can be heard in all parts of the courtroom  
while avoiding distraction and annoyance from movement by  
the public, press or others. There may be a need for reflective or  
absorbent surface treatment to walls and ceilings.  
• *Communications.* – The courtroom should accommodate data  
connections and telephones for the legal teams and judiciary,  
with cabling concealed within a raised floor. Screens to show  
testimony from witnesses outside the courtroom should also be  
incorporated.  
**16.13** *DDA compliant standard criminal court, 10.2 m × 8.4 m, 84.9 m2. Source\: Court Standards Design Guide, Ministry of Justice* **16-12 Civic buildings**  
# 2.6 Functional relationships outside the courtroom  
Courthouse accommodation is divided into areas, each with its  
own self-contained circulation. Movement between areas is limited  
and restricted. Even those who need to move freely can only enter  
certain restricted areas by passing through manned control points  
or other secure doors. The relationship and pattern of movement  
between the elements is shown in the functional relationship dia-  
gram in Figure 16.14.  
# 2.7 Judiciary  
The judiciary \(judges, recorders, etc.\) arrive at the court building  
and enter through a manned or otherwise restricted entry directly  
into their own secure area of the building. This contains the judges’  
retiring rooms and all areas devoted to judicial use.  
The only other users of this area in ‘working hours’ are the staff,  
that is, ushers, court clerks, security staff and invitees \(legal rep-  
resentatives, guests and some members of the public invited to a  
judge’s room\). Invitees will always be escorted, and access for all  
will be either via the judges’ entrance into court or through staff  
areas. Each entrance will be via a self-locking, secure door.  
# 2.8 Jurors  
Persons, the number depending on the number and size of trials  
programmed, are summoned to the court building. They enter  
through the main public areas until they reach the reception area to  
the jury assembly suite where they are booked in.  
They then wait in the lounge or dining area where refreshments  
are available until called upon to form a jury panel. The period  
of waiting is variable and can be all day. Highest usage is before  
courts sit, and during lunch periods.  
Egress from the assembly area, other than back past reception,  
is into jury-restricted circulation, which leads to court and jury  
retiring rooms. These should be adjacent or close to related court-  
rooms, and all capable of supervision by one jury bailiff.  
Once jurors have entered the jury assembly suite, they remain  
there, in court or in the jury retiring room, until sent home at the  
end of the day, or on dismissal.  
# 2.9 Defendants  
The custody area \(see Chapter 16, 3.5\) is a self-contained com-  
partment within the court building designated for the temporary  
use of prison governors in the discharge of their duties to the court  
to produce and retain prisoners in custody. It consists of the fol-  
lowing principal parts, each separate from its neighbour and all  
non-custody uses\:  
• Custody core  
• Vehicle entrance  
• Visitors’ entrance  
• Courtroom entrance  
• Three independent secure connecting routes from custody core  
to vehicle dock, courtroom entrance and visitors’ entrance.  
While courts are sitting, the custody area is staffed and admin-  
istered by prison officers. A principal or senior officer is in charge,  
supported by number of officers according to the number of courts  
and the level of risk. Some officers have fixed duties, for instance  
dock officer and cells officer, but the remainder are on escort duties.  
Custody areas are designed and constructed to contain defend-  
ants, and to produce them to the court. Containment requires the  
meticulous and consistent application of passive security measures.  
Confinement and attendance at court for defendants is stressful, and  
this is compounded by natural frustration and anxiety. The designer  
must\:  
• Give careful attention to all aspects of the design from the over-  
all plan and its approaches, down to fixtures, fittings, fixings,  
finishes, alarms and communications.  
• Devise a layout that will achieve maximum control, make the  
best use of staff resources and maintain an acceptable level of  
safety and security.  
• Use the building fabric and the facilities within it to provide a  
secure envelope.  
• Deny the public direct view or contact with defendants while  
they are inside the custody area, except during authorised visits.  
**16.14** *Functional relationship diagram for a courthouse* **2.10 Public**  
The public areas with their associated circulation form the central  
core or axis from which most non-judicial functions of the court  
building radiate.  
Except for the judiciary and specified car park users, all users  
enter the building by the main entrance door where space and  
facilities for security checks are provided. The arrival concourse  
contains the information/enquiry point and the Cause List display,  
both of which should be clearly seen on entering.  
Public circulation then leads to court waiting areas. These may  
be combined with associated circulation to form concourses off  
which are located the courtrooms and consultation/waiting rooms.  
Waiting areas should be visually interesting, preferably with exter-  
nal views. All furniture should be fixed.  
Public circulation also gives access to private and semi-private  
accommodation occupied by Court Service \(CS\) staff, non-CS staff,  
the Probation Service, custody visits and to refreshment facilities.  
Access must also be available to the Crown Court office counters.  
Direct access from the arrivals concourse to the jury assembly area  
is desirable.  
# 2.11 Advocates  
Advocates enter the court building by the main entrance, reach-  
ing their suite via the public circulation. This is the area reserved  
for solicitors and barristers preparing for court, combining lounge/  
study/retiring room for relaxation and quiet study in comfortable  
conditions, and for assembly, discussion, robing, etc. The lounge  
and robing room should, if possible, be contiguous, otherwise direct  
access should be provided.  
The suite has easy access to courtrooms via the public con-  
course where advocates meet clients, and to the advocates’ dining  
room. The advocates’ clerks’ room is closely related and shares the  
same private ‘advocates’ circulation.  
# 2.12 Crown Court office  
The Crown Court office is occupied by executive and administra-  
tive staff engaged in the general administration of Crown Court  
business.  
The general office counter must be conveniently located to  
allow easy access for the public and for the legal profession; pay-  
ment of expenses to jurors and witnesses may be made here.  
There should be separate circulation to other staff areas and for  
direct access to the judges, and restricted circulation by ushers.  
Within the Crown Court offices, accommodation is provided for  
some more specialised groups\:  
• Court clerks who are responsible for business in specific court-  
rooms and who spend part of their day in court  
• Ushers who spend part of their time in court and attending to  
judge and/or jury but will also do minor clerical work  
• Listing staff who are responsible for the planning and program-  
ming of the court timetable \(lists of cases\).  
# 2.13 Non-courts service users  
Non-courts service users includes police, Crown Prosecution  
Service, Probation Service and shorthand writers, concerned with  
the running of the court.  
The police area consists of two sections\:  
• *The Police Liaison Unit*. This is the suite of offices for police  
staff attached to the courts and providing antecedents, etc.  
Included is a room where police witnesses can assemble and  
change if necessary.  
• *The Police Law and Order Unit*. This suite of offices is for police  
who maintain security or ‘Law and Order’ in the building.  
*The Crown Prosecution Service* is responsible for the prose-  
cution of defendants in court. It needs an office for law clerks to  
# Civic buildings 16-13  
perform casework arising during the progress of the case, and to  
consult with members of the legal profession and witnesses.  
*The Probation Service*, as attached to a Crown Court, will be  
active where persons have been made subjects of probation orders  
or inquiry reports at court, although they may do some paperwork  
on other cases. The probation suite is a separate individual unit  
and, where night reporting facilities are required, must be able to  
operate in isolation while full security to the remainder of the court  
building is maintained.  
*Shorthand writers* are usually hired directly or via a service firm  
to take notes and transcribe court proceedings.  
# 2.14 Catering  
Catering within Crown Courts involves self-service facilities for  
advocates, jurors, public and court staff, together with waiter  
service, from a sideboard or servery for the judiciary. The cater-  
ing area should be sited on one floor with easy access for all  
court users, maximising usage and minimising operating costs.  
Multilevel catering areas should be avoided as less convenient and  
more expensive to operate.  
# 3 CASE STUDY – NORTH SOMERSET  
# COURTHOUSE, WORLE, WESTON-SUPER-MARE  
# ARCHITECT\: BDP  
# 3.1 Introduction  
A new courthouse was required as part of a rationalisation of  
Magistrate Courts in North Somerset. BDP’s brief was to provide  
five courtrooms and associated facilities in a building that embod-  
ied the gravitas of the British legal system. Alongside the court  
building are offices for Avon and Somerset Area Probation Office.  
The project was procured as part of the Avon and Somerset Courts  
PFI Project for HM Courts Service.  
# 3.2 Site  
The greenfield site was an edge-of-town location close to low-rise  
housing and a supermarket.  
# 3.3 Design  
The courthouse is organised as an L-shaped orthogonal block con-  
taining the courtrooms behind a softer, curved form containing the  
court halls. This sweeps around the front of the building to create a  
butterfly shape to give a strong visual identity \(Figure 16.15\).  
The courtrooms are located on the first floor with the custody  
suite on the ground floor. The core challenge was achieving the  
separation of circulation needed for members of the public, the  
judiciary, and the defendants \(Figures 16.16, 16.17a, b and 16.18\).  
At Worle, the public circulation and waiting area is positioned  
to the front of the building served by two staircases. The custody  
suite contains male, female and juvenile cells and associated legal  
and officers’ facilities, control room, van dock and assembly area.  
This suite is served by dedicated stair and lift cores to the court-  
rooms, one to every two courts.  
A number of small interview rooms are positioned off the first  
floor public waiting area as well as toilets and a kitchen. Seating  
is robust and fixed and toilets have low-level lighting to deter  
intravenous drug use. A separate staircase and waiting area is  
provided to segregate accommodation for youth and children’s  
court cases.  
Five courts are positioned to the rear of the building on either  
side of the central magistrates’ and courts staff area. They range  
from approximately 80–100 sqm each. Of these, Court 1 has full  
height security glazing to the dock while Courts 2, 3, 4 have  
half height, non-secure screens. Court 5, as a family court, has  
neither.  
The magistrates’ bench is raised 450 mm at the rear to provide  
security and authority, with separate access for judiciary. The room **16-14 Civic buildings**  
**16.15** *North Somerset Courthouse*

is timber-panelled to provide a warmer, less intimidating atmos-

# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 Briefing  
By their nature, community buildings must serve a variety of func-  
tions among which are\:  
• Meetings  
• Child care \(crèche, day nursery, pre-school playgroup\)  
• Children’s activities \(scouts, guides\)  
• Concerts and plays  
• Dances  
• Parties and receptions  
• Exhibitions  
• Sporting and leisure activities  
• Adult education.  
The client, such as a church or a local authority, may have its  
own specific requirements; but the financial viability of community  
facilities usually depends on letting them out to other organisations.  
At the briefing and planning stage, it is wise to consider activities  
which could or should be accommodated.  
# 1.2 Space requirement and arrangement  
The following points should be borne in mind\:  
• Meetings can range from committee meetings of half a dozen  
people to public meetings with an audience of a couple of hun-  
dred. If this range is anticipated then accommodation should  
include one or two smaller meeting rooms as well as the main  
hall.  
• Child care and children’s activities invariably require storage for  
furniture and equipment. If Scouts use the facilities on a regular  
basis, for example, they are likely to need permanent storage for  
camping equipment, such as tents and poles, and cooking as well  
as games equipment.  
• Some indoor sporting activities such as badminton require gen-  
erous space provision. See Chapter 37. These are likely to dictate  
the dimensions of the hall.  
**17.1** *Elements of the plan of a community centre*  
# 2.2 Space requirements  
Table I gives recommended floor areas for various functions and  
activities.  
# 2.3 Design  
Community centres are multi-purpose buildings. Needs and priori-  
ties will often conflict; the skill of the designer in consultation with  
the client, statutory authorities and specialists must be exercised so  
that a balance is struck. All the following factors should be con-  
sidered.  
# 2 PLANNING AND DESIGN  
# 2.1 Relationships  
The principal plan elements and their relationship to each other  
illustrated in Figures 17.1, 17.2 and 17.3 are typical examples of  
the type.  
# 2.4 Structure and construction  
Most new-build self-contained community centres are domestic in  
scale. The most economic forms of construction are those used in  
domestic building\: solid ground floors, masonry load-bearing walls  
and lightweight flat roofs or framed pitched roofs. Alternative  
forms of construction are only occasionally justified\: for a diffi-  
cult site or when only a short-life building is required. In the latter  
case, it is worth considering proprietary off-the-peg buildings. The  
appearance of such a building is not always aesthetically pleasing,  
but there are exceptions. Where the community facilities are to be  
accommodated in a larger building also used for other purposes,  
structure and construction will be determined by the wider consid-  
erations.  
# 2.5 Materials and finishes  
For self-contained community centres, it is worthwhile designing  
for minimum maintenance, as upkeep funds are always limited.  
Choice of finishes should be influenced by the following consid-  
erations.  
*Nature of use* may dictate forms of construction and finish  
which are non-standard. For example, when regular pro-  
vision for dancing \(particularly classical ballet\) or indoor  
sport such as badminton or gymnastics is required, the floor  
should provide some resilience and specialist advice should  
be sought.

# 2.6 Means of escape  
Care in planning and signposting the means of escape in case of fire  
is especially important because\:  
• The users, such as audiences at occasional concerts and meetings  
will not be familiar with the building layout.  
• Small children are likely to be present in a crèche or day care  
centre.  
• Elderly and disabled people may use the centre.  
• Facilities for leisure or educational purposes may be used by  
people with learning difficulties.  
• Early consultation with the local fire authority is essential.  
# 2.7 Licensing  
A licence will be required for certain uses and these invariably have  
conditions attached.  
# 2.8 Noise  
A community centre is more likely to generate than to suffer  
from high noise levels. They are commonly used at night and at  
the weekend, and are often situated within residential communi-  
ties. They must therefore be designed to avoid nuisance. Where  
uses take place simultaneously, sound separation will be necessary  
between a noisy activity such as a dance and one requiring relative  
quiet such as a lecture.  
The basic principles of acoustic design should be applied\:  
• Orientation, e.g. location of entrances, exits and windows rela-  
tive to adjoining buildings  
• Layout  
• Shape of rooms  
• Double glazing, only viable in association with mechanical ven-  
tilation  
• Sound-absorbent finishes, balanced with requirements of dura-  
bility and cleanability  
• Landscaping, including trees, to contain external noise.  
Unless unavoidable, noise-producing spaces should not be  
located alongside quiet spaces. Absorbent surfaces may have to  
be concentrated at ceiling level or provided by means of drapes  
and wall hangings. Management can also play a significant part in  
controlling noise and this should be discussed with the client at an  
early stage.  
# 2.9 Security  
Community centres are more than usually vulnerable to break-ins  
and vandalism as they do not have resident caretakers or 24-hour  
surveillance, are not continuously occupied, are visited by a large  
number of people, contain expensive equipment and are isolated

# 2.11 Disabled people  
There are statutory regulations relating to access for disabled  
people. These apply not only to those using wheelchairs but also  
include people with visual and auditory impairments and those  
using other types of walking aids. All these have difficulties with  
steps and changes of direction, and the design of entrances, circula-  
tion spaces and toilets should take this into account.

requirements. It is particularly important to ensure full conformity  
if the public are going to be charged for admission.

# 3 ELEMENTS OF THE PLAN  
# 3.1 Entrance  
This should be large enough to accommodate an influx of people,  
such as prior to a meeting or concert. Signposting should be clear,  
as many will be unfamiliar with the building. Unless there is a sep-  
arate goods entrance, it should allow for bulk delivery of food and **17-4 Community centres**  
drink, display material and equipment. Consider the arrangement  
of the doors, the durability of surfaces and easy accesses to both  
the kitchen and the hall.  
# 3.2 Hall  
For sports purposes refer to Chapter 37. A rectangular shape is  
likely to be suitable for a wider range of uses than a square or any  
other shape. If black-out is required, pay special attention to size  
and location of windows; mechanical ventilation may be needed.  
# 3.3 Meeting rooms  
If more than one, make them different sizes. Alternatively, have  
one space that can be divided using sliding folding doors, although  
some of these do not provide adequate sound insulation. At least  
one meeting room should have direct access to the hall.  
# 3.4 Toilets  
Separate toilets will be needed for men, women and disabled  
people. There may also be a need for smaller toilets for little  
children. Unisex baby-changing facilities should be provided. If  
considerable sports usage is expected, showers will be necessary  
for each sex.  
# 3.5 Kitchen  
There should be little need for more than a domestic kitchen. If  
catered functions are expected, provide space for setting out and  
final preparations.  
# 3.6 Storage  
A separate store should be provided for each main use\:  
• Kitchen  
• Sports  
• Seating and other furniture  
• Crèche/kindergarten  
• Scouts.  
The kitchen store should be directly accessible from the kitchen,  
the others from the hall. Storage space should be as generous as  
space and budget will allow. **18 Data centres**

# 2 DATA CENTRE TYPES  
DCs can be divided into two main typologies based on the owner-  
ship of the data that is stored within them\:  
Owner-occupied DCs are purpose built to serve the needs of the  
company’s operations or services. They are designed and built with  
the owner’s specific requirements in mind, as a priority. Sometimes  
the owner will have its own Basis of Design \(BOD\) or template that  
needs to be followed. The second type, described as colocation,  
refers to a service provided by organisations that offer a shared,  
secure space for enterprise businesses to store hardware related to  
data storage and other equipment. These colocation companies pro-  
vide leasing services to enterprise businesses, and institutions, and  
so forth, and offer a large selection of computing power and storage  
requirements. The leased space can be subdivided into different  
zones.  
For moderate storage needs, sometimes known as ‘retail’,  
Figure 18.1, the data halls are typically subdivided into small areas,  
with a moderate number of racks in each and separated by secure  
cages. These subdivisions are adaptable to client requirements.  
A single client may also be able to lease a complete data hall,  
without the need for subdivisions, or whole building. This can be  
referred to as large footprint, Figure 18.2, or hyperscale DC and  
provides support to large clients with specific needs.  
# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 Definition  
A data centre \(DC\) is defined as ‘a large group of networked computer  
servers, typically used by organisations for the remote storage, pro-  
cessing or distribution of large amounts of data’ \(Oxford Advanced  
Learner’s Dictionary, Oxford University Press, 2020\). Therefore, a  
DC is, fundamentally, a container of digital data. This data is usu-  
ally stored in servers that are housed alongside networking devices,  
cables and other DC computing equipment in a type of physical steel  
and electronic framework known as a rack. These racks are usually  
modular, with typical dimensions of 600 × 1200 × 2000 mm. The  
array of long, evenly spaced rows, flanked by winking lights, is easily  
recognised as the quintessential image of a data hall, an integral part  
of the infrastructure of modern society.  
The first purpose built rooms for computers date back to the  
1960s, and in the 1990s servers started being installed within stan-  
dalone buildings. Today DC campuses can occupy an area of up to  
four football pitches and can include replication both within a site  
and across a number of sites.  
# 1.2 Characteristics  
All the included electronic equipment creates three characteristics  
that drive the design of the DC building\:  
**18.1** *Typical ‘retail’ data centre layout*  
• It needs a clean, uninterrupted flow of energy to avoid data loss  
• It creates a large amount of heat, which needs to be dissipated  
• It requires a robust data network infrastructure to connect to,  
whether that be cabled or satellite.  
In addition, the stored information within these facilities is usu-  
ally of great value and consequently, the security needs are high  
compared to other building typologies. A DC can be placed in any  
location throughout the globe, and can utilise existing buildings or  
be newly constructed to serve specific client needs.  
DCs are highly efficient, continuously occupied buildings that  
have a large power demand. Energy efficient MEP \(mechanical,  
electrical and plumbing\) solutions can drive the design of the  
building and the location of the site. Due to the importance of pro-  
viding an uninterrupted service, DC buildings are usually grouped  
together to provide resilience.  
**18.2** *Typical large footprint data centre layout*  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-21 **18-1** **18-2 Data centres**  
# 3 ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN  
# 3.1 Basis of design  
The BOD, often provided by the client contains the basic design  
parameters for the DC and describes specific requirements for cer-  
tain types of user. Understanding the BOD and its compatibility  
with local code compliance, and following best practice, is crucial  
for delivering a DC that responds robustly to the ever-increasing  
demands of DC storage globally.  
# 3.2 Site evaluation  
When a potential site is being evaluated as a viable location for  
a DC, the main criteria taken into consideration includes ground  
conditions, transport accessibility, electrical power source relia-  
bility and infrastructure connectivity \(satellite and fibre\). In some  
countries, the main electrical grid may not be reliable, requiring  
generators to become the main source of energy. Equally, if there is  
no fibre connection, or the connection is not fast enough, a satellite  
connection may be preferred.  
The initial stage of a project is to prepare a series of test fits  
in order to arrange all the component parts within the site bound-  
ary, aligned to any planning constraints. Logistics planning for  
goods, plant and deliveries within a secure facility can be chal-  
lenging, since road widths, distances between main buildings and  
secure fence lines overlaid with accessible infrastructure pathways  
becomes a complex web, Figure 18.3. In addition, placement of  
the adjacent mechanical and electrical plant, substation and sup-  
porting equipment compounds can be influenced by neighbouring  
property, wind, ground conditions and site utility intake locations.  
The scope and scale of these plant areas will depend on the pre-  
ferred MEP strategy and, ultimately, the outcome of this task will  
require confirmation by CFD simulation \(Computational Fluid  
Dynamics\) that the positions of the exhaust air intakes for the dif-  
ferent MEP elements are far enough apart to avoid re-entrainment,  
Figure 18.4.  
Adaptability of the building and services to the growing needs  
of the industry can also be a requirement under phased develop-  
ment principles during these early stages of the project.  
# 3.3 Local regulations  
The typology of DCs is not always recognised within the plan-  
ning application categories. The closest building type is usually  
**18.3** *Data centre infrastructure*  
**18.4** *Data centre site components*  
industrial, however the number of building users is often  
much lower than that found within in a manufacturing facil-  
ity. Data centres will require fewer car parking spaces, while  
imposed landscaping requirements can breach security needs  
or affect plant function. Building envelopes have more diverse  
performance criteria and gross external plant areas can be con-  
siderably larger as a percentage comparison. Early engagement  
and clear communication with the Local Authorities is therefore  
crucial to obtain mutual understanding of the particularities of  
the typology.  
# 3.4 Envelope design  
Key points that need to be taken under consideration during the  
early stages of the DC shell design are as follows\:  
• Façade response to climate and aesthetic requirements  
• Weatherproofing  
• Blast and fire resistance  
• Building phasing  
• Façade demountability.  
# 3.5 Layers of security  
Security is one of the most important aspects in the design of the  
DC. As such, a security layering strategy is usually implemented,  
with the data hall itself at the core. The first security level thresh-  
old would be located at the site entrance \(gatehouse\), the second,  
in the entrance to the DC building, and from that point, additional  
zones are defined by access controls, as we approach the core. The  
exact number, disposition, geometry of these layers and the nature  
of the security thresholds are usually defined by the client’s secu-  
rity team.  
# 3.6 Design considerations  
Structural grids are usually scaled up from the basic unit, the racks  
themselves. Fixed rack layout assists with coordination between  
structural and architectural elements, Figure 18.5. Of equal impor-  
tance, is the provision of area for building expansion. Slab-to-slab  
height in the data halls is dependent on the cooling strategy and the  
building services distribution requirements. The cooling strategy  
may be executed from under a raised access floor, directly from the  
sides and into the rack aisles \(creating hot and cold aisles\), or some  
alternative strategy.  
The roof of the DC building can be used to place cooling equip-  
ment. Cooling strategies that are able to effectively handle the  
enormous amount of heat created from the racks often result in  
additional load capacity requirements. The design must consider  
the size of the mechanical elements, their placement within the  
facility and appropriate maintenance.  
Data hall façades should be provided with removable panels  
that allow easy access to the inside of rack areas. Fragile elec-  
tronic equipment should be housed within sealed zones, with a rain  
removal strategy and dust protection to be implemented utilising  
high-quality material finishes throughout, Figure 18.6.  
# 3.7 Adjacencies  
Adjacencies and room sizes present a starting point from which  
designers should instigate the distribution of space. Figure 18.7  
provides an explanation of interfaces between the entrance, staff  
accommodation, customer care, shipping, receiving areas and data  
storage areas.  
Levels of security vary between rooms, and access routes  
for people and equipment are important to resolve in the early  
stages of DC design. Width and height of doors and corridors is  
determined by the dimensions of the server cabinets. DC layout  
and security division is highly affected by the logistics route,  
Figure 18.8. The importance of the position of the loading dock  
has to be included in the early stages of the space distribution  
layout. **Data centres 18-3**  
**18.5** *Data centre spatial coordination*  
**18.6** *Typical data centre components*  
# 4 STRUCTURE  
# 4.1 Purpose  
DCs are functional buildings with a low occupancy. The main  
purpose of the structure is to support the floors and building enve-  
lope as efficiently as possible with minimal impact to the layouts.  
Speed and programme, both in the design and construction phases,  
are usually significant drivers for clients. The key challenge for  
the structural team is to design an efficient structure which is well  
co-ordinated with the MEP services.  
# 4.2 Data centre forms  
DC buildings are typically low-rise as they tend to be located in  
semi-industrial areas, where it is cheaper to purchase additional land  
than to construct multiple storeys to achieve a given floor area. Typical  
DCs have one or two storeys with ground-bearing ground floor slabs,  
where ground conditions permit. Where ground conditions are poor,  
ground slabs are suspended from a grid of piled foundations at close  
centres. However, trends towards locating DCs at the edges of towns  
or cities may lead towards taller, multi-storey DCs in the future.  
# 4.3 Choice of material  
The choice between a steel or concrete frame will likely be driven  
by local practices. In-situ frames are not a typical solution as they  
are characteristically slow to construct. Steel-framed solutions  
incorporating composite floor slabs are a preferred solution within  
the UK and northern Europe, due to the speed of site construction  
and the maturity of the steel industries in these countries. Precast  
solutions, incorporating precast beams/columns and hollow core or  
T-section slabs with a structural topping, are more common among  
other global locations. Concrete options, particularly precast **18-4 Data centres**  
**18.7** *Data centre room adjacencies*  
**18.8** *Data centre logistic routes*  
concrete, which typically has a higher cement content than in-situ  
concrete, will likely contain significantly higher embodied carbon  
than a steel-framed option.  
# 4.4 Stability  
DCs do not tend to lend themselves to having stability cores, as is  
typical in commercial or residential buildings, for example. This is  
because stairs and lifts are fewer in number and are small in size  
compared to the plan size of the floor plates. Stability is typically pro-  
vided by braced bays in steel-framed construction or by reinforced  
concrete walls in precast construction. Stability elements should  
be placed towards the centre of floor plates to minimise strains and  
shrinkage of floor slabs. A symmetrical arrangement of stability is key  
for buildings in seismic regions. Large floor plates will require move-  
ment joints to split the building up into lengths of around 80–100 m  
maximum to limit movements due to shrinkage and thermal effects. **Data centres 18-5**  
# 4.5 Column grids  
Maximising the usable floor space within a data hall is a key design  
consideration for a DC. Columns cause disruption to rack layouts  
and each column may mean the loss of a cabinet position. Some  
common examples of structural grids are 9.6 m × 9.6 m or 7.2 m ×  
12 m for multi-storey data centres. However, longer spans are  
preferred by some clients to reduce the impact on cabinet layouts.  
Single-storey DCs without roof plant typically also have longer  
spans.  
Grids are usually a multiple of 600 mm as this is the grid of  
a typical raised floor system or ceiling tile. Longer spans will  
necessitate deeper beams or trusses, which may increase the sto-  
rey height unless service routes can be designed to pass through  
beam web openings, or between truss diagonals. For shorter  
spans, the services zone is usually located below the structure  
to allow for greater flexibility of the positioning and routing of  
these services. Some DCs incorporate a lightweight suspended  
services support grid below the main services to support cabling  
for the server cabinets. There is often scope to adjust the col-  
umn grid within the administration or front-of-house areas as  
the layouts are not governed by the regular grid of the data halls.  
Floor levels within these areas may also be adjusted to allow an  
additional floor, as the floor to ceiling height required is smaller  
– 4 m typically as opposed to 6 m or more required in the data  
halls.  
# 4.6 Floor loading  
DC loads are very high – some typical values are provided in  
Table I. The loading for data halls is governed by the weight and  
density of the server cabinets with some additional allowance for  
personnel access loads. The density of suspended services at ceil-  
ing level is also high, with typical allowances varying between  
1.5 kN/m2 in data halls to 2.4 kN/m2 along corridors where services  
routes are concentrated. DCs that are water-cooled can have par-  
ticularly high services loads from heavy water-filled pipes. Point  
loads may be governing for the design of thin concrete slabs in  
composite construction.  
# 5 RESILIENCE  
# 5.1 Concepts  
Resilience and redundancy are key concepts that are critical for the  
design and deployment of DC infrastructure. Resilience is defined  
as the ability to recover from a fault or equipment failure, mini-  
mising or avoiding any downtime to the system. Redundancy, on  
the other hand, is defined as the intentional duplication of system  
components in order to minimise or avoid any disruption to opera-  
tion, therefore improving resilience. These concepts are commonly  
applied to all disciplines to achieve the level of continuity desired  
for the specific DC type required.  
# 5.2 Definitions  
Within the following section, the different redundancy typologies  
will be explained and therefore it is important to define how they  
are referenced. Generally, the term N is used to define the mini-  
mum amount of equipment or components required for the system  
to operate, Figure 18.9. Based on this, the definition of the follow-  
ing redundancy typologies is\:  
• N\: the system consists of one component of each type with no  
redundancy. In this case, the system only provides power via one  
path to the load. There is a single point of failure \(SPOF\) on the  
final load being supplied.  
# 4.7 Vibration  
Response factor is a consideration for DC floors, although this  
does not tend to be a governing factor. Vibration limits for data  
communication equipment varies between items and values pre-  
sented in different ways, and by different manufacturers. The  
ASHRAE publication *Structural and Vibration Guidelines for*  
*Datacom Equipment Centres* \(2008\) suggests 0.07 g is a typical  
maximum level of operational vibration encountered in a data cen-  
tre. Response factors of R = 4 are typically targeted in line with  
workshop limits. Low levels of fit-out with infrequent partitions  
mean that critical damping may be as low as 1.5 per cent for steel-  
framed construction.

• N+N\: the system consists of two components of each type. The system provides power via two separate paths to the load.  
There is no SPOF on the final load being supplied.  
• N+1 Distributed redundant\: System provides power via two  
separate paths to the loads. There is no SPOF on the final load,  
system configuration shares load across different power systems.  
# 5.3 Tier ratings  
When defining the system resilience of a DC, tier ratings are com-  
monly used within the industry. DC tiers provide a framework  
used to describe specific kinds of DC infrastructure in a consist-  
ent way, Table II. Tier 1 is the simplest infrastructure, while Tier  
4 is the most complex and has the most redundant components.  
Each tier includes the required components of all the tiers below it.  
Typically, colocation or enterprise DCs tend to fall under the Tier  
III category.  
# 6 MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT  
# 6.1 Introduction  
This section explains the basic principles of the mechanical systems  
present in a DC. One of the main purposes of a DC is to maintain  
the optimal environmental conditions required for the operation of  
the IT equipment within it. These are commonly temperature and  
humidity. In the majority of DCs, these systems are expected to  
operate continuously and reliably to guarantee the operation of the  
IT infrastructure.  
To achieve this, the mechanical system is required to remove  
the heat produced by the IT equipment, transferring it to a heat  
sink \(typically the atmosphere\) and ensuring that the air is clean  
and with the correct level of humidity for the specific equipment  
characteristics. The ventilation system is in charge of extracting  
and supplying fresh air to the data halls, controlling the humidity  
levels and filtering any particles that could damage the equipment.  
The cooling system of a DC can be split into two different sections  
of data hall cooling and the heat rejection system, as described in  
the following sections.  
# 6.2 Data hall cooling  
The data hall is the main area where the IT equipment is installed  
and operated. Within these areas, cold air is commonly used to  
cool down the servers and other ancillary equipment. This cold air  
would be blown from an air-conditioning unit into the area where  
the servers are located. The most typical types of air-conditioning  
units are\:  
• CRAC – computer room air-conditioning  
• CRAH – computer room air handler  
• Fan Walls – a type of CRAH, usually offering larger cooling  
capacities  
• In-row cooler – air-conditioning system placed between the  
server cabinets offering a more direct and effective solution, and  
handling higher power densities.  
Once cold air leaves the air-conditioning units, it is either chan-  
nelled using a pressurised floor void system or simply blown  
straight into the IT equipment. After passing through the serv-  
ers, this air rises in temperature, so it is extremely important  
that it return immediately to the air-conditioning unit for cool-  
ing. This process is repeated, continuously forming a cycle. In  
Figure 18.10, two typical data hall cooling arrangements are  
presented. It is very common for these rooms to use air con-  
tainment systems to segregate the cold and hot areas to prevent  
undesired recirculation. This allows the heat exchange process to

reducing running costs of the cooling infrastructure. The two air  
containment systems are\:  
• HAC\: hot aisle containment, where hot server exhaust air is con-  
tained, returning to the air-conditioning units via a plenum. In  
this configuration the common server room areas are generally  
colder as the heat is channelled straight back into the air-condi-  
tioning units.  
• CAC\: cold aisle containment, where the cool air from the  
air-conditioning units is contained and directed straight into the  
IT equipment. In this configuration, the common server room  
areas are generally hotter as the heat is exhausted into the server  
room instead of channelled straight back into the air-condition-  
ing units.  
# 6.3 Heat rejection system  
Once the server heat is removed from the server room, it must be  
rejected to a heat sink. The most typical heat sink is the atmos-  
phere; however other choices are available, such as water or the  
ground. In order to do so, the heat rejection equipment must be  
located externally. The preferred location is the roof area of the  
facility; however, if roof areas are not available due to planning  
restrictions, plant can be located to the side of main DC. The heat  
rejection process is carried out by using heat exchangers. These  
devices transfer heat between two or more fluids. Heat travels by  
conduction through the exchanger materials which separate the  
fluids being utilised. Heat flows from hot to cold elements and in  
the particular case of the DC, the hot fluid coming from the server  
room \(either air, water or any other refrigerant\) would transfer the  
# Data centres 18-7  
heat into the cooler air located outside the facility. Some examples  
of equipment used for heat rejection are chillers, cooling towers,  
direct air coolers and air handing units. In a DC, the main systems  
used to facilitate the passage of heat from the server room to the  
heat rejection system are\:  
• Air based system – using a ductwork system to route the hot air  
from the server room into the external heat rejection plant sys-  
tem. This air is moved by fans.  
• Water or refrigerant based system – using a pipework system to  
get the warm water or refrigerant coming from the server room  
into the external heat rejection plant system. These liquids are  
moved by a pumping system.  
# 7 ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS  
# 7.1 System types  
Another key purpose of a DC is to provide sufficient power for  
the IT equipment to operate continuously. Similarly, to the cool-  
ing systems, these systems are expected to operate reliably without  
interruption to avoid any downtime in the IT infrastructure. Within  
the following sections, the basic principles of the electrical systems  
present in a DC will be explained. The electrical systems within a  
DC can be subdivided into the following\:  
• Transformers  
• Back-up generators  
• UPS and energy storage  
• Power distribution.  
**18.10** *Data hall cooling arrangements* **18-8 Data centres**  
# 7.2 Transformers  
In a DC, like any other building typology, the main power is pro-  
vided by the local distribution operator via their network, which  
can operate at different voltage levels\:  
• Extra high voltage \(\>230 kV\)  
• High voltage \(35 kV-230 kV\)  
• Medium voltage \(1 kV-35 kV\)  
• Low voltage \(\<1 kV\).  
Depending on the local voltage, it is often required to transform it  
to a suitable level for either its distribution within the facility, or  
directly power the end IT equipment. Power transformers are used  
to convert the electricity to the desired voltage and would usually  
be located in dedicated substations, either externally or internally.  
These come in different sizes depending on the power and voltage  
requirements.  
# 7.3 Back-up generators  
Due to the requirement for continuous power, DCs demand  
auxiliary back-up systems that allow the IT equipment to run con-  
tinuously, even if the utility power is lost. The reliability of utility  
companies vary dependent on specific location, and therefore it is  
essential for a DC to be provided with a resilient back-up system  
that can take over the load. The most common back-up systems are\:  
• Diesel generators  
• Gas generators  
• DRUPS \(Diesel rotary uninterruptable supplies\).  
# 7.4 Uninterruptible power supply \(UPS\)  
Despite generators providing full back-up to the installed load  
within the facility, these can normally take some time to become  
online. This means that for a short period of time, between the tran-  
sition from utility to generators, the load would lose power. To  
mitigate this, UPS are commonly used in DCs. UPS is a type of  
equipment that provides power continuously without downtime,  
relying on batteries to power the load when the mains power has  
failed. This is achieved by using extremely fast auto-changeover  
systems, ensuring that the transition from utility to battery supply is  
quick enough to be unnoticeable for the IT systems \(milliseconds\).  
In addition to this, the units condition the incoming power filtering  
any voltage or frequency deviations that could affect the operation  
of the final load, providing clean uninterrupted power.  
# 7.5 Power distribution  
From the point where the facility connects to the utility network to  
the final circuits powering the racks, the system is subdivided into  
different steps that distribute the power throughout the DC. This  
is normally achieved by introducing electrical panels \(also known  
as switchboards\) that will allow the power to be shared between  
multiple systems. These switchboards will power the mechanical  
and IT systems, as depicted in Figure 18.11, by either using cabling  
or busbars to transport the energy down into the system. The power  
distribution within the server rooms is normally provided by the  
following equipment\:  
• PDU \(power distribution unit\) – a device similar to a distribution  
board used to power the IT equipment within the server room.  
These are provided with special metering systems that allow cus-  
tomer billing and energy monitoring.  
• Busway system – a prefabricated electrical distribution system  
consisting of busbars in a protective enclosure, running at high  
level within the rack aisles. It is common that servers are pro-  
vided with dual power supplies, using diverse routes to ensure  
full power redundancy.  
# 8 IT SYSTEMS  
Connectivity with wider telecommunications infrastructure is a  
significant aspect of the DC facility comparable to the MEP sys-  
tems. The IT system infrastructure design needs to be prudently  
designed to provide the right level of resilience and redundancy  
to the data transported to the servers. To achieve this, dual and  
diverse networks are usually required, Figure 18.12. Commonly  
within DCs, the following elements can be identified \(note that  
these terms and topologies vary depending on the different type of  
facilities and clients\)\:  
• Incoming telecommunications – the point at which the external  
networks enter the site wide telecoms network.  
• Zero vault – the point at which the external telecoms network  
enter the DC building.  
• PoE \(Point of Entry\) or entrance facility – this is usually a room  
and is where the point of transition between external grade and  
internal grade cabling occurs.  
• Fibre room – the space used to facilitate the interconnection  
of different service providers as well as network distribution  
throughout the facility.  
• MMR \(Meet-me-room\) – the space where interconnection equip-  
ment is housed. This is also used to facilitate the interconnection  
of different service providers.  
• IR \(Infrastructure room\) – the space where landlord IT equipment  
is housed to support the internal infrastructure required to run the  
facility such as Building Management System, Environmental  
Monitoring System, security, corporate network, and so forth.  
# 9 HANDLING AND EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE  
Within critical facilities, where business continuity is an essential  
factor to be considered for its design and operation, the replace-  
ment and maintenance of the equipment and their component parts  
**18.11** *Typical electrical distribution* **18.12** *Typical IT network typology* must be carefully planned. This should allow for all the appropriate  
health and safety measures to ensure personnel safety is not com-  
promised. All equipment must be positioned so it can be replaced  
relatively easily upon either failure or due to end of life. This pro-  
cess should be planned by producing a plant replacement strategy,  
establishing the requirements, routes and procedures to be used to  
enable the equipment removal, Figure 18.13.  
Equipment, during the course of its life, requires periodi-  
cal maintenance to ensure its durability and correct operation.  
To ensure this, equipment must be positioned respecting man-  
ufacturers’ access, clearance requirements and aligned with  
the respective local code requirements. This will allow equip-  
ment to be accessed comfortably by the relevant technical  
staff, increasing the health and safety and overall operation of  
the facility. Due to phasing and expansion in DCs, the facility  
must be afforded the means of installing equipment post-build-  
ing completion, as not all equipment and infrastructure will be  
required from Day 1. The DC must be provided with alternative  
ways of having an operational building while the contractor is  
expanding its infrastructure. This should be achieved without  
mutual interference.  
Lastly, one of the latest trends in the industry is the off-site man-  
ufacture of modularised systems. This is effectively the process of  
creating complete systems integrated into a single platform that can  
be manufactured away from site \(in an improved health and safety  
environment\) ready to be installed in the facility with minimal  
on-site integration, providing programme improvements as well as  
increased on-site health and safety.  
# 10 SECURITY  
# 10.1 Aim  
Today, these facilities are considered as critical national infra-  
structure components due to the prevalence of cloud computing,  
outsourced IT provisions by organisations and government, and  
the adoption of internet-based communication and social media by  
the general public. Security of the facilities and the information  
held within them, is therefore, vital to the operation of ensure ser-  
vice continuity. Service-level agreements, and various regulations  
such as GDPR, and those set by the location country’s Information  
Commissioners are to be adhered to. All DC security design should  
be risk-led and aim at ensuring that the principles of ‘deter, delay,  
detect and detain’ are achieved when planning the facility. Not  
all of these can be implemented as part of the design of the built  
environment, as operational measures will be required. It is vital  
that the design be aligned with the operations and that the design  
team work closely with the client operation and security teams to  
ensure this.  
**18.13** *Transformer replacement example*  
# Data centres 18-9  
# 10.2 Security zones  
To implement the principles, it is important that the facility be  
divided into security zones. These may align with operational and  
functional zones. Complete physical segregation can be used, or  
an overlap, which means electronic security is applied to enforce  
movement controls on portals on boundary transitions. The funda-  
mental aim is to prevent unauthorised access to information, the  
systems managing information and the supporting MEP infrastruc-  
ture, which could disrupt the service. DCs provide a wide range  
of services which require different levels of segregation to be pro-  
vided within the ‘white space’, depending upon the service being  
provided. Typically, the site can be divided into up to five security  
zones, the criticality of the function increasing with the zone num-  
ber, as shown in Figure 18.14, thus adopting an onion layer effect  
and increasing levels of security.  
Security considerations must start at the point of site selection  
and orientation to ensure that critical functions are not located in vul-  
nerable positions and access to the facility is controlled, Table III.  
Zone 1 is considered semi-public and the measures should deter and  
detect unauthorised access by providing a secure boundary to peo-  
ple and vehicles. This will require clear margins to be established  
on both sides of the boundary and minimum clearances between the  
boundary and the facilities. Entrances into the site should be kept  
to a minimum and may require significant space and organisation  
subject to the client requirements. Figure 18.15 shows a complex  
entry-exit arrangement. It is important that as a minimum, it is  
possible to hold vehicles outside of the site boundary, check their  
credentials and reject them without them gaining access to the site.  
# 10.3 Segregation  
Once inside the site, segregation is required between technical areas  
and those accessible to visitors and staff. Access to these areas and  
the operational areas should be controlled and not accessible to vis-  
itors. All people accessing Zone 3 should be fully accredited and  
passed through a control point that ensures this. Other areas that  
required special consideration are\:  
• Secure stores  
• Security operational control room  
• Security equipment room  
• Unloading and goods receipt area  
• MMRs  
• Destruction/ shredding facilities  
• White space/data halls.  
Details of the zones they fall in are outlined in the zoning table,  
Table IV and in Figure 18.16. These areas should be discussed with

# 11 FIRE PROTECTION  
DCs, like other buildings in the UK, must comply with the life  
safety requirements defined in Part B of Building Regulations.  
However, DCs are highly valuable assets and therefore, property  
protection and business continuity must also be considered as part  
of the fire strategy design. With regard to life safety, the guidance  
in Approved Document B or BS 9999 Fire safety in the design,  
management and use of building – Code of practice is considered  
appropriate in order to define\:  
• Detection and alarm provisions  
• Means of escape  
• Internal fire spread due lining materials

• Fire compartmentation • Structural fire resistance • External fire spread to adjoining buildings or properties • Fire brigade access and facilities. BS 9999 is commonly used in the design of DCs as it provides  
greater degree of flexibility, for example on the definition of maxi-  
mum travel distances. Some key considerations that must be given  
to the design of DCs regarding fire safety are\: • Design of DC ventilation systems and their impact on detection  
and/or fire suppression  
• Provision of high-risk areas and equipment such as generators  
and associated diesel storage, high voltage equipment and bat-  
tery storage  
• Conflicts between security and fire safety \(e.g. secured access  
failing safe on fire detection, available access points for fire bri-  
gade intervention\).  
In addition to the measures in the selected fire safety guidance doc-  
ument, the following are typically requested by clients to fulfil the  
property protection and business continuity goals\:  
• Automatic detection and alarm  
• Automatic fire suppression \(sprinklers, water mist or gas suppression\)  
# Data centres 18-11  
• Additional fire compartmentation leading to smaller fire  
compartments  
• Use of non-combustible materials.  
In addition to in country code compliance, all DC providers will  
have additional insurance requirements in relation to property  
protection.
