# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 Health  
The World Health Organization defines health as ‘a state of com-  
plete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the  
absence of disease or infirmity’ \(*Constitution of the World Health*  
*Organization – Basic Documents*, 45th edition, Supplement,  
October 2006\).  
Traditionally, healthcare provision has focused primarily on the  
latter half of this definition\: the technical challenge of defeating a  
medical condition, at the expense of the less easily definable and  
measurable actions required to support the first part. The result is a  
reactive system that treats healthcare as a series of isolated episodes,  
rather than a proactive ongoing process focused on anticipating and,  
where possible, preventing the need for medical treatment.  
Too often, the design of healthcare buildings has reflected this  
imbalance, creating institutional and de-humanising environments.  
However, research clearly demonstrates the benefits of a more  
holistic approach to healthcare design, and architects have devel-  
oped new approaches that better support the needs of all hospital  
users. The ability to deliver these benefits is challenged, however,  
by current economic conditions, and by procurement routes that  
focus on narrow definitions of value.  
# 1.2 Challenges  
Hospitals are among the most complex of building types, requiring  
the designer to find a solution that resolves numerous potentially  
conflicting needs. Hospitals are highly advanced facilities,  
incorporating complex circulation networks, extensive environ-  
mental systems and advanced technologies. But they are also civic  
buildings that must prioritise the creation of attractive and coherent  
spaces that are inherently legible, safe and secure and spatially effi-  
cient.  
Several standardised design templates for hospitals have been  
developed in the past, such as the Nucleus Hospitals built in  
large numbers in the UK from the mid-1970s to the early 1990s.  
However, these large-scale standardised systems could not adapt  
to deliver the specifics of local healthcare need, or to overcome  
site constraints, resulting in hospitals that were inherently compro-  
mised and, in some respects, inflexible. Subsequent standardisation  
initiatives have focused on smaller elements such as repeatable  
rooms and components.  
In reality, every hospital is different. In the UK, new hospital  
developments are mostly sited on an existing hospital campus,  
and therefore must deliver the specified accommodation, while  
resolving complex challenges imposed by the existing estate, and  
devising a construction strategy that enables clinical services to  
continue with minimal disruption during construction.  
The key to successfully negotiating these complexities is to  
develop an iterative design process that alternates engagement with  
input from stakeholders with the progression of the design propos-  
als. This approach will need to be bespoke to each project. At the  
early stages, several strands might be developed in parallel, such  
as consultation to capture and sign off the client’s functional needs  
and aspirations, high-level testing of building organisation strate-  
gies, site analysis and design studies for the key repeating building  
blocks \(such as a standard single bedroom or outpatients consult-  
ing room\) that will combine to form a high proportion of the total  
building. As the design moves forward through multiple iterations,  
it will become progressively more detailed and coordinated, and  
will need to negotiate a series of client approval processes. During  
these stages, the architect performs a crucial role in defending the  
client’s aspirations against dilution or compromise.  
# 1.3 Hospital design skills  
The design of hospitals draws upon both general design skills and  
highly specialised sector-specific knowledge. Maintaining a careful  
balance between achieving quantitative objectives and creating an  
environment that enriches the lives of all those who use the build-  
ing is fundamental\: hospitals are places of care, and care cannot be  
defined in purely technical terms.  
To achieve this balance, it is essential that the architect\:  
• Understands how a medical facility will be used and occupied  
from the perspective of patients, clinical staff, support staff and  
the families and carers of patients  
• Knows what guidance can be drawn upon to ensure that a new  
facility will achieve current best practice, and how to apply that  
guidance to the unique needs of a specific project  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-23 **20-1** **20-2 Hospitals**  
• Keeps abreast of changes in health needs and healthcare and the  
latest research  
• Plans for current needs, while ensuring that future change is  
facilitated  
• Works collaboratively with the other design disciplines to  
resolve the complex technical and coordination issues associated  
with highly serviced healthcare environments  
• Prioritises creating the best possible environment for all building  
users by using the same tools as for any other building type\: light,  
colour, spatial variety, simplicity and a relationship with nature.  
# 2 CONTEXT  
# 2.1 The National Health Service \(NHS\)  
The NHS is the name used to refer to the autonomous public health-  
care systems in England, Scotland and Wales. In Northern Ireland  
public health services are provided by Health and Social Care  
Northern Ireland \(HSC\). These four health systems are responsible  
for the provision of the vast majority of healthcare services in the UK.  
In the UK, the majority of healthcare services are provided by the  
NHS. Though it is synonymous with healthcare in the UK, it is just  
the largest component in a complex network of care providers that  
also includes local government provided social care, care provided  
by voluntary and charitable organisations, and private healthcare.  
Alternate providers may provide their services ‘privately’ or may  
provide services which are procured by the NHS to deliver ‘public’  
services. In many cases the same organisation will do both.  
The NHS was founded in 1948, based on three key principles\:  
• That it meets the needs of everyone  
• That it be free at the point of delivery  
• That it be based on clinical need, not ability to pay.  
Publicly funded healthcare provision in England is controlled  
at governmental level by the Department of Health, which takes  
overall responsibility for the organisations that comprise the NHS.  
Recent reforms have focused on introducing market-based reforms  
to the service. These changes have been driven both by adherence  
at governmental level to free market economic principles, and by  
the need for the NHS to evolve to meet the challenges of changing  
health needs and demographics.  
In *The NHS Constitution* \(2011\), the founding principles of the  
NHS were expanded\:  
• Access to NHS services is based on clinical need, not an individ-  
ual’s ability to pay  
• The NHS aspires to the highest standards of excellence and pro-  
fessionalism  
• The NHS aspires to put patients at the heart of everything it does  
• The NHS works across organisational boundaries and in part-  
nership with other organisations in the interest of patients, local  
communities and the wider population  
• The NHS is committed to providing best value for taxpayers’  
money and the most effective, fair and sustainable use of finite  
resources  
• The NHS is accountable to the public, communities and patients  
that it serves.  
These reflect a changing political context in which facilitating  
consumer choice and creating competition between healthcare  
providers is seen as crucial to meeting increasing demands upon  
healthcare providers, and to driving efficiency. These changes are  
reflected in the relegation of the commitment for the service to be  
free at the point of delivery to a note within Principle 2, which  
states that ‘NHS services are free of charge, except in limited cir-  
cumstances sanctioned by Parliament’. Instances where charges  
currently apply include drug prescriptions, and most eye care and  
dental services, where patients are required to pay a contribution  
towards the cost of their care, calculated based \(to some extent\) on  
their ability to pay.  
# 2.2 Whole health economy  
The structure of healthcare provision in the UK is a complex sys-  
tem referred to as the whole health economy. Care in a hospital  
setting may occur at several points in this process. Healthcare pro-  
vision is structured as follows\:  
• *Primary care*\: The first point of contact a patient has when they  
require a healthcare service. Primary care includes General  
Practitioners \(GPs\), dental practices and optometrists.  
• *Secondary care*\: Healthcare provided by clinicians who do not  
usually have first contact with patients, including specialists.  
Patients will generally either receive secondary care following  
a referral by a GP, or following attendance at an Emergency  
Department. Non-emergency secondary care could take the form  
of a consultation with a specialist, a planned surgical procedure  
or a diagnostic investigation. Secondary healthcare is most often  
provided in a hospital setting, but not always.  
• *Tertiary care*\: Highly specialised healthcare, for instance care that  
requires input from consultants with very specific expertise, or  
access to advanced diagnostic modalities or surgical facilities, of a  
level that is not available at most hospitals. Tertiary care will gener-  
ally be received following a referral from primary or secondary care.  
Due to its specialist nature, Tertiary care will normally be available  
on a regional basis, rather than local to a particular population.  
• *Quaternary care*\: The most specialised healthcare, such as  
advanced diagnostic and surgical procedures, or the application  
of experimental approaches to the treatment of medical con-  
ditions. Such services are only provided in a small number of  
locations, either regionally or nationally.  
• *Mental health care*\: Including community, day and inpatient ser-  
vices for people requiring mental health care.  
• *Community health services*\: Community Healthcare NHS Trusts  
provide a wide range of non-acute services that include com-  
munity nursing, therapies, non-acute outpatient and inpatient  
services, support for people with disabilities and chronic health  
conditions, and walk in and urgent care centres.  
• *Social care*\: The definition of social care includes a wide range  
of services to support people who are at risk, or who have needs  
caused by illness, disability, old age or poverty. Social care  
services such as home/domiciliary care and residential nursing  
home care are closely related to and impact upon healthcare ser-  
vices. In England and Wales, social care is currently in most  
instances the responsibility of local authorities, though there are  
moves towards greater integration with the NHS. In Northern  
Ireland and Scotland, health and social care are delivered by  
integrated service providers.  
• Care funded by the NHS may also be provided by private and  
third sector organisations.  
The vast majority of hospital buildings will be for the provision  
of secondary care. Most of the facilities in these buildings will be  
developed from tried-and-tested standard approaches, and design  
guidance will therefore be applicable in most instances, although  
changing methods of delivery may result in differing require-  
ments. Health buildings providing tertiary and quaternary care may  
require more innovative and bespoke approaches to their design to  
reflect the more specialist nature of the care they provide, and more  
project-specific research regarding the architectural implications of  
new or experimental forms of care.  
# 2.3 Specialist hospital and healthcare facilities  
These cater specifically for a type of illness, chronic or complex  
condition in an appropriate environment. Hospitals include\:  
• *Cancer/oncology hospitals*\: These combine the highest quality  
of diagnosis, treatment and care, include research and education  
and provide specialist equipment with latest technologies. Refer  
to *HBN 02–01 Cancer treatment facilities*.  
• *Children’s hospitals*\: By grouping children together, a safer  
environment can be created. Children must be treated by clini-  
cians specialised in their care. Further specific requirements are  
the provision of accommodation for parents within the patient  
room, a variety and choice of play areas, and stimulation through  
interior and graphics besides specially designed fittings and fur-  
niture for children of different ages \(Figure 20.1\). Refer to *HBN*  
*23 – Hospital accommodation for children and young people*.  
• *Maternity*\: The facility needs to cater for women at different  
stages of their pregnancy. Maternity buildings provide different  
types of accommodation accompanying the birthing process as  
well as critical care services. Specific requirements include a  
variety and choice of delivery rooms, and an emphasis on pri-  
vacy, dignity and a less clinical and more domestic environment.  
Refer to *HBN 09–02 Maternity Care Facilities*.  
• *Heart \(cardiac care\) hospitals*.  
Healthcare facilities include\:  
• *Accommodation for rehabilitation*\: Due to the nature of injuries  
being treated and facilities being provided \(e.g. hydrotherapy  
pool\), the accommodation is mainly provided in single storey  
# Hospitals 20-3  
buildings to provide level access for the patients, and the build-  
ing usually spreads over a larger footprint.  
• *Renal \(kidney\) units*\: Refer to HBN 07–02 Main Renal Unit or  
HBN 07–01 Satellite dialysis unit.  
• *Elderly/nursing homes*\: Compared to a hospital environment, nurs-  
ing homes and facilities for the elderly provide more communal  
spaces for interaction, consist of mainly single room accommodation  
and emphasise the separation between genders to enhance dignity.  
• *Dementia centres*\: Refer to HBN 08–02 Dementia-friendly  
Health and Social Care Environments.  
• *Primary and Community Care Services*\: Refer to HBN 11–01.  
# 2.4 The Health and Social Care Act 2012  
The current structure for how healthcare services in England are  
commissioned was created through the implementation of the  
Health and Social Care Act 2012. In the previous structure, most  
hospital-based healthcare was controlled by geographically defined  
Primary Care Trusts \(PCTs\), working within a strategic context  
established by Strategic Health Authorities \(SHAs\). This system  
has been replaced by a structure in which Clinical Commissioning  
Groups \(CCGs\) control the commissioning of hospital-based and  
community healthcare services.  
CCGs are currently responsible for commissioning services  
that comprise approximately two-thirds of the total NHS England  
budget. The key difference between CCGs and the PCTs they  
replaced is that CCGs are membership bodies, comprising local GP  
practices, led by an elected governing body primarily comprising  
GPs, together with other clinicians and lay members.  
**20.1** *Sheffield Children’s Hospital by Avanti Architects. A light-filled and playful main entrance atrium entices and engages children* **20-4 Hospitals**  
These changes to the structure of the NHS were implemented  
with the aim of promoting localised control of commissioning, in  
order to increase patient choice, drive cost efficiencies through the  
elimination of a layer of administration, and open up opportuni-  
ties for private and voluntary sector organisations to compete with  
NHS Trusts to deliver publicly funded healthcare services.  
Since 2017, mergers between CCGs have been permitted, and  
a process of consolidation into bodies covering larger portions of  
cities and regions is now ongoing.  
# 2.5 Sustainability and transformation partnerships and  
# integrated care systems  
In recent years, portions of the NHS have increasingly struggled  
to deal with the challenges of increasing demand and changing  
demographics. This is compounded by the fragmented nature of  
healthcare provision in England that recent NHS reorganisations  
have contributed to. A need for joined up local strategies, devel-  
oped with input from stakeholders from across the Whole Health  
Economy, has been identified as the means to tackle these chal-  
lenges, and in so doing help to address the increasing financial  
pressures affecting many parts of the NHS.  
This identified need led to the implementation of Sustainability  
and Transformation Plans \(STPs\) for all parts of England during  
2016\. These created ‘place-based plans’ for the future of health  
and care services in each of the 44 areas. The stakeholders for each  
plan area are the local NHS Trusts, local authorities and CCGs. The  
collaborative process for the creation of these plans is intended to  
ensure that services are delivered by the most appropriate part of  
the local health and care system, and that decisions are not skewed  
by the priorities of individual organisations.  
The definition of the STP acronym has more recently been  
changed to Sustainability and Transformation Partnership, and a  
process has begun in which all STPs will become Integrated Care  
Systems \(ICSs\). ICSs comprise NHS organisations, local authori-  
ties and other bodies, which take collective responsibility for the  
effective management of care provision, and for the health of the  
population they serve.  
Together, these changes represent a move from the focus on gen-  
erating competition between healthcare providers that was central  
to the 2012 Health and Social Care Act, towards the prioritisation  
of collaboration between public sector bodies with responsibilities  
relating to health and care.  
# 2.6 Key differences in how health services function  
# across the UK  
The key differences between the NHS organisations providing  
care in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland relate to  
the relationship between healthcare and social care provision. The  
separation of social care from health care, with the former being  
provided by local authorities and the latter by the NHS, has been  
seen in recent years as significantly contributing to deteriorating  
quality and escalating financial deficits among NHS Trusts in  
England. In Northern Ireland, there is a long-established princi-  
ple that health and social care services are provided by combined  
organisations. Scotland has recently established Integration Joint  
Boards \(local authority social care and NHS community care inte-  
grated boards\) to ensure that the provision of healthcare and social  
care is coordinated. In England, several regions have pioneered  
similar integrated approaches.  
# 2.7 Healthcare funding  
Since the financial crisis of 2008, growth in government expenditure  
on the NHS has fallen behind. While it is still matching inflation, it  
is not matching increases in need caused by demographic change,  
and increases in cost required to fund new treatments.  
Cost per person of healthcare varies to a very substantial degree  
worldwide. While the UK is ranked towards the upper end of the  
scale for healthcare expenditure per capita, it is ranked below many  
similarly developed economies. By many measures, the NHS is  
highly efficient in how it uses the funding it receives. Outcomes  
related to treatment for certain conditions, such as cancers, lag  
behind other similar nations, however, and this has been argued is  
the result of long-term underinvestment.  
In the current funding climate, NHS client bodies are needing  
to optimise the efficiency of spending on capital projects \(such  
as buildings\), making the best possible use of existing assets \(for  
instance through refurbishment of existing buildings\), and not  
committing to large scale redevelopment projects whose benefits  
will only be fully felt in the long term.  
In recognition of the risks associated with longstanding restric-  
tions on capital funding for healthcare infrastructure in 2019, the  
UK government introduced the Health Infrastructure Plan \(HIP\) as  
the means to plan and fund the upgrading of the built estate used  
by the NHS. The aim of the plan is to modernise the estate, support  
the use of new treatments and technologies, eliminate safety risks  
and reduce the drain on resources caused by the increasing cost of  
backlog maintenance. The ambition of the plan is to transform the  
NHS’s infrastructure – whether funding will be made available to  
achieve this goal is not yet clear.  
# 2.8 Demographic change  
Demographic changes are putting ever-increasing pressures on  
healthcare delivery. People are living longer, and improvements in  
treatment are extending the lifespans of patients with chronic medi-  
cal conditions, but at a cost. These changes will increasingly be felt  
in the design of hospitals, particularly in the need to create environ-  
ments that take into account the needs of patients with dementia.  
These demographic changes have played a key role in one of  
the most significant issues to affect the operation of hospitals in  
recent years – ‘bed-blocking’. The ageing population, shortages of  
funding for social care, and the split in responsibility for inpatient  
and social care between NHS and local government organisations,  
have led to problems in discharging patients. This in turn results  
in unnecessary costs being incurred caring for patients who do not  
need to be in hospital, while reducing the throughput of patients  
who require inpatient care.  
The impacts of the ageing population are not uniform, however,  
and a single, generalised design response would not be appropri-  
ate. The design of healthcare facilities should reflect local needs,  
taking into account the age, income and cultural profile of the local  
population.  
The nature of hospital accommodation is also being impacted  
by the rise in the proportion of the population that are overweight,  
with facilities increasingly being designed to enable care for  
severely overweight \(bariatric\) patients.  
# 2.9 Technological advances  
Medical advances have also affected the types of healthcare buildings  
that are being commissioned, generating some important efficiencies  
in the quantity of accommodation required to deliver services. In par-  
ticular, advances in minimally intrusive surgical procedures mean that  
many patients that would previously have required inpatient care dur-  
ing their recovery can now be treated and discharged during one day.  
This is one of a number of changes that may result in reductions  
of inpatient beds on hospital sites in the future. As a high propor-  
tion of low-risk and routine surgery is dealt with on a day basis,  
however, those requiring inpatient care in the future will tend to be  
sicker, with more complex needs, than was the norm in the past.  
The long-term trend towards a reduction in bed numbers across  
the NHS has come under scrutiny during the Covid-19 pandemic,  
however, with concerns raised regarding the ability of hospitals  
with reduced inpatient capacities to respond to surges in the num-  
ber of patients needing inpatient care. In future, strategies will be  
required to enable this flexibility, for example by enabling the rapid  
re-purposing of clinical accommodation to provide additional crit-  
ical care capacity. Other key changes that are affecting the design of hospitals  
include\:  
• *New imaging modalities*\: The increasing number of imaging  
modalities used in healthcare increases the need for appropriately  
designed buildings that meet highly technical specifications.  
Larger magnets in Magnetic Resonance Imaging \(MRI\) equip-  
ment are becoming more common, yielding much higher detail  
and image clarity. New developments in Nuclear Medicine  
are also calling for very particular bespoke designs, such as  
those required for Positron Emission Tomography – Computed  
Tomography \(PET CT\), and Single-Photon Emission Computed  
Tomography \(SPECT\).  
• *Advances in cancer treatment*\: Linear Accelerators \(Linac\) have  
been used for the treatment of cancers for several decades, but  
have been becoming increasingly accurate with less co-lateral  
damage as the processes are refined. Proton Beam Therapy  
Centres are one of the latest forms of cancer treatment, allowing  
pinpoint accuracy of treatment but requiring enormous, highly  
serviced and technically complex facilities.  
• *Genetics and genomics*\: One of the most promising areas of med-  
ical innovation over recent years has been driven by research  
into how health and disease are influenced by human genetics.  
It is anticipated that further developments in this field will open  
up the potential in future for treatments that are tailored to the  
individual, targeting a wide range of conditions that are cur-  
rently difficult to treat. This reflects a general trend towards the  
increased personalisation of treatment.  
• *Smart hospitals*\: innovation in digital technologies and data  
analytics have created the potential for the creation of power-  
ful tools to enable the optimisation of clinical and operational  
processes. The increasingly sophisticated and integrated digital  
infrastructure within hospital estates will be utilised to provide  
instant insights into operational efficiency, and will inform  
data-driven simulations of options for ways in which processes,  
clinical services and infrastructure can be improved. This will in  
turn enable improvements in patient care, user experience and  
operational efficiency.  
• *Virtual consultations*\: one of the key changes that has been  
driven by the Covid-19 pandemic has been the rapid adoption  
of virtual communication tools across all business sectors and  
by the public more broadly. In future, this revolution in how  
people communicate will be reflected in how hospitals operate  
and how they are designed. Consultations will increasingly take  
place remotely, reducing the need for patients to travel to the  
hospital. Outpatient departments will reduce in size, as only  
those patients requiring treatments and diagnostics that must be  
delivered in person will be required to attend clinics. In order for  
this transformation to benefit all users in an equitable manner,  
however, it will be necessary to address issues of access to and  
use of the required technologies, to avoid discriminating against  
people based on their economic circumstances, age or physical  
capabilities.  
# 3 REGULATIONS AND STANDARDS  
# 3.1 Regulatory bodies  
There are many regulatory bodies that control the standard of  
healthcare provision in the UK. Most are primarily concerned with  
the services provided by specific medical specialties, and will rarely  
have a direct impact upon the work carried out by an architect.  
Two regulatory bodies that do have a significant impact upon  
healthcare building requirements in England are the Care Quality  
Commission \(CQC\) and the Health and Safety Executive \(HSE\)\:  
• *The CQC* is the independent regulator of all health and social  
care in England. This regulates all bodies that provide care, not  
# Hospitals 20-5  
just the NHS. The scope of the CQC’s responsibilities include  
local authority provided social care, and health care and resi-  
dential care provided by the independent and charitable sectors.  
The CQC conducts inspections that draw upon data, feedback  
from users and inspections by experts. Reports and rating are  
published following each inspection \(to drive improvement and  
to inform the public and other healthcare providers in making  
informed choices\). Findings from CQC inspections will often  
inform the development of the brief for a healthcare design pro-  
ject.  
• *The HSE* is the enforcing authority with regard to health and  
safety for workers in England, Scotland and Wales and also for  
patient and service users in Scotland and Wales \(in England this  
role is performed by the CQC\). The HSC carries out inspections,  
and investigations in response to incidents or complaints. The  
remit of the HSC includes responsibility for investigating many  
issues that are closely related to the design of healthcare build-  
ings, such as slips and trips, manual handling problems, and  
legionella/infections. Other aspects of its remit, such as stress  
and violence at work, can also have a relationship to the design  
of a healthcare facility.  
# 3.2 Regulations affecting hospital design  
Hospital design is subject to many of the same regulations that must  
be addressed in all types of architecture\: workplace regulations,  
the Building Regulations, Health & Safety legislation, and national  
and local planning regulations/requirements. One area where regu-  
lations differ is with regard to fire, where the Department of Health  
published Health Technical Memoranda \(HTM\) Firecode suite of  
documents take precedence over the Building Regulations \(with  
the exception of areas that are not healthcare-specific, such as  
office buildings built for NHS Trusts\).  
# 3.3 Healthcare design standards  
The Department of Health has issued several series of standards  
documents providing guidance to support the design of healthcare  
facilities\:  
• *Health Building Notes \(HBNs*\) provide the standard guidance for  
planning and design where hospital facilities are to accommo-  
date NHS services.  
• *Health Technical Memoranda \(HTMs\)* provide technical, com-  
ponent and engineering standards and requirements.  
Health services in the UK are devolved to national govern-  
ments. Despite information often having the same sources, there  
are some differences in standards. Current versions of these doc-  
uments can be downloaded from the respective document portals  
on www.gov.uk.  
The recommendations, sample layouts and space standards  
established in the HBN series provide a valuable starting point for  
the development of design proposals, and a means to subsequently  
audit developing designs. They should not be accepted unquestion-  
ingly, however, as there may be design approaches that differ from  
the standard which are more appropriate to the specific require-  
ments of a project. All areas must be ratified against activities and  
client needs.  
On all projects for NHS clients, a list of derogations from HBN  
or HTM standards should be maintained, to ensure that changes  
have been identified, that there are reasons for taking a different  
approach to that described in the document, and that the client body  
has understood and signed off the derogations.  
The future of guidance for building design is becoming  
increasingly uncertain as the centralised and knowledgeable  
organisation which established them, NHS Estates, has been  
disbanded. Many organisations, such as Architects for Health,  
are campaigning to have the quality of guidance maintained and  
updated. **20-6 Hospitals**  
# 4 PROCUREMENT AND CONSTRUCTION  
# 4.1 Client types  
There are several different client types who might procure buildings\:  
*NHS Hospital Trusts/NHS Acute Trusts*  
NHS secondary, tertiary, quaternary, mental health, community  
care and ambulance services are provided by organisations called  
NHS Trusts. In the case of secondary, tertiary and quaternary  
care providers, these are referred to as NHS Hospital Trusts or  
NHS Acute Trusts. Some NHS Trusts are devoted to a particular  
specialism, such as paediatric, cardiothoracic or cancer care.  
*NHS Foundation Trusts*  
In England, NHS Foundation Trusts have a degree of auton-  
omy from the Department of Health, greater financial freedom  
than conventional NHS Trusts, and can earn up to 49 per cent of  
their income from providing care to private patients. Subsequent  
changes to the organisation of the NHS have eroded some aspects  
of the differences between Foundation and non-Foundation NHS  
Trusts, with all types of trust now falling under the control of a sin-  
gle organisation, NHS England and NHS Improvement \(NHSEI\).  
*The independent sector*  
In the UK, there are a small number of major private hospi-  
tals, generally located in the London area, providing advanced,  
bespoke care. These hospitals target high-income customers  
from the UK and abroad. They market themselves on providing  
access to the best consultants, and on their high-tech facilities,  
which will include advanced imaging modalities and surgical  
facilities, and potentially their own intensive care units.  
The vast majority of private hospitals in the UK are part of a  
series of chains that dominate the mid-market of private health-  
care provision. They are more widely distributed geographically  
than the leading private hospitals, and are generally much  
smaller than NHS hospitals, focusing on outpatient and day care  
and low-risk surgical procedures.  
Some NHS Trusts operate their own private wings. These are  
often specialist hospitals such as centres of excellence for cancer  
care. These may be separately accessed from the main hospital to  
create a clear distinction from facilities providing NHS services,  
but will in practice often share some clinical and clinical support  
facilities.  
Private hospitals seek to differentiate themselves from the NHS  
through branding and interior design in order to convey an  
impression of exclusivity.  
# 4.2 Procurement routes  
The role of the architect in the design of a hospital can vary depend-  
ing on the procurement route \(the process followed to purchase the  
new facility\) adopted by the client body.  
The most frequently used procurement routes are\:  
• *Traditional procurement*. The client appoints a design team to  
design the project and prepare tender documentation. Contractors  
are then invited to submit tenders for the construction of the  
project on a competitive basis. In traditional procurement, the  
architect and design team remain appointed by the client \(e.g. an  
NHS Trust\) throughout the construction process. The architect  
will also generally perform the role of contract administrator.  
• *Design & build procurement*. The client appoints a design team  
to design the project and prepare an Employer’s Requirement set  
of documents, which are used to appoint a contractor through a  
competitive tender process. The tender documentation is gener-  
ally at a lower level of detail than in a traditional contract, and  
following appointment the contractor will employ their own  
design team to develop the proposals. Post tender, the design  
team initially appointed by the client may no longer be involved  
in the project, or may be appointed by the contractor to develop  
their detailed contractor’s proposals, or may be retained by the  
client to advise them during the detailed design development and  
project delivery stages.  
• Both traditional and design & build procurement can utilise  
either single stage or two stage tender processes. Two stage pro-  
cesses enable the earlier appointment of a contractor\: in the first  
stage, a limited appointment is agreed allowing the contractor to  
begin work, and in the second stage, a fixed price is negotiated  
for the contract.  
• *Private Finance Initiative \(PFI\) procurement*. This procurement  
route utilised private sector funding \(underwritten by the public\)  
in the delivery of public sector projects such as hospitals. It is  
a form of Public Private Partnership \(PPP\). The private sector  
organisation builds, funds and operates the facility. PFI procure-  
ment has been used to procure a large proportion of the major  
hospital projects built in the UK since the late 1990s.  
• Concerns over whether PFI provided value for money over the  
lifespan of the building led to the introduction of an amended  
approach, referred to as PF2. The use of PFI procurement was  
‘retired’ by the government in 2018, and information is currently  
awaited on any replacement process by which private investment  
can be utilised in NHS infrastructure projects. Most of the exist-  
ing PFI contracts are still in operation, however, and where this  
is the case, the contractual terms of these deals can have signifi-  
cant implications on how development takes place.  
• *ProCure22 \(P22\) Procurement* \(previously P21 / P21+\). This  
procurement route, which has been widely used in England in  
recent years, is a form of two stage design and build procurement  
in which a Principle Supply Chain Partner \(the PSCP – effec-  
tively the contractor\) is selected at an early project stage from  
a list of the six private sector partners included on a national  
\(England-wide\) framework. In this route, the architect would be  
appointed by the PSCP, and would be drawn from their list of  
pre-selected consultants. It is planned that the P22 framework  
will be replaced by a new framework operating on similar prin-  
ciples, named ProCure23, during 2022.  
• *NHS Building for Wales Framework*. This is a similar approach  
to P22 used in Wales for the procurement of healthcare build-  
ings. This framework comprises four national \(for larger  
projects\), and five regional \(for smaller projects\) supply chain  
partners \(constructors\).  
• *Performance Related Partnering \(PRP\)*. Here a contractor is  
appointed to deliver multiple projects, but their appointment on  
the subsequent projects will be dependent on achieving required  
levels of performance against pre-established measures. This  
approach has been widely used in Northern Ireland, where it has  
been favoured by Health and Social Care Northern Ireland as a  
means to incentivise high quality project delivery.  
• *Hub*. Used in Scotland for the procurement of publicly funded  
buildings. In this system, Scotland is divided into five geograph-  
ical areas known as ‘territories’. A private sector development  
partner is appointed in each area to work in partnership with  
the public sector to deliver projects on a PPP basis. Within each  
territory, there is a supply chain of constructors and consultants  
\(including architects\) who can tender to carry out work. The  
hub approach differs from other frameworks described earlier in  
that it can be used to procure any public sector project, not just  
healthcare.  
# 4.3 Construction  
Building in an urban environment or on an existing hospital site can  
present a wide range of challenges during the construction period.  
The majority of hospital projects include refurbishment of existing  
buildings and are required to maintain continuity of care through-  
out the construction process. For this, coordination between the client, hospital estates teams,  
architects, service engineers and the contractor is essential along  
with the development of a detailed phasing strategy. This might  
require floors to be vacated or accommodation to be decanted tem-  
porarily or provided off site. Preparation of a logistics plan and  
communication with the client, staff and patients can alert them at  
an early stage to what to expect during the construction. This may  
increase tolerance levels.  
Other logistical challenges include\:  
• *Site access* – particularly where building sites are adjacent to  
busy roads, or in close proximity to existing buildings. Site cir-  
culation, parking, contractor’s site set up, site hoarding, delivery  
and storing of building materials can therefore be restricted. This  
needs to be managed appropriately.  
• *Exposure of harmful elements* – this needs to be considered and  
minimised. Asbestos removal for example is part of the majority  
of refurbishment or demolition projects and requires a specialist  
to be appointed.  
• *Noise, vibration and dust* – this needs to be managed if the  
building is remaining operational. Some medical equipment is  
sensitive to interference, and construction work might need to be  
stopped temporarily.  
• *Wayfinding and accessibility* – public and staff circulation needs  
careful consideration in order to minimise inconvenience and  
confusion. If a main entrance cannot be kept operational at day  
and night, temporary entrances might need to be provided and  
require clear external signage.  
# 4.4 Approvals and benchmarking  
*NHS approval gateways*  
In the NHS, processes have been created to ensure that potential  
investments are scrutinised and undertake a formal sign-off process.  
All projects need to demonstrate that value for money is achieved  
in the use of public funding, and that project risk is understood  
\(which could lead to delay and cost overrun\). This requirement is  
achieved on publicly funded projects, including NHS projects, by  
following the Five Case Model. At each stage, a proposal must  
demonstrate its value by\:  
• Establishing the case for change \(the ‘Strategic Case’\)  
• Demonstrating best public value \(the ‘Economic Case’\)  
• Proving commercial viability \(the ‘Commercial Case’\)  
• Providing evidence that the proposal is affordable \(the ‘Financial  
Case’\)  
• Showing that procedures have been put in place to make sure  
that project delivery is achievable \(the ‘Management Case’\).  
These criteria are applied via a series of approval gateways. At  
each stage, the proposal is refined and more detail is provided, with  
the intent of achieving greater cost certainty and reduced project risk.  
The key NHS approval gateways follow the process defined by  
the HM Treasury Green Book. The precise timing and scope of  
these gateways will vary depending on project size and procure-  
ment route.  
STRATEGIC OUTLINE CASE \(SOC\)  
This first approval process takes place prior to the development of  
the design for the new facility. It will establish the strategic context,  
the service need, the formulation of options, affordability, timeta-  
ble and deliverability. It may be produced prior to the appointment  
of an architect. Any architectural input into the SOC would be  
equivalent to the work required to complete RIBA Workstages 0  
and 1. Where approval is sought for a series of linked business  
cases, a Programme Business Case will be used instead of a SOC,  
with each of the constituent projects being dealt with separately at  
subsequent approval gateways.  
# Hospitals 20-7  
OUTLINE BUSINESS CASE \(OBC\)  
This revisits the SOC in more detail, identifying a preferred option  
which demonstrably optimises value for money. It also sets out the  
likely deal, demonstrates its affordability and details the supporting  
procurement strategy, together with management arrangements for  
the successful rollout of the scheme. Architectural inputs into the  
OBC do not align with the completion of a RIBA workstage. The  
OBC submission would align with the completion of P22 Stage 2/  
BIM Data Drop 2.  
FULL BUSINESS CASE \(FBC\)  
This takes place within the procurement phase of the project,  
following detailed negotiations with potential constructors prior  
to the formal signing of contracts. This is usually the stage at  
which final Treasury approval is required. The purpose of the  
FBC is to revisit the OBC and record the findings of the subse-  
quent procurement activities, together with the recommendation  
for an affordable solution which continues to optimise value for  
money, and detailed arrangements for the successful delivery  
of the project. Architectural input into the FBC would com-  
prise a fully designed scheme equivalent to completing RIBA  
Workstage 4.  
For further information on how the NHS approvals gateways  
correspond to stages in the design development process, see  
Section 6 of the NHS England Five Case Model Consolidated  
Business Case Checklist.  
*Optimism bias*  
In the procurement of healthcare buildings, problems have always  
been encountered when attempting to establish the true costs of a  
project in advance. This is in part to do with projects being reported  
based on the budgets allocated to them and not on their actual cost.  
While coming in over budget suggests a failure in management, in  
many cases cost overruns are due to an underestimation during the  
costing process of site-specific infrastructure costs, such as costs  
associated with unforeseen difficult site conditions and upgrading  
incoming services \(e.g. gas, electricity, etc.\).  
To address this, the NHS introduced the concept of optimism  
bias within its business cases. This is the principle that costs should  
be adjusted upwards to cancel out any ingrained tendency towards  
optimism. Applying this factor generally results in a cost uplift of  
about 30 per cent – this percentage relates to the difference between  
what an initial cost plan will project versus the actual costs gener-  
ally experienced. The allowance made for optimism bias may be  
reduced if it can be demonstrated that project-specific risks have  
been identified and mitigated.  
*NHS design review and benchmarking*  
In order to promote continuous improvement in the delivery of  
healthcare projects, systems have been implemented to review  
and benchmark design quality of NHS procured buildings, and to  
ensure that lessons are learnt on subsequent projects. The princi-  
ple tool to achieve this goal is the Design Quality Indicator \(DQI\)  
toolkit, which is used to measure, evaluate and improve the design  
quality of buildings. This process assesses design quality using the  
following criteria\:  
• *Functionality* – the arrangement, quality and interrelationship of  
spaces and how the building is designed to be useful to all.  
• *Build quality* – the engineering performance of the building,  
which includes structural stability and the integration, safety and  
robustness of the systems, finishes and fittings.  
• *Impact* – the building’s ability to create a sense of place and have  
a positive effect on the local community and environment.  
The DQI process involves a number of stakeholders from the  
design team and client body, and building users, and takes the form  
of a facilitated workshop led by a certified facilitator. It can be **20-8 Hospitals**  
used both during the design stages and following completion of  
the facility.  
# 5 METHODOLOGIES  
# 5.1 Evidence-based design  
Evidence-based design is defined as the ‘conscientious, explicit,  
and judicious use of current best evidence from research and  
practice in making critical decisions about the design of each  
individual and unique project’ \(Hamilton and Watkins, *Evidence-*  
*Based Design for Multiple Building Types*, New York, John Wiley  
& Sons, Inc., 2008\).  
The challenge in this is two-fold\:  
• For researchers to measure the more qualitative aspects of design  
and prove the value of aesthetically high-value design; and  
• For designers to access and reference all evidence on very spe-  
cific features/topics \(offered most often as discrete pieces of  
scientific research\) and apply to project-specific needs.  
However, many design aspects are technical, and as such are  
more measurable, such as the benefits of design features including  
single bedrooms, good ventilation, good acoustic environment,  
daylight and nature distractions \(see Review of the Research  
Literature on Evidence-Based Healthcare Design by Roger Ulrich  
et al, in the *Health Environments Research & Design Journal*,  
April 2008\).  
Progress has also been made by researchers in compiling evi-  
dence into databases and guidance ready for designers to use, with  
a notable example in the Sheffield University’s Evidence Base  
cited in Health Building Note 00–01. Adopted by the Department  
of Health as a guidance tool for designers, it organises the broad  
activities occurring in a healthcare setting into a set of tables and  
pictograms linking evidenced outcomes with design considera-  
tions. Activities are considered from both the patient/visitor and  
staff perspective and range from arrival to consultation-examina-  
tion-intervention to meeting and socialising.  
It should be recognised, however, that each project may have  
unique specific needs and priorities and at times evidence can be  
conflicting or inconclusive. To reflect that, there is increasingly  
reference to evidence-influenced design rather than evidence-based  
design.  
• Centralising and grouping activities together to provide a human  
scale to the building which can reduce anxiety, discomfort and  
stress  
• Creating communal spaces for interaction and education  
• Providing high quality working and resting environments for  
staff.  
An example of this approach is the Ambulatory Care and  
Diagnostic \(ACAD\) at Central Middlesex Hospital, Figure 20.2.  
# 5.3 Flexible design  
Change happens in healthcare buildings approximately every 5  
years and buildings need to be future-proofed in order to facilitate  
these future requirements. These can result from\:  
• Change of function requiring new clinical services  
• Change in the model of care requiring different ways of working  
which need to be implemented  
• Change in demographics leading to additional patient capacity,  
occupants, activities and social changes  
• New trends/developments in healthcare technology resulting in  
retrofits to existing hospitals.  
To provide flexibility, a healthcare building needs to be adapt-  
able to allow for the possibility of expansion or contraction. This  
should already have been considered during the strategic planning  
in the design process. Strategies include\:  
*An adaptable structural grid*  
This can allow for a future internal reorganisation of accommo-  
dation. The use of steel and concrete frames provides the greatest  
flexibility. The choice of walls/divisions within the building should  
be adaptable, that is, lightweight.  
# 5.2 Person-centred design  
Person-centred care focuses on understanding a person, their fam-  
ily situation, social circumstances and lifestyles. This methodology  
is tailored to a person’s individual needs and does not only focus  
on treating a condition or illness. It includes sharing decisions with  
patients and helps people to manage their health needs in a working  
partnership with professionals. This can reduce recovery times and  
alleviate pressure on other health and social services.  
Person-centred design changes the design of hospital buildings  
from technical ‘white boxes’ oriented around the medical staff  
to buildings which in themselves support wellness and recovery.  
However, care must also be taken to provide areas and environment  
suitable for the carers and families as well as patients and also, of  
course, the all-important staff.  
This approach can include\:  
• Understanding the nature of the patient experience and their  
journey within a hospital, and ensuring this is clear, light and  
marked with wayfinding ‘events’  
• Providing a therapeutic environment \(Section 9\)  
• Bringing services together to create essential functional relation-  
ships which are more tailored to the individual needs of patients,  
thus reducing journeys through the building and contributing to  
an enhanced visitor experience  
**20.2** *ACAD \(Ambulatory Care and Diagnostic centre\),*  
*Central Middlesex Hospital by Avanti Architects, one of the*  
*first centres in Europe to embody the philosophy of ‘person-*  
*centred care’* *Flexible services*  
For true adaptability, Mechanical, Electrical and Public Health  
\(MEP\) systems should not be embedded in the walls. Services  
\(ventilation\)/plant should ideally be sized to be capable of coping  
with an increased demand in the future.  
*Horizontal expansion*  
This allows the building to increase its footprint. New build areas  
are placed at the perimeter, and where necessary connect to the  
main communication system in order to maintain the internal  
organisation of the hospital.  
*Vertical expansion*  
This can be achieved by providing ‘soft space’ accommodation  
which can easily be relocated \(e.g. offices\), above or below depart-  
ments which are likely to expand.  
*Co-location*  
Flexibility can be achieved by co-locating services that are likely to  
shrink \(e.g. Medical records\) adjacent to services which are likely  
to expand \(e.g. Emergency Department, Radiology\) in order to  
respond to changing requirements in the future.  
# 5.4 Universal design  
Hospitals are often designed with reference to the principles of uni-  
versal design, also called inclusive or barrier-free design. These  
principles aim to make the built environment usable \(to the great-  
est extent possible\) by everyone regardless of their age, physical,  
sensory or mental abilities. This approach can benefit all users,  
for instance good lighting at a reception desk will help those with  
hearing loss who lip-read, the visually impaired and reception staff.  
Acoustic design that minimises background noise helps those with  
impaired hearing, but also helps reduce stress for people with men-  
tal illness, anxious users generally and can help visually impaired  
people to navigate space more easily. See also Chapter 4, Inclusive  
and accessible design.  
In the UK, the Equality Act 2010 and the Equalities Act 2010  
\(Disability\) Regulations enshrines the principles of equality.  
The Building Regulations Approved Document Part M lays out  
guidance on how this should be interpreted in the built envi-  
ronment. Part M has an emphasis on facilitating independent  
access, but within hospitals there is a need to balance design  
for independent access with the often more pertinent need for  
assisted access.  
HBNs sometimes differ from Part M guidance in order to reflect  
the new or temporary nature of patient disability and its acuity.  
Typically, disabled Part M layout toilets will be included within  
main entrance and outpatient areas whereas a mix of en suite and  
assisted bathrooms to Health Building Note layouts will be pro-  
vided within inpatient areas.  
# 6 BUILDING DESIGN AND PLANNING  
# 6.1 Masterplan and development control plan  
A site masterplan shows an overall development concept that  
includes urban design, landscaping, infrastructure, service pro-  
vision, site circulation, present and future land use and building  
forms. Masterplans are usually commissioned by the landowners,  
the hospital trust or local authorities.  
A hospital site masterplan provides a long-term strategy and  
indicates new developments as well as existing buildings and pos-  
sible future phases. It enables an assessment of the capacities of the  
site and how the land can best be used based on the requirements  
established in the brief. Key elements and considerations for the  
development of a masterplan are\:  
• Topography of the site including site levels  
• Site boundaries and neighbouring developments/communities  
# Hospitals 20-9  
• Existing and future infrastructure including access to the site and  
site circulation  
• Proposed new buildings taking into account essential clinical  
adjacencies and ensuring easy identification of entrances  
• Retaining estates and existing refurbished buildings and consid-  
ering how these are linked to new developments  
• Car parking, landscaping and open spaces  
• Identification of expansion zones to provide future flexibility  
• Appropriate phasing and decant strategies.  
Developing a masterplan for a hospital site with existing build-  
ings which might have evolved over decades, requires several  
development stages which inform the final solution of the master-  
plan. The next stage is implementation in the form of a development  
control plan. The masterplan informs the development control plan,  
which contains similar information but provides a greater level of  
detail in terms of building forms, volumes and adjacencies.  
The development control plan provides design guidelines to  
support planning and will be adopted by the authorities. The devel-  
opment control plan is also required for the submission of a final  
business case.  
An example of a masterplan dealing with complex issues is the  
redevelopment of Ulster Hospital in Belfast, Figure 20.3.  
# 6.2 Developing the design brief  
The design brief is one of the most important elements in the whole  
process of delivering a hospital. Developing the brief is a collabo-  
rative process involving the health organisation \(the client\), health  
planners and often also design professionals including architects,  
master planners, engineers and cost consultants with input in early  
testing. The brief development starts with the client’s vision and  
aspirations for the project, often in the context of a masterplan,  
development control plan or other similar framework for devel-  
opment. Throughout a project’s planning stages, the design brief  
will undergo gradual development and will eventually be framed in  
accordance with the preferred and agreed procurement route.  
*Health planning*  
Client and health planner work closely to define\:  
• Capacity requirements \(calculated on current need and future  
need projections, accounting for change in catchment areas,  
demographics and factors like ageing population etc.\)  
• Clinical service needs \(taking into account factors such as those  
mentioned previously\)  
• Model of care \(this derives from client aspirations and opera-  
tional principles informed by capacity and clinical service needs,  
and defines the hierarchy, grouping and organisation of the main  
clinical activity streams\), Figure 20.4  
• Operational policies \(more detailed requirements for each activity  
or clinical specialty in terms of its scope, clinical requirements,  
service users’ considerations, functional relationships with other  
activities, as well as access, service and spatial requirements\)  
• Schedules of accommodation with target areas \(HBNs focus on  
ergonomics of certain clinical activities and these can be used  
as building blocks for room sizing, although this is always sub-  
ject to project-specific requirements and subsequent testing\).  
Recommended ‘best practice’ areas for typical rooms are iden-  
tified in Section 7.3  
• Adjacencies matrix \(this is a standard matrix defining critical  
and desirable adjacency requirements between functional ele-  
ments of the brief\), Figure 20.5  
• Requirements for future flexibility.  
*HBN guidance on developing a design brief*  
HBN 00–01, *General Design Guidance for Healthcare Buildings*  
March 2014, offers healthcare organisations guidance in develop-  
ing a design brief. The document stresses that key decisions in the **20-10 Hospitals**  
development of the brief fall into the sustainability and infection  
control agendas. It also provides a list of example design brief  
issues organised in broad categories \(functionality, impact, build  
quality\) containing prompts for healthcare organisations to explore  
particular design issues. This is offered as a checklist against which  
to organise briefing work.  
*Feasibility*  
Following initial brief development, architects get involved with  
initial tasks to conduct feasibility studies for a specific site \(or  
sites\) and in context with the masterplan/development control plan  
\(where applicable\), client vision and aspirations and against cost.  
This is an iterative process that informs the brief. In the context of  
the RIBA Plan of Work 2020\:  
• Stage 0\: Strategic brief and core project requirements  
• Stage 1\: Project objectives including quality objectives and  
project outcomes, sustainability aspirations, budget and initial  
project brief supported perhaps by feasibility studies and review  
of site information  
• Stage 2\: Agree alterations to brief and issue final project brief.  
# 6.3 Building design process  
*Function and adjacency*  
Hospital building design is function led. The process entails trans-  
forming a clinical diagram \(clinical scheduled area components  
with prescribed adjacencies, flows and access requirements\) into  
a building diagram that organises these components while taking  
into account external drivers \(urban design, masterplan context,  
site opportunities and constraints\) and technical requirements. A  
building diagram, see Figure 20.6, that allows for clear organ-  
isation of functions and appropriate separation of flows, while  
providing for efficient interconnectivity of related areas, is crit-  
ical to the successful development of detailed and coordinated  
design.  
*Stakeholders*  
The hospital building design process also involves a series of itera-  
tions with input from stakeholders. These typically include\:  
• Client clinical/health planning lead  
• Clinical end users  
• Managers of whole-hospital policies in areas such as\:  
− Infection control  
− Facilities management and maintenance  
− Health and safety  
− IT systems infrastructure and implementation  
− Security, etc.  
• Patient groups  
• Charity stakeholders.  
Stakeholder input informs clinical planning, equipment, inte-  
rior finishes design, wayfinding and arts integration, and carries on  
from initial concept to detailed design. This process, traditionally  
branded ‘user-centred’ approach is increasingly moving towards  
‘co-design’, where the stakeholders move from their external posi-  
tion of ‘brief-comment-approve’ more actively into the design  
process.  
The design naturally progresses from large scale to detail, but  
elements of it will feed from a small scale back into the large. Key  
repeating elements \(such as inpatient single bedroom and en suite  
or operating theatre and support spaces\) are often the modules  
requiring detailed design \(and co-design\) and decisions at an early  
stage as they impact on massing, structural design and services  
coordination at a strategic level.  
*Structural choice*  
Civil and structural engineers undertake the assessment of struc-  
tural systems to be implemented in a healthcare building project. All  
building types are possible; however, a framed system allows the  
biggest spans – essential in technical areas of healthcare buildings –  
and the most future flexibility.  
Reinforced in-situ cast concrete structure is popular as a frame  
of columns and beams with reinforced concrete floors, or pref-  
erably flat slab design, where no downstand beams obstruct the  
integration of ducts and other services into the ceiling voids.  
Advantages of concrete construction include resistance to vibra-  
tion, acoustic performance and fire resistance. Steel \(beams and  
columns\) is also used as a structural frame for hospital buildings.  
It is a relatively fast and precise construction; however, much of  
the benefit and more can be lost through the details required to  
achieve fire resistance, acoustic performance and air-tightness  
detailing.  
Decisions are made based on the healthcare services require-  
ments such as the provision of large structural span for large rooms  
such as operating theatres, the use of very heavy equipment such  
as MRI scanners, or the requirement for flat slabs to avoid any det-  
rimental impact on the services distributions in the ceiling voids.  
Many key issues will be taken into account when defining  
which structural framing system will be applied to a healthcare  
building project; for instance, fire, acoustics, construction schedul-  
ing, environmental considerations. Table I illustrates some of these  
key issues.  
*Services*  
MEP services’ coordination also factors in heavily in the iterative  
process – typically 40–45 per cent of volume \(and budget at that\) of  
a hospital build is taken up by services. Another important consid-  
eration \(critically in refurbishment and conversion\) is floor-to-floor  
height since deep ceiling service zones are required in high-tech  
areas. Heights are also influenced by clinical functional/spatial  
requirements and structural systems \(or vice versa for the latter\).  
*Typologies*  
include\:  
Other factors influencing building massing and organisation  
• Horizontal/vertical organising strategies \(determined by func-  
tional relationships, logistics and site area and topography\)  
• Different circulation types \(public, inpatients, staff, facilities  
management \(FM\)\) and best practice appropriateness to context  
• Deep/shallow plan \(high-tech acute areas typically dictate deep  
plan while inpatient or outpatient low-tech accommodation com-  
prising smaller modules and high percentage of rooms where  
daylight is essential drives shallow plan arrangements\)  
• Proportion, distribution and connections between high-tech and  
low-tech zones \(high-tech is defined as heavily serviced inter-  
vention and diagnostic areas; low-tech as outpatient consulting  
or inpatient accommodation areas\)  
• Trend towards 100 per cent single room accommodation  
\(increasing shallow plan and building perimeter\)  
• Stacking of ‘like’ function versus horizontal distribution.  
An example of different massing response options is shown in  
Figure 20.7.  
*Infection prevention and control*  
The control of infection is a vital part of healthcare provision,  
and measures include behavioural and procedural ones \(includ-  
ing the frequent washing of hands, use of alcohol gel and access  
restrictions\) to design tactics \(all surfaces should be accessible to  
cleaning teams\).  
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, infection prevention  
and control guidance in all healthcare settings is being reviewed and **Hospitals 20-11**

revised. All services require new ways of working during the con-  
tinued pandemic and in future. During the pandemic, Public Health  
Bodies in the UK have jointly issued updates to guidance based  
upon emerging evidence, experience and expert opinion. Following  
the pandemic, the lessons learnt will form the basis of new ways of  
working designed to mitigate the impact of a further event of simi-  
lar or greater magnitude. The outcome of this process will in some  
instances necessitate changes in how hospitals are designed.  
It should be recognised that infection by different pathogens can  
be minimised by different methods. Alcohol gel, for example, can  
work against MRSA but not C. Difficile, which requires meticulous  
hand washing. The design of the environment cannot in itself elim-  
inate the risk of infection, but the strategic placement of hand-wash  
basins and alcohol gel dispensers can enable good management by  
encouraging good practice. Horizontal surfaces which are difficult  
to clean represent a hazard. Radiused skirtings and the elimination  
of inaccessible areas, behind WCs for example, assist a cleaning  
regime in being effective.  
The presence of highly infectious and dangerous pathogens  
such as MRSA and C. Difficile is a constant concern as are those  
associated with air and water supplies such as legionella and pseu-  
donomas. Designers should take advice from medical and infection  
control experts at all stages of the design process and in addition  
pursue a wider engagement with estates and housekeeping teams  
on the implications of infection control design decisions made.  
Examples of infection control consultation at the various design  
stages include\:  
• Preparation and brief \(RIBA Stage 1\) – department adjacencies,  
support services for sterile supplies, disposal, etc.  
• Concept design \(RIBA Stage 2\) – input into the brief for iso-  
lation facilities, utility rooms, sanitary facilities, staff change  
facilities, engineering services, adequate storage, etc.  
• Developed design \(RIBA Stage 3\) – sign off on the location of  
hand wash stations, specification of internal finishes and fittings  
• Technical design and construction \(RIBA Stages 4 and 5\) – input  
into the quality control process particularly with regard to prod-  
uct substitutions and elements of contractor design.  
# 7 CLINICAL PLANNING  
# 7.1 Clinical planning process  
Not to be confused with health planning, clinical planning describes  
the process of architecturally planning a healthcare building. What  
differentiates it from plan development of other building types is  
the particularly complex logistics of organising clusters of func-  
tional space and the networks that connect them. Clinical planning  
entails mapping of adjacencies, functional relationships and flows  
\(the movement of patients, public, staff and goods\) onto stacked  
plan diagrams with the aim of achieving optimum briefed clinical  
adjacencies – horizontally or vertically – and organising access and  
circulation, Figure 20.8.  
This collaborative and iterative process engages health planners  
and stakeholders and moves from the briefing stage with a progres-  
sive increase in detail\:  
• *Bubble diagrams*\: Scaled diagrams of schedule components  
organised to achieve briefed adjacencies. This starts horizon-  
tally, then progresses to identify potential footprints and vertical  
organisation, Figure 20.9.  
• *1\:500-scale adjacencies, functional relationships and circula-*  
*tion diagrams*\: Mapping of components \(traditionally identified  
as hospital departments\) in plan, section and stacking diagram  
showing relationships, access requirements, entrances and  
different circulation routes \(the latter are referred to as commu-  
nication, while circulation describes the corridors within each  
individual department\), Figure 20.10.  
• *1\:200-scale adjacencies*\: These are plan diagrams of departments  
organising adjacencies and functional relationships of rooms or  
clusters of rooms within a department. Same principles apply as to  
larger scale with requirements for separation of entrance/public face  
areas from clinical or ‘back-of-house’, discrete access for inpatients  
or emergency and separation of clean from dirty, Figure 20.11.  
• *1\:200-scale plans \(or 1\:100 for smaller projects\)*\: These are the  
concept design plans \(typically developed at RIBA Stage 2 of a  
project\), Figure 20.12.  
• *Room data sheets \(RDS\)*\: Data on every room in the building  
is assembled in a set of room data sheets. These are compiled  
from a set of typical room types that exist in the DoH Activity  
Database \(ADB\) and are usually modified to suit particular pro-  
ject needs. The set comprises\:  
− Room data sheet, describing the activities, personnel and plan-  
ning relationships  
− Room environmental data, including temperature, ventilation,  
lighting and acoustic requirements, health and safety and fire  
safety requirements  
− Room design character, with briefing information and com-  
pliance requirements on interior finishes, doors and windows.  
• *Schedule of components by room*\: listing all room contents, fixed  
or not, with quantities, description and information on who is  
expected to supply them \(typically main contractor or health  
organisation\).  
• *1\:50-scale drawings and other detail information*\: Different sets  
of drawings to accommodate elements of the detailed design,  
including\:  
Fixtures, Furniture and Equipment \(FFE\) plans and elevations.  
These include all furniture, fixed elements like sockets, switches,  
sanitary assemblies \(toilets, hand-wash basins, etc.\) joinery \(recep-  
tion desks, cupboards, etc.\) and all medical equipment fixed or not,  
as listed in the RDS Schedule of Components.  
Construction plans including information on partitions, doors,  
finishes with details and specifications. **20-14 Hospitals**

# 7.2 Schedule of accommodation  
A schedule of drawn areas often referred to as the SoA \(Schedule of  
Accommodation\) follows alongside plan development, from target  
areas to net as-drawn areas \(to be tested and agreed with stakeholders  
where they deviate from the guidance targets\) and departmental  
gross internal \(drawn\) areas \(GIA\). An often-underestimated 30–50  
per cent increase from the total of net areas to drawn GIA is typical  
for new builds and that is usually exceeded in a refurbishment or  
conversion by varying factors dependent on the existing building  
configuration. This is distributed usually as follows\:  
• Planning \(allowance for walls, service drops, etc\)\: 5 per cent  
• Engineering \(allowance for service zones and cupboards within  
clinical zones – not overall plant provision\)\: 3 per cent  
• Circulation \(within departments\)\: 25–35 per cent – this varies  
as some clinical areas plan more efficiently than others, mostly  
depending on separation of flows requirements  
• Communication \(circulation areas linking departments\)\: 10–20  
per cent  
• Refurbishment factor \(allowance for inefficient planning due to  
existing shell configuration, servicing and links to other accom-  
modation\)\: 5–15 per cent.  
The experience of the Covid-19 pandemic will inform reviews to  
assess whether established area allowances need to be modified in  
order to enable appropriate operational procedures to be adopted to  
mitigate the impact of future pandemics. The effect of social distanc-  
ing on occupancy capacities \(for instance for waiting areas and office  
accommodation\), requiring either increases in area allowances, or  
temporary reductions in capacity, will need to be considered. Social  
distancing requirements and the need to segregate routes in order to  
enforce separation of patient pathways for those either with, or with-  
out, the infection that has caused a pandemic may also necessitate an  
increase to circulation and communication area allowances.

All hospitals **Hospitals 20-17**  
Front door for patients who require specialised emergency care. Patients either walk in or are brought in by ambulance.  
Department is divided into treatment clusters based on severity of injury and length of stay\:  
– Reception, waiting area and first assessment/triage  
– Minor injuries – treatment cubicles/rooms for walk-in patients  
– Major injuries – treatment cubicles/rooms for more severely injured patients plus facilities for a major incident  
– Observation unit – extended stay for patients requiring monitoring  
– Resuscitation – treatment bays for lifesaving activities  
– Children’s unit  
– Specialist rooms for ophthalmology, orthopaedic or fracture clinic  
– Staff, relative areas and support  
Often embedded in community and primary care services but also in acute hospital settings, they provide a service to  
deal with more minor issues which can be kept out of the main flows of A&E  
Imaging facilities consist of different modalities; some are for diagnosis only, others include treatment\:  
– General X-ray uses electromagnetic radiation to create still images of mainly bones and joints and occasionally  
internal organs  
– Ultrasound uses high-frequency sound waves to create an image of internal organs  
– CT to produce images of bones, internal organs and blood vessels. Can determine location, size and shape of tumours  
– Nuclear medicine includes SPECT CT and Gamma camera. Patient receives injection of small amount of  
radioactive material.  
– MRI uses magnetic fields and radio waves to scan any part of the body  
– Fluoroscopy produces real time video images of dynamic body functions  
Testing to diagnose issues involving the heart and or lungs; can be stationary or include exercise\:  
– Electrocardiography \(ECG\)  
– Echocardiograms \(echo\)  
– Pulmonary function tests  
Investigation in which an instrument is introduced into the body to give a view of its internal parts  
Intervention includes surgical operations on patients in a sterile environment. It includes surgical and some  
diagnostic procedures\:  
– Operating theatre is part of a suite including anaesthetic, clean preparation room, scrub room and a dirty utility  
– Following procedure, patients recover in two stages prior to transferal to inpatient accommodation or discharge  
home \(day procedures\)  
Many interventions are carried out within a day. The flows through a day surgery unit are therefore different from a  
main operating theatre suite  
Endoscopy is used for treatment and intervention as well as diagnostics. This may take place in an operating theatre  
for major interventions  
Includes thoracic diagnostic and interventional procedures  
Involves high-energy radiation to treat tumours or blood disorders  
Patients with kidney failure have their blood cleaned though a dialysis machine. They usually attend three days a  
week for four hours a day  
Outpatients consist of general and specialist clinics, which can be co-located for flexible use of rooms\:  
– General outpatients  
– Oral surgery/orthodontics  
– Ophthalmology  
– ENT \(Ears, Nose, Throat\) and audiology  
– Children  
– Cancer care/haematology  
– Renal services  
– Endoscopy  
– Main accommodation for outpatients includes rooms for consultation, examination and treatment  
Hospitals typically have anything between 300 and 1200 beds. This is often quoted as measure of the size of a  
hospital.  
Wards can be generic \(surgical or medical\) or specialised, e.g. stroke, renal, elderly, gynaecology or trauma.  
Patients are accommodated in single bedrooms or multi-bed bays  
ICU/HDU provide intensive treatment medicine to patients with severe and life-threatening illnesses and injuries  
This range of services is sometimes provided independently and sometimes falls into the general provision of high/  
low-tech facilities within the hospital. It includes\:  
– Outpatients  
– Antenatal services  
– Maternity  
– Operating theatres  
– Inpatient care  
Includes activities with or without equipment to improve physical movement after an injury or illness, e.g. exercise  
bars, treadmill. It may also involve exercises carried out in water \(Hydrotherapy\)  
Helps patients to address difficulties with everyday tasks and aims to achieve practical solutions to gain  
independency. This can be practised in e.g. Activities of Daily Living kitchens or bedrooms  
Includes activities to help patients with communication, speech and language difficulties  
ADL facilities provide training for relearning skills required to live at home for stroke or trauma patients  
This includes consumables stores, equipment stores, clean utility, dirty utility and clinical offices \(which must be  
co-located with the clinical areas\)  
These areas are outside of the clinical departments and are usually shared throughout the hospital. They are FM areas  
such as estates department, pathology services, pharmacy department, Clean and Sterile Services Department  
\(CSSD\), café, restaurant, kitchens, waste disposal, etc. **20-18 Hospitals**
