Adjacencies and other relationships, access requirements and  
flows distribution or separation differ from project to project, often  
significantly. Also, in the context of the fast-changing healthcare  
sector, new elements and new priorities emerge frequently. It is  
therefore very difficult to prescribe functional relationships in  
healthcare buildings. However, Table IV offers a general guide of  
typical relationships. Key space requirements for clinical and sup-  
port activities are provided in Figures 20.16 to 20.18.  
# 7.4 Ward design/single rooms  
Since the general trend in healthcare delivery is for treatment to be  
delivered within the community whenever possible, patients who  
are admitted to hospitals are often acutely ill and may have multiple  
conditions.  
Consideration needs to be given to\:  
• Departmental relationships – critical care beds are often the  
beds sited closest to operating theatres; specialist wards such as  
oncology may be sited close to specialist diagnostic and treat-  
ment facilities \(but not always as these may be shared with  
outpatients\).  
• Vertical adjacencies – wards stacked in a tower provide oppor-  
tunities for consistent planning of accommodation, flexibility in  
allocation of beds, ease of maintenance and servicing.  
• Horizontal adjacencies – internal streets or atria often incorpo-  
rating reception and information points, commercial and social  
spaces \(cafes, pharmacy, shops, etc.\) are replacing the traditional  
hospital corridor.  
The move towards a more patient-led healthcare system has  
begun to be reflected in initiatives around\:  
• Patient choice including the environment and facilities for  
healthcare treatment  
• Recognition of difference in personal values, beliefs and rela-  
tionships  
• Privacy and dignity  
• Same-sex accommodation.  
Same-sex accommodation can be provided in\:  
• Same-sex wards, where the whole ward is occupied by men or  
women only  
• Single rooms, Figure 20.19  
• Mixed wards, where men and women are in separate bays or  
rooms.  
Ward designs typically combine\:  
• Inpatient accommodation \(bed and sanitary facilities and staff  
touchdown spaces\) to include isolation accommodation  
• Patient support facilities  
• Storage spaces  
• Utilities  
• Administration and staff facilities.  
The balance of facilities provided will reflect the provision of  
facilities elsewhere in the hospital and locally, the demands of  
different specialisms and the desire for standard layouts, the bal-  
ance of multi-bed or single rooms. An organisation diagram to  
# Hospitals 20-19  
interrogate, develop and record the agreed brief will need to con-  
firm the requirement for facilities.  
*Factors to consider*  
• Access to the ward – ward entrances need to consider access  
control for visitors, patients and staff. Public entrance to a ward  
can be achieved by a manned reception desk or staff base, and/or  
remote entry system. A second ‘back door’ may be provided for  
discrete patient transfers and FM services.  
• Clustering of patients within a ward – for instance a ward of  
24 beds may be organised in clusters of 8 beds perhaps as 100  
per cent single bedrooms or a mix of one four-bed bay and four  
single rooms.  
• Evidence for all single or a mix of single and multi-bed rooms  
is vigorously debated. Arguments are often nuanced and inter-  
linked and the optimum choice may vary for different projects  
and patient groups.  
• Sociability and privacy – single bedrooms can encourage family  
members to spend more time with the patient, but a patient with-  
out visitors can feel isolated and ignored; multi-bed wards can  
foster support between fellow patients or disturb patients’ ability  
to rest and sleep undisturbed.  
• Patient safety – in multi-bed wards patients will often alert the  
nursing staff to patients requiring attention while in single bed-  
rooms family members will often be on hand to supervise trips  
to the toilet.  
• Clinical observation – balanced with the patient’s need for pri-  
vacy and dignity.  
• Bed management – single rooms facilitate bed management as  
issues such as gender mix on adult wards or age mix on chil-  
dren’s wards are avoided.  
• Availability of single rooms reduces the need to move patients  
and there is some evidence that this helps to reduce incidents  
of slips, trips and falls, medication errors and the spread of  
infection.  
• Infection control – the spread of airborne pathogens between  
patients is less in single rooms. There is less risk to others from  
patient beds being cleaned on change over, and single rooms are  
more suited to the more effective vapour disinfection methods.  
There is some evidence that single rooms impact hand wash-  
ing behaviour by reducing incidents of staff not washing hands  
between attending different patients. While it will take time for a  
consensus to be reached regarding lessons learnt from the Covid-  
19 pandemic, the result may be an increase in the proportion of  
single rooms across hospital estates.  
• Mixed single and multi-bed room types have the potential for  
‘patient choice’; a powerful contribution to feelings of well-  
being, Figure 20.20.  
• Single room with en suite – layouts with outboard en suites tend  
to reduce natural light and views to the external world; layouts  
with inboard en suites tend to restrict clinical observation from  
outside the room; layouts with inline en suites usually lead to  
mirrored room arrangements, Figure 20.21.  
• Facilities should reflect nursing practices – the recent trend is  
towards reduced time spent at centralised staff bases and more at  
touch down spaces at or near the bedside.  
• Distances staff need to walk to check and treat patients, write up  
and access patient treatment records and access support spaces.  
• Hoists for moving and handling patients.  
• Where 100 per cent single rooms are briefed, a dedicated treat-  
ment room may not be required as treatments can be provided at  
the bedside.  
• Post-Covid 19, in all settings, the manner in which designs  
address issues including the segregation of clean and dirty  
activities, the isolation of infectious patients, and infec-  
tion prevention via distance and by separation of circulation  
flows will be reviewed and may change from current typical  
approaches. **20-20 Hospitals**

*By Christopher Shaw of Medical Architecture*  
# 8.1 Introduction  
Modern settings for mental health care have distinct characteristics  
that set them apart from medical hospital facilities. However, just  
as with the medical hospital, in mental health there are clinical,  
operational and qualitative concerns that underpin organisation,  
planning and design of new facilities.  
Note that this section does not cover sub-specialties of mental  
health that have very specific needs, such as forensic mental health,  
child and adolescent mental health, dementias, learning disabilities  
and complex neurological disorders.  
# 8.2 Context  
Mental health problems are a growing public concern. Nearly half  
\(43.4 per cent\) of adults think that they have had a diagnosable  
mental health condition at some point in their life \(35.2 per cent of  
men and 51.2 per cent of women\).  
Mental illness has both an economic and a social cost as well as  
diminishing well-being of individuals and carers affected. Certain  
parts of the population are at a higher risk of mental health prob-  
lems because of greater exposure and vulnerability to unfavourable  
social, economic and environmental circumstances. Black, Asian  
and minority ethnic communities are also generally considered to  
be at increased risk of poor mental health.  
# 8.3 Guidance and standards  
In addition to medical hospital guidance \(see Section 3\), there are  
a range of facility standards and guidance particularly relevant for  
the planning, design and commissioning of mental health facilities\:  
• Health Building Note Designing Health and Community Care  
Buildings \(HBN 00–01\)  
• Health Building Note Efficient Management of Healthcare  
Estate and Facilities \(HBN 00–08\)  
• Health Building Note Adult Mental Health Units\: Planning and  
Design \(HBN 03–01\)  
• Standards for Inpatient Mental Health Services, published by the  
Royal College of Psychiatrists \(2015\)  
• Laying the foundations for better acute mental health, Department  
of Health and Care Services Improvement Partnership Acute  
Care Programme \(2008\)  
• National Association of Psychiatric Intensive Care & Low  
Secure Units \(napicu.org.uk\) guidance.  
Mental health charities including Mind \(www.mind.org.uk\) and  
Time to Change \(www.time-to-change.org.uk\) are also sources of  
valuable advice on the needs of specific care groups.  
# 8.4 Care groups and services  
*Outpatient accommodation*  
The majority of mental healthcare in the UK takes place at home  
or in an outpatient setting. The type of facility used can vary and is  
often associated with a community mental health team base, which  
would require flexible and often open plan administrative office  
space, shared ‘touchdown’ facilities for outreach staff and confi-  
dential communication space where mental health care workers can  
talk to service users.  
Consultation, diagnosis, therapy and treatments should be  
accommodated in local and accessible primary and community  
health facilities. Planning should take account of the wide range  
of often incompatible service groups, for example vulnerable  
children with mental illness can find disinhibited adult behaviour  
disturbing. Layouts should have a single managed entrance but  
be able to cater for different patient groups being cared for in  
distinct areas.  
# Hospitals 20-27  
Outpatient services require the following patient accommoda-  
tion described in Section 8.7 ‘Key rooms’\:  
• Mental health consultation room  
• Mental health group room \(dry and wet\)  
• Medical treatment room with clean and dirty utility rooms.  
*Inpatient accommodation*  
Mental health inpatient accommodation is grouped into four types.  
Each type represents a tier of physical risk and requires different  
treatments\:  
• Private patient accommodation, bedrooms, toilets and washrooms  
• Public patient accommodation, day rooms, lounges, dining areas  
and main circulation  
• Supervised accommodation, treatment, therapy and amenity spaces  
• Staff only accommodation, administration, offices and support  
accommodation.  
The basic components are\:  
• Wards which comply with the residential component  
• Therapy, treatment and amenity areas which may be shared  
between wards  
• Administrative and support accommodation.  
The quality of physical environment plays a crucial role in achiev-  
ing positive clinical outcomes for service users, staff and the wider  
community. An adult inpatient environment should provide a famil-  
iar, safe environment with ‘hotel-like’ levels of comfort and privacy.  
*Adult mental health*  
Inpatient accommodation for adults with mental illness is the most  
common form of mental hospital. The focus is on stabilising what  
may have been a chaotic period for the patient, developing a per-  
sonal care plan and jointly managing recovery to a point where an  
individual can return home. It is good practice to provide accommo-  
dation that can flex and adapt to cater for a wide range of services.  
This may mean clustering or grouping of inpatient accommodation.  
Adult inpatient facilities are generally arranged in wards of  
12–18 bedrooms each with en suite WC and shower room. There  
should be appropriate levels of security to enable supervision and  
control of access and egress from the unit.  
*Frail and elderly mental health*  
Care pathways for older adults with mental illness can be complex  
and generally mean longer periods of stay in an inpatient facility.  
The focus is still on jointly managing recovery to a point where an  
individual can return home, but may also need to address physical  
ailments and some loss of cognitive function.  
Older adult inpatient facilities are generally arranged in wards of  
16–20 bedrooms each with en suite WC and shower room. Particular  
attention should be paid to providing handrails, grab rails in WCs  
and ironmongery hardware which is both easy to grasp and offers  
reduced ligature opportunities. Movement, parking and charging of  
mobility scooters should be considered in the layout. This group is  
likely to require some bariatric standard facilities. Staff will need  
hoists built in or storage facilities to be located locally.  
Maintaining physical activity is particularly important.  
Movement and access to gardens should be encouraged, but care  
should be taken to avoid trip hazards, and boundaries need clear  
physical delineation. Access and egress should have appropriate  
levels of security for this group to enable supervision.  
*Addictions and substance abuse*  
Specialist inpatient units are uncommon, but they have distinctive  
requirements. Admission to an inpatient unit is likely to be for a  
short period, usually one to two weeks, during which medically  
supervised withdrawal management may be provided. **20-28 Hospitals**  
**20.22** *Building typologies for basic single storey plan*  
Units are usually small, 6–12 beds each, with en suite WC and  
shower room in a broader mental health setting. Particular attention  
should be paid to access panels, fittings and grilles to reduce oppor-  
tunities for the concealment of drugs.  
As these units have a limited staffing compliment, the design  
should maximise opportunities for sharing support, therapy and  
amenity resources with other units so that patients are not unduly  
disadvantaged.  
*Psychiatric intensive care*  
Psychiatric intensive care is for patients who are in an acutely dis-  
turbed phase of a serious mental disorder. A Psychiatric Intensive  
Care Unit \(PICU\) forms an important and specialised component  
of adult inpatient care.  
A PICU is generally a small self-contained facility of 6–12 beds  
associated with one or more adult inpatient units. Integral therapy  
accommodation should be multi-functional and materials, compo-  
nents and finishes must be robust and securely fixed.  
For guidance, see *PICU National Minimum Standards* \(2014\)  
published by National Association of Psychiatric Intensive Care &  
Low Secure Units.  
# 8.5 Organising principles  
A mental health inpatient unit should be organised to cater for a  
wide variety of functions and interactions. Unlike a medical set-  
ting, mental health patients are mostly out of bed and moving  
between activities. A well-organised setting distinguishes between  
patient day spaces and bed areas, groups staff and support areas,  
and provides an easily navigable circulation system.  
*Building typologies*  
Buildings are typically organised as variants of the following plan  
arrangements \(Figure 20.22\)\:  
• Cruciform  
• Tee or Y form  
• Courtyard.  
*Recovery focused*  
Environment plays a role in aiding recovery. The quality of design  
communicates important values to patients, staff and visitors. A  
familiar scale environment that can be easily understood and  
navigated helps rebuild self-confidence and supports the many  
treatments and therapies available.  
*Therapeutic environment*  
The term ‘therapeutic environment’ describes a setting where the  
surroundings support a sense of individual well-being which under-  
pins recovery \(see Section 9\).  
*Safety and security*  
Safety and security are often considered together, but are distinct  
requirements. Personal safety for patients who may be suicidal  
means reducing opportunities for violence and self-harm. By  
categorising spaces in tiers of risk \(see Section 8.4\), appropriate  
levels of safe design can be applied. For example, patient bedrooms  
should have anti-ligature features for door and window ironmon-  
gery. Fixtures and furniture should be selected or designed to be  
both robust to avoid breakages being used as weapons, and safe to  
avoid self-harm. However, there is a balance to be struck between  
risk reduction through safe design features and promoting recovery  
by incorporating familiar domestic and attractive components.  
Security should be considered in three interdependent ways\:  
• Physical security which determines the boundaries, fabric,  
access-control systems, etc.  
• Operational security which caters for safe methods and systems  
such as admission, food delivery, maintenance  
• Relational security which determines the balance between intru-  
siveness and openness and governs trust between individuals.  
Each of these matters should be considered separately and  
together. In particular, relational security will determine the organ-  
isation of circulation space and lines of observation. Operational  
security should be considered carefully in detailing managed  
escape in case of fire \(see also Section 10\).  
*Privacy and dignity*  
Quality of life and a sense of self-worth underpin a sense of mental  
well-being. Same-sex accommodation and single bedrooms are a  
requirement for adult inpatient wards. Individuals should be able to  
mitigate the effects of living in a restricted space with strangers, by  
preserving privacy, dignity and control over the environment as far  
as possible. Particular care should be taken with mitigating noise  
between bedrooms and providing for quieter spaces for reflection.  
Where monitoring systems such as CCTV and occupancy detec-  
tion are used, these should be considered alongside the NHS CCTV  
Code of Practice. Although it is common for male and female ward units to be entirely  
distinct, it is possible for gender separation to be arranged in a single  
ward unit as long as occupants can access all the key facilities without  
passing through residential space occupied by a different gender group.  
*Flexibility and adaptability*  
Mental health facilities should be able to accommodate shifts in demand.  
Inpatient wards may be designed with four or six bed sub-clusters of  
bedrooms that could cater for a wide range of differing care groups.  
# 8.6 Planning and design  
When considering a site for a mental health facility, the designer  
should have a clear sense of the public frontage and private spaces.  
The more public zones should address matters of stigma and image  
by providing a direct and encouraging route to an identifiable  
entrance. Private zones offer inpatients opportunities for amenity  
and relaxation without being overlooked by the public.  
The organisation of the components of a psychiatric inpatient  
unit should show a clear distinction between residential ward  
accommodation, day therapy and sports areas and support accom-  
modation. Entrances and exits should be limited and carefully  
considered in respect of safely and security.  
*Location, boundaries, neighbours and stigma*  
The selection of an appropriate location for an inpatient unit should  
consider\:  
• Accessibility for the patient and staff population served  
• Size of the site and availability of level access gardens to inpatients  
• Compatibility of existing local users, for example an adjoining  
primary school would be likely to provoke public disquiet.  
Psychiatric hospitals are often the target of the stigma often asso-  
ciated with mental illness. The designer should consider features  
that challenge stigma by communicating well-being and openness.  
These include landscaped gardens, public art and a well-illuminated  
entrance. Visible fencing enclosures should be avoided.  
*Accessibility*  
It is important to consider accessibility for mental health inpatients  
in the broadest sense as illness itself may contribute to disability.  
Some medication may reduce cognitive ability so the design should  
have features such as contrasting architraves and skirting boards to  
help navigation.  
The designer should pay particular attention to providing  
accessibility features such as grab rails in a manner that reduces  
opportunities for self-harm. In some instances, this may require  
rails to be removable.  
*Circulation and graduated territory*  
The inpatient environment should encourage recovery and self-con-  
fidence. The term graduated territory is used to describe a feature of  
planning where space is allowed at the border between areas where  
different levels of social interaction are expected. For example, a  
bedroom is personal space, the corridor outside is more public. A  
slight recess or lowering of the ceiling delineates a threshold. This  
manipulation of space reflects the social transaction of moving  
from one space to another. Having a threshold is comforting and  
encourages the patient to choose their next step.  
This form of circulation planning can be used between private/  
semi-public and semi-public/public areas.  
*Engineering, controls and maintenance*  
Heating, ventilation and electrical systems can all represent a risk.  
Horizontal and vertical services distribution should be contained in  
ducts with limited access. Controls, switches and ventilation grilles  
should be anti-ligature specification in high-risk areas.  
Maintenance access should be planned as part of the operational  
security strategy. Where maintenance staff \(with tools that may  
# Hospitals 20-29  
represent a risk in themselves\) are required to enter a patient envi-  
ronment, they must be accompanied by a trained member of staff.  
*Interior design*  
Interior design and careful selection of furniture and fittings con-  
tributes to the overall quality of the environment and endows a  
sense of self-worth and purpose on those who occupy the space.  
The designer should focus on providing a ‘hotel-like’ setting with  
modulation of lighting, colour and materials working with the func-  
tional and operational constraints of providing a safe, robust and  
manageable setting. Grilles, general light fittings and soft acoustic  
finishes should be out of reach. Fixings on furniture should be tam-  
per-proof and artwork securely fixed.  
*Landscape design*  
Nature has a valuable therapeutic role. Access to gardens widens the  
range of activities available to patients and can encourage healthy life-  
styles. In a busy, self-contained environment gardens offer a valuable  
opportunity for solitude and reflection. Maintenance should be consid-  
ered as part of operational security and hard landscape materials should  
be monolithic if possible to avoid paving being used as weapons.  
# 8.7 Key rooms  
The organisation of functional zones and pattern of circulation deter-  
mine how well the building meets the objectives of the model of care.  
*Mental health consulting room*  
Unlike a medical consultation room, this will not have a patient  
couch. It will have a round table and two or more chairs and a desk  
with an IT workstation. Floor finishes are often carpeted and col-  
ours selected to be calming.  
*Mental health group room*  
Group rooms cater for groups of 6–12 patients and provide for a wide  
range of therapies including talking, cognitive behaviour, occupa-  
tional therapies, etc. They often need storage attached and are best  
viewed as multi-functional rooms with wet and dry variants.  
*Mental health bedroom*  
The mental health inpatient bedroom has evolved into a commonly  
accepted model with the en suite WC and shower room splayed to  
allow clear observation from the bedroom door and access to the  
drainage and plumbing from the corridor \(see Figure 20.23\).  
*Bedroom design and layout issues*  
• Patient privacy/dignity vs observation – extent of views into  
room from door  
• Extent of anti-ligature concerns/measures  
• Control of access to perimeter – privacy and security  
• Control of environment – light/heat/cooling/ventilation – patient  
vs staff control  
• Services access from outside room  
• Views out of room  
• Inboard or outboard en suites – light and ventilation  
• Swing of door  
• Control of access to en suite  
• En suite door lockable in open position?  
• Division of room into day and night zones  
• Positioning of bed  
• Seating and work space/desk  
• Storage – clothes and possessions  
• TV positioning – good viewing angles  
• Reduce climbing possibilities  
• Noise transfer between bedrooms  
• Construction complexity  
• Robustness of construction, fixtures, finishes and furniture  
• Ease of inspection  
• Ease of cleaning/maintenance. **20-30 Hospitals**  
**20.23** *Mental health bedroom design and layout*  
*Source*\: Courtesy Medical Architecture  
*Section 136 suite*  
A Section 136 suite is a ‘Place of Safety’ under the mental health  
acts. It should be located to allow a police car or ambulance to park  
nearby.  
*Seclusion room*  
Secluding a patient can be a traumatic experience and may lead to  
harm for the patient involved. Inadequate seclusion facilities can  
make the experience worse.  
# 9 THERAPEUTIC DESIGN  
# 9.1 Well-being  
It has long been asserted that the quality of the environment has an  
impact on the physical and mental well-being of both patients and  
staff, and that this leads to improved clinical outcomes.  
Recent research has shown quantitative measurable outcomes  
such as reduced uptake of pain medication due to qualitative  
improvements in the environment encompassed by a holistic and  
integrated approach to therapeutic design including\:  
• Wayfinding  
• Interior design  
• Lighting design  
• Art  
• Landscape design.  
# 9.2 Wayfinding  
Wayfinding to and within hospitals should address the differ-  
ent needs of a wide variety of users – patients, staff and visitors  
including those who arrive stressed at a critical point in their lives,  
whether happy or sad. This includes people of all ages and many  
cultural backgrounds, regardless of physical or sensory ability \(see  
Section 5.4 ‘Universal design’\), those who use the hospital regu-  
larly, and those arriving for the first time.  
Wayfinding design should fit within the NHS or other private  
branding strategy. It should start before patients or visitors arrive  
on site with, for example, consistent site, building and department  
names used on website and appointment letters.  
Once on site, wayfinding should be as intuitive as possi-  
ble, incorporating clear pathways leading to easily identifiable  
entrances, with signage used to re-enforce a logical site or building  
diagram. Views from inside to outside can help orientation. Visual  
and physical clutter should be kept to a minimum to promote unim-  
peded access and establish a legible environment. There should be  
a hierarchy for the presentation of information, and a controlled  
and orderly background for wayfinding decision points which may  
include place-markers such as works of art.  
In recent years, digital technologies have become available that  
can support wayfinding and remove potential stressful or confusing  
aspects of a hospital visit. Smartphone Apps can assist the patient  
and carers at each stage of a hospital attendance from travel to the  
hospital, through check in and to attendance at a clinic. Digital tech-  
nologies have the potential to address many of the issues that have  
in the past often made visiting hospital an intimidating, frustrating  
and disempowering process. The use of these technologies may  
in time have a significant impact on how hospitals are designed,  
for instance by reducing the need for waiting areas. They should  
always be thought of by the designer of the physical environment  
as an aid to use, however, rather than as a replacement for the clar-  
ity created by a well-considered design.  
# 9.3 Interior design  
Research has shown that patients, including children, will often  
draw connections between the quality, order and cleanliness of  
the healthcare environment and their own care. Aspects of the design have been shown to act directly on clinical outcomes, for  
instance\:  
• Natural light – this has been demonstrated to improve recovery  
rates in ICU, to maintain circadian rhythms in both patients and  
staff, and to promote production of vitamin D \(low levels of vita-  
min D have been linked to dementia\).  
• Therapeutic views – views of nature and/or human activity have  
been shown to increase speed of recovery.  
• Acoustic design – incorporation of acoustically absorptive sur-  
faces appropriate for infection control will promote rest and sleep  
in an increasingly noisy technological healthcare environment.  
The ability of the user to have some control over their envi-  
ronment, particularly temperature, ventilation and light, is highly  
valued.  
# 9.4 Lighting  
Integrated natural and artificial lighting design needs to address not  
only technical aspects \(sustainability, life cycle costs, light levels  
and colour rendering required for clinical process\) but also the ther-  
apeutic agenda. This includes appropriate user control and variation  
in light levels over time to support circadian rhythms. Lighting may  
also be used to support different functions within an area, such as  
a single bedroom used both for minor clinical procedure and rest  
and recovery, which therefore requires both clinical observation of  
a patient at night and uninterrupted patient sleep.  
# 9.5 Art  
Access to appropriate works of art have been found to be highly  
beneficial in terms of providing a positive, welcoming and engag-  
ing healthcare environment. Many different forms of art have been  
found to help support patient and staff well-being including sculp-  
tural objects, paintings, prints, photographs, moving image, music,  
soundscape, tactile pieces, poetry and spoken word.  
Integration is a key aspect in the successful use of art for ther-  
apeutic design, with hospitals often commissioning art alongside  
refurbishment or new building projects. Ongoing art in hospital  
programmes can add hugely to the life of the healthcare commu-  
nity.  
# 9.6 Landscape  
Access to external spaces whether landscape, courtyard or balcony  
are valued by patients, visitors and staff, and can provide wel-  
come relief from often necessarily clinical interior environments.  
External spaces can include facilities such as a terrace attached to a  
café, play spaces for children, rehabilitation areas or quiet gardens  
for remembrance or reflection. Multi-sensory design including  
scented plants and encouraging insect and bird-life can provide  
interest and help reduce stress for staff, patients and visitors.  
# 10 SPECIFICATION  
# 10.1 Infection control  
Infection control is one of the key principles behind the design of  
hospital interiors – it is vital that healthcare associated infections  
\(HCAIs\) are kept to a minimum. Infection control input should be  
included at all stages of the design from feasibility studies to post  
project evaluation.  
Advice will range from space/sizing, requirements for specialist  
areas, siting of linen, waste, cleaning and hand hygiene facilities,  
engineering systems, approach to control of legionella, etc., equip-  
ment schedules and choice of finishes and fittings.  
One impact of the Covid-19 pandemic will be a greater  
emphasis on building infection prevention into the SoA and the  
hospital organisation diagram. This may include increases to cer-  
tain space allowances to enable social distancing, additional hand  
# Hospitals 20-31  
washing facilities to support enhanced hygiene measures. It may  
also involve the segregation of the hospital into semi-autonomous  
zones for patients with a known or suspected pandemic infection  
\(referred to as ‘blue pathways’\) and for patients who have tested  
negative for the infection \(referred to as ‘green pathways’\).  
At a detailed level of design, the specification of interior prod-  
ucts and the design of interior details requires that ease of cleaning  
and disinfection be kept constantly in mind.  
Traditional methods of disinfection often use solutions of  
chlorine in water; more modern systems include ‘fogging’ with  
disinfecting vapour. Both traditional and modern methods of dis-  
infection require prior cleaning of surfaces to physically remove  
contaminants. ‘Fogging’ requires rooms/areas to be sealed during  
the process. Materials used need to be resilient to cleaning and  
disinfection methods used. Commonly, coved skirtings and sealed  
light fittings will be used in clinical areas.  
Although a range of antimicrobial-impregnated products \(such  
as surface coatings, paints and curtains\) is available, there is, at  
the time of writing, no definitive data to support their efficacy in  
reducing HCAIs.  
# 10.2 Materials  
Specification of materials for the interior of a hospital need to  
reflect a balance between factors such as robustness, frequency and  
cost of maintenance, sustainability and infection control.  
While the infection control agenda tends towards the selection  
of hard, smooth surfaces and products with few or sealed joints,  
this needs to be balanced with therapeutic, other safety, and main-  
tenance considerations including\:  
• Acoustics – hard, smooth surfaces can reduce speech intel-  
ligibility increasing the risk of clinical error, difficulty in  
communication between clinicians and patients, lack of privacy,  
stress, lack of sleep, disorientation for dementia sufferers.  
• Heating and ventilation – the choice will need to consider energy  
efficiency, type of facility, local conditions, appropriate patient/  
user control.  
• Artificial lighting design – needs to go beyond consideration  
of light levels and uniformity required for clinical procedures  
to include requirements for therapeutic environment including  
variety and control. Luminaires should be selected with energy  
efficiency, frequency and cost of lamp replacement in mind.  
• Safety – smoother floors are generally easier to clean but are  
more slippery, so careful risk assessment is needed to select  
appropriate material for different areas.  
• Maintenance – adequate access to mechanical and electrical  
services for maintenance and repair needs to be considered  
alongside the infection control agenda for smooth, sealed sur-  
faces.  
# 10.3 Engineering services  
Building services engineering refers here to mechanical, electrical  
and public health engineering \(MEP\) and includes general and spe-  
cialist installations such as medical gases and nurse call systems  
and, when necessary, the storage and disposal of radioactively con-  
taminated waste.  
The adequate provision of the building services strategy in a  
healthcare building depends on many factors that underline the  
importance of developing its approach as early as possible in paral-  
lel with the building design.  
Hospital buildings are highly serviced facilities, and the engi-  
neering services account for 40–50 per cent of a healthcare project’s  
construction budget. The scale of the services required has a sig-  
nificant impact on the final volume of the healthcare building, of  
which 5 per cent of total building area is used for vertical services  
distribution risers, while plant rooms comprise a total building area **20-32 Hospitals**  
of 10–15 per cent, and ceiling voids are commonly provided with  
1 m depth or more to allow for the services distribution.  
The variation in type and size of healthcare buildings, the  
increasing complexity of healthcare treatments, the reduction in  
energy consumption, and the provision of consumerism \(patient  
and relative comfort and convenience\) are only a few issues to be  
tackled when defining the building services strategy requirements.  
HTMs provide advice and guidance on the design and opera-  
tion of a variety of engineering matters in healthcare premises such  
as requirements for air quality and ventilation to operating depart-  
ments, intensive treatment units and isolation suites including  
negative pressurised rooms, and the control of air pressure, clean-  
liness and humidity. In addition, HTMs also detail requirements  
for temperature control where, for example, internal temperatures  
in patient areas do not exceed 28°C for more than 50 hours per  
year during the summertime, and for water quality control on the  
prevention of infection, for example, legionella and pseudomonas.  
Integration of services and building design is a key success factor  
for the project to achieve a high level of occupant comfort and building  
performance. This requires time-consuming coordination and gener-  
ally involves the development of a 3D-coordinated model in BIM.  
Passive measures such as massing, orientation and fabric of  
the building should be the focus of building design to create com-  
fortable environmental conditions inside a building. However, the  
balance of such passive measures with active systems \(boilers and  
chillers, mechanical ventilation, electric lighting and so on\) has to  
be considered for the achievement of energy efficiency. Many hos-  
pitals contain much heat generating equipment, deep plans, specific  
performance in terms of temperature and humidity control and are  
continuously occupied. This creates quite a challenge.  
As with other aspects of hospital design, the response to the  
Covid-19 pandemic will also have implications for the design of the  
services infrastructure. In particular, the infection risk associated  
with Aerosol Generating Procedures \(AGPs\) has been highlighted  
as being of particular significance. Addressing this risk in existing  
facilities may entail physically enclosing zones within previously  
open-plan treatment areas, and upgrading mechanical ventilation to  
provide a higher number of air changes per hour.  
# 10.4 Sustainability  
The basic objective of sustainability is to minimise the negative  
environmental impact of development, through the reduction of the  
consumption of non-renewable resources and production of waste,  
for the creation of a healthy environment.  
The government is committed to the three facets of sustaina-  
ble development \(environmental, social and economic\), meaning  
that decisions should consider the needs of individuals, maximise  
well-being and protect the environment, including the reduction  
of energy consumption, waste, water usage and carbon emissions.  
The commitment of the NHS to sustainable development is pre-  
sented in the document entitled Sustainable Development Strategy  
for the Health and Social Care System 2014–2020. In 2020 these  
goals were reinforced by a commitment to achieve net zero carbon  
by 2040 for emissions it controls directly and by 2045 for emis-  
sions it can influence.  
BREEAM \(Building Research Establishment Environmental  
Assessment Method\) and LEED \(Leadership in Energy and  
Environmental Design\) are widely used environmental assessment  
methods. BREEAM Health has been specifically developed, taking  
into account issues particular to this building type \(it has super-  
seded NEAT, which was the NHS’s own system\).  
# 11 SAFETY  
# 11.1 Fire safety  
Healthcare buildings must comply with requirements for fire safety  
and means of escape. Key regulations are\:  
• Approved Document Part B of Schedule 1 \(Vol 2\) of Building  
Regulations – provides guidance on compliance with fire safety  
requirements for some of the core common building types \(see  
also Chapter 11, Fire safety\).  
• Firecode – fire safety in the NHS HTM 05–01, HTM 05–02 and  
HTM 05–03. These have been prepared by the Department of  
Health to provide specific guidance for healthcare premises.  
Hospital emergency evacuation strategies are based on the  
concept of Progressive Horizontal Evacuation \(PHE\) whereby  
patients are moved to adjoining areas within the building. The  
Firecode HTM05–02 defines the principle of PHE as ‘moving  
occupants from an area affected by fire through a fire-resisting  
barrier to an adjoining area on the same level, designed to protect  
the occupants from the immediate dangers of fire and smoke \(a  
refuge\)’.  
Depending on the mobility of the patients \(Firecode has  
three classifications for patient dependency\), PHE is usually  
undertaken utilising beds or wheelchairs. In some situations,  
depending on the location of the fire, vertical evacuation is the  
only option. Nevertheless, the decision to move patients is not  
taken lightly, as any movement can potentially aggravate the  
patient’s condition.  
The HTM 05–02 is a very comprehensive document that covers  
all major principles of fire safety in healthcare buildings. It pro-  
vides guidance to means of warning and escape. Its three main  
requirements are explained next.  
*Compartmentation*  
Compartmentation of a large building into areas \(compartments\)  
of limited size, divided by fire-resisting partitions, allows escape  
away from the fire source into a nearby place of relative safety in  
the initial stages of the fire. Compartments containing patient-ac-  
cess areas should be divided into smaller sub-compartments to  
limit the number of patients who may be affected by a fire.  
*Hospital street*  
The hospital street, a primary circulation route between areas of the  
hospital, can form a major fire-fighting platform. It also provides  
an alternative to an adjacent department for the purposes of PHE.  
Hospital streets have particular requirements of maximum travel  
distances defined within the Firecode.  
*Travel distances and escape routes*  
There is a limitation on maximum travel distance within a compart-  
ment and sub-compartment. Within a compartment, the maximum  
distance is 60 m; within a sub-compartment this is 30 m.  
Furthermore, the HTM also provides guidance on items such  
as fire detection and alarm, vertical escape, assisted patient evac-  
uation, final exits, external escape routes, departments providing  
specialised care, and about internal fire spread for linings and  
structure, external fire spread and access and facilities for the fire  
service.  
Fire engineering, which provides recommendations and guid-  
ance on the application of fire safety engineering principles, is  
recognised as an acceptable alternative method of compliance with  
the Approved Document B. It is covered by the British Standard  
7974\:2001 Application of fire safety engineering principles to the  
design of buildings, code of practice. This approach provides an  
opportunity for innovative design, where it is possible to reconcile  
the qualitative design aspirations of the healthcare building project  
\(e.g. the provision of public stairs, atria\) with the fire strategy and  
regulations.  
The design of the fire safety strategy for a healthcare building  
is not an end in itself. It ties in with lifelong client commitment to  
assess, manage and implement. In short, anyone who has control  
to any extent of over the healthcare premises will have responsi-  
bilities for ensuring that those using or occupying the premises are safe from harm caused by fire. The duties include carrying out a fire  
safety risk assessment of the premises, identifying safety measures  
and implementing them.  
# 11.2 Health and safety  
There are two major types of hazard in any type of healthcare envi-  
ronment due to the type of activity and the nature of the building  
occupants.  
*Slips, trips and falls*  
The need to prevent slips, trips and falls is essential as many  
building users are frail and/or elderly. Many factors can cause  
them, including flooring type, lighting levels and lack of contrast  
between floors, walls and doors. The most effective approach is  
therefore to ensure that slips and trips hazards are designed out of  
a building. For example, floors should be slip resistant for wet or  
dry conditions and be clear of obstacles; level changes should be  
clearly identified, and rooms should be large enough to provide  
for the required activities without clutter. Nevertheless, any pro-  
posed measures must be evaluated to avoid potential conflict with  
infection control.  
*Manual handling*  
The hospital can be a very physical work environment, including  
having to lift and move patients \(some of whom can be very large\)  
and also equipment, laundry, catering, supplies or waste. Poor  
practice can cause accidents, musculoskeletal disorders that can  
lead to inability to work, and discomfort and lack of dignity for the  
patient being moved. However, there is an opportunity to build in  
equipment to protect staff from harm and enhance patient privacy  
and dignity. For instance, the use of mobile or ceiling-mounted  
hoists to assist the staff to raise fallen individuals from the floor, to  
transfer patients from one place to another, and to handle bariatric  
\(plus size\) patients.  
Key safety regulations relating to healthcare premises and  
equipment include\:  
• Health and Safety at Work Act \(HSWA\) 1974. This Act of  
Parliament is the main piece of UK health and safety legislation.  
It requires employers to ensure, as far as is reasonably practica-  
ble, the health, safety and welfare at work of all their employees.  
• The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations  
1999\. This places a duty on employers to assess and manage  
risks to their employees and non-employees arising from work  
activities.  
• Workplace \(Health, Safety and Welfare\) Regulations 1992.  
These regulations are concerned with the working environment.  
They place a duty on employers to make sure that the workplace  
is safe and suitable for the tasks being carried out there, and that  
it does not present risks to employees and others.  
• The Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992 \(MHOR\)  
\(as amended in 2002\). These regulations are designed to protect  
and safeguard people in the workplace in situations that involve  
manual handling tasks.  
• The Construction Design and Management Regulations \(CDM  
2015\). The regulations set out what people involved in con-  
struction work need to do to protect themselves from harm and  
anyone the work affects. The aim is to create awareness of the  
importance of health and safety integration right through the  
beginning of the design and the construction process.  
# Hospitals 20-33  
into account not only the healthcare facility but also the surround-  
ing external areas, such as the car park.  
Access controls to doors are widely used throughout the health-  
care facilities in the ingress/egress of staff/patients/visitors to  
sensitive areas to and within the building, and for specific func-  
tions, for example the storage of drugs. However, any requirements  
to secure doors should be discussed with the fire officer to address  
any fire-related matter.  
Access-control requirements will vary pending on their location  
and function, and a variety of security systems can be implemented,  
such as a combination of proximity cards, press-to-release switches  
and entry phone/intercom systems linked to reception desks or staff  
bases.  
The use of personal protection devices \(tagging\) for babies and  
young children is one solution to address the safety concerns by  
protecting the child from unauthorised removal from the healthcare  
premises. Another option is the use of CCTV in non-private areas,  
for example in circulation corridors leading to the entrance/exit  
points of the Paediatric department.  
Panic alarm buttons should be provided in areas where a mem-  
ber of staff is likely to be alone with a member of the public.  
# 12 OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT  
# 12.1 Logistics  
Operational logistics is a useful instrument to increase efficiency  
and quality, and decrease cost in operational functions such as  
material flows in healthcare facilities. The use of automation,  
health information technology with bar coding technology, phar-  
maceutical robots and lean storage solutions can all assist with  
creating efficient support services.  
*Robotic systems*  
Known variously as Automated Guided Vehicles \(AGVs\), Self-  
Guided Vehicles \(SGV\), Laser-Guided Vehicles \(LGV\) or  
Automated Guided Carts/Trolleys – robotic systems are increas-  
ingly used as a material-handling solution in hospitals. Their usage  
allows the automatic pick-up and delivery from central processing  
areas such as the kitchen, laundry, waste, sterile and drugs stores  
to the patient floors. The AGV system has the potential to increase  
efficiency, reduce operating costs and potentially improve the  
patient experience.  
*Health Information Technology \(Health IT\)*  
Health IT is a broad concept that encompasses an array of tech-  
nologies \(e.g. electronic medical records, bar coding\) to store,  
share and analyse health information to improve patient care  
and safety. For example, the use of standards-based bar coding  
technology can provide improvements in material management  
coordination, in patient safety, clinical care delivery, patient  
tracking, patient registration and admission processes in the  
healthcare environment.  
*Lean storage*  
Use of a lean storage system is designed to eliminate waste through  
automating processes that improve productivity, inventory man-  
agement and space utilisation.  
# 11.3 Security  
Maintaining the safety and security of staff, patients, visitors and  
the NHS assets \(equipment and consumables\) is a crucial part of  
the service provided by the health bodies. A risk assessment is  
required to identify the security risks, and to identify measures that  
can be applied to reduce them. The safety procedures should take  
# 12.2 Facilities Management \(FM\)  
FM is a profession that encompasses multiple disciplines to  
ensure functionality of the built environment by integrating peo-  
ple, places, process and technology. FM includes the integration  
of the planning and management of a wide range of services  
both hard \(e.g. building fabric\) and soft \(e.g. catering, cleaning,  
security, mail, porterage, waste management\) to achieve quality  
economically. **20-34 Hospitals**  
# 12.3 Whole Life Cycle Costing \(WLC\)  
WLC assesses the cost of an asset \(e.g. a healthcare facility\) over  
its lifetime. It takes into consideration initial capital costs, finance  
costs, operational costs, maintenance costs and replacement or dis-  
posal costs at the end of its life. Therefore, the whole life costs  
consider a healthcare facility project from inception through to  
design and construction, operation and finally re-use or disposal.  
It enables investment options in healthcare estates or buildings  
to be evaluated more effectively by considering the impact of all  
costs rather than only the initial capital costs.  
WLCs are substantially greater than capital or costs of initial  
construction, and so a small improvement in design organisation  
or specification could save a huge amount of revenue over the life  
of the facility. **21 Hotels**  
# Fred Lawson  
# CI/SfB\: 85  
*Fred Lawson is a hotel expert and the author of many books on hotels and tourism.*  
*KEY POINTS*  
• *Competitive industry with high capital and operating costs*  
• *Standards dictated by market demands and location*  
• *Increasingly dominated by chain operators and branding*  
• *Design must ensure efficient operation and value for money*  
• *Ancillary facilities may be a major generator of business*

# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 The hotel industry  
Hotels serve the needs of travellers, tourists, business visitors and oth-  
ers seeking temporary accommodation and other services. Essential  
requirements are clean, quiet and comfortable bedrooms together with  
good services that usually include meals. Ancillary facilities for busi-  
ness users and/or leisure attractions often influence choice although  
the costs involved and value for money are primary considerations.  
Prior to the design stage, many of the key requirements will have  
already been decided such as the location, number and types of rooms  
and the extent of facilities to be provided. Preliminary estimates of  
costs and revenues form part of the feasibility analysis for the invest-  
ment. Design briefs are normally provided by developers, including  
hotel companies who may be involved in managing the property.  
The trend is towards multiple chain operating groups special-  
ising in hotel management. These offer a wide range of services  
including professionally trained staff, established confidence in the  
standards provided and the advantages of scale in their advertising  
and reservation systems. Chain hotels may be company owned but  
are frequently financed by separate investors and then operated by  
the hotel company under contract or through a franchise.  
Hotels are seen as a business investment rather than property  
investment. The specific design requirements generally make  
future conversion to other uses difficult and expensive. High-grade  
hotels typically offer a choice of suites as well as standard rooms  
and often extend their hotel services to apartments in associated  
developments such as in condominiums. Aparthotels are designed  
with apartments, instead of individual bedrooms.  
# 1.2 Hotel classification  
Standards of services and facilities in hotels vary widely from  
luxury to basic. Hotel groups distinguish the types of hotels they  
operate by branding with specific names and design features.  
Tourism authorities in most countries use symbols \(stars, crowns,  
etc.\) to classify hotels and other types of tourist accommodation.  
Some commercial agencies and travel publications also grade their  
members by prices and services offered.  
Hotels are primarily categorised by their location \(e.g. city, sub-  
urban, resort, country, airport, motel\) and also by the main markets  
they serve \(e.g. business travellers, convention groups, holiday  
seekers, motorists\). Typical categories cover\:  
• 5\* Luxury\: exclusive named hotels in exotic destinations and  
prime city locations  
• 4\* High class\: with extensive facilities for business users and  
high spend tourists  
• 3\* Mid-grade\: full service traditional hotels, independent or  
company managed  
• 2\* Budget\: standard branded designs with some services for  
motorists and tourists  
• 1\* Basic\: economy brands designed with minimal space and lim-  
ited facilities.  
Grading also takes account of the extent of services offered.  
Staff requirements in a full service hotel are substantial with pay-  
roll absorbing up to one-third of the turnover. Designs must ensure  
maximum working efficiency and provide adequate employee facil-  
ities including controlled entry, separate changing rooms, lockers,  
toilets, restroom, canteen, security, personnel offices and – often –  
some living accommodation. Ratios of employees to guestrooms  
range from 0.2–0.3 budget, 0.5–0.6 mid-grade, 0.8–1.0 high-grade,  
to 1.5 luxury standard.  
Demands for value and convenience have led to increases in  
standardised chains’ budget hotels \(e.g. motels, inns\) sited with  
highway service stations or around towns and near attractions.  
Some brands are designed to provide basic facilities operated with  
a minimum of staff.  
# 1.3 Other tourist accommodation  
Internet tourism services provide choice from a wide range of alter-  
natives including domestic properties \(e.g. B&B, guest houses\),  
traditional inns and vacation use of university and college accom-  
modation. Tourists, particularly families, increasingly choose  
self-catering facilities in new or converted properties and resort  
areas with alternative choice of eating places nearby.  
Resort complexes are developed as self-contained tourist des-  
tinations complete with extensive leisure facilities and supporting  
services on site. Most are designed as seaside, marina, ski, spa, golf  
or forest-based holiday village resorts. Tourist resorts may be operated  
by a commercial company, or co-ownership management. In the latter,  
accommodation is based on apartments, lodges and other properties  
for sale on individual, time-share or condominium arrangements.  
# 2 GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS  
# 2.1 Sites and surroundings  
The location and site largely dictate the design and relationship of  
the different parts of a hotel\:  
• Resorts – views of the attractions \(e.g. sea, lake, park, spec-  
tacular scenery\) provide marketing and higher value revenue  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-24 **21-1** **21-2 Hotels**  
benefits. This should be maximised for guestrooms and public  
areas such as restaurants. Interesting site activities \(e.g. marina,  
golf course, swimming pool\) and exotic landscaping also influ-  
ence the layout.  
• City centre developments – these are determined mainly by site  
constraints and planning considerations. High site costs may lead  
to high value frontages being used for shops and malls; pent-  
house floors as luxury serviced apartments or suites. Invariably,  
development costs are increased by the need for underground  
parking and basement services, including goods entry and dock-  
ing. Multiple floors of guestrooms require extensive guest and  
service lifts as well as complex technical systems. The need for  
ancillary facilities such as convention/function halls can occupy  
a large part of the site area.  
• Key city sites – these allow for high-rise statement buildings  
which, themselves, attract attention. They may be designed  
entirely as a hotel or for multiple users with specific floors allo-  
cated for hotel accommodation and services. The latter requires  
more complex separate arrangements for guest reception and  
transportation as well as for goods services. Tower buildings  
require large structural core areas housing vertical services  
\(lifts, stairs, ducts, service rooms, etc.\) and the ratio of perimeter  
rooms per floor area is limited.  
• Suburban sites – here site and construction costs are lower and  
allow greater flexibility in site layout and building design. There  
are savings in foundation and structural costs, technical services  
are often simplified and lift systems may be rationalised. These  
include hotels sited within or near airports on the outskirts of  
towns, or in locations which attract a mixed market of tourists,  
local functions and business travellers.  
• Roadside and stopover places – these cater for motorists and other  
travellers and are invariably chain operated budget designs, with  
standardised rooms and minimal facilities for meals. Typical  
buildings are modular with prefabricated technical services, one  
or two storeys in height. Optimum sites are associated with other  
motorway services along highways, at main junctions and near  
attractions along tourist routes.  
**21.1** *Circulation and relationship diagram*  
# 2.2 Access and site development  
In the preliminary design stage, consideration must be given to\:  
• Restrictions, including planning, property rights and other legal  
limitations, which may limit plot ratio and height of building.  
• Access routes to separate guests from goods delivery/services  
and employee entries.  
• Site planning for parking requirements and potential future  
extensions.  
• The main entrance must be prominent, appropriate for the style  
and grade of hotel. In urban hotels, secondary access from the  
car park must lead directly to the reception lobby. A separate  
entrance and reception may be required for large convention/  
function groups.  
Car parking space depends on the location, patterns of use,  
transport modes and availability of public parking/taxi services.  
Motor and airport hotels typically provide 1.1 spaces/room, city  
centre hotels about 0.3 spaces/room plus 0.2 spaces/convention  
or function seat. Resort hotels may require only 0.2 spaces/room  
plus coach parking. Provisions must also be made for separate staff  
parking.  
# 2.3 Spatial and functional relationships  
The functional requirements of a full service hotel can be grouped  
into three distinct but linked areas\: public, guest room and back of  
house/administrative \(Figure 21.1\).  
# 2.4 Public areas  
For guests and usually open to non-residents, public rooms include  
lounges, restaurants, bars, meeting rooms, ballrooms and other  
rooms catering for functions. Other facilities, such as fitness rooms,  
spas and leisure pools, may also allow for local club membership.  
Typical requirements include\:  
• Large span spacious areas to accommodate planned numbers of  
users and allow changes in layout and design to suit different  
requirements.  
• Situated at or near ground floor level to allow easy access, con-  
trol and emergency exit.  
• External views required for restaurants. Speciality restaurants  
and bars may be sited at rooftop level in tall buildings with  
dedicated lift access and services. In lobbies and convention/  
function halls, an impressive, spacious interior design is impor-  
tant. Natural light is an advantage in lounges and break-out  
foyers.  
• Support areas \(e.g. foyers, equipment stores, food service facili-  
ties, staff access\) must be sited adjacent or easily accessible with  
effective screening to avoid disturbance in use.  
# 2.5 Guestrooms  
Bedrooms and suites for resident guests are located to benefit from views  
and designed to minimise noise and disturbance. Residential accom-  
modation is the largest generator of net revenue and typically occupies  
some 70–75 per cent of the built area in full service hotels, see Table I. **Table I Residential area ratios**

• Repetitive modular construction of rooms adjacent to vertical

• Careful planning of stairs, lifts and corridors to facilitate easy

• Guest circulations via the main reception area while staff have

• Specific requirements apply for disabled access, fire escapes,

# 2.6 Back of house and administration areas  
These accommodate the technical and operational installations  
including staff facilities and workrooms. They are located in the  
least valuable areas with vehicle access for goods delivery and  
waste/recycling removal, maintenance and emergency services.  
Facilities include\:  
• Basements in large hotels and high value sites. Lift motor hous-  
ing and ventilation/air-conditioning plant sited in screened  
rooftop locations  
• Separate areas for loading docks, waste containment, control,  
storage rooms, engineering, housekeeping, laundries, employees  
and main food storage and production  
• Internal service access \(separate from guest areas\) to guestrooms,  
and from service areas to public rooms \(restaurants, bars, func-  
tion rooms, furniture/equipment stores\)  
• Separate facilities for hotel administration are required. Offices  
for duty management are located near the reception lobby with  
access to the reception desk.  
# 2.7 Circulation and signage  
Routes to be taken by guests, non-residents and staff must be  
carefully planned to facilitate easy movement and control \(Figure  
21.2a–c\). This also indicates the optimum locations for support  
facilities and the services required. All routes must be kept clear of  
obstruction and be wide enough to avoid congestion, particularly  
in areas where people congregate \(e.g. reception desk, foyers, lift
