# 5.5 Internal planning  
Opinions differ over the relative positions of living room and  
kitchen. In narrow frontage houses where the living room needs to  
occupy most of the full width of the front of the house, the dining  
kitchen will therefore tend to be at the rear, where it can provide a  
route to the garden. In three- or four-storey houses this sometimes  
works well in combination with a front living room at first floor  
level as in Figures 22.18 and 22.19. Rooms can then be full width,  
and offer good outlook and supervision both to the front and rear,  
as well as benefiting from sunlight with almost any orientation.  
Figure 22.18 shows a medium frontage plan with a through din-  
ing/kitchen and first floor living room. Figure 22.20 shows a wider  
plan which gives greater flexibility. It allows the living room to  
be at the front or rear of the dwelling depending on its orientation.  
In this instance, it is also possible to provide a first floor layout to  
suit the private for sale sector \(with an extra en-suite\) or the social  
sector.  
# 5.6 Living/dining versus kitchen/diner  
Certain types, such as Figure 22.15, have the great advantage of  
offering alternative ground floor plans with the dining space in  
either the living room or the kitchen; also the possibility of open-  
ing the two spaces into one. Use of the kitchen/diner is generally  
preferable and suits current lifestyles better as it offers two recep-  
tion rooms allowing greater flexibility for active family life. This  
arrangement also ensures that one reception room will receive sun-  
light for much of the day.  
# 5.7 Homeworking  
In recent times, there has been an increased need for many to work  
from home, yet many homes are poorly designed for homeworking.  
There should be a flexible space which can be turned over for work-  
ing if required. Suitable spaces might include within bedrooms, a  
landing or hallway alcove, living room or beneath stairs. Ideally,  
the space would be self-contained. Wherever a space is located,  
consideration must be given to the provision of generous natural  
light and sufficient services.  
# 5.8 Bathrooms  
The main bathroom should preferably be located on the floor with  
the most bedrooms. In three-storey houses, this might be the first  
or the second floor. A ground floor WC is now a requirement in  
all family houses, however small \(*Building Regulations Approved*  
*Document Part M4\[1\]*\). Although there is no longer a legal prohibi-  
tion of WCs opening directly from kitchens, this arrangement is not  
normally either popular or advised. An exception might sometimes  
be a utility room containing a WC and forming the route to the  
garden. WCs must always have a hand basin \(*Building Regulation*  
*Approved Document G*\).  
In larger family houses with four or more bedrooms, a sec-  
ond bathroom or shower room, is desirable. This can be useful in  
three-storey houses, as it can mean having a WC on each floor. One  
bathroom or shower room can be en-suite with the main bedroom;  
however, this has not normally been considered to be appropriate  
in social housing.  
In private sector housing, it is normal to provide one family  
bathroom plus en-suite shower rooms to the master bedroom and  
any further double bedroom. Thus in a four bed, seven-person  
house, there would normally be a family bathroom and two en-suite  
shower rooms.  
# 5.9 Multi-generational houses  
The affordability of housing and the cost of child care and elderly  
care has led to the development of multi-generation houses, which  
provide a flexible home for extended families who want to live  
together while retaining a degree of mutual independence. An  
example is shown in Figure 22.21. This example shows a three-bed-  
room dwelling with a one-bedroom annex with a shared courtyard.  
# 5.10 Design of external areas  
Refuse storage space is almost always needed at the front of the  
house, Figure 22.22. The location for the dustbins or ‘wheelie-bin’  
needs to be clearly identified, for example, by partial enclosure or  
change of paving surface. It needs to be close to the highway, the  
front gate and path, and not too far from the front or kitchen door. It  
should not be where smells would cause a problem, such as imme-  
diately under the window of a habitable room.  
Refuse storage requirements can vary from area to area. Many  
now require two ‘wheelie-bins’, one for general waste and one for  
recycling. Others have a requirement for a number of containers for  
different types of recycling. Many also offer an option to have one  
specifically for garden waste. Designers must check local require-  
ments to ensure refuse storage is properly integrated into the design  
at an early stage in the process.  
In 2015, the government published guidance on suitable provi-  
sion for proper waste storage in new homes to tackle ‘bin blight’ **Houses and flats** **22-17**  
**22.21** *A three-bedroom house with a one bed annex and a shared courtyard multi-generational house designed for the social sector*  
**22.22** *Front garden of a terraced house showing refuse and cycle storage* **22-18** **Houses and flats**  
of bins dominating residential streets and contributing to increased  
odour and roadside litter. This includes both covert storage units  
for residents’ bins, or simply ensuring that there is space for bins  
to be stored in backyards so that they are taken out only on bin-col-  
lection day.  
Meter positions can sometimes be integrated with that of bins,  
so that one can partially mask the other.  
The function of a front garden enclosure is different from that  
of the rear garden, and this should be reflected in the design, as in  
Figure 22.22.  
Front fences, railings or walls should allow visual surveillance,  
both ways. A height of between 800 mm and 1300 mm is usually  
appropriate, and it is useful if the enclosure can be seen through  
below this level  
Enclosure of rear gardens is simpler. An impermeable wall or  
fence of approximately 1.8 m height is normally recommended  
at the far end. The side \(party fence\) enclosures can be reduced  
to approximately 1.2 m. Most people seem to welcome some  
garden-to-garden contact with their neighbours, though not imme-  
diately next to the house, where a greater height is preferred. If  
gates are provided in rear garden walls or fences, these should be  
full height \(at least 1.8 m\) and lockable.  
# 6 PURPOSE-BUILT FLATS  
# 6.1 General  
A block of flats nearly always involves shared entrances, stairs,  
landings, balconies or lobbies, and often one or more lifts. These  
features tend to make flats undesirable for families with children.  
In many developments, one would expect the majority of flats to be  
two-bedroom, with a lesser number of one-bedroom and three-bed-  
room flats.  
Common areas and facilities become exponentially more diffi-  
cult to manage with increasing numbers of flats in the block. Small  
blocks of four or six flats are easier to manage than those where  
the numbers get into double figures. Shared systems such as entry  
phones rely upon responsible behaviour. This is more achievable  
with a small number of households who know each other. London  
Plan Guidance has a requirement for a maximum of eight dwellings  
per floor served off a single stair core and this can be considered  
good practice \(Figure 22.23\). There is also the need to consider the  
provision of ventilation and natural daylighting to common areas.  
# 6.2 Height of blocks  
Parker Morris stipulated the maximum walk-up to a flat front door  
to be two storeys. Blocks of up to three storeys, without lifts, later  
became commonplace. Four-storey blocks without lifts are on the  
limit of acceptability. For five storeys and above, a lift is essen-  
tial. *Approved Document M Category 2* and *Approved Document*  
*M Category 3* require ‘step-free access to all dwellings above or  
below ground level’ and therefore makes the provision of lifts a  
statutory requirement where they are implemented.  
# 6.3 Common stairs and corridors  
Common corridors and lobbies are generally required to be smoke  
vented in order to prevent smoke and the products of fire in a flat  
**22.23** *Upper floor of a block of flats containing five flats per stair core, with a mix of one bedroom, two-bedroom and three-bedroom*  
*flats* from reaching the fire protected common escape stair. This can  
be achieved by natural smoke venting to external air via an AOV  
\(automatic opening ventilator\) or an internal smoke shaft. Note  
that AOVs are not permitted in buildings over 30 m in height.  
Protected enclosures should also be provided with a smoke vent at  
the top storey, linked to open upon activation of the corridor vents.  
Alternatively, a mechanical smoke exhaust or pressure differential  
system can be utilised. Dry risers and possibly fire-fighting lifts,  
staircases and lobbies may be required in certain arrangements  
depending on building heights and floor areas.  
Common corridor lengths are normally determined by the lim-  
itations of travel distance allowed for means of escape. These are  
7.5 m where a single direction of escape exists or 30 m if alter-  
natives routes are available. The provision of designed smoke  
control systems can allow for extended travel distances. Also, the  
provision of sprinkler coverage within the flats enables the travel  
distance to be doubled.  
In small single stair buildings \(with no more than four storeys  
and no floor level over 11 m above ground\) some allowances are  
made. If there are only two flats per storey these can open directly  
into the stair core as long as the flats have internal fire protected  
hallways. If the travel distance in a common lobby or corridor  
does not exceed 4.5 m then the lobby/corridor is not required to  
be smoke vented. The stair enclosure must still be provided with a  
smoke vent as noted previously.  
Designers should also be aware of the potential problem of com-  
mon areas over-heating if not adequately ventilated. BS 5925\:1991  
recommends that a free area of 1/50th of the floor area is provided  
for adequate ventilation.  
# 6.4 Internal flat layouts  
For fire safety purposes any flat that has an internal travel distance  
of over 9 m from the entrance door to any point of accommoda-  
tion must be provided with a cellular layout around an internal  
fire protected hallway, that in itself must not exceed 9 m length.  
Open-plan layouts are possible if they fall within this limit or  
if sprinklers are provided. Duplexes require alternative escape  
routes from the non-entrance levels, unless either a sprinkler  
system is installed or an internal fire protected hall, landing and  
stairway is formed and an automatic fire detection system pro-  
vided.  
Open-plan layouts areas make the maximum use of space  
and have thus become ubiquitous, particularly in smaller flats.  
However, they can be problematic if there are many activities  
going on in the one space. In particular, a space for home working  
should be provided, wherever possible, preferably capable of being  
self-contained, with generous natural light.  
# 6.5 Build to Rent \(BtR\)  
In recent years, an acute housing shortage and soaring land values  
have led to an unprecedented rise in prices. Over the same time,  
the provision of affordable housing has plummeted. As a result,  
it is now much harder for young, single professionals to purchase  
a flat, or to trade-up to a house in many urban cities. Now, many  
who want to buy are forced to flat-share into their late thirties and  
even forties.  
This has led to the recent growth of the BtR sector, also known  
as the private rented sector \(PRS\). Typical dwellings are self-con-  
tained one-bedroom flats for single occupancy, for which the  
*Nationally described space standard* \(where applied\) recommends  
a minimum area of 39 m2 \(or 37 m2 where there is a shower room  
instead of a bathroom\). See Figure 22.24.  
Larger dwellings will usually have equal sized bedrooms with  
en-suite facilities and shared living facilities. The ‘dumb-bell’  
plan illustrated in Figure 22.25 puts a bedroom and bath or shower  
room each side of the living space. Although intended for young  
sharers, this typology could work well for a number of other occu-  
pants.  
**Houses and flats** **22-19**  
**22.24** *Self-contained one-bedroom one person flat of 38* *m2*  
*Source*\: Provided courtesy of Pocket Living Ltd.  
**22.25** *Typical two-bedroom flat designed for the private rented*  
*sector*  
Often shared spaces such as residents’ lounges, communal  
working and meeting spaces, roof terraces and fitness centres are  
also provided.  
Most BtR schemes tend to deliver just apartment accommoda-  
tion. However, there is a growing demand for private rented family  
size housing, such as three-bedroom duplexes with private outside  
space. **22-20** **Houses and flats**  
# 6.6 Multi-generational flats  
Multi-generational flats with one connecting room, such as a kitchen/  
dining room, but two separate units, are an emerging typology,  
Figure 22.26. These cater to families who wish to care for the older  
generation or to help younger families bring up children with the  
grandparents on hand, saving on childcare costs and making it easier  
to go back to work. Additionally, this typology would suit families  
where adult children return to live in the family home.  
# 6.7 Stacking of similar rooms  
All party floors have to provide sound insulation; but the levels of  
insulation that are mandatory cannot prevent all noise nuisance,  
and it is best if similar rooms are stacked one above the other. The  
worst combination is for a living room directly above another flat’s  
bedroom.  
# 6.8 Configuration of rooms around the common stairs  
The minimum levels of sound insulation specified in the Building  
Regulations between all habitable rooms in flats and the common  
parts of the block are less than fully satisfactory and the adoption  
of higher performance standards is always preferable. It is desir-  
able therefore to situate bedrooms away from the common stairs,  
Figure 22.27; and particularly, well away from any lift shaft.  
It is usually preferable to plan day rooms at the front and bed-  
rooms at the quieter rear, perhaps alongside the kitchen. There are  
however, many examples of small blocks of flats with bedrooms  
**22.26** *Typical intergenerational flat designed for the private rented sector. a\) Arranged as inter-connected dwellings with a shared*  
*kitchen/dining space; b\) Arranged as two separate dwellings* **Houses and flats** **22-21**  
**22.27** *Block of one and two-bedroom flats with bedrooms located away from lift and stairs. Lobbies between stairs and flats are*  
*required in larger blocks*  
at the front alongside the stairs, and living rooms at the rear. This  
plan form combines the worst exposure of the bedrooms to noise  
nuisance from the common stairs with the least satisfactory orien-  
tation of day and night rooms.  
# 6.9 Balcony access  
Balcony or deck access was largely discredited by the social fail-  
ures of much of the deck access, medium-rise, LA housing built in  
the 1960s and 1970s. However, some of the smaller, self-contained  
balcony access flat blocks built between the wars have proved quite  
satisfactory in long-term use. Balcony or deck access can avoid the  
squalor associated with wholly internal common circulation areas  
and provide cross-ventilation \(an advantage in avoiding over-heat-  
ing\) but they can also enable the planning of large extended blocks,  
with too many flats using a single entrance and stair.  
A potential problem with balcony access flats is the dual aspect  
nature; some windows are directly onto the balcony \(Figure 22.28\).  
These can be unpopular, owing to lack of privacy and the security  
risks. Kitchens and bathrooms tend to be placed on the balcony  
side, but residents dislike strangers passing close to their kitchen  
sinks. There is also the potential for means of escape to be restricted  
\(compromised\) in the event of smoke from fire escaping out of flat  
windows. However, with careful design and a reasonable limit on  
the number of flats served, balcony or deck access has become more  
widely acceptable.  
# 6.10 Lifts  
Where provided in blocks of flats these should always be capa-  
ble of taking a wheelchair as noted in *Approved Document M* of  
the Building Regulations. Lifts in medium-rise flat blocks have  
become rather easier to plan, using hydraulic lifts with pump  
rooms at or near the base, as opposed to electric lifts with motor  
rooms at the top. Hydraulic pump rooms can be very compact  
and flexibly positioned. In blocks of flats with a floor level  
higher than 18 m above entrance level a firefighter’s lift must  
be provided. **22-22** **Houses and flats**  
**22.28** *Upper floor of a block of flats where one flat in the cluster*  
*is accessed via an external balcony*  
# 6.11 Refuse  
This is always a challenge with flats. Traditionally, social sector  
housing has used chutes. However, these can cause a noise nui-  
sance and tend to become blocked. Additionally, the inlet points  
and chambers at the base of the chutes can become particularly  
unsavoury.  
For large or tall blocks, Building Regulations have an implied  
recommendation for refuse chutes. For the reasons stated earlier,  
in actuality they are hardly ever provided. Even very tall blocks  
rely on ground level refuse storage chambers and residents using  
vertical transportation for disposal from flats. However, chutes are  
becoming more popular, evident in some new developments within  
the BtR sector, where blocks are well managed. If they are pro-  
vided, the base area needs to be carefully designed, with robust  
and easily cleaned surfaces, good access for cleaning and copious  
ventilation.  
If blocks of flats can be kept small \(up to six or eight flats\), then  
it is quite possible to provide a discreet but easily accessible area  
containing a separate rubbish bin for each flat, clearly and individ-  
ually marked, Figure 22.29.  
The maximum distance that residents should be required to  
carry waste to the storage point is 30 m. Waste collection vehicles  
should be able to get within 25 m of that point. Maximum reversing  
distances for vehicles will also have to be considered and this will  
have an impact on the building and road layouts.  
# 6.12 Incoming utilities\: meters and services ducts  
The provision of sufficient space for meters and services to the  
apartment block is paramount when planning the floor layouts, par-  
ticularly around the common access stairs, lobbies and corridors.  
It is usual to provide vertical risers to house all incoming services,  
such as electricity, gas, telecommunications, phone/video entry,  
cable TV, data cabling, and so forth. Access into these service ris-  
ers is often via fire doors opening onto the ventilated lobbies as  
discussed earlier.  
It is advisable to obtain advice and guidance from the relevant  
national and local service providers, particularly regarding location  
of meters and routing of their services. Gas routing needs special  
consideration as all spaces containing a gas pipe, meter, valve etc.  
need to be vented to prevent the building up of undetectable gas,  
which could lead to explosion.  
There may be a requirement for meter rooms to be designed into  
the ground floor or at basement level, to facilitate easy access by  
the providing authority. Routing from these meters rooms and the  
vertical risers will need careful consideration to avoid the risk of  
clashes with structure or compromising fire integrity.  
Horizontal routing of these services from the vertical service  
shafts into the apartments should also be considered at an early  
stage. Access for ongoing maintenance will be a consideration  
when choosing finishes to ceilings and floors.  
# 6.13 Design of external areas  
Communal gardens require good management by residents’ asso-  
ciation or landlord. Unless this is in place, shared external areas  
should be either minimised or avoided. Clearly, the latter is not  
entirely possible, as access is needed to the common front door.  
**22.29** *External planning for typical three-storey block of flats showing refuse storage* The route to this entrance should be as simple as possible\: broad  
and short. Areas to the sides of this access can be given to the  
ground floor flats as front gardens; and these will be much more  
successful if these flats have separate front doors independent of  
the common entrance. Similarly, the best use for the ground behind  
the block is normally as rear gardens for the ground floor flats.  
The enclosure of front and rear gardens to ground floor flats  
should be similar to that for single-family houses \(see Section 5.2\).  
The shared approach to the main entrance door should be treated  
rather differently. If there is no unallocated garden space, there will  
be no fencing except on either side of this approach.  
If there is any soft landscaping along the shared approach route,  
it needs to be carefully planned to withstand limited care. If flanked  
by well cared for private gardens, then the common approach path  
is best left as good quality hard landscaping and paving.  
The importance of having access to private amenity space has  
been emphasised in recent times, particularly for flats. External  
space for upper-floor flats is often provided by private balconies  
or terraces. If these can be designed with an ability to be converted  
into winter gardens in the colder months, a more useable space for  
leisure, or home working, can be provided all year round.  
The recommended minimum areas for private balconies is a mini-  
mum of 5 m2 for 1–2 person dwellings with an extra 1 m2 provided for  
each additional occupant. A minimum width and depth of 1500 mm  
should provide sufficient space for either a meal around a small table,  
clothes drying or for the occupants to sit outside with visitors.  
# 7 CONVERSIONS  
# 7.1 General  
The conversion of large houses into self-contained flats in the  
1970s and 1980s used to be the stock-in-trade of inner city housing  
providers, as well as private developers. There has been a falling  
off of this type of project but there remain many situations where  
conversions of existing buildings in sensitive urban areas and con-  
servation areas are relevant.  
# 7.2 Planning  
Splitting up a single-family house involves creating at least one  
new dwelling, and thereby constitutes ‘development’ under the  
Planning Acts. Unlike extending a single-family house by an  
allowed percentage of its volume, this is not ‘permitted develop-  
ment’. Therefore, house conversions require planning permission  
that allows planning authorities to control this type of development  
if they feel that it is eroding the balance of single-family houses in  
the district.  
Houses that are statutorily listed have more onerous constraints  
and require Listed Building Consent for any demolition \(however  
small\). Certain restraints also apply to all properties within conser-  
vation areas. Conservation area approval is no longer required for  
a small amount of demolition, such as of an outhouse; but a pro-  
posal of this nature might well lead to a spot-listing, when a Listed  
Building Consent would then be required. In many of these cases,  
the planning authority and/or Historic England may then get very  
involved in detailed design and aesthetics.  
This introduces the first discipline when dealing with an exist-  
ing house, which is to respect its existing qualities and character.  
A natural conversion should aim to keep well-proportioned rooms  
intact wherever possible. This commonly means at least the main  
front rooms at ground and first floor levels. Avoid boxed-in lobbies  
in the corners of previously good rooms. These disrupt original dec-  
orative elements such as cornices and picture rails, and also make  
the rooms more difficult to furnish. Another implicit aspect of nat-  
ural conversions is the aim to keep similar rooms stacked over each  
other. Day rooms of one flat should not be planned over bedrooms  
of another flat and bathrooms and kitchens are best stacked, thereby  
simplifying drainage and plumbing.  
**Houses and flats** **22-23**  
The same considerations about accommodation for families  
with children apply as for new build. Family dwellings should be  
at ground and/or basement level, or at least have direct street entry  
and garden access. This will usually mean only one large unit in  
the conversion of a house, with one or more smaller units over it. In  
a wish to reduce the common areas, many conversions have been  
built the ‘wrong way up’ with a large unit over a one-bedroom  
flat at ground floor level. This is unsatisfactory, especially in social  
housing. Family life is noisy, and does not fit well over single peo-  
ple or couples.  
However it should be the aim to abolish or minimise common  
areas and stairs wherever possible, as these often cause continuing  
management problems. New external stairs may be added in some  
cases to achieve the objective of a separate direct entrance for each  
dwelling.  
# 7.3 Building Regulations  
Creating new dwellings constitutes building work and is controlled  
by the Building Regulations. Most of the same parts \(see Table  
IV\) apply to conversions as to new build. The main exception is  
*Approved Document L*. In recognition of the fact that it may not  
be reasonably possible to add thermal insulation to all elements of  
the existing fabric to the standards required for new buildings, con-  
versions must meet the requirements of *Approved Document L1B*,  
which applies only to existing buildings.  
Some elements such as top floor ceilings, though, are quite  
simple to insulate, and could be upgraded to a higher level  
than required for new build to compensate for not insulating  
the walls. Thermal insulation can also often be added to the  
walls of rear extensions, where there is a greater proportion  
of exposed wall surface to floor area, and decorative features,  
which would be lost, are absent. The replanning of rear parts of  
the house to provide new service rooms may also give opportu-  
nities to add insulating linings. Also worth considering \(subject  
to planning restrictions\) is external insulation, as this can the-  
oretically give a better thermal performance and reduces cold  
bridging. *Approved Document B1* and *Approved Document E*  
apply to conversions as for new build, and can impose signifi-  
cant requirements.  
# 7.4 Loft conversions  
If habitable rooms are converted out of loft space, the resulting  
floor area is measured over those parts that are more than 1.5 m  
high. A two-storey house is covered by *Approved Document B1*  
only for escape from upper-floor windows. However, when its loft  
is converted, extra requirements of *Approved Document B1* come  
into force.  
Under *Approved Document K*, alternating tread stairs are specif-  
ically allowed up to single rooms and bathrooms in a loft. Despite  
this, there are considerable reservations about the safety of alternat-  
ing tread stairs, and they are not recommended, especially in social  
housing. A reasonable width for a staircase leading to a single hab-  
itable room in a loft is 800 mm, with a minimum of 700 mm.  
# 7.5 External areas  
Similar considerations apply as to purpose-built flats. The best  
answer is often the simplest – to give both front and rear gardens to  
the lowest dwelling, which is likely to be the largest. Balconies to  
upper-floor units are less likely to be feasible than with new build,  
unless a low rear extension provides an opportunity for a roof ter-  
race. Some planning authorities discourage these as prejudicing  
the privacy of neighbouring gardens. In cases of detached, semi-  
detached and end-of-terrace properties with easy access to the rear,  
plots for the upper flats can be provided by dividing the rear gar-  
den. There are also examples where first floor flats have been given  
access by means of external stairs. There is, however, evidence that  
small, subdivided rear gardens can lead to neglect, because resi-  
dents feel less well ‘connected’ to them. **22-24** **Houses and flats**  
# 7.6 Office to residential  
In a drive to increase the delivery of new homes, the government  
relaxed the planning policy for conversion of office buildings into  
residential dwellings – which are now classified as permitted devel-  
opment obviating the need for planning approval. However, this  
has led to many unsatisfactory conversions, mainly undersized,  
studio and one-bedroom flats. Homes built under permitted devel-  
opment rules will now have to meet the Ndss and ensure adequate  
light. Nevertheless other issues remain, namely\: poor location; lack  
of private space; poor soundproofing and poor ventilation.  
# 8 ESTATE REGENERATION  
# 8.1 General  
LAs have recently built little new housing, but they still own an  
enormous stock of existing estates built over the last 100 years.  
Many of these are now decrepit and out of date. Regeneration of  
these estates can take many forms depending on the location of the  
estate, its age, its degree of dilapidation and the extent of home  
ownership present. Often, it is feasible to retain buildings which are  
serviceable or have satisfied residents, and remove those that are  
beyond their useful life to make way for new build interventions.  
# 8.2 Challenges  
Many flat blocks built before the First World War are characterised  
by sub-standard small floor areas, outdated internal planning with  
inadequate kitchens and bathrooms, and unsatisfactory means of  
escape. The building services are probably obsolete, and central  
heating and thermal insulation absent. Some of these blocks, how-  
ever, possess considerable architectural character, and have stable  
and supportive communities of residents.  
Blocks built between the wars may also be lacking in modern  
services, heating and insulation but can be better planned internally  
and well-built structurally. Kitchens are still usually too small for  
modern requirements although otherwise floor areas increased.  
External planning was simple, but with more communal space than  
is now desirable. Blocks from this period represent a vast invest-  
ment in housing stock, with enormous potential for improvement  
into good-quality modern housing and, on larger estates, the trans-  
formation of whole neighbourhoods.  
Since the Second World War, social housing has suffered from  
too many well-intentioned attempts to rethink design and planning  
from scratch. Consequently, the last 50 years have seen widely dif-  
fering forms of housing, many of which have proved dramatically  
unsuccessful. High-rise blocks of flats are only the most prominent  
and publicised of mistakes. Some of the medium-rise \(five or six  
storey\) deck access estates have proved even less satisfactory.  
Dwellings in these large, usually inner city estates generally  
complied with the good internal standards of Parker Morris. The  
problem is the external estate design, that is often hated and feared  
by the residents, which fails to provide private and public open  
spaces appropriate for families with children.  
# 8.3 Consultation  
Estate modernisation presents many varied, peculiar and acute prob-  
lems. First, an investigation to establish what the problems really are  
has to be carried out. These are rarely simple, and may vary widely  
from estate to estate. The people who understand the problems best  
are the residents, and careful approaches and techniques under the  
general description of community engagement should be adopted to  
identify and address the tenants’ concerns. There are many aspects  
that need consideration including tenure integration; extent of home  
ownership; size of dwellings; open space and amenity; community  
facilities; energy provision; and inclusive design.  
# 8.4 Proposals  
After this consultation, designs and proposals can be worked up  
in close collaboration with the residents. The works needed to  
improve estates will be different in each case; but may include  
some or all of the following\:  
• Moving family units down to ground level, perhaps by combining  
flats on ground and/or first floors into larger flats or maisonettes,  
and subdividing large flats on upper floors into small ones.  
• Using unwanted external space to provide private gardens for the  
ground floor units, with separate direct access from the public  
highway or estate road.  
• Remodelling the flat interiors, giving larger dining/kitchens and  
better bathrooms.  
• High-rise blocks that cannot be split up or effectively use entry  
phones can be provided with *concierge* systems; using a combina-  
tion of electronic and human portering to provide 24-hour security.  
• Improving refuse arrangements, aiming to disperse rather than  
concentrate collection points. Consideration should be given to  
an underground refuse storage system where the local authority  
can facilitate collection.  
• Improving the fabric; adding thermal and sound insulation; add-  
ing pitched roofs on top of flat roofs; replacing windows with  
double glazing and controllable trickle ventilation.  
• Renewing the mechanical and electrical services; adding cen-  
tral heating; improving ventilation by putting extract fans into  
kitchens and bathrooms. Where there is district heating with a  
central boiler house and a history of problems, replacing with  
unit systems in each dwelling. Consider heat-retrieval systems.  
• Consider converting some blocks to integrated sheltered hous-  
ing. In these cases, entrances and gardens must be clearly  
distinguished and separated.  
• Communal external spaces to be reduced to either a minimum  
or abolished.  
• If all family flats and maisonettes have their own private gar-  
dens, there is an argument that communal children’s play space  
within the estate may be unnecessary. If not, it must be carefully  
sited as it may cause nuisance to neighbouring dwellings. Play  
space in local parks is preferable if they are nearby; or situated  
in clearly public spaces such as the squares that might feature in  
some large estates. A lack of security is often perceived; ideally,  
family accommodation without sufficient, private, open space  
should be avoided.  
• Estate roads, car parking and emergency vehicle access often  
need to be replanned. Parking within the curtilage may be pos-  
sible if the front gardens are deep enough; otherwise provide  
small parking bays in clear view of the dwellings they serve.  
Basement parking and car courts at the rear of blocks are best  
avoided because of the security risks they pose.  
• Replan pedestrian routes in order to eliminate unnecessary foot-  
paths and to maximise natural supervision from the dwellings  
of all routes.  
• Adding lifts if over three storeys high.  
• Consider enclosing open balconies and staircases, and splitting  
up long balcony access buildings into smaller more manageable  
blocks, preferably with no more than 10 or 12 flats in each.  
• Adding entry phones to privatise staircases.  
# 9 CASE STUDY – CHOBHAM MANOR,  
# STRATFORD, LONDON. PRP ARCHITECTS  
# LLP \(WITH MAKE\)  
# 9.1 Introduction  
Chobham Manor is located in the first of the Olympic legacy  
neighbourhoods with the Olympic velodrome as a backdrop. The  
aspiration for the masterplan was to create a medium density com-  
munity which takes the best aspects of traditional London living  
to form a model for future cohesive and inclusive communities.  
Three-quarters of the 850 new homes are for families, provided  
in a range of typologies that cater for different lifestyles includ-  
ing multi-generation homes. Alongside the new homes, Chobham Manor also provides new shops, community facilities and 1,500 m2  
of publicly accessible open space.  
# 9.2 Site  
The wider site comprises 64 hectares \(ha\) of the Queen Elizabeth  
Olympic Park in East London, Figure 22.30. Outline planning per-  
mission was granted in 2012 for a phased, mixed-use development.  
The scheme is a long-term regeneration project, which is being  
developed over a period of 20 years.  
**Houses and flats** **22-25**  
Chobham Manor comprises approximately 13.5 ha of land  
with a varied history including uses as a manor house and farm-  
land, railway sidings and industry and most recently, as the  
location for the Olympic basketball arena. The velodrome and  
velopark are to the north of the site, with parkland to the west.  
Temple Mill Lane forms part of the eastern boundary, beyond  
which is Chobham Academy school. To the south is the East  
Village \(the former Athletes’ Village\) and the wider Stratford  
City development.  
**22.30** *Site plan*  
# 9.3 Masterplan  
Structured around the principles of community interaction, the  
masterplan allows residents to identify with their locality, their  
green open spaces and the streets on which they live, instilling a  
strong sense of ownership and community empowerment.  
The form of the masterplan generates a strong design identity  
that blends the boundaries to connect with adjacent communities.  
It continues the street grid of the East Village and establishes a  
robust urban grain that mediates between the higher densities of  
East Village and Stratford, and the lower densities of Leyton and  
Hackney Wick. An emphasis on the spaces between buildings is  
one of the key principles of the masterplan, with each street and  
space designed to have a distinct yet complementary character,  
Figure 22.31. Three linear, linked greens thread through the cen-  
tre and are the location for play, social interaction for all ages  
and gardens. These create an informal east – west route between  
Leyton and the North Park and form a strong sense of landscape  
identity through the masterplan. The urban blocks create strong  
frontages overlooking the public realm and secure rear gardens  
and courts \(with some above podium parking\). Mews streets are  
incorporated within the middle of some blocks, providing diver-  
sity with shared surfaces that generate a quieter, more intimate  
environment. Movement and permeability through the site is  
shown in Figure 22.32.  
**22.31** *Masterplan. a\) An ‘Everyone lives by the green’ design philosophy is used to instil community interaction and ownership by the*  
*neighbourhood; b\) Tree-lined streets and green spaces connect to the wider Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park; c\) Non-residential uses*  
*and front doors promote activity at key nodes including the Velo Plaza; d\) Amenity space for residents are provided in a number of*  
*ways such as courtyards, podiums and private gardens* **22-26** **Houses and flats**  
**22.32** *Movement and Permeability. a\) The ‘Veloroute’ connects Chobham Manor with the Velodrome, East Village and Stratford City;*  
*b\) A clarity in the street hierarchy defines a legible masterplan for all users; c\) Informal and formal pedestrian and cycling routes*  
*connect to the wider context including the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park*  
# 9.4 Community engagement  
Significant public consultation took place with the local com-  
munity and stakeholders at every stage of the development. The  
first stage of public engagement comprised three consultation  
events in the local community, displaying outline proposals and  
seeking feedback on public open space. Attendees were given  
the opportunity to suggest ideas for the public open spaces  
within the site. These ideas were used to help devise the detailed  
proposals for the open spaces and play areas. There was a gen-  
eral appreciation of the ‘London Squares’ concept planned for  
Chobham Manor and of the approach to the management and  
maintenance of them.  
# 9.5 High sustainability standards  
Chobham Manor was designed to meet high standards of envi-  
ronmental performance with a focus on a ‘fabric first’ approach  
to the specification. This was established at a very early stage and  
regularly reviewed through the detailed design and construction  
stages. The aspiration for zero carbon was backed up by building  
performance modelling including a detailed review of the fab-  
ric specifications, and the modelling of thermal bridging. Close  
collaboration between the architects, consultants and an in-house  
team of sustainability and energy specialists facilitated an inte-  
grated and multidisciplinary approach to design development and  
delivery.  
# 9.6 Typologies  
Five principal housing typologies enable diversity and choice  
across the masterplan, comprising apartments, maisonettes, mul-  
ti-generational homes, mews and townhouses, Figure 22.33.  
Apartments are contained within the taller mansion blocks, pro-  
viding a transition in height from the adjoining site, while the corner  
blocks are four-storey apartment buildings, with some commercial  
use on the ground floor, Figures 22.34–22.36. The ‘Veloblock’,  
opposite the velodrome, has a retail space on the ground floor with a  
‘spill-out’ area in front of the building, complementing the facilities  
offered by the velodrome. Duplex apartments occupy the intermedi-  
ate floors and penthouses. All have a view of the velodrome and are  
dual aspect with multiple balconies and roof terraces. The ‘Multi-  
generation House’, is a typology created especially for Chobham  
Manor. It provides a flexible home for extended families who want  
to live together, while retaining a degree of mutual independence,  
Figure 22.21. The mews houses include an open-plan living/kitchen/  
dining area with access to a courtyard garden, three bedrooms, a  
large terrace on the first floor, and on-plot parking. The ‘House on the  
Green’ is a four-storey town house with its primary entrance on the  
green and a secondary entrance off the mews. It offers generous fam-  
ily accommodation with five bedrooms, on-plot parking, a sun deck  
and a roof terrace, Figure 22.18. The articulation of these houses  
takes cues from historical London precedents, providing inspiration  
for the contemporary façades fronting the greens. **Houses and flats** **22-27**

# 1 INTRODUCTION  
Meeting the needs of our ageing society requires a number of dif-  
ferent housing solutions. The age 65+ population is increasing and  
this will require appropriately designed housing that can adapt to  
changing needs. Most people prefer to remain in their own homes  
and if their health deteriorates receive home care. However, a pro-  
portion of the population actively seeks or requires specialist older  
people’s housing. Individuals may wish to downsize or move if  
their accommodation is inaccessible, or may require the security of  
staff, or the care offered in a care home.  
The continuum of care diagram \(Figure 23.1\) illustrates the  
variety of older people’s housing with general needs housing at the  
lowest level and care homes for those with dementia at the highest  
level. Differing housing typologies sit between these limits. A num-  
ber of names are given to similar typologies, so for the purposes  
of this chapter retirement housing \(similar to sheltered housing and  
independent living\) and extra care housing \(similar to assisted liv-  
ing, very sheltered and housing with care\) will be referenced.  
An increasing demand for specialist older people’s housing is  
a reflection of people living longer due to a better environment  
and healthcare. Retirement and extra care housing promotes a res-  
ident’s independence, increasingly a lifestyle choice, whilst care  
homes provide security and support to the most vulnerable in our  
society.  
# 2 RETIREMENT AND EXTRA CARE HOUSING  
# 2.1 Overview  
The main housing typologies for older people are retirement and  
extra care. Both offer independent flats, specifically designed for  
older people, which can be adapted to meet residents’ changing  
needs providing as far as possible a home for life. Buildings should  
deliver an enabling environment incorporating dementia friendly  
design principles. Technology plays an important role in maintain-  
ing the independence and security of residents.  
Retirement housing has limited communal facilities and may  
have concierge type support. Extra care housing has additional  
communal facilities and access to 24-hour care and support.  
Since extra care housing has an onsite housing management and  
care service, a minimum of 50 units is desirable in each scheme  
to ensure viability. Communal spaces provided in an extra care  
scheme are dependent on size, viability, proximity of neighbouring  
facilities and whether the development provides outreach services,  
intermediate \(recuperative\) care, community hub or coffee shop,  
hairdresser, and so forth open to the public.  
The planning use class varies between local authorities \(either  
C2 or C3\) and should be resolved early on. There is often confusion  
regarding car parking and access requirements. Typically, less car  
parking is required than for general needs, and provision is made  
for emergency vehicle access \(including ambulances\), a drop-off  
area and parking for a mini-bus. Planning applications often require  
a transport statement/travel plan.  
# 2.2 Standards  
The Building Regulations and the National Technical Standards  
do not define older people’s housing. Dwellings designed for  
older people are an enhancement of the requirements set out in  
the Building Regulations Approved Document M4 \(Cat2\). This  
enhancement allows adequate space for carers and any future adap-  
tions without the space and cost implications of full M4 \(Cat3\)  
wheelchair access. In addition, a number of dwellings for wheel-  
chair users are sometimes provided in each new development  
and meet the requirements set out in the Building Regulations  
Approved Document M4 \(Cat3\).  
Current aspirations are outlined in the HAPPI report by Homes  
and Communities Agency 2009 \(not prescriptive design standards\).  
In addition, wide ranging information can be found at the Housing  
LIN website and design guides listed in the bibliography at the end  
of this chapter.  
Retirement and extra care accommodation is outlined in Table I.  
# 2.3 Designing for impairments  
The accommodation should be ‘enabling’ in terms of the likely  
impairments \(physical, visual, audio and cognitive\) that residents  
may experience with increasing age and frailty. Recommendations  
include\:  
• All dwellings and communal areas should comply with acces-  
sibility standards set out in the Building Regulations Approved  
Document M4, which includes bathroom/WC layouts, heights of  
controls, taps/ironmongery, etc.  
• Level access throughout including out to terraces, balconies, etc.  
• Automatic opening doors in key locations.  
• Structure should be strong enough for ceiling mounted hoists.  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-26 **23-1** **23-2 Housing for older people**  
• ‘Free-swing’ door closers, linked to the fire alarm, should be  
fitted to doors regularly used by residents where closers are  
required. Fire compartment doors should be held open on mag-  
netic pads or hold open type door closers linked to the fire alarm.  
This will avoid the hazard and frustration associated with heavy  
overhead door closers.  
• Handrails to circulation routes should be returned to the wall to  
avoid snagging of clothing.  
• Internal ramps should be avoided.  
• Outward opening en-suite doors to facilitate rescue in the event  
of a fall.  
• Views out from dwellings and communal spaces from seated and  
standing positions.  
• For design solutions for the visually impaired, reference should  
be made to Building Sight by the Royal National Institute for  
the Blind.  
• There should be a light reflectance value contrast of at least 30  
points between the floor, walls, ceiling, fixtures and fittings.  
• Avoid glossy, shiny and highly patterned surfaces that can be  
confusing to those with visual impairment or dementia. Avoid  
changes in colour of floor finishes or contrasting threshold strips  
because they can appear as a step or barrier. Do not use dark or  
black flooring to lifts as this can appear as a void.  
• Consider enhanced acoustic separation \(TV high volume\).  
• Installation of an induction loop system to communal rooms and  
reception areas.  
• Incorporate dementia friendly design principles through-  
out. Guidance can be found in a series of publications by the  
Dementia Services Development Centre at the University of  
Stirling.  
• For a ‘visually accessible’ environment, provide views from cir-  
culation to the outside and into communal spaces. Provide views  
out and possibly a seating bay at the end of corridors.  
• Older people are potentially at a greater risk of falling. Therefore,  
tamper proof window restrictors may be required. In addition,  
it is recommended that balustrading to all communal external  
spaces used by residents with dementia should be a minimum of  
1800 mm high. Ensure that any communal balconies are suffi-  
ciently deep to avoid 1800 mm high balustrading becoming too  
oppressive.  
• Barrier type entrance matting rather than coir type.  
# 2.4 Building layout  
The building should have a logical layout that can be easily  
understood with clear views through including atria. ‘Progressive  
privacy’ describes the zoning of access allowed to residents, visi-  
tors and the general public. Circulation spaces should be more open  
and attractive than typical in general needs.  
Relationship diagram Figure 23.2 illustrates how spaces within  
these buildings are interrelated. For a good example of an extra  
care housing scheme, refer to Figure 23.3.  
# 2.5 Dwellings  
The orientation of dwellings is fundamental since all habitable  
rooms should enjoy a sunny aspect for part of the day. Halls, stores  
and en-suite wet rooms should be generous for accessibility and

space. This external space may be provided by patios or balconies.  
Inset balconies \(Figure 23.4\) are preferred since they offer privacy  
and shelter. Glazed winter gardens \(Figure 23.5\) are particularly  
appropriate for older people, sheltering the external space from  
wind, rain and noise.  
External deck access \(Figure 23.6\) is becoming more popular  
to allow dual aspect dwellings and contact with garden spaces.  
The deck must be slip resistant and sheltered from the elements.  
For dual aspect dwellings two directions of escape avoid fire con-  
straints \(Ref. BS9991\). If escape is in one direction only, windows  
facing onto the deck will need to be fixed shut and fitted with fire  
insulating glazing since older people cannot be expected to crawl  
beneath windows to escape.  
Within corridors or deck access, entrances to flats should be  
celebrated as the threshold of the resident’s private domain by  
recessing, the use of colour/texture, and provision for personalisa-  
tion e.g. display shelf.  
For typical dwelling plans refer to Figures 23.7 and 23.8.  
care home is commonly regarded as a cost-effective size. There  
are two differing typologies for care homes, the ‘hotel’ and the  
‘cluster’.  
The ‘hotel’ typology provides communal accommodation close  
to the main entrance with bedrooms arranged along corridors.  
There is a central staff office for the whole building. Staff are called  
on pagers to give care or support to residents in any of the build-  
ing’s bedrooms/care suites.  
The ‘cluster’ typology divides the building into units each with  
its own domestic scale communal facilities. Clusters vary in size  
from 15–20 bedrooms for care homes and care homes with nurs-  
ing and 8–10 bedrooms for dementia care. \(To achieve the Stirling  
dementia gold standard, no more than 10 bedrooms are allowed  
per cluster.\)  
The planning use class is C2 institutional. Residents have no  
tenancy agreement but pay a monthly cost for housing and care  
provision. The transport and parking needs of residents, staff and  
visitors must be properly met. Planning applications may require a  
transport statement/travel plan. The ‘cluster’ typology is covered  
here.  
# 3 CARE HOMES  
# 3.1 Overview  
Care homes provide 24-hour care for residents in bedroom  
accommodation with en-suite shower/WC facilities. A 60-bed  
# 3.2 Standards  
Care home design is required to meet the standards outlined in  
*Care homes for older people, national minimum standards, care*  
*homes regulations*, 3rd edition, 2006. The standards outline a  
number of requirements including that bedrooms must provide a  
minimum 12 m2 usable floor space excluding the en-suite area. This **23-4 Housing for older people**

Care home ‘cluster’ accommodation is outlined in Table II.  
# 3.3 Designing for impairments  
Refer also to Section 2.3 Designing for impairments. There are a  
few additional recommendations relevant to care homes\:  
• Bedrooms to have views out from a seated position in the bed.  
• Consider acoustic separation, since excluded from the Part B  
Building Regulations definition ‘rooms for residential purposes’.  
• Dementia care kitchen serveries should look into a room rather  
than towards a wall, i.e. open plan ‘L’ shaped with an island unit.  
• One-and-a-half door leaves to improve accessibility.  
• Flush jointing strips between floor finishes to aid walking frames.  
# 3.4 Building layout  
The building should be welcoming, light and airy. Spaces must be  
visually connected to promote ease of use. The reception desk must  
be visible on entering the care home. **Accommodation – for approximately 4–5 clusters \(60–70 bedrooms\)**  
Care home/care home with nursing, clusters 15 to 20 bedrooms with en-suite facilities.  
Dementia care clusters 8 to 10 bedrooms with en-suite facilities.

# 3.5 Bedrooms  
It is good practice to ensure two alternative locations can be  
provided for the bed in the bedroom. Wireless nursing staff com-  
munication systems allow the bedhead position to be easily moved.  
One location should allow staff to view the bed from the doorway,  
the alternative location can be positioned to provide greater pri-  
vacy. Ensure that the toilet can be made visible from one of the  
bed positions for residents who require this prompt. As a mini-  
mum, the bedroom furniture must include a bed, bedside table, two  
# Housing for older people 23-7  
comfortable seats, a table and clothes storage. \(Kitchenette provi-  
sion offered in care suites.\)  
For typical standard and specialised bedroom plans, refer to  
Figures 23.12 and 23.13.  
# 4 INTERIOR AND LANDSCAPE  
# 4.1 Interior design  
Well-designed interiors can dramatically influence the overall suc-  
cess of a development. Furniture, fixtures and equipment should  
have a domestic, non-institutional appearance with rounded edges  
and comply with Fire Safety Regulations. Within communal areas,  
there should be a choice of seating to suit residents’ mobility needs.  
Chairs should be fitted with arm rests. Sofas must have legs \(rather  
than solid construction below seat height\) to allow a seated occu-  
pant to position their feet slightly back before standing. Consider  
providing some chairs to suit bariatric residents. Appropriate fab-  
rics that are impervious, antibacterial and flame-retardant should  
be specified.  
Communal areas must be well lit with appropriate fittings and  
good controls. Provide directional or task lighting in offices and  
activity rooms. Kitchens should have pelmet lighting above the  
worktops. Locate plug sockets where extra directional light sources  
are required to avoid unnecessary flexes, which are a safety hazard.  
External lighting should enhance outside space particularly when  
viewed from resident accommodation and communal areas.  
Only provide internal signs where absolutely necessary.  
Symbols and lettering should be clear, visible \(in a relatively large  
font\) and contrast with the background. The choice of signs should  
be domestic and be considered as a key element of the interior  
design package.  
# 4.2 Landscape design  
Buildings should create and define external spaces with the best  
possible outlook. The landscaped, wheelchair accessible garden  
should be an extension of internal communal spaces. It is important  
that the garden is secure and safe. All schemes should include a  
sunny terrace with a shaded area adjacent to the building to allow  
residents to sit outdoors on warm days.  
Walking routes should be as level as possible making use of  
any features and views with adequate seats for resting. The gar-  
dens should surprise and delight through sound, smell and touch as  
well as the visual senses. Areas should be identified for bird feeders  
or nest boxes. Planting should be selected that encourages butter-  
flies and other insects to enhance the biodiversity of the garden.  
Consider the inclusion of a small ‘kitchen garden’ area or a few  
fruit trees so the garden can be productive.  
Consider incorporating raised planters as a means of bring-  
ing plants closer to residents and enabling them to participate  
in gardening from a wheelchair or a standing position. Provide  
external taps for garden watering purposes. Select trees and  
plants that provide year-round colour. Do not specify poisonous  
or thorny/spiky plants. Roof gardens, see Figure 23.14, may be  
appropriate to supplement a ground level garden, accessible by  
lift and ideally associated with other communal facilities \(e.g. an  
activity room\).  
# 5 FIRE  
# 5.1 Overview  
The level of fire precautions provided within older people’s housing  
should be determined following a client risk assessment \(own-  
er’s obligations under the Regulatory Reform \(Fire Safety\) Order  
2005\), of the needs of the residents, alongside complying with  
the requirements of the Building Regulations. This should ensure  
that the management regime \(led by the ‘Responsible Person’\) is  
accommodated by the building design, which may result in the **23-8 Housing for older people**

**23.10** *Relationship diagram of care home* **Housing for older people 23-9**  
**23.11** *Ground floor plan, care home, Streets Heath, West End, Surrey. Architect\: PRP*  
**23.12** *Typical standard bedroom plan* **23.13** *Typical specialised bedroom plan* **23-10 Housing for older people**  
**23.14** *Roof Terrace, James Terry Court, care home, Croydon*  
*Source\:* Architect\: PRP  
requirements of Part B being exceeded, including fire-engineered  
solutions \(e.g. sprinklers\).  
Liaison between client, fire consultant and the design team at  
early design stage on the risk assessments and safety strategy is  
essential.  
As this edition of *Metric Handbook* went to press, a review into  
Fire Safety Regulations in care homes and specialist buildings was  
underway. Carried out by PRP Architects, this includes an assess-  
ment of evaluation strategies and is likely to inform future policy  
decisions.  
# 5.2 Fire\: retirement and extra care housing  
Housing for older people is typically considered as flats \(AD Part  
B Vol. 1 purpose group 1\(a\) flat\) and therefore typically operates a  
stay put fire strategy.  
Fire precautions and means of escape for extra care flats may  
include the following additional design measures\:  
• Alarm system with both audible and visual signals to alert those  
who are hard of hearing or have visual impairment.  
• Mobility scooters must not be parked or charged in communal  
corridors. It is essential that mobility scooters are parked in des-  
ignated stores with a fire-resisting enclosure.  
• Stairs and corridors to provide refuge areas as future-proofing.  
• It is not realistic to expect frail older residents to use egress win-  
dows or crawl below 1100 mm.  
• The fire alarm system is to be linked to the warden call and staff  
handsets to allow swift reset.  
• Where older people are incapable of independent evacuation, a  
fire-protected area \(e.g. cross-corridor door\) should be accessible  
within 7.5 m to provide a short distance to a place of relative safety.  
• Alarms on final exits to alert staff that external doors are open.  
# 5.3 Fire\: care homes, care homes with nursing and  
# dementia care  
The accommodation consists of bedrooms \(AD Part B Vol. 2 pur-  
pose group 2\(a\) residential institutional\) and therefore typically  
operates a progressive horizontal escape strategy from bedrooms to  
sub-compartments with two alternatives per compartment.  
Fire precautions and means of escape for care homes may  
include the following additional design measures\:  
• Avoid dead ends. A fire-engineered smoke extract system may  
allow an increase to escape distances.  
• Maximum size of sub-compartment dependent on minimum  
time for staff to evacuate residents. Sprinklers will increase flex-  
ibility.  
• Stairs sufficiently sized to provide a refuge.  
• Evacuation lifts where the strategy requires.  
# 6 ASSISTIVE TECHNOLOGIES  
# 6.1 Assistive technologies\: dwellings  
An assistive technology Telecare hub is fitted in the resident’s  
main living room, which as a minimum is hard wired to the  
dwelling’s shower room emergency pull cord. If an alarm call is  
made, the system notifies onsite or offsite care staff. Additional  
devices can be added to the system \(connected by Wi-Fi\) to suit  
the requirements of the individual resident. Telecare devices can  
automatically and remotely monitor residents to manage the risks  
associated with living alone. Telecare safety devices include the  
following\:  
• Environmental sensors which can detect flooding/gas and  
changes in temperature.  
• Motion sensors that can monitor the lifestyle of a resident with  
bed occupancy, fall, door and movement detectors.  
• Tracking sensors which are sometimes used if people have  
dementia.  
In addition to Telecare, the introduction of Telehealth may be  
considered suitable for some residents. Telehealth can assist in the  
management of long-term health conditions by monitoring blood  
pressure, blood glucose levels or weight. Patients undertake the  
tests themselves in the home environment with the results auto-  
matically transmitted to a health professional for evaluation and  
appropriate action. **6.2 Assistive technologies\: care homes**  
Assistive technology wireless nurse communication system points  
are positioned in residents’ bedrooms and communal areas. If the  
system is pressed for attention, the system will contact staff, often  
by a site-wide paging system, who can then visit the location of the  
call. Wireless rolling displays can also inform staff of alarm calls  
rather than pagers. Telecare devices can be added to the system to  
tailor the technology to individual residents.  
# 7 ENVIRONMENT  
# 7.1 Sustainable design  
Older people’s housing should have high levels of insulation to  
ensure good thermal comfort for residents and reduce heating costs.  
Furthermore, these managed buildings provide opportunities for  
the use of renewable energy systems.  
Overheating can be a problem. Older people are at an increased  
risk of heat-related illness if their health is already compromised. A  
fabric-first approach to overheating should be adopted, by providing  
suitable thermal mass; dual aspect dwellings where possible; shad-  
ing; efficient light fittings/equipment; appropriate window sizes/  
secure night venting; and correct building orientation. However,  
a natural ventilation system may be insufficient to reduce temper-  
atures to an acceptable level for frail older people. Providing air  
conditioning to one of the communal spaces should be considered  
to provide a respite area for residents during a heat wave. Dynamic  
thermal 3D modelling should be used to test the design.  
Older people tend to spend long periods of time at home, which when  
combined with frail health may lead to higher risks from poor air quality.  
Air quality should be considered when selecting a site. Building design,  
including the location of windows, ventilation intakes and exhausts in  
relation to external sources of air pollution should be carefully planned.  
Materials used for the internal finishes should be selected to avoid sub-  
stances such as formaldehyde or other volatile organic compounds.  
Access to adequate levels of daylight and sunlight is of particu-  
lar importance to older people due to the prevalence of sight loss  
and the health benefits of sunlight. Windows to habitable rooms  
must be adequately sized and orientated. A daylight and sunlight  
assessment should be undertaken for cases where the site has been  
identified to be at risk of reduced access to daylight and sunlight.  
Older people often have significant hearing impairments. The  
ability to understand a normal conversation can be further reduced  
by high levels of background noise. Sites for older people’s accom-  
modation should be selected, where possible, away from major  
roads and other sources of high external noise. Internally, enhanced  
sound insulation should help reduce noise transmission and rever-  
beration between residents.  
# 7.2 Services  
Simplicity of all controls and operation is essential.  
Older people may have limited mobility and reduced heat  
sensitivity placing them at greater risk of injury from hot water  
or heating systems. Thermostatic blending valve controls must  
ensure that hot water is less than 44°C at outlets in accommodation  
accessed by this group. Towel rails should be specified with a low  
surface temperature of a maximum of 43°C.  
Under-floor heating should be specified to avoid dangers from  
hot surfaces and to provide unrestricted wall space. During the  
winter months, heating controls can be set to provide a minimum  
temperature within dwellings. This protects vulnerable people from  
cold weather. Cold weather is associated with an increase in deaths  
and in addition has significant impact on morbidity. Gas services  
within apartments are to be avoided.  
# 8 LIFETIME/CONTINUING CARE  
# NEIGHBOURHOODS  
There has been a shift in the provision of older people’s housing  
away from institutional settings to more independent typologies  
# Housing for older people 23-11  
and care in the home. This shift is motivated by aspirations and  
costs.  
The location of housing for older people is very important. Ideally,  
new developments should be sited in the heart of an existing commu-  
nity or act as a hub, with generous communal facilities, open to the  
surrounding neighbourhood. Older people value the social cohesion  
and intergenerational contact offered by the wider community.  
Promoting a united approach to housing, health and adult ser-  
vices for older people has become an important focus. Continuing  
care neighbourhoods, providing integrated services for older  
people, requires strategic planning by local authorities, health  
authorities and public/private developers.
