# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 Scope  
This chapter deals with the design of accommodation for students,  
but is also relevant to accommodation that is occupied for a lim-  
ited period by other groups of independent, single people, such as  
‘spring-board’ accommodation for young professionals. The term  
‘university’ is used to refer to Higher Education Establishments  
\(HEEs\), Further Education Establishments \(FEEs\), colleges and  
other similar institutions.  
Please note that plans used to illustrate this chapter are of built  
projects, and that there may have been changes to standards and  
legislation since they were completed. They are therefore illustra-  
tive only.  
At the time of updating in early 2021, it is anticipated that  
Covid-19 will have a lasting impact on the way in which students  
learn, potentially involving a greater degree of home study and/or  
remote learning. Brexit may also lead to changes in the university  
sector that influence the design and provision of student accom-  
modation.  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-27  
The chapter provides a sound starting point, but detailed  
requirements should be reviewed with the university client and/or  
private provider client.  
# 1.2 Importance  
In recent years, legislative and economic change has had a signifi-  
cant effect on students and the provision of student accommodation.  
Government policy has led to a considerable expansion in student  
numbers, while the impact of the sharp rise in student fees has  
resulted in students becoming increasingly discerning. Availability,  
variety and quality of accommodation are important factors when  
choosing a university. There is more competition between univer-  
sities to attract good students and so the universities – and also  
private commercial providers of accommodation – are increasingly  
concerned with the ‘student experience’ that they offer. As costs  
increase, the views of parents on standards of accommodation have  
also become more important. It is, however, important to note that  
due to an increase in both tuition fees and accommodation costs,  
affordability is increasingly gaining in importance.  
# 1.3 Ownership  
Student accommodation is owned and managed in a variety of ways,  
which can have significant implications for design. Universities  
provide communal rented accommodation on or off campus, which  
they own and/or manage. The recent growth in private sector com-  
mercial operators building and managing accommodation has  
continued to such an extent that the NUS/Unipol Accommodation  
Costs Survey 2018 notes that the split in ‘purpose built student  
accommodation’ between the private sector and educational insti-  
tutions in now 50\:50. Additional growth is predicted in the private  
sector in the future when compared to educational establishments.  
Large developments are more economic to build and run, so recent  
schemes often accommodate 400 to 1000 students or more. Private  
developments are often pre-let to a university and may be designed  
and managed in liaison with the university. Meanwhile, a large  
proportion of students still live in individual shared houses or flats  
within the community, while many others live at home.  
# 1.4 Rents  
The government does not fund student accommodation and  
schemes are normally self-funding through the rental income that  
is charged for the rooms. Project budgets are therefore determined  
by the level of rents that students can afford or are willing to pay,  
and this is directly reflected in the size of the study bedrooms and  
extent of other facilities provided in the scheme.  
Where accommodation is provided by a university, there is a  
concern to keep rents to affordable levels, although their offer usu-  
ally includes some choice of accommodation at different rents. The  
private market also offers a range of room types and rents, and there  
has been a marked increase in ‘luxury’ accommodation, targeted at  
those who can afford high rents, including a high proportion of  
international students. To illustrate the wide range of rents, the  
NUS/Unipol Accommodation Costs Survey 2018 reported a lowest  
rent of £65 per week \(40 week let\) for a room in an institutional  
**24-1** **24-2 Housing for students and young people**  
cluster \(Manchester\) and a highest cost of £535 per week \(51 week  
let\) for a private studio in Bloomsbury, London. With annual rents  
continuing to outstrip inflation, achieving affordability is a key  
challenge in the sector if stated aims of inclusivity, opportunity and  
diversity are to be achieved.  
# 1.5 Student experience  
Issues relating to social sustainability and the ‘student experience’  
have become increasingly critical, and are particularly challeng-  
ing in the design of larger, potentially impersonal, schemes,  
particularly where these are off campus. Where accommodation  
is designed for a university, there will generally be a concern to  
make the students feel part of the university community. \(This  
might be achieved through the design of the building, for exam-  
ple, by arranging buildings around a courtyard to provide a shared  
focus for the residents, or by placing social spaces such as com-  
mon rooms and kitchen/dining rooms on busy circulation routes  
to encourage interaction.\) Universities generally also have systems  
of pastoral care with wardens or senior students living among the  
students. With a private commercial provider, there is likely to be a  
different emphasis to the student experience as the provider has to  
attract the students and, in many instances, justify higher charges  
by providing extra facilities such as a gym or café and promoting a  
particular ‘lifestyle’ and branding through the design of the build-  
ing. The styling of these schemes often has the more commercial  
character of a modern hotel, rather than that of a university.  
The student experience has recently been brought into sharp  
focus with the Covid-19 pandemic, both in terms of the relative  
value of tuition fees and for the metal health and well-being of stu-  
dents. It is anticipated that the effects of the pandemic will influence  
the design brief of student housing, with the potential requirement  
for less dense developments, a more varied set of communal spaces  
for studying, socialising and relaxation, easy access to communal  
external space and provision for remote learning.  
# 1.6 Context  
Consideration should be given to the relationship of the accom-  
modation to the local community, particularly where it is located  
in a town rather than on campus. The design of the building and  
landscape can help to integrate the university and its students  
within the community, and it can also help to avoid potential con-  
flict. Students can cause nuisance to neighbours, particularly where  
there are large areas of student accommodation within one neigh-  
bourhood \(known as ‘studentification’\). Conversely, there can be  
risks to the students for personal safety and theft of property.  
# 1.7 Sustainability and climate emergency  
Sustainability is an important issue for universities as well as for  
many individual students. Following the UK government’s decla-  
ration of a climate emergency in May 2019, the NUS has created  
the charity Students Oganising for Sustainability – UK \(SOS-UK\).  
In parallel, the Climate Commission for UK Higher and Further  
Education has been established with the primary aim of drastically  
increasing the contribution of universities and colleges in the fight  
against climate change. By creating a Climate Framework, their  
aim is to guide and support all universities to be net zero carbon by  
2050 at the latest.  
Consideration should be given in the design of residences to all  
aspects of sustainability including reducing energy consumption,  
carbon emissions and the inclusion of renewable energy sources.  
Technologies and system efficiencies are constantly evolving. For  
example, the use of CHP \(Combined heat and power\) was well  
suited to this building type, but with the decarbonisation of the  
electricity grid it is now possible to use heat pumps \(air or ground  
source\) instead of CHP to further reduce carbon emissions and  
omit gas systems.  
Other issues include reducing water consumption, rainwater  
harvesting, the use of LED lighting and intelligent controls, waste  
and recycling facilities in both construction and use, sustainable  
urban drainage and sustainable transportation. Pre-fabrication,  
which is widely used for ensuite bathrooms in student accommo-  
dation, can also be used for the fabrication of structural frames and  
elevation panels, reducing waste while improving quality. Modular  
construction, where full rooms can be fitted-out in factory condi-  
tions and delivered to site, would also appear to be well matched  
to student housing.  
Provision for future flexibility should be incorporated into the  
design where possible, as requirements and aspirations change –  
examples in recent years include the impact of advances in computer  
technologies, the preference for ensuite bathrooms and improved  
standards for access for disabled people. Ultimately, there may even  
be a need to adapt accommodation to new uses if the demand for  
student residences reduces.  
# 1.8 Timing  
Projects will generally be programmed to complete construction in  
summer in time for occupation in a new academic year.  
# 2 STUDENTS  
# 2.1 Tenant range  
Conventionally, students are perceived as young, single, mobile,  
adaptable and with little money to spend. This is still true of many  
students – in particular an increasing number of students are strug-  
gling to afford the rents charged for accommodation. However,  
there is also a need to cater for a broader range of cultural and eco-  
nomic backgrounds, and for students with different needs\: disabled  
students, mature and married students, and those with families.  
There is also an increasing demand for single sex, quiet and alco-  
hol-free residences. Postgraduate students are older and require  
a quieter and more ‘adult’ living environment. Many universities  
have a significant number of students from overseas, including  
‘international students’ from outside the EU who pay higher fees  
and make a significant contribution to university income. Some  
students study part time, while many have to manage part-time jobs  
to support themselves through university. There is an increasing  
demand for convenience and flexibility in the way that services,  
including accommodation, are provided to them.  
# 2.2 Availability  
Universities rarely have accommodation for all of their students,  
and priority is usually given to first year students who need support  
to settle into the university community. Other groups, such as final  
year students sitting exams, and students from overseas, may also  
be offered priority. Some accommodation is rented only during  
term time, and is used for conference and holiday lets out of term,  
while other accommodation, including accommodation by private  
providers, is rented for the whole academic year. Average contract  
lets are 40 weeks for educational establishments and 46 weeks for  
private providers.  
# 2.3 Characteristics  
The characteristics which differentiate student accommodation  
from other housing and from hotel accommodation, and which  
should be addressed in design, are\:  
• An appropriate environment in which to study as well as to live,  
socialise and sleep, and a building in use 24 hours a day.  
• Creating a university community, with opportunities to form  
friendships and for informal academic and social interaction.  
• Privacy where people are living in close proximity and are shar-  
ing facilities – many students will not have the opportunity to  
choose their neighbours.  
• Design, including the selection of materials and fittings, must  
be appropriately robust for student use and easy to maintain –  
whole life costing is an important consideration. • Avoiding an unpleasant institutional character, which can eas-  
ily arise where large numbers of identical study bedrooms are  
arranged to maximise efficiency.  
• For many people student accommodation will be their first  
experience of living away from home. Well-designed student  
accommodation has the potential to broaden awareness of archi-  
tectural design and issues of sustainability.  
# 2.4 Priorities  
Student experience polls have revealed students’ priorities for  
accommodation\:  
• Availability of internet access in the study bedroom  
• Availability of cooking facilities  
• Security  
• Journey time and closeness to the university  
• Cost  
• Local amenities and communal facilities  
• Number of students in each flat  
• Provision of ensuite bathroom  
• ANUK accreditation \(see Section 5.2\)  
• On site amenities  
• Catering provided  
• Car parking  
• Room size  
• Noise  
• Clean facilities.  
# 3 TYPES OF ACCOMMODATION  
# 3.1 Brief  
When establishing the brief for accommodation, key items for dis-  
cussion are\:  
• The ‘style’ of the accommodation\: staircase, house, hall or flat  
• Number and mix of room types\: single, shared and studio  
• Number of students sharing each kitchen  
• Provision of ensuite bathrooms or shared bathrooms  
• Provision of other facilities\: common room, reception, gym,  
laundry etc.  
• Accessibility requirements \(university/ building regulations/  
local plan\)  
• Whether the facilities will be used for conferences or holiday  
letting out of term time  
• Client standards and requirements for specific products, e.g. a  
particular ensuite bathroom pod.  
# 3.2 Style of accommodation  
The vast majority of student accommodation is based on provision  
of an individual study bedroom for each student, although uni-  
versities and private providers are offering an increasing range of  
choice to suit different requirements and budgets, including study  
bedrooms shared by two students \(for lower rents\), ‘studio’ rooms  
with an en suite bathroom and a kitchen area, or larger studio flats  
for one person or a couple. There has been a significant growth  
in the number of studio rooms, generally in private developments,  
although supply of these now appears to be outstripping demand.  
There is a concern that the nature of self-containment provided in  
this room type can lead to a sense of isolation. Care must be taken  
to ensure that other means of social interaction are provided in  
order to encourage a sense of community \(see 3.3\). Studio rooms  
or flats are particularly suited to postgraduates and mature stu-  
dents who are more independent and are also appropriate for other  
young, single people outside the world of education – for example,  
young professionals or key workers. A proportion of rooms should  
be designed for wheelchair users, with numbers agreed with the  
local authority.  
# Housing for students and young people 24-3  
In schemes with individual study bedrooms, the style of the  
accommodation is largely determined by the way that study bed-  
rooms are grouped together to form a social unit, and the way that  
shared facilities \(kitchens, common rooms, etc.\) are provided. A  
university may instil a sense of responsibility and independence by  
placing small groups of students in separate shared flats, or it may  
exercise a greater degree of supervision and pastoral care through a  
communal hall arrangement, where typically several hundred stu-  
dents are accommodated in rooms off shared corridors.  
# 3.3 Number of students in each unit  
Forming good relationships is crucial to support students who are  
new to university and to reduce drop-out rates. The use of comput-  
ers and technology can result in students spending too much time  
alone in their rooms and becoming isolated, so student accommo-  
dation needs to be designed to encourage interaction. It is generally  
agreed that students form friendships more easily and are more  
likely to behave responsibly – reducing management and mainte-  
nance problems – if they are in smaller groups\: typically, five to ten  
students sharing a self-contained flat or house. However, in small  
groups, students who have not chosen to live together may not get  
on. Larger groups can provide a greater choice of friends, particu-  
larly when combined with a greater level of pastoral support from  
university staff\: in a traditional ‘hall’, the social unit is the whole  
hall, creating a stronger sense of engagement with the university  
itself.  
# 3.4 Shared facilities in each unit  
*Kitchens*  
Traditionally, central catering facilities were provided in larger  
halls of residence, with minimal facilities for cooking close to the  
study bedrooms. The intention was to encourage students to engage  
with the wider university community, and many universities still  
offer accommodation with central catering included as part of  
the rent. However, for reasons of economy, culture and conveni-  
ence, most students prefer the freedom of catering for themselves  
or of eating out. As a consequence, in most new accommodation  
– whether in the form of halls, flats or houses – kitchen-dining  
rooms are provided for self-catering, each serving a group of study  
bedrooms and effectively defining the social groups. The kitch-  
en-dining room may incorporate a ‘living room’ area with soft  
seating, and may also be used for informal study. As noted earlier,  
some schemes include studio rooms, where each student has their  
own kitchen facilities. In this situation, the provision of common  
facilities shared by all the residents is important to build a sense of  
community.  
*Bathrooms*  
The majority of new study bedrooms are now provided with ensuite  
bathrooms, usually as prefabricated pods, and where it is intended  
that the rooms will be used for conference accommodation out  
of term time, ensuite bathrooms are generally essential. In some  
schemes, a single ensuite bathroom is shared by two study bed-  
rooms. Schemes with ensuite bathrooms are not necessarily more  
expensive than those with shared bathrooms, particularly when  
washbasins are also provided in all of the study bedrooms as well.  
Costs will depend on the detailed arrangement of the plan and over-  
all floor areas as well as the number of sanitary fittings.  
*Other shared facilities*  
Common rooms, laundries, reception, shared study area or seminar  
rooms, staff/wardens’ flats, etc. will be provided where the student  
numbers are large enough to support them, where there is a demand  
associated with teaching or conference uses or, especially in the  
case of commercial providers, where the facilities are intended to  
attract a particular market. Facilities in commercial schemes can be  
extensive\: for example, a games room, gym, cinema or café. **24-4 Housing for students and young people**  
# 4 BUILDING FORM  
# 4.1 Study bedrooms  
Study bedrooms form the basic building block of student accom-  
modation and can be arranged in a number of ways. In each case,  
the study bedrooms may have ensuite bathrooms or there may be  
shared bathrooms.  
# 4.2 Staircase model  
In the traditional ‘Oxbridge’ model, buildings arranged around a  
quadrangle are divided into ‘staircases’ with a small number of  
study bedrooms at each level served by a single stair \(Figure 24.1\).  
A small kitchen may be provided on each floor or on one level,  
and is shared by the rooms on the staircase. A loose social group is  
defined by the staircase, but there is also a strong association with  
the wider college or university.  
However, it is difficult to incorporate lift access economically,  
as separate lifts are required for each staircase. An arrangement  
where lifts are not provided and wheelchair access is restricted to  
the ground floor level may not be acceptable to the university and  
may not be appropriate where conference use is proposed.  
# 4.3 House style  
This replicates the popular model of a traditional private house  
shared by students \(Figure 24.2\). It is similar to the staircase model  
with a limited number of study bedrooms on several levels served  
by a single stair, and a shared kitchen/dining room at ground level.  
**24.1** *Generic type\: Student residence with a traditional college*  
*staircase arrangement, Jowett Walk, Balliol College, Oxford.*  
*Architects\: MJP Architects. 1\) study bedroom; 2\) en suite*  
*bathroom; 3\) kitchen; 4\) dining*  
**24.2** *Generic type\: Terraced house plus self-contained flats. Constable Terrace, University of East Anglia. Architects\: Rick Mather*  
*Architects. 1\) study bedroom; 2\) kitchen; 3\) living/dining; 4\) services/storage/cleaners; 5\) shower/WC. a\) Ground floor plan, b\) First*  
*floor plan, c\) isometric sectional view* Accessible rooms are also provided at ground floor level, but full  
accessibility is limited. The house has its own front door so that  
the social group is well defined and there is a greater sense of  
independence. However, the problems of incorporating lifts and  
providing access for disabled students or visitors to upper floors  
are the same as for the staircase model.  
# 4.4 Hall or corridor  
Rooms are arranged off a corridor \(Figures 24.3–24.5\). Corridor  
schemes allow for large numbers of rooms to be served economi-  
cally by lifts, providing disabled access as well as easy access for  
conference guests, cleaning staff and students with luggage. The  
hall itself forms a single large social group, but smaller units are  
less easy to form. The corridors may be divided along their length  
to form groups of rooms with a shared kitchen, but this cannot pro-  
vide the domestic character and scale of a shared flat or college  
staircase. In some schemes, corridors are doubled up to form sep-  
arate flats. Schemes which consist of studio rooms or studio flats  
are usually also arranged on corridors. Corridor access schemes  
tend to have a higher proportion of circulation area than staircase  
schemes. It is difficult to bring natural light and ventilation into  
double-loaded corridors, and their design requires careful handling  
to avoid monotony and a dull institutional character. They also pro-  
vide the unwelcome opportunity for a few un-neighbourly residents  
to disrupt all the others.  
# 4.5 Flats  
Rooms are grouped into self-contained flats with a number of  
study bedrooms \(typically five to eight\) and shared kitchen/din-  
ing room \(Figures 24.6 and 24.7\). This ‘cluster-flat’ arrangement  
is very common and defines a self-contained social group with its  
own front door. Lift access can be arranged economically to serve  
groups of flats.  
# 4.6 General design factors  
*Depth of plan*  
Student study bedrooms are usually small – typically 13 m2 for a  
room with ensuite bathroom – and the space is more useable if the  
room is rectangular. Placing the ensuite bathroom at the back of the  
room in the centre of the building produces a deeper building plan,  
particularly with a double-loaded corridor, and reduces the length  
# Housing for students and young people 24-5  
of corridor. It is therefore generally the most cost-effective layout.  
Providing bathrooms as shared facilities \(as opposed to ensuite\)  
will impact on corridor length and escape distances.  
*Escape distances*  
The escape distance from the farthest study bedroom to the escape  
stair is a key factor in the arrangement of the plan. Arranging  
narrow study bedrooms in a row allows the number of rooms  
served by each escape stair to be maximised. However, the width  
of the rooms must also be considered in relation to the use of  
space within the room. Escape distances are set out in Approved  
Document B of the UK Building Regulations and will vary  
dependent on the nature of the design and the number of available  
staircases.  
*Lifts*  
The requirement for inclusion and for access for wheelchair users to  
different parts of the building is discussed in Section 5.7. Provision  
of lift access to all floors and all study bedrooms will have impli-  
cations for the arrangement of the plan, as it is normal to aim to  
limit the number of lifts in a scheme to reduce cost. Fire-fighting  
lifts will be required above a certain height, in line with Approved  
Document B of the UK Building Regulations, and it is anticipated  
that evacuation lifts, to provide dignified emergency egress, will  
become more commonplace.  
*Modern Methods of Construction \(MMC\) and*  
*pre-fabrication*  
Study bedrooms are repetitive units and, where large numbers are  
involved, they lend themselves to MMC such as prefabricated  
structural elements, tunnel form or off-site modular and volumet-  
ric construction, although care is required to ensure that this does  
not produce a dull, institutional character in the internal layout or  
elevations of the building. Pre-fabrication is commonly used for  
ensuite bathroom pods and can be used for whole rooms. The sys-  
tem speeds up construction, reduces waste and allows complicated  
elements to be constructed to a high standard in factory conditions.  
However, there is usually a capital cost premium to be balanced  
against any savings from the reduced construction programme.  
Acoustic and fire separation between rooms needs to be carefully  
considered where modular elements are used as they are often

lightweight construction. The decision to use modular construction  
needs to be taken at an early stage in the design process as there are  
implications for dimensions \(both plan and section\) and interfaces  
with surrounding elements and for the procurement route.  
*Maintenance and management*  
The university or private provider will have arrangements for  
maintenance and management of the accommodation and possibly  
preferences for specification that will impact on the design. These  
need to be accommodated while still achieving an attractive and  
welcoming design for the residents.  
# 5 STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS  
This section gives guidance on key areas of legislation, but is  
not intended to be comprehensive. The standards and legislation  
referred to are current at January 2021. Designers should check that  
these have not been superseded.  
Designs should comply with all statutory requirements contained  
within Housing, Building, Planning, Disability Discrimination Act  
\(N. Ireland only\) Equality and other relevant legislation and standards.  
# 5.1 Town and Country Planning Act 1990 and  
# amendments\: planning permission  
Student accommodation falls into different use classes under the  
Town and Country Planning Act 1990 \(as amended\). This depends  
on size and whether \(and also how\) it is provided by a university/  
college or by a private provider. Under the Use Class Order 1987  
\(as amended\), student accommodation mainly falls within Use  
Class C2 \(Residential Institutions\), Use Class C4 \(small houses in  
multiple occupation \(HMOs\) of three to six residents\) or sui gen-  
eris \(‘of their own kind’\). Student accommodation may also fall  
within Use Class C3 if the dwelling is occupied by a single person  
or people who form a single household.  
*Developments by Higher Education Establishments*  
Student accommodation for residential universities and colleges  
will generally fall into Use Class C2. However, accommodation  
that is remote from the campus may be classed as sui generis, or  
Class C4 or Class C3, as for accommodation by private providers –  
see next subsection.  
*Developments by private providers*  
HMOS\: LARGER PROPERTIES \(OVER SIX OCCUPANTS\)  
Larger HMOs with more than six tenants and large purpose-built  
accommodation units are unclassified by the Use Classes Order and  
are described as sui generis. Discussion with the planning authority  
will be required to clarify their requirements.  
HMOS\: SMALL PROPERTIES S \(THREE TO SIX OCCUPANTS\)  
Use Class C4 HMOs covers small shared houses or flats occupied  
by three to six tenants who are not related to each other and who  
share one or more basic amenities \(such as a kitchen or bathroom\).  
STUDENT ACCOMMODATION FALLING WITHIN USE CLASS C3  
\(DWELLING HOUSES\)  
Student accommodation may fall within Use Class C3 if the  
dwelling/flat is occupied by one person or people who form a sin-  
gle household, e.g. a couple or family. This is most likely to be a  
self-contained one- or two-bedroom flat or studio apartment.  
Amendments to the Town and Country Planning \(General  
Permitted Development\) \(England\) Order 2015, updated permitted  
development rights between certain use classes. Unless an Article  
4 Direction is in force, a change of use from Use Class C4 \(small  
HMO\) to a single house \(Use Class C3\) is covered by permitted  
development rights. This also applies in reverse where change of  
use from Use Class C3 to Use Class C4 can be carried out through  
permitted development. Where permitted development rights  
apply there is no need to apply for express planning permission for  
change of use although if any external building works are involved,  
or if buildings are amalgamated or sub-divided, planning permis-  
sion will be needed. Some local authorities have made Article 4  
Directions to remove these rights either in parts or all of their areas  
to prevent a high concentration of student rented houses in one  
area, a situation known as ‘studentification’, which can cause prob-  
lems for the local community.  
# 5.2 The Housing Act 2004  
*Part 1\: housing conditions*  
Part 1 of the Housing Act relates to housing conditions and applies  
to every type of accommodation. It provides a system for assess-  
ing conditions – the Housing Health and Safety Rating System, **24-8 Housing for students and young people**  
HHSRS – and gives local authorities powers to tackle poor housing  
based on the severity of the health and safety hazards.  
*Part 2\: licensing of Houses in Multiple Occupation \(HMOs\)*  
ACCOMMODATION MANAGED OR CONTROLLED BY PRIVATE  
SECTOR PROVIDERS  
Statutory controls on HMOs under the Housing Act can be con-  
fusing. The term HMO applies to a wide range of housing types,  
mainly in the private rented sector where standards have histor-  
ically been low. In essence, the Housing Act defines HMOs as  
accommodation occupied by more than one household and where  
households share one or more basic amenity \(such as a kitchen\).  
Part 2 of the Housing Act regulates HMOs by providing for  
them to be licensed by the local authorities. Licensing is mandatory  
for larger HMOs \(this includes those that are three storeys or more,  
five or more people of two or more households\) but can also be  
extended to smaller HMOs by the local authority.  
ANUK/Unipol’s *Code of Standards for Larger Residential*  
*Developments\: For Student Accommodation Not Managed and*  
*Controlled by Educational Establishments, \(2006, updated 2020\)*  
gives guidance for private sector providers of student accommo-  
dation and their tenants on similar lines to the codes that apply to  
HEEs described later.  
ACCOMMODATION MANAGED OR CONTROLLED BY HEES  
Student accommodation for people attending full-time courses that  
are managed or controlled by an educational establishment can be  
‘excepted’ from the definition of an HMO and from the licensing  
requirements of the Housing Act \(except for Part 1, which still  
applies\), provided the accommodation is designed and managed in  
accordance with an approved code of practice. The following codes  
were current at the time of writing in 2021\:  
• *The Universities UK/Guild HE Code of Practice for the*  
*Management of Student Housing*, 2019  
• *ANUK/Unipol’s Code of Standards for Larger Residential*  
*Developments for Student Accommodation Managed and*  
*Controlled by Educational Establishments*, 2019.  
The codes deal with a range of physical standards and manage-  
ment practices and also address student welfare and the fair and  
reasonable treatment of student tenants, reflecting the special char-  
acteristics of student accommodation which encompasses more  
than the basic provision of facilities. The codes are designed as  
‘statements of good practice’ and provide general guidance for the  
design of accommodation rather than detailed specifications, as the  
provision will vary between different projects and different loca-  
tions.  
The codes are also appropriate for accommodation for other  
non-HEE students and young people, but additional legislation  
may apply, for example if accommodation is provided for students  
under 18 years of age in FE establishments.  
# 5.3 Local authority requirements for HMOs  
Different local authorities develop their own codes of practice for  
HMOs, which are generally more specific than the aforementioned  
codes. The requirements may vary for different types of student  
accommodation – bedsits, studios, shared flats, etc. – and there may  
be variation in the way they are applied, for example, where there  
are requirements from other legislation, such as for listed build-  
ings. The local authority’s environmental department should be  
consulted at an early stage in the design. Typical requirements are  
as follows\:  
*Space standards*  
• Minimum room areas for study bedrooms, for single and shared  
occupancy  
• Minimum room areas for kitchens, kitchen/dining rooms and  
living rooms  
• Minimum areas for external communal space.  
*HHSRS rating system \(see aforementioned\)*  
• Design requirements to avoid hazards – damp, cold, security,  
lighting, sanitation, water, falls, electricity, heating and cooking.  
*Personal washing facilities*  
• Ratio of baths/showers to number of occupants – typically a  
minimum of one bath or shower for five people  
• Washbasins to be provided with all toilets  
• Washbasins may be required within bedrooms in larger HMOs  
• Maximum distance of shared bathrooms from bedrooms – typically  
no more than one floor away  
• Design and layout of bathrooms, minimum dimensions of appli-  
ances, finishes, heating, lighting and ventilation.  
\(Note\: The trend for ensuite facilities effectively means that  
actual requirement is now well in excess of the minimum standard  
set out earlier.\)  
*Toilet facilities*  
• Ratio of toilets to number of occupants – typically a minimum of  
one toilet for five people  
• Provided in a separate room to the bathroom if serving more than  
four people  
• Maximum distance of shared toilets from bedrooms – typically  
no more than one floor away  
• Design and layout, finishes, heating, lighting and ventilation.  
\(Note\: The trend for ensuite facilities effectively means that  
actual requirement is now well in excess of the minimum standard  
set out earlier.\)  
*Facilities for storage, preparation and cooking of food*  
• Maximum distance of kitchen from bedrooms – typically no  
more than one floor away, but can be further in smaller buildings  
such as ‘house’ style accommodation  
• Provision of dining rooms and furniture  
• Design and layout of kitchens to allow safe use by several people  
at the same time. Finishes and minimum dimensions of appli-  
ances, heating, lighting and ventilation  
• Ratio of kitchen facilities to number of occupants – typically one  
set of facilities for five people comprising a sink and drainer, a  
food cupboard \(500 mm wide base unit or 1000 mm wide wall  
unit\), a fridge \(130 litres\), freezer space \(60 litres\), worktop  
\(1000 mm min.\), three double power sockets in addition to those  
required for the appliances, a cooker with four burners, oven and  
grill. Additional facilities should be included where the kitchen  
is shared by larger numbers of people.  
\(Note\: Increasingly, educational and private providers are  
requesting a single fridge/freezer shelf per person, as opposed to  
the 130/60 litre appliances described earlier.\)  
*Fire safety and means of escape*  
• Requirement for fire doors, fire separation, lobbies, emergency  
lighting, fire-fighting equipment and automatic fire detection  
systems  
• Internal layout of shared flats – escape from bedrooms must not  
be through a higher risk area such as a kitchen.  
*Management\: The Management of Houses in Multiple*  
*Occupation \(England\) Regulations 2006*  
These regulations set out the responsibilities of both managers  
and occupiers. They include requirements for cleaning, mainte-  
nance and repairs, and provision of water supply, drainage, gas and electric supplies, means of escape, ventilation, recycling and waste  
management as well as safety protection to roofs, balconies and  
windows.  
# 5.4 Fire safety  
Each local authority has requirements prior to issuing a licence  
for use of a building as an HMO. All must comply with *The*  
*Management of Houses in Multiple Occupations \(England\)*  
*Regulations 2006*. As for other building types, the responsibility  
for safety lies with the ‘responsible person’, who is required to pre-  
pare a fire risk assessment under the Fire Safety Order.  
New-build HMOs should be designed in accordance with  
the UK Building Regulations. *Fire Safety\: Approved Document*  
*B* provides guidance on the design of escape routes, with rec-  
ommendations for the planning and protection of escape routes  
and separation between areas of higher fire load. It also sets out  
provisions for splitting larger buildings into smaller fire rated  
compartments. External fire spread from the building of fire ori-  
gin to adjacent premises is addressed in the Approved Document  
B and provisions are made for the fire service to access the build-  
ing externally and internally. Note that access for fire engines to  
different parts of the building can have significant implications  
for the site plan and form of the building, particularly on con-  
stricted sites. A key introduction in the revised 2020 Approved  
Document Part B is that sprinklers are now required in all new  
residential buildings with a top habitable floor above 11 m. This  
is likely to include a very large proportion of new student res-  
idential developments. Following the Grenfell disaster, added  
focus has been placed on the design and specification of external  
wall systems and their combustibility, which should be carefully  
considered.  
An alternative approach to following the Approved Document  
B is to adopt a fire engineered solution, designed by a technically  
proficient fire consultant, where the fire safety for the building is  
tailored to the risk involved and the layout to achieve an equal level  
of life safety protection. Longer travel distances may be acceptable  
if a higher level of detection and warning systems are provided.  
Means of escape in case of fire is also covered by the Housing  
Act and by the approved codes of practice that apply to educa-  
tional establishments \(as discussed earlier\). Sprinklers will still be  
required in line with Approved Document B.  
False fire alarms can be a problem in student residences both  
for the fire services and for residents, particularly where full evac-  
uation is required. In some areas, the fire services will only answer  
an alarm call if the existence of the fire is confirmed. Fire systems  
should be designed to minimise accidental false alarms insofar as  
this is possible. The location of extinguishers, detectors and call  
points, the design of fire doors and glazing should be considered  
carefully to reduce the risk of misuse, for example, extinguishers  
let off, fire doors wedged open and to avoid an institutional feel.  
See also Chapter 11, Fire Safety.  
# 5.5 Noise  
*The Building Regulations, Resistance to Sound\: Approved*  
*Document E* applies to ‘Rooms for Residential Purposes’, and  
includes requirements for different parts of the construction. Since  
noise is a major source of annoyance in student residences, some  
universities may require standards above Part E. The use of adja-  
cent study bedrooms rooms for leisure, study and sleep contains  
inherent conflict and students do not keep regular hours. Consider  
noise from both inside and outside the building\: from kitchens  
and circulation areas, badly adjusted door closers, lifts, service  
ducts, etc. In planning the accommodation, it is important to sepa-  
rate potentially noisy areas, such as common rooms, from student  
bedrooms and to insulate each individual study bedroom to a high  
standard. In some more demanding environments, ambient external  
noise levels may dictate ventilation strategies, so an acoustic strat-  
egy should be reviewed early.  
# Housing for students and young people 24-9  
# 5.6 Ventilation  
*The Building Regulations, Ventilation\: Approved Document F*  
applies to student accommodation.  
Student accommodation is predominantly naturally ventilated,  
except where external conditions make this inappropriate – for  
example because of noise or air pollution – and this allows students  
to exercise some control over their environment by opening their  
windows. This is particularly important in study bedrooms, which  
are usually small and may feel claustrophobic when temperatures  
rise. An open window also allows the student to hear activity in  
the wider campus, or city, providing a sense of connection. Where  
mechanical ventilation is necessary, heat recovery should be con-  
sidered. Artificial cooling should be limited, and in some cases will  
need to be justified to meet carbon reduction requirements. Student  
rooms may be left unoccupied for long periods during the holidays,  
and adequate background ventilation is important. Overheating can  
be an issue in corridors and, as in other communal areas, building  
management systems can be used with opening windows to man-  
age ventilation.  
Shared bathrooms and kitchens are used intensively. As the  
rooms are generally stacked vertically, extracts can be combined  
to discharge efficiently at roof level. In student accommodation  
bathrooms are usually internal, so problems of condensation are  
common where ventilation is inadequate.  
# 5.7 Access and inclusion\: Equality Act, BS8300 and  
# Disability Discrimination Act  
From 2010, the Equality Act replaced the Disability Discrimination  
Acts except in Northern Ireland where the DDA still applies. Under  
the Equality Act 2010, universities must not discriminate against  
students in the provision of education, or access to any benefit,  
facility or service, by excluding them or by subjecting them to  
any other detriment. It is important to consult with the university/  
private developer about provision for disabled students under the  
Equality Act from planning stages through to construction. BS  
8300\:2018 Volumes 1 & 2 give recommendations for the design  
of buildings and their approaches to meet the needs of disabled  
people including requirements for accessible rooms. It applies to  
university and college halls of residence.  
*The Building Regulations, Access to and Use of Buildings\:*  
*Approved Document M, Volumes 1 & 2* aims to ensure that build-  
ings are accessible and useable by everyone, regardless of disability,  
age or gender, and without unnecessary separation or segregation.  
Universities place great importance on inclusion. It is likely  
that many disabled students will not be wheelchair users but will  
have other impairments. Sleeping accommodation should aim to be  
convenient for all – a proportion should therefore be designed for  
independent use by wheelchair users, while standard rooms should  
have a degree of flexibility or adaptability to be suitable for people  
who do not use a wheelchair, but may have other difficulties, e.g. a  
visual impairment or limited dexterity.  
There are different standards for the proportion of wheelchair  
accessible bedrooms that should be provided in any scheme. The  
university or private provider will have a view on this and the local  
authority will have their own requirements, so early consultation  
is essential. Provision is often made up of a number of accessible  
rooms plus adaptable rooms – these are rooms that can easily be  
converted to accessible rooms if there is a demand.  
Accommodation for disabled people should be integrated with  
other student rooms, which suggests that they should be distrib-  
uted throughout the residences at different floors. Wheelchair  
users should be able to reach and use all facilities – common  
rooms, kitchen, laundry, etc. Socialising with other students is an  
important part of student life – and therefore protected through  
equality legislation as a civil right – so access to social areas, such  
as kitchen/dining rooms, is doubly important. These issues have  
implications for provision of lifts and consequently for the form of  
the accommodation \(see Section 4\). Some universities will require **24-10 Housing for students and young people**  
disabled students and wheelchair users to be able to access all study  
bedrooms so that they can visit friends. Others provide study bed-  
rooms for wheelchair users and the kitchen/dining room at ground  
floor level, but no lift access to other rooms \(for example in ‘house’  
style accommodation\). This approach can be argued as acceptable,  
but it is still likely to be interpreted on a case-by-case basis by each  
different local authority. Where residential accommodation is used  
for conferences and holiday letting, it becomes more like ‘hotel’  
accommodation, and should therefore incorporate appropriate pro-  
visions, e.g. sizing of stairs, doors and the provision of lifts. Where  
there is provision for wheelchair users to visit other students, the  
effective clear width of doors to standard study bedrooms will need  
to be adequate to admit wheelchair users. Some students require a  
high level of assistance. Consideration should be given to the pro-  
vision of an adjacent bedroom next to the accessible room, with a  
connecting door, for a ‘companion’/personal assistant. Appropriate  
fittings and equipment will be required in shared facilities such as  
kitchen/dining rooms and laundries as well as in accessible rooms.  
A unisex wheelchair accessible WC should be provided for visi-  
tors.  
# 6 THE STUDY BEDROOM  
# 6.1 Functions  
The study bedroom is the most important element in the design.  
It has to facilitate a range of functions in a small space – sleeping,  
studying, relaxing and socialising. It is the students’ home while  
they are at university, and they should be able to impose their  
personality on it to help avoid the institutional character that can  
easily arise with large numbers of repetitive rooms. It must feel  
private and secure and, ideally, have a reasonable view. It must  
have good light and ventilation that the student should be able to  
control. Good acoustic insulation from adjoining rooms, corridors  
and from the outside is very important. The room and furniture  
must be robust and easy to clean and maintain. Study bedroom  
types include rooms with or without ensuite bathrooms, and ‘stu-  
dio’ rooms with ensuite bathroom and kitchen area. Rooms may be  
single or shared. The most common type is the single, ensuite study  
bedroom \(Figure 24.8\).  
# 6.2 Room size and shape  
A study bedroom for one person \(without ensuite bathroom\) can be  
as small as 8 m2, but this is extremely tight and a more appropriate  
minimum area is 10 m2. A small sized room with ensuite bathroom  
is typically 13 m2. To optimise the plan, study bedrooms are usu-  
ally rectangular with the ensuite bathroom at the rear of the room.  
Typical modest room sizes for other types of student room are\:  
• Studio room for one student with ensuite bathroom and kitchen  
area\: 18 m2  
• Studio flat for one student or a couple with ensuite bathroom and  
kitchenette\: 30 m2  
.  
Carefully consider the proportions of the room – the furniture  
layout and the position of the door, window, built-in cupboards,  
sockets and fixed lighting to ensure that the room will accommo-  
date different activities and moods. The larger the area, the easier  
this becomes, but even a small room can be designed to allow some  
variation in the arrangement of furniture. Features such as window  
seats, built-in shelves, alcoves, etc. can also be used to enhance  
character. Consider the height of the window and views when the  
student is sitting at their desk or on the bed. Where it is feasible to  
provide larger rooms – for example where students have a choice  
of rents – it is possible to design for greater flexibility and to ‘zone’  
the different functions of the room and to allow the student to  
change the furniture layout, Figures 24.9a and 24.9b.  
# 6.3 Furniture and finishes  
The careful design of built-in furniture and careful selection of loose  
furniture is essential to the function and appearance of small study  
bedrooms, which should feel welcoming and attractive. Lighting,  
fabrics and colours should be selected to create a harmonious design.  
Furniture and fittings should be robust, but not institutional in charac-  
ter. Built-in furniture can be used to enhance the character of the room  
and optimise the use of the space. Typical provision is as follows\:  
• Bed\: single bed or wider bed \(approx. 1220 mm\). Beds may have  
a storage drawer under. Usually doubles as a sofa, so consider pro-  
viding a back rest along the wall. Provide a bedside table or shelf.

books, files, etc. May include drawers. If the window sill is at, or

• Desk chair.  
• Easy chair\: if sufficient space.

# Housing for students and young people 24-11  
• Shelving\: often built-in. May be arranged to serve the function  
of a bedside table.  
• Wardrobe\: often built-in. Incorporate shelves if there is no chest  
of drawers.  
• Chest of drawers\: if sufficient space. Can be used to extend the  
desk if it is same height and depth.  
• Mirror\: position where there is enough space and light for the  
student to see themselves full length.  
• Pin board\: generous provision to discourage use of walls. A  
small pin board or other writing surface on the outside of the  
room door is useful.  
• Curtains and blinds\: rooms are small but often have full-height  
windows – consider issues of privacy.  
• Washbasin\: a washbasin is often provided in study bedrooms  
when ensuite bathrooms are not provided, and should be sepa-  
rated from the main area of the room by containing it within the  
wardrobe unit or behind a room divider.  
• Mini-fridge\: occasionally required.  
# 6.4 Ensuite bathrooms  
Standard ensuite bathrooms add approximately 2.8 m2 to the study  
bedroom area and should be carefully planned to ensure that the  
small space functions well. Bathrooms are now usually supplied  
as prefabricated pods, which allows the intricate work involved in  
the finishes and in waterproofing showers and floors to be carried  
out under factory conditions and avoids delays to other trades on  
site. If a supplier’s standard ensuite pod is used, the dimensions  
will have significant implications for the overall design of the  
study bedroom. Pods can be constructed in concrete, steel or glass  
reinforeced plastic. Concrete and steel pods can be more easily  
designed as bespoke items and have a greater choice of finishes.  
Acoustic and fire separation between study bedrooms requires  
careful consideration with prefabricated pods. Access to service  
ducts should be from the corridor.  
Bathrooms with traditional construction can be designed as a  
wet room, or incorporate a shower tray with a door or curtain. A  
wet room helps to optimise use of the space, but make it more diffi-  
cult to keep the contents of the small space dry. The floor also takes  
time to dry. Accessible bathrooms require a flat floor.  
# 6.5 Studio rooms  
Studio rooms include an ensuite bathroom and a kitchen area  
\(Figure 24.10\). The kitchen area usually includes a fridge, sink,  
cupboard, hob and/or microwave and cooker extract. Some worktop  
area will be required and ideally also a surface to eat on, separate  
from the desk. Extraction will require ducts to be incorporated into  
the plans. The kitchen should be designed so that it does not domi-  
nate the study bedroom. If the kitchen area is located on the escape  
route between the sleeping area and the room door, details should  
be agreed with the local authority. Additional fire provisions, such  
as fire suppression, or hobs with timers, may be required.  
# 6.6 Services  
Students should be able to control their environment to some  
degree. Consideration should also be given to erratic patterns of  
occupation of study bedrooms and measures should be incorpo-  
rated to reduce energy consumption, e.g. to ensure that lights are  
not left on when rooms are vacant \(see also Section 5\). Access for  
maintenance and meter reading should be arranged from corridors  
to avoid the need for access to the student rooms.  
*Lighting*  
Good natural light is essential. General artificial lighting should  
be supplemented by task lighting to serve desk and bed positions  
and should be switched so that it can be controlled from the bed  
and room door. The student should be able to adjust the artificial  
lighting to suit different activities and moods – working, social-  
ising, etc. **24-12 Housing for students and young people**  
# 6.7 Disabled students  
Requirements for accessible rooms are addressed in the *Building*  
*Regulations, Access to and Use of Buildings\: Approved Document*  
*M*. Standards set out in BS 8300\:2018 Volumes 1 & 2, which can be  
more onerous, may also be required by the university. Wheelchair  
users require larger study bedrooms, with room for a wheelchair  
turning space between furniture and provision of an appropriate  
ensuite bathroom. The design of fittings and finishes should be  
suitable for access from a wheelchair. Study bedrooms may also  
require adaptations to meet the specific needs of individual disa-  
bled students, as these will vary depending on the particular nature  
of their impairment. Consider\:  
• Design of room door and access into the room  
• Height of the desk \(which may be adjustable\) and space below  
for wheelchair to slide under  
• Access and use of cupboards and shelving  
• Design of ironmongery and controls for window opening, cur-  
tains and blinds  
• Position of electrical sockets and switches  
• Provision of telephone, emergency call point and fire alarm bea-  
con  
• Provision of space to store the unused wheelchair without  
obstruction  
• Design of ensuite bathroom  
• Levels of lighting and choice of colours for people with visual  
impairments  
• Visual alarms or vibrating alarms for people with hearing  
impairments.  
**24.10** *Studio room with ensuite shower/WC/basin and kitchenette*  
*at Torquay House, London, designed by MJP Architects. 1\) bed;*  
*2\) desk; 3\) kitchenette; 4\) kitchen storage; 5\) shower room;*  
*6\) wardrobe*  
*Heating*  
Systems and controls will be determined by the university or  
commercial provider’s strategy for energy conservation and for  
charging, and also by the length of let \(term time only, or all year\).  
*Internet and power*  
*S*tudents require excellent internet access for study and social activ-  
ities. Technology for internet access is constantly advancing, so  
that the most appropriate system should be agreed as each project  
is designed and to suit the requirements of the university. Wi-Fi is  
cheaper than data cabling and gives students the flexibility to work  
where they choose. TV provision is generally accessed via the inter-  
net. As a guide, a typical provision would be three double sockets,  
one twin USB outlet and one double data point. The location of  
sockets and electrical trunking should be considered in relation to  
furniture arrangements. Surface trunking is unattractive and can be  
concealed beneath the desk, but should also be arranged to allow  
easy access to sockets – for example to easily remove a laptop.  
*Ventilation*  
Natural ventilation should be provided with opening windows  
where possible, fitted with restrictors to prevent students from fall-  
ing and also for security for ground floor rooms. Adjustable louvres  
or perforated screens may also be used \(in combination with fixed  
windows\) to provide natural ventilation while avoiding the risk of  
falls or dropped objects.  
*Recycling*  
Bins for recycling may be required within the study bedroom.  
# 7 KITCHEN/DINING ROOMS  
# 7.1 Role  
In student accommodation, kitchen/dining rooms provide a key  
social focus for each group of students that they serve, with oppor-  
tunities for casual encounters, friendship and support. Kitchen/  
dining rooms may be extended to incorporate a living area with  
sofas and a TV. Kitchens may also be used for informal study  
and group working. The activities foster a sense of ownership of  
the accommodation that in turn encourages responsible behav-  
iour. The design and character of the room should be attractive  
and welcoming and allow the students to adopt the space as their  
own. One kitchen/dining room will typically serve five to eight stu-  
dents, although in some universities they may serve ten or more,  
particularly in ‘house’ type accommodation or in halls where the  
university also provides central catering facilities as an alternative.  
Kitchen/dining rooms can be arranged to overlook common  
areas such as entrances, stairs and halls, providing further oppor-  
tunities for interaction and a degree of security through informal  
supervision. They should be located to avoid noise and nuisance  
to study bedrooms. The dining areas should be designed to allow  
all the students in the unit to eat at the same time. Furniture should  
not be fixed to avoid creating an institutional character. Provision  
of Wi-Fi is essential to allow students to make full use of the space.  
Kitchens will be heavily used and should allow several peo-  
ple to prepare food simultaneously. They must be designed to be  
functional, robust and easy to clean. As a guide, a length of work  
surface of approximately 3600 mm, including cooker and sink, will  
be sufficient for five people. Where kitchens serve larger numbers  
of students, the provision of cookers, sinks, fridges and storage will  
need to be increased to meet statutory requirements \(see Section 5  
above\). Ideally, a microwave oven should be provided as well as a  
conventional cooker.  
Cupboards should be provided for each student for storage  
of dry food and kitchen equipment. Locks are often provided on  
cupboards, and sometimes even on fridges, to avoid food being  
stolen. However, in accommodation such as self-contained flats **Housing for students and young people 24-13**  
and houses there may be no locks, to promote a sense of mutual  
responsibility. At the other extreme, in some accommodation,  
students are expected to keep cooking equipment and food in  
their rooms, but this is inconvenient, causes mess and undermines  
social interaction. Kitchens can be messy\: consider what will  
be visible from outside the building and ensure that there is an  
appropriate storage place for unattractive items, such as ironing  
boards and bins.  
# 7.2 Services  
Measures should be incorporated to reduce energy consumption  
\(see Section 9.6\).  
*Internet and power*  
Provide sockets at worktop and at low level. Some universities  
monitor and charge for cookers separately to discourage wasteful  
use of energy. Cookers can be fitted with a time switch in case they  
are left on by mistake. Wi-Fi should be provided. Provide sockets  
by sofas and seating.  
*Lighting and mechanical extract*  
Provide generous opening windows where possible \(with restric-  
tors if necessary\) positioned to avoid nuisance from noise and  
smell to neighbouring study bedrooms. Artificial lighting should be  
appropriate for preparing food in the kitchen area, but more subtle  
and attractive lighting should be provided in the dining and living  
spaces.  
*Refuse and recycling*  
Position bins for easy cleaning and emptying. Separate recycling  
bins should be provided in line with university/ private providers’  
waste management strategies. It is important to design a place for  
bulky bins into the kitchen layout, otherwise they can spoil the  
appearance of the room.  
# 7.3 Inclusive access  
Where the kitchen serves study bedrooms for wheelchair users, it  
should be designed with appropriate equipment and fittings and  
sufficient area to allow for wheelchairs to manoeuvre, including  
worktops with adjustable height and room for the wheelchair  
to slide below. It is not possible to provide cupboards under  
these worktops, as in standard kitchens. This may require the  
room to be enlarged. Some duplication of equipment may also  
be necessary.  
# 8 BATHROOMS  
# 8.1 Facilities  
Bathrooms, showers and WCs are usually designed to the mini-  
mum practical area. Numbers of facilities should be in accordance  
with statutory requirements \(see Section 5\). Shared WCs should be  
separate from bathrooms unless serving very few people. Where  
facilities are shared, additional washbasins are sometimes provided  
in study bedrooms.  
Facilities need to withstand rough use and simpler arrange-  
ments are potentially easier to construct, clean and maintain.  
Factory-assembled bathroom ‘pods’ are now generally used to  
achieve a high standard of construction \(see Section 6.4\). Service  
ducts should be carefully detailed and located, with service access  
to ensuite bathrooms from corridors. Where bathrooms are not  
ensuite, consider proximity to study bedrooms, and acoustic and  
visual privacy.  
Provide good mechanical ventilation, especially in showers,  
with moisture-resistant light fittings. Towel rails, shelves and hooks  
in the shower area should be out of the way of the shower itself.  
Controls should be provided to showers to avoid risk of scalding.  
Flooring should be slip resistant.  
# 9 OTHER FACILITIES  
Provision will depend on the number of students living in the accom-  
modation and on the availability of facilities nearby and to some  
extent the nature of the provider. They may include the following\:  
# 9.1 Reception and circulation areas  
Entrances should be light and welcoming and avoid a mean or  
utilitarian character – the design should create an identity for the  
residences. In larger residences, there may be a staffed reception  
or porter’s lodge or office. In other schemes, provision may be  
required for a temporary reception to receive students at the start  
of term or conference guests in the holidays. In up-market com-  
mercial schemes, the design and ‘branding’ of the reception are  
important and a more generous area with seating may be required.  
Wi-Fi should be provided. Long narrow corridors without daylight  
or views should be avoided. Staircases are a place where chance  
meetings occur, and are an opportunity to design an attractive  
feature on circulation routes. Mailboxes may be provided in the  
entrance area. Students receive an increasingly large number of  
parcels through mail order.  
# 9.2 Laundry  
A laundry serving groups of residents should be provided with  
washing and drying machines of a robust commercial type with  
emergency cut-off switch. There may be a sink for hand washing  
clothes, facilities for ironing and folding clothes, and seats for wait-  
ing. Provide good lighting and ventilation and floor gullies to avoid  
flooding. Fittings and equipment should allow easy maintenance.  
Services such as electricity supply, hot water, etc. must be adequate  
for the level of use. Choose the location carefully – a laundry close  
to a common room can form part of a social hub, but laundries can  
be noisy, smelly and humid and should be arranged to avoid nui-  
sance to study bedrooms or at the building’s entrance.  
# 9.3 Cleaners’ storage  
Where accommodation is in independent flats or houses, cleaning  
is often the students’ responsibility and a tall cupboard \(housing a  
hoover/mop/ironing board\) will be sufficient. Where the university  
arranges cleaning, provide central stores for the cleaners within a  
reasonable distance of the rooms. In larger schemes, there should be  
a store on each floor. Provision may also be required for facilities  
for the cleaning and reception staff\: WCs, lockers, staff room, etc.  
# 9.4 Other possible facilities  
• Central common room/television room/party room that may also  
be used for informal or group working. Often poorly used if insuf-  
ficient thought has been given to demand and the kind of activities  
that could take place. The room and furniture should be designed to  
be welcoming and attractive. Wi-Fi should be provided. Common  
rooms should be located so that activity is visible from main circu-  
lation routes to encourage use. Party rooms need to be located to  
reduce nuisance to study bedrooms. A kitchen area will be required  
for students to prepare food and drink.  
• Area for vending machines  
• WC/accessible WC for visitors  
• Seminar room/study area\: central rooms with Wi-Fi can provide  
a place for group working and a sociable alternative to working  
in study bedrooms  
• Games room  
• Music practice room  
• In more luxurious schemes, a gym, cinema, café or convenience  
store may be provided  
• Luggage store  
• Wardens/staff flats may be provided adjacent to or within the  
scheme, and may be studios or flats of various sizes, including  
family accommodation  
• Guest bedrooms. **24-14 Housing for students and young people**  
# 9.5 External areas and parking  
Well-designed landscaped areas around residences can provide  
places for recreation, socialising and informal working and will be  
significantly more useful if Wi-Fi is available. Promoting health  
and well-being is an increasing concern, and areas for exercise and  
informal games – football, Frisbee, etc. – should be provided where  
possible. With university projects, the design of the public realm  
should aim to create the sense of a coherent, integrated campus.  
The planning authority and the university will have policies for  
the provision of parking, and the allowance for student parking is  
usually very minimal, although spaces will be required for park-  
ing for disabled people, which should be close to entrances. To  
guard against theft and for personal safety, parking areas should be  
overlooked, well lit and relatively close to entrances. Each student  
arrives at the start of term with quantities of luggage, and sufficient  
space should be provided near to entrances for unloading several  
vehicles simultaneously. Taxis are often used for nights out and  
there should be provision for taxi drop-off close to entrances. To  
encourage use of sustainable modes of transport, there should be  
well-designed, well-lit footpaths and cycle routes and good pro-  
vision of secure, covered cycle parking. The local authority will  
provide guidance on the level of cycle storage although this will  
typically be 1\:2–1\:4 \(cycle space\: student\). Approx. 5 per cent of  
the total amount are typically required to be enlarged spaces for a  
range of accessible options  
# 9.6 Energy consumption  
There are many opportunities to reduce energy consumption in the  
detailed design of the accommodation and choice of controls, fit-  
tings and appliances, including\:  
• Building management systems, and a good understanding of  
how to use the building \(heating, ventilation, etc.\) by staff and  
residents  
• Low energy light fittings  
• Presence detectors for kitchen, ensuite bathroom and communal  
area lights  
• Thermostatic radiator valves  
• Heat recovery systems  
• Low flow rate taps and dual flush WCs  
• Sustainable urban drainage  
• Air and ground source heat pumps  
• Renewable energy sources.  
# 9.7 Refuse and recycling collection  
Develop a waste management strategy at an early stage and consult  
the waste collection services about their requirements for access.  
The size of any bin store will depend on the number of students,  
the requirements for recycling and the frequency of collection. Bins  
filled by staff may be cleaner and tidier than those used by students,  
but all are potentially untidy, smelly and attract vermin. Stores  
should be easy to access, clean and maintain. Locate to reduce nui-  
sance to residents, and provide good ventilation.  
# 9.8 Safety and security  
The design should address potential risks of attack, vandalism  
and theft. Personal safety is a major issue in student housing and  
students often return home late at night. Theft is also a common  
problem as students own computers and other valuable equip-  
ment, and it is difficult to prevent strangers entering residences by  
‘tail-gating’. Windows to ground floor rooms are particularly vul-  
nerable.  
The building should be designed so that external areas – such  
as entrances, paths and car parks – and common areas within the  
building – such as staircases – are overlooked to provide informal  
supervision. Good external lighting is essential, with provision of  
safe walking routes. CCTV and alarm points may also be required  
in external areas.  
Access control swipe card systems are commonly used for doors  
instead of keys, which are a nuisance to replace when lost. Where  
there are sufficient numbers of residents, there may be a staffed  
reception. Provide spy holes in study bedroom doors/entrance  
doors, as applicable.  
The design should also avoid features that encourage anti-social  
or dangerous behaviour\: skateboarding and climbing are common  
problems.  
# 10 CONFERENCE USE  
# 10.1 Additional needs  
Many universities use student residences for conferences or holi-  
day lets during the vacations and this has implications for design\:  
• The fire risk assessment should address the proposed use  
• Rooms with ensuite bathrooms will be preferred  
• Double beds, accessed from both sides, may be required with  
implications for room size  
• A higher standard of fittings and finishes with a ‘hotel’ design  
style may be required  
• Central linen stores may be required with easy access to study  
bedrooms  
• A term-time store for equipment that is provided to conference  
guests, such as kettles  
• Lockable storage may be provided for students’ possessions and  
a safe for conference guests  
• Reception area, seminar rooms or other facilities to support con-  
ference activities. **25 Laboratories**
