Religious bodies, as charities, are regulated in ways that do not  
apply to most other clients, \(and there is also variation on charity  
law between different parts of the United Kingdom\). As a result, at  
local level the officers of religious bodies may be unaware of the  
legal implications of their charitable status.  
This may have implications for their professional advisers, who  
should take care to ascertain the scope and extent of the authority of  
trustees at, or prior, to accepting an appointment. Typically, the trustee  
role of officers of religious organisations may constrain their ability to  
enter into contracts, to purchase or dispose of land and/or buildings,  
and to make payments. As a result, final authority for certain deci-  
sions may be reserved for their regional or national authorities.  
# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 Scope  
This chapter covers churches and places of worship for various  
Christian denominations, synagogues, mosques, gurdwaras and  
Hindu temples. Local places of worship only are dealt with, not  
larger buildings like cathedrals, or \(in general\) separate social  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-34  
# 1.2 History and tradition  
In the architecture of places of worship for the more established  
Christian denominations and for some other faith groups, the architect  
is bound to be more concerned with tradition than in other fields. Users  
are more conscious of history \(and more sensitive about it\) than most  
other clients\: they will not allow an architect to ignore established  
precedents and will expect a full understanding of them. Many places  
of worship are listed buildings. The majority of these are Anglican  
churches, but other long-established denominations also have signifi-  
cant numbers of listed premises and, in some cases, church buildings  
no longer required by their original denomination have been sold to  
another denomination and re-purposed for their style of worship.  
Many of the new ‘Community Churches’ expect to see a differ-  
ent approach more akin to performance architecture than established  
precedents. These new movements have also had a major impact  
upon the more established denominations, and have resulted in  
a movement away from one-person ministry to more participa-  
tion by members of the congregation. Large, free-span structures  
are required to accommodate large congregation numbers, seating  
capacities of 500–1000 are not uncommon, for which the conversion  
of redundant retail warehousing and similar structures are ideal.  
Exact details of the forms of worship and building procedures  
should be discussed with the individual clients, and the architec-  
tural implications thoroughly understood.  
# 1.3 Local Ecumenical Projects \(LEPs\)  
Many churches are now uniting to form LEPs, both as a visible  
expression of church unity and in recognition of declining numbers  
and reducing resources. In these, the uniting congregations may  
continue to worship separately at different times in shared prem-  
ises; this would be typical, for example, of LEPs incorporating a  
**31-1** **31-2 Places of worship**  
Roman Catholic congregation. Alternatively, they may unite to  
form a single congregation recognising the practices of each of  
the participating denominations; this would be typical of congre-  
gations from within the same tradition or related traditions. The  
building may be either that belonging to one of the congregations,  
or purpose built \(less often\), possibly on a site previously occupied  
by one of the participating denominations.  
Such projects are set up \(in England and Wales\) under the Sharing  
of Church Buildings Act 1969, which imposes some legal require-  
ments for LEPs in addition to the expectations of the participating  
denominations. This may be relevant to designers, as the investment  
of capital in buildings is one of the areas dealt within the Act. For  
every LEP, there will be \(or should be\) a formal ‘Sharing Agreement’,  
which sets out terms of the Agreement, and is intended in particu-  
lar to safeguard the traditions and assets of both \(or all\) the uniting  
congregations, and the premises, which are commonly \(though not  
universally\) vested in one of the participating denominations, *not* in  
the local congregation. Architects involved in LEPs should take time  
and care in understanding the legal constraints entailed by the Act and  
the Sharing Agreement, and should be aware that officers and leaders  
of the local congregation are unlikely to be *au fait* with these details.  
# Part A Guide to Christian Denominations  
# 2 OVERVIEW  
# 2.1 Range  
The history of the Christian churches in the UK is complex, and  
closely interlinked with the political history of the British Isles. In  
2017, there were approximately 50173 congregations in the UK,  
of which about 42000 used church premises, demonstrating that  
churches can, and do, operate without buildings. These congrega-  
tions were divided into around 250 Christian denominations in the  
UK. Of these, 10 broad groupings of churches can be identified\:  
**Anglican\:** Including Church of England, Church of Ireland \(in  
NI\), Church in Wales, Scottish Episcopal Church  
**Baptist\:** Including Baptist Union of Great Britain, Independent  
Baptist churches, Baptist Union of Wales, Baptist Union of  
Scotland, Grace Baptist Churches, the Association of Baptist  
Churches in Ireland \(NI\), Gospel Standard Strict Baptists.  
**Roman Catholic\:** Roman Catholic Church in England and  
Wales, Roman Catholic Church in Ireland, Roman Catholic  
Church in Scotland  
**Independent churches\:** Including Christian Brethren \(Open\),  
Fellowship of independent Evangelical Churches, Union of  
Welsh Independents, Christian Brethren \(Exclusive\), other  
Congregational Churches, Churches of Christ  
**Methodist\:** Including Methodist Church of Great Britain,  
Methodist Church in Ireland, Wesleyan Reform Union,  
Independent Methodists and Free Methodists  
**New Churches\:** Fluid category of independent churches, some  
of them members of wider groupings and networks  
**Orthodox\:** Including Greek Orthodox, Romanian Orthodox,  
Russian Orthodox, other Eastern Orthodox Churches, oriental  
Orthodox Churches and other Orthodox Churches  
**Pentecostal\:** Including Redeemed Christian Church of God,  
Elim Pentecostal Churches, Assemblies of God, several churches  
of African and West Indian origin and a significant number of  
smaller denominations and independent churches  
**Presbyterian Churches\:** Including Church of Scotland,  
Presbyterian Church in Northern Ireland, the United Reformed  
Church, Presbyterian Church of Wales, Free Presbyterian  
Church of Ulster, Free Church of Scotland and other smaller  
Presbyterian denominations  
**Other denominations\:** Including the Salvation Army, Seventh-  
Day Adventists, Lutheran Church, the Religious Society of  
Friends \(Quakers\), Church of the Nazarene, Moravian churches,  
Mennonites, the Unitarian and Free Christian churches.  
# 2.2 Control of church premises  
Works to existing churches and places of worship are likely to be  
constrained by at least some of the following;  
• Procedures of the denomination in question  
• Extent to which control of premises is devolved to the local con-  
gregation  
• Age of the building \(and especially whether it is a listed building\)  
• Whether the building was originally for designed for the current  
or some other denomination, or for some other purpose entirely.  
In addition, the architect may encounter among church office-hold-  
ers the mistaken conviction that various aspects of planning and  
building control legislation do not apply to places of worship. This  
is rarely, if ever, correct, though it may have been the case in the  
past. However, certain denominations do have the specific right  
to determine listed building applications themselves. These are\:  
Church of England; Church in Wales; Roman Catholic Church;  
Methodist Church; Baptist Union of Great Britain, Baptist Union  
of Wales and United Reformed Church. This power is *not* devolved  
to the congregation and the architect may find that the relevant  
body in the denomination can be more demanding than the local  
planning authorities in considering listed building applications.  
# 3 ANGLICAN  
# 3.1 The buildings, and how they are used for worship  
After the Reformation, the Anglicans inherited many mediaeval,  
mostly Gothic, buildings, strongly directional in their east–west ori-  
entation and with the main action remote from the congregation.  
The people therefore had lost the sense that they were engaged with  
the clergy in a common action and tended to become spectators with  
an individualistic rather than a corporate response to the liturgy. The  
Church has now moved into a period of experiment with a fuller  
expression of the corporate nature of worship, and the equal impor-  
tance of the Word \(which must be heard\) and of sacrament, within  
a building which remains true to the Anglican sense of proportion.  
# 3.2 Altar \(or table\), priest and people  
The influences of the Reformation, and later the Oxford Movement,  
have produced variations to the layout of the sanctuary. The Book of  
Common Prayer \(BCP 1662\) assumes the table, or altar, to be against  
the east wall with the priest standing at the north end, Figure 31.1.  
In many churches this has been superseded by the priest facing  
east, Figure 31.2.  
**31.1** *Communion table is placed against east wall, priest stands*  
*at north end* **Places of worship 31-3**  
# 3.4 Church design  
Apart from the altar, the general principles of layout and design  
are the same as for the Roman Catholic and Methodist churches.  
These are described in Sections 4, 5 and 7. These sections also  
give appropriate space requirements for aisle widths, pew sizes and  
areas within the sanctuary.  
**31.2** *Eastward position\: priest faces altar with his back to the*  
*congregation*  
This was thought to be contrary to the spirit of the Anglican liturgy.  
Altars were moved west with the priest facing the people across the  
altar, Figure 31.3.  
More recently, there are churches which bring the people even  
closer to the celebration by positioning the altar in the centre of a  
square or circular building, with seating on three sides. Figure 31.4  
shows the plan of the church of St Paul at Bow Common in London  
\(1960, Architect\: Robert Maguire and Keith Murray\).  
# 3.3 Main services  
There are several types of service\:  
• All age services  
• The Eucharist  
• The offices of matins and evensong  
• Baptism  
• Confirmation  
• The solemnisation of matrimony  
• Burial of the dead.  
# 3.5 Alterations and extensions to existing churches  
Although some new churches are being built, the majority of  
works are for the provision of community facilities, meeting  
rooms, toilets and kitchens. In listed buildings, any propos-  
als are judged with great scrutiny by the Diocesan Advisory  
Committee \(DAC\) and English Heritage. Proposals that are  
reversible and do not encroach on the existing structure tend  
to be favoured.  
At the Church of St Andrew in Farnham, Figure 31.5, advan-  
tage is taken of the large floor space to create a glass and timber  
two storey pavilion structure at the west end of the nave and the  
two aisles taking no support from the existing fabric. The pavilion  
encloses meeting rooms and a kitchen with a viewing and meeting  
gallery over. The altar is in a centre position with seating on all  
four sides.  
A different approach was taken at the refurbished Church of All  
Saints Flore, Figures 31.6 and 31.7. In this mediaeval church with a  
Georgian flat ceiling, the walls are plain with cornice and panelled  
dado. The two aisles flank the west tower. The full width of the  
west end is separated from the aisles by full height walls, and the  
mediaeval tower arch was glazed to create a meeting space, toilet,  
kitchen and vestry.  
**31.3** *One of the many variations of plan where the priest faces*  
*the congregation across the altar. The seating may extend around*  
*three sides of the altar*  
**31.4** *Church of St Paul at Bow Common, with seating on three*  
*sides of the altar*  
**31.5** *Plan of the Church of St Andrew, Farnham \(Architect\:*  
*Ptolemy Dean Architects\)* **31-4 Places of worship**  
• Either the DAC or the Chancellor may refer the proposals to an  
appropriate conservation body such as English Heritage whose  
observations may or may not be accepted by the DAC or the  
Chancellor.  
# 4 ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH  
# 4.1 Worship as a corporate act  
The term ‘Roman Catholic’ \(or to members simply ‘Catholic’\)  
denotes the Christian community which has continuously accepted  
the authority of the Pope. The chief problem of a community which  
is building a Catholic church is that, though its building must suit  
the liturgy as it now is, community and architect must also make  
some estimate of what the total ultimate change in form of services  
is likely to be.  
The corporate nature of Catholic worship is again now being  
stressed. Catholic churchgoing has for centuries been highly indi-  
vidualistic. The congregation should participate in the liturgical  
action and not merely watch it. Baptism is being restored as the  
corporate act of the local assembly, but it is still conducted as a  
private ceremony held at a time to suit the parents and which only  
they and their friends attend. The architect must make corporate  
baptism possible in a church, even though it may not be practised  
for some time.  
The existence of societies within the parish is always impor-  
tant in its social life and the architect should find out which they  
are, what they do, and whether they are to be accommodated in  
any way.  
**31.6** *Church of All Saints Flore, original plan*  
**31.7** *Church of All Saints Flore, plan after conversion \(Architect\:*  
*Stimpson Walton Bond\)*  
# 4.2 The main services  
The six main services of the Catholic Church are\:  
• Mass  
• Easter liturgy \(Holy Week ceremonies\)  
• Baptism  
• Marriage  
• Burial of the dead  
• Devotions.  
Other liturgical activities include blessing, dedication, conse-  
cration, confirmation, ordination.  
# 4.3 Church design  
Apart from the altar, the general principles of layout and design  
are the same as for the Church of England. These are shown, with  
separate altar details, in Part B.  
# 3.6 Obtaining a faculty  
There are several considerations to bear in mind when securing a  
faculty for church building work\:  
• New, extensions and repair works are subject to faculty, an  
approvals procedure dating back several centuries.  
• This was consolidated in 1993 by the *Care of Churches and*  
*Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction Measure Code of Practice* granting  
exemption from listed building consent for work to Grade I and  
II\* listed church buildings.  
• The Measure is administered in each diocese by a DAC.  
• The process is often initiated by a site visit with the Parochial  
Church Council and the architect followed by preliminary and  
detailed submissions to the DAC.  
• If there are no objections, the DAC informs the Parish and the  
Chancellor of the diocese to whom the Parish submits a formal  
request for a Faculty. The Chancellor is a judge or a QC.  
• Exemption is only from listed building consent. External alter-  
ations may be subject to planning approval from the local  
planning authority.  
# 5 FREE, NON-CONFORMIST AND PRESBYTERIAN  
# CHURCHES  
# 5.1 Origins and buildings  
During the Reformation, one of the leaders, John Knox, became  
greatly influenced by the Swiss John Calvin and it was basically  
his system of church government and structure, as well as much  
of his theology, which he brought into the church. This system of  
church government by courts, basically government by the mem-  
bers of the church congregation, is known as ‘Presbyterian’, as  
opposed to ‘Episcopalian’ which is government by an appointed  
hierarchy.  
Other reformers came to similar conclusions by slightly dif-  
ferent historic routes; most such denominations operate with  
various arrangements for self-government at local, regional  
and national levels. Most \(but not all\) such denominations  
have agreed Statements of Faith, and formal Constitutions set-  
ting out what decisions are to be made at which level within  
the denomination’s structures. The governing body of each congregation is responsible for day-to-day organisation and  
management of the affairs of the congregation and are usually  
the charity trustees.  
There may be denomination-wide or local variations from what  
is stated here. The architect should therefore always ascertain the  
actual situation, taking into account any information or guidance  
published by the denomination\(s\) involved.  
This is particularly important when dealing with LEPs, as there  
are likely to be differing opinions within the congregation and the  
local leadership, and a building project may well bring such differ-  
ences to the fore.  
# Places of worship 31-5  
for the whole service or may take part of the service from a prayer  
desk or a lectern, or from behind the communion table, using the  
pulpit \(if any\) only for preaching. The minister may move from  
the pulpit to the communion table to receive the offering, and will  
certainly do so to administer communion. The font and/or baptistry  
will of course be used for administering baptism, and the front of  
the sanctuary steps \(if any\) for admission of new communicants or  
for ordination of elders.  
In more recent buildings, or in the course of modernisation or  
re-ordering, a raised sanctuary floor would be avoided because of  
the difficulty this presents for disabled persons, and also because  
there is no theological justification for it.  
A pulpit might not be required – the introduction of sound sys-  
tems reduce the need for the pulpit which was historically an aid  
to audibility.  
Pews are rarely now installed. Where they exist, they are fre-  
quently removed as an obstacle to multi-purpose use and/or to  
experimental forms of worship and/or to congregational partic-  
ipation generally. They can also be extremely uncomfortable.  
However, their removal can nevertheless be contentious, and in a  
listed building may become a major issue in determining an appli-  
cation. Movable seating may be left in position or stored when not  
in use to allow other uses of the space.  
# 5.3 Ways of worship  
The Reformation established the doctrine of ‘the priesthood of  
all believers’\: it was not necessary for any human being to come  
between God and a worshipper, and the only mediator accepted  
was Jesus Christ. There is therefore no good theological reason for  
a chancel in its literal sense of a ‘railed-off area’ in ‘Free’, Non-  
conformist and Presbyterian churches. In practice, many such  
churches do have a sanctuary or chancel area which is therefore  
now simply where the central act takes place.  
All take part in the full worship and sacramental act. There is  
now a fairly general departure from the earlier rectangular form of  
church in favour of a more open form where the sense of gathering  
the people round the Word and sacrament, as represented by the  
pulpit and communion table, can be expressed.  
Present thinking seeks to emphasise the close links between  
the worship room and the rooms for secular purposes, so that  
there may not be a complete divorce between the weekday and  
Sunday activities of the congregation. The economic circum-  
stances of the congregation may well lead to multi-purpose  
buildings where only a portion is kept entirely for worship,  
while the rest is used for other purposes, with the use of par-  
titions and screens. Sometimes, no area is exclusively reserved  
for worship.  
# 5.4 The main services  
There is a wide variety of practices within the ‘Free’, Non-  
conformist and Presbyterian Churches and local congregations can  
adopt their own practices. The types of services normally held \(but  
subject to both denominational and local variations\) are\:  
• Public worship on Sundays \(morning, evening or both\)  
• As above, with addition of Holy Communion  
• As above with the addition of Baptism \(usually of infants using a  
font but in the case of LEPs which include a denomination which  
practices adult Baptism, a baptistry as described in Section 8  
below may also be required\)  
• As above, with ordination of elders/deacons or admission of new  
communicants/church members  
• Marriages \(in England and Wales only if the building is regis-  
tered for marriages\), and/or the blessing of civil marriages and  
civil partnerships; note that marriage law in Scotland differs  
from that in England and Wales and does not require registration  
of the building  
• Funerals – although in many cases the service will be held at the  
cemetery or crematorium  
• Weekday services – apart from Christmas Eve, Christmas Day,  
Maundy Thursday and Good Friday services – are relatively  
uncommon; where held they may be joint services with other  
local congregations of different religious traditions.  
# 5.5 Minister  
The ordinary conduct of worship is left largely to the minister \(or  
in some denominations to any authorised lay person\). In a more tra-  
ditional building, they may choose to remain in the pulpit \(if any\)  
# 5.6 Church design  
While there is great variety in the way services are conducted,  
much of the speaking is done by the minister. The congregation sit  
for prayers and do not kneel in the pews or at their seats. The pews  
or seating may be seen as an extension of the communion table,  
so the congregation is, in effect, sitting around the table. Where  
seating is movable, the communion table may sometimes be set in  
the centre of the space with the congregational seating surrounding  
the table.  
Depending on the denomination, worshippers remain in their  
seats throughout the services, with the elements of communion  
being passed around by the elders/deacons; or may come to the  
front of the church/the sanctuary to receive communion.  
Baptism must take place in the face of the congregation and the  
font or baptistry should therefore be visible to all. The font should  
be in advance of, and \(if fixed\) probably to one side of, the com-  
munion table and at a slightly lower level. It can be movable but in  
some traditions may have a permanent site in the sanctuary. It need  
*not* be at the entrance to the church \(as was traditional in Anglican  
churches\).  
Where pews are to be used, a central aisle is desirable for  
marriage ceremonies. However, in any new installation, the  
requirements for evacuation in an emergency would take prec-  
edence and in a large capacity building might require additional  
aisles.  
The choir \(if any\) should be visible to the congregation but need  
not be in the sanctuary.  
The communion table is a table and not an altar. It is usually  
rectangular but other shapes are not precluded. Basic sizes are  
given in Section 11.  
A large or fixed lectern is not essential but where provided it  
should be to the sizes shown in Section 12, taking account of the  
comments in Section 12.1  
If a pulpit is required, it may be centrally in front or to one side  
of the table or, more rarely, behind the table. It should not be more  
elevated than is required for the congregation to see the preacher.  
General design is as shown in Section 12; see also the comments  
in Section 12.5.  
A chair for the minister is provided centrally behind the com-  
munion table with often at least one additional chair on each side  
for elders/deacons. Alternatively, seats for elders/deacons may be  
provided against the rear wall of the sanctuary/the rear wall of the  
church. **31-6 Places of worship**  
# 6 THE SALVATION ARMY  
# 6.1 Origins  
The Salvation Army arose from evangelical meetings conducted in  
east London during 1865 by the Reverend William Booth, a min-  
ister of the Methodist New Connection. Booth decided to take the  
church to the people. His services were held in the open air, in tents  
and in theatres\: later he built barracks and citadels in which his con-  
verts could hold their meetings. His services were sensational\: he  
used brass bands playing secular tunes to accompany hymns; con-  
verts \(soldiers\) wore uniform. He became a ‘general’ and directed  
the organisation in quasi-military style. Men and women had equal  
rights in office. Booth regarded social work, care of the poor and  
rehabilitation of the outcast as an essential part of his Christian  
mission.  
The Christian mission, as it was first called, grew beyond all  
expectations and in 1878 became known as the Salvation Army.  
In its belief, it is protestant, evangelical and prophetic. The corps  
assembles for worship in a hall – a multi-purpose building some-  
times called a citadel, temple or barracks. Sometimes within the  
complex there are two halls, for senior and junior soldiers respec-  
tively. Religious services and social activities may be conducted in  
either or both halls.  
# 6.2 Ceremonies  
Ceremonies may be divided into two types\:  
• Ordinary services held on Sunday – morning, afternoon and  
evening  
• Ceremonies applicable to marriages, funerals, memorial services,  
covenants, swearing-in of soldiers and presentation of colours  
\(these may be embodied within one of the ordinary meetings\).  
The architectural implications are shown in Figures 31.8 to 31.13.  
**31.9** *Praise meeting or festival*  
**31.10** *Swearing-in ceremony*  
**31.11** *Wedding*  
**31.12** *Funeral*  
**31.8** *Salvation Army\: possible basic arrangements. Note that*  
*access from officers’ room to platform may be on either a side or*  
*rear wall*  
**31.13** *Presentation of colours* **6.3 Design of the assembly hall**  
There will be no communion service and visually there will be no  
elevation or placing of the sacred elements in a part of the build-  
ing. The font, lectern, pulpit, communion table and altar are not  
essential to the Salvation Army form of worship. In every Salvation  
Army hall there is a place for the mercy seat, Figure 31.14. This is  
a simple wooden form, usually placed at the front of the platform  
in front of the congregation, and is a place where Christian and  
non-Christian penitents may kneel at any time.  
**31.14** *Mercy seat*  
*Platform*  
The platform will be required to accommodate, at various times,  
officers taking a leading part in the services; the band \(possibly a  
visiting one which may be larger than that designed for\); the song-  
ster brigade or a visiting choir.  
The size of the platform will depend on local conditions and  
requirements but approximately 0.5 to 0.6 m2 per person \(seated  
in rows\) should be allowed. The platform should not be less than  
about 4–5 m depth, but will normally be more. Its height above the  
hall floor should not normally be less than 760 mm or more than  
1100 mm but sightlines must be considered in relation to a level  
floor both on the platform and in the hall.  
If there is a gallery, there must be a view of the mercy seat from  
every seat. Movable seats, not fixed pews, are always used both on  
the platform and in the hall\: flexibility is important.  
*Hall*  
As a first estimate for the overall area of the hall, allow 0.56 m2 for  
each person to be accommodated. Aisles should not be less than  
1.35 m wide. The space between the front edge of the mercy seat  
and the front face of the congregational seating should not be less  
than 1.5 m. A wide rectangle, polygon or square will be a more  
satisfactory shape than a long narrow rectangle.  
The requirements will be for a reasonable standard of acoustics  
for speech, choral singing and brass band playing. There should be  
a reasonable level of natural lighting and a reasonable standard of  
artificial illumination, both on the platform and in the body of the  
hall. The ventilation in most cases should be natural.  
*Officers’ room*  
The officers’ room \(vestry\) is used as a meeting-place by leaders  
or chairmen of meetings and officers of the Census Board who will  
assemble in the room before taking their place on the platform. The  
room should accommodate between two and ten persons. Corps  
records will be kept in this room. Lavatory accommodation will be  
required, normally one unit for each sex.  
*Cloakrooms*  
Lavatory accommodation should be provided for both sexes near  
or adjacent to the entrance vestibules of the senior or junior halls.  
# Places of worship 31-7  
This will be required for women in the songster room and for men  
in the band room.  
*Storage*  
Storage will be required in a band room for brass band instruments,  
music stands and music. The room will also be used for assem-  
bly, briefing and cloakroom. Minimum area shown will usually be  
23–28 m2. Instruments are stored in individual lockers to suit sizes  
of instruments with a small store for reserve instruments and cup-  
board with shelves for music.  
Storage will be required in a songster room for a wind-type  
portable organ or electric portable organ with amplifier, and  
music. The room will also be used for assembly, briefing and  
cloakroom for the women members who would number about  
20 to 30 in an average-sized brigade\: 18.5 m2 would be a min-  
imum area.  
Where there are junior and senior corps activities, there may  
be a junior band and singing company \(junior choir\). Storage will  
be required for brass band instruments for this junior band and for  
music for the singing company.  
Where there is a separate junior hall, storage compartments will  
be contained in that hall. Other social and club activities may also  
require storage.  
# 7 METHODIST CHURCH  
# 7.1 Origins  
The Methodist Church grew out of the Church of England dur-  
ing the eighteenth century and was founded by John and Charles  
Wesley. A distinct feature of the new movement was the intro-  
duction of lay preachers or, as they came to be known, local  
preachers. The strong emphasis on evangelical preaching is  
rooted in the Methodist tradition\: ‘Methodism is nothing if it is  
not evangelical’.  
The church or chapel is normally reserved for worship alone,  
although meetings, lectures and musical recitals of a specifically  
religious character may also take place there. A multi-purpose hall,  
with a sanctuary that can be screened or curtained off, may also be  
used for public worship during the early stages of the development  
of a local congregation. There may be other units within the com-  
plex such as classrooms, club rooms and assembly halls, both for  
religious and secular purposes.  
# 7.2 Ceremonies and buildings  
Many of the comments made under the ‘Free’, Non-conformist  
and Presbyterian Churches will apply. The kind of church required  
today will seat between 100 and 300 people. The influence of the  
liturgical movement is shown in certain specific ways, and particu-  
larly in a new emphasis on the place of the sacraments in the life  
of the church, and in the increasing use of set prayers and liturgical  
forms of service. The altar, therefore, is seen again as the Lord’s  
table, used for the family. The font is no longer viewed as making  
possible a semi-magical act. It is the place at which and the means  
by which the person baptised, whether child or adult, is sacramen-  
tally incorporated into the body of Christ. This rediscovery of the  
laity, the Lord’s table and the font has to be considered in designing  
a church, for in the end it is the function of the church which is of  
supreme importance.  
These theological rediscoveries will affect the building of a  
Methodist church\:  
• In relation to the shape of the church  
• In the arrangement of the sanctuary  
• In the siting of the choir.  
There are normally two services on Sunday, one in the morn-  
ing and one in the evening. These are conducted by a minister or **31-8 Places of worship**  
local preacher from the pulpit, though the earlier part of the service  
may be conducted from a lectern, the pulpit being used only for  
the sermon.  
Holy Communion is normally celebrated once a month. In  
order to emphasise the theological statement that the minis-  
try of the Word is of equal importance to the ministry of the  
Sacrament, pulpit and communion table may be placed close to  
each other. The minister dispenses the bread and the wine \(the  
latter in small individual glasses\) to each of those who have  
come forward from the congregation to kneel at the communion  
rail. A small trough or perforated shelf should be fitted to the  
inside of the communion rail, about 50 mm or 65 mm deep and  
slightly lower than the top of the rail, where communicants may  
place the empty wine glasses. See also Section 10, for dimen-  
sions of communion rails.  
All other main services are similar to Church of England prac-  
tice and the architectural requirements are the same, although a  
credence table is not required near the communion table  
# 8 BAPTIST CHURCH AND BAPTISTRIES  
# 8.1 Introduction  
There are two major differences between this denomination and  
most other long-established denominations. The less visible dis-  
tinction is that there is no binding or universal Statement of Faith;  
every congregation is in principle free to determine its beliefs based  
on its understanding of the Bible, though there may be constraints  
on this freedom set out in the trust deeds of the church.  
The more visible difference is the practice of deferring baptism  
to an age at which the person is able to make his or her own deci-  
sion to be baptised, typically 13 or older with no upper age limit.  
This practice \(referred to as ‘Believer’s Baptism’\) is shared by  
other churches such as some of the United Reformed Church and  
many independent churches, but in Baptist churches infant baptism  
is never offered, whereas other denominations will usually offer  
infant or adult baptism as alternatives.  
LEPs which involve a Baptist congregation will normally offer  
both infant and adult baptism – if the premises in question were not  
originally built for Baptist worship they may seek to introduce a  
baptistry, or accept other arrangements which could include a port-  
able pool \(see what follows\) – or hiring the local swimming baths  
for a service including adult baptism.  
The adult, known as ‘candidate’, is baptised by total immersion  
in public ceremony in the context of a service of worship. This  
requires the church to have a baptistry appropriate for such use,  
Figure 31.15, unless they are prepared to accept one of the alterna-  
tives mentioned.  
**31.15** *Baptistry pool for adult baptism as used in Baptist*  
*Churches, LEPs incorporating Baptist congregations and some*  
*others\: a\) section, b\) plan*  
# 8.2 Baptismal ceremony  
The minister will enter the baptistry first, followed by the candi-  
date. If more than one candidate is to be baptised they will be dealt  
with one at a time. The minister may speak briefly, and the can-  
didate may also make a personal statement \(or may have done so  
earlier in the service\). It follows that that minister and candidate  
should be visible while standing in the baptistry, ideally at least  
from the shoulders up. If only the head is visible, the effect can  
become somewhat incongruous. The candidate turns to face the  
steps \(unless there are steps at both ends of the baptistry\) for the  
practical reason that they will be unable to see clearly when leav-  
ing the baptistry, due to water in their eyes. The minister faces the  
congregation.  
The minister then supports the candidate by the shoulders, pro-  
nounces a blessing, lowers the candidate backwards into the water,  
submerging them completely and immediately raises them again.  
The candidate leaves the baptistry, usually supported or guided  
by the minister and/or other assistants, to ensure they do not trip  
or slip.  
On occasions, and particularly if either the minister is small  
in stature or the candidate is large in stature, the minister may be  
assisted by another member of the congregation. Exceptionally, if  
the candidate is infirm, they may kneel.  
In recent years, concerns have emerged about the large water  
usage entailed in baptism by immersion; in new installations the  
possibility of subsequent reuse of water from the baptistry in a  
greywater system should be investigated with the church officers.  
In church buildings without a built-in baptistry \(for example  
where a building has been re-purposed\) the cost or the structural  
implications may prevent the installation of a fixed baptistry. In  
such cases, temporary mobile pools have been used successfully,  
both inside and outside the building. In either case, recycling water  
as greywater should be considered. If used internally, the capacity  
of any suspended floor to sustain the loads imposed by a mobile  
pool should be checked by a structural engineer.  
# 8.3 Key dimensions  
• *Width*, absolute minimum 1300 mm, but this is known from  
experience to be inadequate when an assistant is present, and  
1500 mm to 1600 mm is better. The steps need not be the full  
width of the baptistry  
• *Length*, about 3300 mm, determined by the tallest likely candi-  
date \(95th percentile\) plus space to move and clearance at the  
‘head’ end of the baptistry  
• *Depth* \(surrounding floor level to floor of baptistry\), 1200 mm  
or a little less, determined by the shoulder height of minister and  
candidates \(5th percentile\)  
• *Steps*, suggested rise going and step profile to Part ‘M’ of the  
Building Regulations  
Figure 31.15 shows a rectangular plan, but other arrangements  
meeting the functional requirements are acceptable. The views of  
the local congregation should be sought.  
# 8.4 Other functional requirements  
• *The baptistry* may be located either on a dais or in the body of the  
church; it is normally covered by a removable floor when not in  
use. In either case, sightlines should be considered. If in the body  
of the church, consideration should be given to temporary edge  
protection when open to avoid accidents.  
• *The removable floor sections* should be as light and manoeu-  
vrable as practicable. These will normally have to be moved  
by one or two of the congregation who may well be elderly or  
un-athletic, and the design of the floor sections should allow  
for this.  
• *Floor surfaces*. The baptistry base and the steps should have a  
non-slip finish. Adjacent floor surfaces may need protection. • *Water supply* needs to be available to fill the baptistry in a rea-  
sonable time \(less than one hour\), and drainage is needed to  
empty it in about half an hour. The floor of the baptistry should  
fall gently towards the outlet.  
• *The drainage system* should not be embedded or inaccessi-  
ble. With infrequent use, water traps on the drainage line will  
tend to dry out. Any leak in the drainage system or the bap-  
tistry will be discovered at the most inconvenient moment.  
Suppliers should be asked to confirm that their specifications  
allow for long-term dry conditions with occasional use filled.  
The design life of the complete baptistry installation should  
equal the design life of the building without any significant  
maintenance.  
• *Water heating*. It is normal to temper the water temperature; the  
water need not be warm, but should not make the candidates gasp  
on entry! It is probably inefficient to design the main heating  
and hot water system to supply such a large volume of slightly  
warmed water. Portable electric immersion heaters have been  
used, but all fittings will need to be to an appropriate Ingress  
Protection rating.  
• *Changing spaces* are required for candidates and minister, sep-  
arate for opposite sexes, and possibly for the minister. They  
should be close to the room containing the baptistry, and are  
normally in multi-purpose rooms, but consideration should be  
given to privacy.  
# 9 RELIGIOUS SOCIETY OF FRIENDS  
# 9.1 Origins  
The Religious Society of Friends \(Quakers\) originated through  
the experiences and preaching of George Fox \(1624–1691\). Early  
Quakers reacted strongly against the current religious practices and  
liturgy of the established church. All through their history, Quakers  
have been concerned with a sense of duty to the community.  
Because Friends believe that God can communicate with  
humans directly, they do not partake of the outward sacraments.  
They have no separated priesthood, they do not require their mem-  
bers to subscribe to a creed, and their worship does not make use  
of a liturgy. They are, however, in broad agreement with the main  
emphases of Christian belief, and would claim to be both orthodox  
and evangelical.  
# 9.2 Ceremonies and buildings  
In a meeting for worship, Friends gather in silence as a congrega-  
tion of seeking souls, and ‘wait upon the Spirit’. No one directs the  
worship. Out of the ‘gathered’ silence of united worship, one or  
another may be led to engage in vocal ministry or in prayer or to  
read from the scriptures. There is no music or hymn singing.  
The building must be designed to help the quiet worship and  
the vocal ministry of the participants. There is no observance of  
the Lord’s supper or orthodox communion service; no baptism or  
initiation ceremonies involving ritual. There will therefore be no  
need for font, lectern, pulpit or altar.  
Sizes of meeting halls vary, but they will mostly be designed to  
accommodate 50 Friends or fewer. A square, rectangular or polyg-  
onal room may meet the requirements. It is likely that seating will  
be required in a square or a circle. Meetings may prefer fixed or  
movable, tiered or level seating.  
There is no need for a table in the meeting room, though there  
normally is one to act as a focal point. The position is not usually  
literally at the centre of the room; the seating will be arranged in  
the way felt by the group concerned to be most conducive to a  
good meeting for worship, and the table, if placed anywhere, will  
be fitted in with the general arrangement of the room. Its main use  
is for business meetings.  
When not required for worship, Society of Friends meeting  
halls are often used by other denominations, or for secular purposes  
# Places of worship 31-9  
of an appropriate nature. Other accommodation might include a  
multi-purpose hall, library, small kitchen foyer and cloakrooms and  
a caretaker’s flat.  
# 10 UNITARIAN AND FREE CHRISTIAN CHURCH  
# 10.1 Origins  
The roots of the Unitarian movement lie mainly in the Reformation  
of the sixteenth century. The doctrinal ideas challenged included\:  
• Unity or unipersonality of God \(as opposed to the doctrine of the  
Trinity\) – hence the name ‘Unitarian’  
• Humanity, \(as opposed to the deity\) of Christ  
• Worth of human beings \(as opposed to ideas of original sin,  
inherited guilt and innate depravity\)  
• Universal salvation of all souls \(as opposed to the doctrine that  
most of humanity is predestined to damnation\).  
Congregations may be called churches, meetings, chapels or fel-  
lowships. Congregations may meet in their own buildings, in hired  
premises or in private homes. There are around 170 congregations  
in the UK.  
This denomination is included as an example of the simplest  
type of building programme likely to be encountered among places  
of worship.  
# 10.2 Ceremonies and buildings  
Worship usually takes place on Sundays and may be led by a  
Unitarian minister or layperson.  
The flaming chalice is the internationally-recognised symbol  
of the Unitarian movement. This originally appeared informally  
as a piece of corporate identity, but the lighting of a physical  
chalice is increasingly becoming a feature of communal wor-  
ship in Unitarian congregations, and design of buildings for  
Unitarian worship should make provision for this if desired by  
the congregation.  
Other ceremonies include\:  
• Naming ceremonies for infants \(the terms ‘Baptism’ or  
‘Christening’ are not normally used\)  
• Weddings  
• Funerals  
• Communion – this is at the discretion of the congregation.  
Services may include the singing of hymns.  
Unitarian buildings are appropriately simple in design, reflect-  
ing the absence of a formal liturgy. The local congregation should  
be consulted on all aspects of the design. Emphasis should be given  
to the spoken \(and if appropriate sung\) word, and the participation  
and engagement of the whole congregation.  
The layout should be flexible and much of the building is likely  
to be multi-purpose in use. There may be a lectern, and the flaming  
chalice may require a table or other support. Older existing build-  
ings may include a pulpit but this is unlikely to be required in a  
modern building, or the adaption or re-purposing of an existing  
building. There will be no requirement for a font, baptistry, altar or  
communion table. Depending on the size of the congregation and  
building, some or all of the electronic installations referred to in  
section 15.5 below may be required.  
# Part B Design Data  
This section sets out requirements which apply to one or more of  
the church traditions described previously. The Roman Catholic  
and Anglican Churches have the most prescriptive requirements,  
which should be carefully followed. Similar requirements may  
apply to other denominations, but should be verified with local  
church officers and/or their national representative bodies. **31-10 Places of worship**  
# 11 ALTAR OR COMMUNION TABLE  
# 11.1 Symbolism  
The altar symbolises three things\:  
• The body of Christ  
• The altar of sacrifice  
• The table of the Last Supper.  
The Table in the ‘Free’ and Non-conformist traditions symbolises  
only the table of the Last Supper.  
# 11.2 Canon law  
A Church of England altar may be of wood, stone or other suitable  
material and may be movable. It should be covered with silk or other  
‘decent stuff’ during divine services and with a fair white linen cloth  
at Holy Communion. A Roman Catholic altar must be of natural \(not  
reconstructed\) stone with the top member \(the mensa\) in one piece  
and containing the relics of two canonised martyrs or saints. However,  
this requirement may be fulfilled by a small portable altar, which is in  
effect an altar stone often about 300 mm square \(or less\) and 50 mm  
deep containing a sealed cavity \(the sepulchre\) for the relics. The altar  
may be fixed \(stone cemented to the structure\) or unfixed \(timber with  
inset portable stone altar as described\). Only a fixed altar may be con-  
secrated. Alternatively, relics may be sunk into floor below altar.  
**31.16** *Average size of altars. The exact proportions will depend*  
*on its position, and whether the priest is facing the congregation*  
*or has his back to them. Note that the tabernacle containing the*  
*reserved sacrament is not now normally placed on the altar \(see*  
*Section 14\)*  
# 11.5 Supports and coverings  
Methods of supporting the mensa are shown in Figure 31.18. With  
the altar now normally nearer the congregation, the question of  
clothing the altar may need to be rethought. A traditional Church of  
England altar covering is shown in Figure 31.19.  
# 11.3 Position  
The altar must be related to congregational seating in such a way  
that what is done at it is, and is seen to be, a corporate action of the  
whole assembly. Altars are being brought further forward in the  
sanctuary and with congregations grouped around it, there is less  
need for the altar to stand so high as in the past, especially when the  
priest faces the congregation across the altar.  
# 11.4 Size  
For liturgical reasons, altars can be less long but possibly slightly  
deeper than in the past. Average sizes are shown in Figure 31.16  
and anthropometric data in Figure 31.17.  
# 11.6 Footspace  
The platform or base on which the altar rests must be large  
enough for the number of priests expected to stand around while  
celebrating the Eucharist. It may be raised one or two steps  
above the level of the congregation, but in general, the altar  
should be kept as low as possible to avoid any sense of separa-  
tion between it and the people. Possible dimensions are shown  
in Figure 31.20.

# 11.7 Cross and candles  
The exact requirements must be discussed with the priest. Candles  
and cross should not form a barrier between priest and people.  
Some possibilities for the cross are shown in Figures 31.21 and  
31.22; and for the candles in Figure 31.23.  
# 11.8 Communion table  
A communion table with table lectern as used in Presbyterian  
churches is shown in Figure 31.24.  
# 12 SANCTUARY FURNITURE AND PULPIT  
# 12.1 Lectern  
This should be in or near the sanctuary but sufficiently apart  
from the altar to constitute a separate focus, and conveniently  
sited to be accessible to the congregation to read from, Figure  
31.25\. Occasionally two lecterns may be asked for, one each  
side. The lectern must be in a position where everybody can see  
the reader’s face including those within the sanctuary. It may be  
fixed or movable, and it may also serve as a pulpit. Dimensions  
are shown in Figure 31.26. In the case of denominations which  
recognise the ministry of women, or permit women to read dur-  
ing services, design dimensions for lecterns should take account  
of relevant anthropometric data for females. The lectern should  
be adjustable in height – ideally, capable of lowering to the  
appropriate height for a wheelchair user – and the adjustment  
mechanism should be easily operated. Asking a minister or other  
reader of short stature to stand on a box is *not* acceptable. See  
also Section 15.5 below as regards incorporation of laptops or  
other electronics into lecterns.  
# 12.2 Altar rail  
A rail may be dispensed with in some churches, but most will still  
provide lengths of rail for kneeling to receive communion. It need  
not be continuous, but must be rigid and firm. Minimum dimen-  
sions are given in Figures 31.27 and 31.28.

# 12.3 Credence table  
This serves as a sort of sideboard for water and wine, but check  
if anything else is to be placed on it \(e.g. offertory money, ser-  
vice books, etc.\) in which case a shelf below the table may be  
needed. It should be to the right of the celebrant within the sanc-  
tuary but not where it might cause a visual obstruction. It could  
be a shelf instead of a freestanding table. Dimensions will vary  
from about 610 × 760 mm to 1200 × 460 mm, with a minimum  
height of 820 mm.  
**31.28** *Dimensions for altar rail \(i.e. outside central zone of*

# 12.4 Seating for officiants  
These will vary considerably and requirements must be estab-  
lished with the local community. In Roman Catholic churches,  
the ‘president’s seat’ will be on the centre line behind the altar,  
raised up on one or two steps, Figure 31.29. The seat, which is  
used by the priest, must not look like a bishop’s throne and will  
usually not have a back to it. The bishop’s throne is portable,  
and placed in front of the altar whenever he visits the church. In  
Church of England churches, it is often better to have the ceremo-  
nial seat \(which is used by the bishop\) at the side of the sanctuary  
facing the altar.  
Incidental seating should be kept to a minimum. It will be  
needed for additional priests, servers and laypeople on special **31-14 Places of worship**  
occasions. It will usually be in the form of benches at the side of  
the sanctuary.  
Stalls will be needed \(especially in Church of England churches\)  
for priests at matins and evensong at the side of the sanctuary.  
Dimensions are similar to those for congregational seating \(see  
Section 15\) except that as priests are vested they will need more  
room to move in and out. Surface for resting a book should be  
deeper \(say, 300 mm\) and almost horizontal – not sloping – with  
a shelf below.  
**31.29** *Dimensions around the President’s seat*  
# 12.5 Pulpit  
This should be sited outside but close to the sanctuary. No par-  
ticular location is now insisted on apart from functional reasons  
of good sight and sound. Minimum internal area is about 1–2 m2  
.  
Access should desirably be from the side \(if from back, fit a door\).  
Other details are shown in Figure 31.30.  
A ‘Free’ church or Non-conformist pulpit may be behind the  
communion table or at either side. The traditional location of the  
pulpit at high level with its own stepped access was dictated by  
audibility and visibility requirements in a pre-electronic world and  
is to be deprecated on accessibility grounds. See also Section 14.5  
below.  
The reading desk in the pulpit should be adjustable in height  
and the adjustment mechanism should be easily operated. As with  
lecterns, asking a minister of short stature to stand on a box is *not*  
acceptable.  
**31.30** *Pulpit dimensions*  
# 13 FONT  
# 13.1 Description  
In Roman Catholic churches, movable fonts are not permitted and  
they are not generally approved of in the Anglican communion.  
They can, however, be used in Presbyterian and Methodist churches  
and those ‘Free’ and Non-conformist Churches which practise  
infant baptism. In Church of England, ‘Free’ and Non-conformist  
churches, fresh water is used for each baptism. In Roman Catholic  
churches, water is blessed once a year and the baptismal water is  
stored in the font which has two compartments.  
For baptisteries for adult \(’believers’\) baptism see 8.1.  
# 13.2 Dimensions and shape  
Anthropometric requirements are shown in Figure 31.31. Shape is  
governed by the needs of the priest \(space for service book and  
other small objects\), the comfort of the priest in holding the baby,  
and the safety of the baby \(the priest should not have to lean too far  
over\). Where a movable font is permitted, required consideration  
should be given to maximum weight for safe handling. In the case  
of Anglican and other churches which recognise the ministry of  
women and also utilise fixed fonts, design dimensions should take  
account of relevant anthropometric data for females.  
**31.31** *Anthropometric diagram showing the critical action at the*  
*font*  
# 13.3 Position of fixed font  
Various alternative positions are shown in Figure 31.32. The font  
must be approached from the church \(congregation\) side but be  
divided from it in some way \(e.g. by difference in floor or ceiling  
levels, although this would limit access for wheelchair-using clergy  
and/or parents\). It must be in a prominent position and be seen by  
the congregation when seated, or space provided for most of the  
congregation to stand around. It should be a separate focus from the  
altar and therefore possibly not in the sanctuary.  
# 14 RESERVATION OF THE SACRAMENT  
# 14.1 Siting  
The reserved sacrament in Roman Catholic churches \(the con-  
secrated bread of the Eucharist\) is not now normally kept in a  
tabernacle on the altar. It is normally kept  
• In a separate chapel outside the sanctuary  
• In a position which is architecturally important  
• Where its location will be easily recognised by the congregation.  
The requirements are complex and the practice of the local  
church community must be established and agreed with the DAC.  
Figures 31.33 and 31.34 show height limitations.  
The reserved sacrament is occasionally found also in the Church  
of England, but is rarer and many methods of reservation are prac-  
tised. **Places of worship 31-15**  
**31.32** *Variations on font positioning*  
**31.33** *Removing the ciborium chalice from tabernacle and*  
*putting on lower shelf*  
**31.34** *Maximum height to give view of back of tabernacle*  
# 15 GENERAL ARRANGEMENTS  
This section is applicable in principle to all Christian denomina-  
tions, but should always be referred to the relevant church officers  
and/or published denominational guidance for confirmation or  
alternative requirements.  
# 15.1 Entrance requirements  
There are several considerations for designing entrances\:  
• Provide wind lobbies outside entrance doors – consider the use  
of power-operated doors to reduce the chance that they will be  
wedged open at times of peak flow, which would negate their  
purpose. These would need to be overridden for funerals or other  
ceremonial processions to prevent premature closure.  
• Minimum clear door width \(for processions and funerals\) should  
be 1.7 m \(1.1 m in a small church\).  
• Minimum clear height \(for processional cross\) should be 2.3 m,  
otherwise 2.05 m is sufficient. **31-16 Places of worship**  
• Minimum clear height for pallbearers \(of up to 95th percentile  
height \(male\)\) bearing 450 mm high coffin and 450 mm high  
floral tribute is 2.4 m.  
• Provide proper access for disabled people \(see Building  
Regulations Part M in England and equivalent regulations in  
other jurisdictions\). Level access \(including ramped access\)  
should always be provided to the principal entrance, and where  
practicable to other entrances as well.  
• Provide secondary exit door, especially for weddings.  
• Provide gathering spaces inside and outside the church as part of  
the normal exit route where people can naturally gather to talk.  
• Where needed \(especially in RC churches\) place a holy water  
stoup \(basin\) on the entrance side of each doorway leading into  
the church. Rims should be 710 to 760 mm above the floor.  
• Provide considerable space for notices of all types in a conspic-  
uous position.  
• Allow space, where required, for one or two small credence  
tables just inside the entrance.  
• Provide facilities for selling of publications, etc.  
• Where possible, provide access from the entrance area to the WC  
and to the sacristy or vestry.  
• As a general rule, try to keep the purely *secular* activities more  
in view when the congregation is *leaving* than when entering for  
a service.  
# 15.2 Arrangement of seating  
The congregation should be continuous with the minister with no  
strong dividing line between them. Equally, the congregation must  
be united with one another and all must have good access to circu-  
lation and, where it exists, to the sanctuary. Seats facing each other  
around an altar should not be closer than about 6 m, and nobody  
should look sideways on to anybody else closer than 1.5 to 3.0 m.  
# 15.3 Spacing and dimensioning of seats  
Anthropometric details are given in Figure 31.35. Note also\:  
• Minimum dimension of seat plus kneeling space front and back  
is 920 mm. Where congregations do not kneel \(e.g. Methodists,  
Presbyterians, many ‘Free’ and Non-conformist denominations\),  
the dimension can be reduced to 760 mm.  
• Leave a space of about 280 mm between front edge of seat and  
back edge of kneeler.  
• Allow minimum width of 510 mm per person.  
• Maximum length of row is 10 persons \(5.1 m\) with access from  
both ends, or six persons \(3.06 m\) with access from one end; this  
may be further conditioned by applicable Building Regulations  
governing means of escape.  
• The ledge for hymn books should be about 150 mm wide \(300  
mm for the choir\); but given the increased use of printed hymn  
sheets or service sheets, and video display of words, hymn books  
may not be required.  
**31.35** *Critical dimensions for seating. Black lines indicate*  
*one particular solution found very satisfactory in practice. The*  
*dotted line indicates ‘eye’ level when sitting, and concerns the*  
*relationship with the altar top*  
# 15.4 Circulation  
Basic dimensions are shown in Figure 31.36. Space must be  
allowed for wheelchairs and walking aids during the service where  
users can participate fully in the service, accompanied by their fam-  
ily and/or carers without blocking circulation. This is, of course, far  
easier to accomplish with unfixed seating.  
**31.36** *Aisle widths. Size and pattern will depend on overall plan and liturgical considerations. Seating may be fan shaped or in blocks*  
*around the sanctuary* **15.5 Sound and video systems**  
Most churches now use systems of sound amplification of speech,  
singing and instrumental music. The use of wireless microphones  
and lapel microphones have liberated ministers and other worship  
leaders from being tied to the lectern and pulpit, and can also assist  
in congregational participation, where this is desired. Induction  
loop systems for hearing aid users can be transformative for those  
who rely on them. The traditional locations of lectern and pulpit  
were determined largely by audibility and visibility requirements,  
and the changed circumstances are now affecting their design and  
location to the extent that there is some question whether they are  
needed at all. This can greatly increase the flexibility available, par-  
ticularly where the worship function shares a multi-use space.  
In addition to sound reinforcement, the use of video technology  
is now also being applied in places of worship. This includes\:  
• Playing video clips published, or pre-recorded, for the specific  
service  
• Displaying words of hymns, \(possibly in lieu of hymn books or  
printed service sheets\) readings and responses etc.  
• Notes to reinforce the spoken content of sermons and addresses  
• In larger auditoria, providing an enlarged view of the speaker  
and other participants  
• Relaying proceedings to other rooms in the premises  
• Relaying the service to members of the congregation unable to  
visit the church premises as a result of illness or disability, either  
as a recording or ‘live’ via the internet.  
The design and planning of new or altered church premises should  
provide for sound amplification and induction loop systems, and –  
if required – video installations from the outset, which have signifi-  
cant implications for natural and artificial lighting design.  
However, with the introduction of these technologies, the sight  
of a hapless member of the congregation struggling to master a  
professional sound mixing desk has become a common embarrass-  
ment. Professional advice should be sought, and the requirements  
discussed with church officers. In smaller premises at least, the  
use of a public-address amplifier without a mixing desk may be  
perfectly adequate. The specification for an induction loop system  
should always include the equipment \(usually a receiver and head-  
phones\) necessary for a non-hearing impaired person to test that the  
induction loop is actually working.  
The design of lecterns may be required to accommodate laptop  
computers and connections or other management systems to con-  
trol sound and video systems.

difficult. The vestry could be near the entrance \(but ensure secu-  
rity\) so that priest and procession go through the congregation to  
their place in the sanctuary. Since children often participate in adult  
worship for only part of its duration, movement between the main  
worship space and ancillary rooms should be considered.  
There should be a lobby with double doors between the choir  
vestry and the worship room, and a space out of sight of the con-

is essential as priests and choir should not have to go through the  
worship room to reach their vestries.  
# 16.3 Detailed design  
There is a very wide range of objects and vestments to be stored  
and the precise requirements must be ascertained. A vestment  
storage cupboard is shown in Figure 31.37. Doorways should be  
1700 mm wide × 2300 mm high.
