# 3.7 Steps in interior design  
• Brief, terms of reference\: scope, aims, guidance, requirements,  
programme  
• Sketches, proposals\: design concept, visual ideas, preliminary  
estimates  
• Schematic drawings\: perspectives, images, key features  
• Sample board\: selected materials, finishes  
• Detailed drawings\: scaled drawings for construction and instal-  
lations  
• Specifications\: requirements, quality, quantities  
• Suppliers\: sources, costs, discounts, replacements  
• Contracts\: conditions, coverage of work, critical dates.  
# 3.8 Maintenance and life cycle planning  
Food and beverage service areas are subject to intensive use, break-  
age, spillage and damage requiring daily cleaning and frequent  
replacement or substitution. Carpets and finishes are selected to  
camouflage scratching or staining. Furniture and equipment must be  
durable and retain good appearance over the planned lifetime of use.  
Flexibility may be required to adapt to variable needs such as  
table groupings and re-arrangements or changes in service style  
from daytime to evening dining or for entertainment. This will call  
for furniture stacking and equipment storage facilities  
The life cycle of a restaurant will be affected by many factors  
such as changes in the surroundings, fashion and meal preferences;  
increasing competition; decline in standards and obsolescence.  
Kitchen equipment is usually planned for 7 years usage but  
furniture and furnishings may need replacement in 5 years. In plan-  
ning major refurbishments, it is opportune to revise the original  
# 4 FOOD PRODUCTION AREAS  
# 4.1 Size and type  
The size of the kitchen depends on the number of seats \(covers\)  
served at the peak period of demand – lunch or evening. It will  
also vary with the type of the menu and the extent to which food  
is prepared in advance. With a fixed menu, equipment and labour  
can be rationalised and ready-prepared food enables the kitchen to  
concentrate on finishing the meals to order. Conventional kitch-  
ens providing a varying \(usually cyclical\) range of menu choice  
are required in institutions and employee catering. They are also  
required in high-class restaurants and hotels and have a size ratio of  
0.3 to 0.5\:1 in relation to the size of the dining area. Convenience  
food is prepared in advance in bulk in central kitchens and chilled  
or frozen for distribution and storage prior to use \(see Section 2.1\).  
This allows economies of scale, larger, purpose designed equipment  
and factory type processing. Finishing kitchens can be reduced in  
size and equipment with a size ratio of 0.1 to 0.3\: 1 in relation to the  
size of storage and dishwashing.  
Examples of kitchen areas are indicated in Table IV. Space  
requirements in large kitchens show the economies of scale by cen-  
tralisation \(Figure 33.14\). In large hotels, a central food production  
and dishwashing area may be located to serve a number of alter-  
native restaurants directly or by circulation to more remote outlets  
such as in room service and banquet serveries.  
# 4.2 Goods access  
For sizes of vehicles, see Chapter 38. Typical delivery arrange-  
ments are\:  
• Dry goods\: weekly or fortnightly  
• Frozen goods\: weekly  
• Vegetables and fresh fruit\: twice weekly  
• Perishable foods\: daily  
• Refuse and waste removal\: depends on size and contract\: weekly.  
Large premises use bulk refuse containers \(0.57 m2–0.85 m2\)  
together with separate bottle, broken glass, metal compaction and **33-8 Restaurants and food service facilities**  
**33.12** *Typical counter and table service dimensions*  
packaging storage areas. Food waste must be sited in a refrigerated  
area \(3–5° C\) with suitable screening, vermin exclusion, washing  
facilities and drainage.  
# 4.3 Storage areas  
Storage depends on throughput and frequency of deliveries. Cold  
stores are grouped together and preferably entered through chilled  
holding areas to save energy. Floor slabs may need to be recessed  
to allow level wheeled entry to the store. Vegetable stores have  
direct access to their preparation area.  
Purpose designed movable racks are used in food stores. Racks and  
shelves should allow about 50 mm between and above packages for  
easy access. The top shelf should not be higher than 1800 mm and the  
lowest at least 200 mm above floor \(Figure 33.15\). Shelves for heavy  
and frequently used items are best between 700 and 1500 mm high.  
Space may be required for containers awaiting return to suppliers. **Restaurants and food service facilities 33-9**  
**33.13** *Dimensions for various tables and local seating densities*

Kitchen areas and layout are determined by\:

• Space for working access and circulation.

• Work top and sink rim height 870–900 mm  
• Wall bench width 600–750 mm  
• Island bench or table width 900–1050 mm  
• Length of work area with convenient reach 1200–1800 mm.

• Fresh vegetables, salads and fruit

Note\: Preparation, cooking and dishwashing take up about 50 per cent of the total  
kitchen areas. Storage, service and staff facilities the remainder.  
Specialised operations may require separate bakery and cake dec-

rooms, by low walls 1200 mm high between the areas and main  
kitchen or the grouping of benches and fittings in specific areas  
around the sides \(Figure 33.16\). Cross-contamination of food must  
be avoided and adequate work space with separate sinks provided  
in each area as well as for pan washing. **33-10 Restaurants and food service facilities**

# 4.5 Cooking equipment  
About 30 per cent of the kitchen floor is occupied by equipment,  
10–20 per cent by benches and trolleys and 50 per cent for cir-  
culation and access. Crowded space can lead to obstruction and  
accidents but excess space adds to circulation cleaning, energy and  
maintenance costs \(Figure 33.17\).  
Details of typical modern equipment are given in Table V.  
Size and duty is related to output and most ovens are designed to  
receive gastronorm sizes of dishes and trays. Some items are shown  
\(Figure 33.18\). Combination ovens incorporate both steam and hot  
air convection modes. Other accelerated cooking includes micro-  
wave power with hot air convection. Vitreoceramic induction hobs  
may be used instead of open burners.  
A typical kitchen layout is shown in Figure 33.19 with eleva-  
tions in Figure 33.20.  
Back-bar equipment fitted along a wall behind the serving coun-  
ter is common in small kitchens and for finishing meals enabling  
savings in engineering services, space and labour. Island grouping  
in the centre is better in larger units giving easier access from all  
areas, cleaning and maintenance. Engineering services, including  
fume extraction and floor drainage, are concentrated and perimeter  
sites can be used for refrigerators, storage, preparation areas and  
**33.16** *Alternative preparation area arrangements \(see 33.31 for*  
*key to numbers\)*  
service counters. The minimum aisle width is 1050 mm but may  
need to be increased to 1500 mm to allow for cooker door swings  
or if trolleys are used.  
# 4.6 Dishwashing  
Dishwashing is expensive in terms of space, equipment, labour and  
energy costs. Disposables may be used in fast-food and transport  
catering but give a poor image and problems in disposal. Methods  
of collection for used dishes include self-removal with trays, trol-  
leys or waiter removal. This must be decided at the initial planning  
stage. Trolleys will require straight aisles with minimum 1050 mm  
width and screened trolley parks. **33.17** *Minimum space between equipment for working and*  
*circulation*  
# Restaurants and food service facilities 33-11  
Manual dishwashing in a double sink is inefficient and unhygienic  
for public food services. Spray machines may be intermittent or  
continuous through-flow and designed for corner \(small kitchens\)  
or in line position \(Figure 33.21\). Water softening is often used and  
modern machines incorporate energy and water saving devices.  
Space is required for depositing soiled dishes, scraping/spraying  
and loading as well as separate unloading sections. Trolley spaces  
should be allowed for return of clean dishes and utensils to the  
servery. Typical sizes for tableware are given in Table VI and  
allowances for dishwashing spaces are show in Table VII.  
# 4.7 Serveries  
Arrangements for plating and serving food depend on the type and  
scale of operation. In each case, circulation routes must be planned.  
Counters are designed to avoid risk of accidents, spillages and con-  
tamination, keep food hot, cool or chilled and retain an attractive  
hygienic presentation of the foods on offer.  
# Table V Kitchen equipment  
*\(continued\)* **33-12 Table V \(continued\)**  
# Restaurants and food service facilities  
*Waiter/waitress service*  
Service counter sited within the production area with hot, cold and  
refrigerated sections, shelves for plates and dishes and adjacent  
pantry area for supplementary serving items. Provided with a lobby  
which must be noise and glare screened from the dining area and  
have separate in-out doors, opening in direction of flow. May be  
supplemented by\:  
• Sideboard\(s\) within dining area  
• Side table or trolley circulation, including flambé preparation/  
service at the table  
• Featured display cooking section for special dishes  
• Family service or self-selection from dishes brought to the table.  
*Self-service*  
Serving counter arranged for self-selection of meal items with  
planned circulations for customers and food replacement \(Figure  
33.22\). Display counters arranged in sequence of meal choice.  
Variations include\:  
• Cafeteria style service for high throughput and sales promotion  
• Food hall and food court service with alternative counters and a  
common seating area  
• Temporary or installed buffet presentations, including assisted  
service at the counter  
• Snack and/or beverage vending machines with or without seat-  
ing areas.  
*Central service*  
Distribution of centrally prepared dishes as hot, chilled or frozen  
foods to other locations for service. Central production calls for a  
fully integrated system, with standardised containers, equipment,  
transport and controls. Examples include\:  
• Commissary systems to supply meals to finishing kitchens and  
in transit  
• Hospital systems to distribute meals to wards and individual  
patients  
• Banqueting systems to prepare meals in advance of functions  
• Central production of convenience foods for catering and res-  
taurant outlets.  
# 4.8 Facilities for staff  
Employee ratios vary widely with the type of establishment and  
demand. The ratio of total employees to meals served over the peak  
period is about one employee to eight meals served for full-menu,  
table service restaurants, 20 meals in limited menu table service  
and institutions, and 33 or more in fast-food outlets. Changing  
rooms, lockers and sanitary facilities are required for total full and  
part-time employees.  
# 5 RESTAURANTS  
# 5.1 Investment  
Commercial restaurants are affected by location, image, associa-  
tion and publicity. Location is critical in dictating the catchment  
area and potential market which may be based on local or tran-  
sient customers. The image and association helps to create demand.  
However, sustained success depends on the customers’ valuation  
of the meal experience.  
Commercial restaurants are notoriously subject to fashion. They  
tend to have a short life, not often more than 8 years, and both  
the types of food served and facilities may need to be frequently  
changed. Investment has to be recovered within the planned life  
cycle period, requiring careful control of finance and operation.  
Full-service, high-class restaurants are only 5 per cent of  
establishments. The mid-market range includes steak and seafood  
restaurants, grilles, brasseries and most international restaurants.  
Commercial restaurants usually offer table service but self-service  
\(see Section 6.1\) from attractive counter displays is common in  
departmental stores and some of the larger mid-market restaurants  
for convenience and sales promotion.  
# 5.2 International restaurants  
In Britain, the increase of international restaurants – particularly  
Chinese and Indian/Pakistani – has displaced many of the tradi-  
tional establishments. International restaurants are the main choice  
for evening dining. Design is often symbolic rather than authentic  
and it is essential to research the types of foods, spices, traditional  
preparation and cooking methods represented. Specialist cooking  
equipment is often required to supplement the standard range nor-  
mally used and in international hotels separate Western, Oriental **Restaurants and food service facilities 33-13**  
**33.18** *Kitchen equipment \(continued over\)* **33-14 Restaurants and food service facilities**  
**33.18** *Kitchen equipment \(continued\)* **Restaurants and food service facilities 33-15**  
**33.19** *Kitchens of Post House Hotel, Sevenoaks. Development\: Trust House Forte Ltd. Plans prepared by Stangard Ltd \(see key in*  
*33.31\)*  
and other types of finishing kitchens are required to serve the vari-  
ety of restaurants provided \(Figure 33.23\).  
International restaurants cover a wide range of quality and  
sophistication. The range of food choice is ever increasing with  
travel, holidays abroad and migration. Chinese food divides  
into four regions\: Canton, Peking, Szechuan and Shanghai. The  
kitchens need to provide the extensive menus which can be up  
to 300 items. ‘Indian’ food is strongly spiced and much of it  
can be cooked by standard equipment although special ovens  
may also be used. Japanese food is subtle\: preparation and  
service are seen as an art form and used as part of the presenta-  
tion. Scandinavian food usually requires a counter display of  
smoked food, fish and cold meats. Greek restaurants are often  
designed as peasant-style tavernas and this approach is common  
in Turkish, Mexican, Spanish, Thai and other popular interna-  
tional restaurants. These traditionally use family service with a  
series of communal food dishes brought to the table. Italian food  
is more universal ranging from themed trattorie to specialised  
pizza chain outlets with purpose designed ovens and preparation  
areas \(Figure 33.24\).  
# 6 CAFETERIAS AND FOOD HALLS  
# 6.1 Cafeterias  
Self-service is mainly used in employee, educational and insti-  
tutional catering, airports, motorway service stations and other  
locations which serve large numbers of people at peak meal times  
or in which time for meals is limited.  
Characteristics\:  
# 5.3 Cafes, coffee bars and snack bars  
Typically, these have limited space and seating. The menu range of  
food offered is short and simply produced, normally operated with  
counter service and back-bar equipment. Beverages are an impor-  
tant product, particularly in the more specialised coffee bar chains.  
Cafes tend to emphasise a domestic character and are often located  
in shopping and visitor areas. Snack bars and sandwich bars have  
very restricted seating areas and primarily cater for local work-  
ers and others requiring snack meals or takeaway food prepared  
to order. Compact table or booth areas and/or counter seating are  
used. Chains of specialist coffee bars have expanded into almost  
every town using standard designs and equipment which offer a  
quick service of selected coffee beverages and pastries in comfort-  
able surroundings.  
• Scale of operation\: usually large numbers of meals served allow-  
ing economies of scale in production.  
• Concentrated demand\: a short service period or limited time  
available for a meal demands a high rate of service with  
minimum delay. Above 600 meals per day, free-flow and mul-  
ti-counter service is practical and the counters are often grouped  
in a food hall separate from the seating areas.  
• Space\: counters add 0.2–0.3 m2 to area per seat in the dining room.  
• The average rate of customer flow through a single counter is  
six to nine persons per minute, dictated mainly by the speed of  
beverage service, cash payments and variety of menu choice.  
• By-pass arrangements, duplication of the counter and cash point  
can increase the flow to 14–16 persons per minute. Beverage  
service may be in a separate area.  
• Larger numbers require multi-counter choices, each serving par-  
ticular types of meals and these may be arranged in a food hall  
separate from the seating areas.  
• The layout must allow for direct access to the production area for  
easy food replacement.  
• Menus\: balanced to meet nutritional standards. The extent of  
choice will determine counter layout and length.  
• Counter sections are heated or refrigerated and fitted out for food  
holding and display. Critical features are the design of tray slides,  
easy access to the food items with protection from contamination.  
• Cash-out desks are sited at or near the end of the service lines, dupli-  
cated where necessary and fitted with tray slide waiting areas. Cutlery,  
condiment and so on stands must be sited to avoid congestion. **33-16 Restaurants and food service facilities**  
**33.20** *Elevations of installed kitchen equipment \(continued opposite\)*  
Self-service arrangements require seating areas to be  
arranged in regular order with wide aisles, particularly in the cir-  
culation to and from the serving counters. Self-clearance or/and  
trolleys may be used. Furniture must be durable, easily cleaned  
and retain good appearance. Counter arrangements are shown  
in Figures 33.25, 33.26 and 33.27 indicate equipment require-  
ments although these will depend on the type and range of menu.  
To minimise food handling, counters are designed to receive  
standard gastronorm containers \(Figure 33.28\). An example of  
a midsized employee cafeteria is shown in Figure 33.29 and a  
large hospital arrangement in Figure 33.30 with the standard key  
for three kitchens in Figure 33.31. A large-scale, multi-choice  
layout is illustrated in Figure 33.32 and a large employee service  
in Figure 33.33.

Food is delivered to outlets ready prepared, portioned and frozen or  
chilled. The entire procedure is tightly controlled and unsold hot food  
kept only a fixed period then discarded. Employees have specific roles  
as till operators, backers and crew. Disposable containers are used for  
all food and beverage items and suitably designed waste receptacles  
and cleaning services must be provided in store and the vicinity.  
Depending on the type of outlet, most fast-food stores also pro-

grouped clear from the takeaway routes and may be on upper or  
lower floors. Seating areas are designed for a high turnover, with  
self-service and self-clearance. Arrangements include fixed tables  
and seats, loose seats and wall counter seating. High standards of  
hygiene, cleaning and maintenance are important in system design.  
Trends are towards health conscious eating with emphasis on lower  
fat, salt and sugar products and additional choice of salads, vege-  
tarian, fresh fruit, yoghurt and real juices.  
pizza, pies and pastries to pre-packed sandwiches and vended bev-

popular and international restaurants also offer a takeaway facility,  
some with home delivery.  
# 7.3 Food courts  
Food courts are provided to offer a wider range of choice with a  
number of food outlets serving alternative products grouped around  
a common seating area. They may be provided in shopping centres,  
airports, universities and other places where the demand is high.  
Serving counters are backed by end-cooking, preparation and stor-  
age areas supplied from a service corridor \(Figure 33.34\).  
# 7.4 Other food service outlets  
Food and refreshment services are required by motorists, coaches and  
truck drivers. These are mainly grouped with filling stations, lodges and  
other services at convenient stopping places along main routes, near  
major junctions and within scenic tourist attractions \(Figure 33.34\).  
Snack bars, most delicatessens and food shops offer food ready  
for consumption off the premises. This may range from products  
freshly prepared, baked or cooked to order, including fish and chips,  
# 8 PUBLIC HOUSES  
# 8.1 Licensing  
The requirements of public houses and wine bars are different from  
other food service outlets in that alcohol sales are the dominant  
rather than a subsidiary activity. Licenses to sell alcoholic liquor  
are granted only if the applicant and premises are suitable for the  
purpose. Safety, means of escape, sanitary facilities and separa-  
tion of bars from other areas must be approved before a license  
is granted as well as approval of any structural alterations before  
renewal. Few new public houses are built. The majority of works  
are alterations to update the facilities and provide food services.  
# 8.2 Separation  
Pubs require two separate parts\:  
• Public areas\: bars, lounges, dining areas, toilets and circulation  
used by customers  
• Private areas\: serveries, storage \(cellars\), kitchen and accommo-  
dation used by staff.  
Most pubs traditionally offer a choice of public bar and lounge  
areas. Drink storage areas must be easily accessible to each bar  
servery. Access to the kitchen is required for taking food orders  
from the counter and serving food directly to the dining area.  
The main pub entrance and secondary entrances from car parks  
are usually through lobbies to control temperature and air condi-  
tioning. Facilities must provide suitably located toilets of adequate  
size, separated for men, women and disabled and entered through  
a screened, ventilated lobby. Relationships between areas are illus-  
trated \(Figure 33.35\) in a modernised town pub. **33-20 Restaurants and food service facilities**  
**33.26** *Servery equipment*  
# 8.3 Pub meals  
Most pubs offer meals to boost their sales by attracting a wider  
clientele and increased use of existing facilities and staff. Usually  
a separate room or area of the lounge is used for food service with  
access \(directly or via food hoist\) to the kitchen. In country inns,  
glass-house extensions are common to extend the space into a  
garden environment. Most menus are standardised around popu-  
lar choices with daily special additions to add variety – often with  
blackboard listings. Much of the food is bought in ready prepared.  
Kitchens are typically fitted with back-bar equipment \(e.g. micro-  
wave oven, grill, griddle, convection oven, boiling hob\), together  
with preparation worktops, sinks, dishwasher, under-bench cup-  
boards and refrigerators including chilled salad and food counters.  
An example of a pub conversion is shown \(Figure 33.36\).  
**33.25** *Alternative arrangements for self-service counters*  
# 8.4 Drink storage and bars  
Traditional drink storage is in naturally cool cellars with CO2  
pressure or pumps to transfer ale and other brewed drinks from  
metal kegs or barrels to ground floor bars. Access to adjacent truck  
bays must be provided for deliveries \(Figures 33.37, 33.38, 33.39,  
33.40\). Temperature control is critical and cooling may be required **Restaurants and food service facilities 33-21**

of drinks.  
Drink serveries are usually centrally located to serve more than  
one room and provide a bar counter, and back-bar fitting with work  
space between having access to the bar store. Counter lengths vary  
but the height and width are standard. A worktop with inset sink is  
provided below the counter top and dispense points. The back bar  
is designed as a decorative feature and includes a sideboard with  
cooled shelves, a display for spirits \(‘optics’\), wine and glasses, cash  
register, cooler and glass washing machine \(Figures 33.42, 33.43\).  
An alternative choice of bars is often provided and one may be  
adapted for food service. A high proportion of drinkers stand at  
the bar and stools may be fitted or loose. Traditional pub tables are  
heavy, with cast iron base or wood frame, and used with peninsular  
seating and stools.  
Depending on trade, drinking bars often provide a large screen  
television for sports interests and areas may be set aside for darts,  
pool, game machine\(s\) and a piano \(Figure 33.44\). Located mainly  
in city commercial districts, wine bars are more upmarket and often  
offer a bistro-type food outlet. Cocktail bars are sophisticated in  
design and service style, usually associated with high class dining  
facilities, hotels and clubs.  
# 8.5 Clubs  
Clubs tend to specialise in late entertainment together with sales  
of beverages. Food may be served as in night clubs. In each case,  
the design is specific to create the desired atmosphere and mode **33-24 Restaurants and food service facilities**

of operation. Entertainers require changing rooms with direct

systems with programmed control equipment are required as well  
as discotheque music centres. A traditional bandstand is illus-  
trated \(Figure 33.45\).  
# 9 HOTELS AND RESORTS  
# 9.1 Hotels and cruise ships  
Hotels are graded according to the quality of accommodation,  
price and range of services offering to guests. The extent of res-  
taurant provision will also depend on the location and number **Restaurants and food service facilities 33-25**

A high-grade city centre hotel with more than 200 rooms will

\(Figure 33.47\).

# 9.2 Resorts and attractions  
Self-contained holiday centres and villages offer food service  
options, ranging from all-inclusive to self-catering facilities. In  
a large complex, a variety of themed restaurants, cafes, bars and  
other outlets is provided, often operated independently under

restaurants as part of the facilities. These are invariably operated by  
catering contractors who supply the food partially or fully prepared

# Lucy Dewick-Tew and Eddie Miles  
*Lucy Dewick-Tew is an associate and Eddie Miles is the CEO of Hyphen, a leading retail architectural practice*.  
*KEY POINTS*  
• *Retail is a fast-moving and competitive sector, where store*  
*fit-outs are changed or updated more frequently than in other*  
*sectors*  
• *The growth in online sales has forced retailers to reconsider the*  
*need for physical stores, and if stores are to be built, to reassess*  
*their purpose*  
• *Major brands are looking to experience-led retail to distinguish*  
*their physical retail offer from their online offer*  
• *Pop-up stores and temporary sites are increasingly being used*  
*to test new retail concepts*

Those retailers maintaining a viable and sustainable physical  
presence in the high street or mall are increasingly looking towards  
technology to better understand their customers and their behav-  
iour. The combination of customer tracking and machine learning  
has given retailers better insights into customer demographics,  
footfall, dwell time, conversion rate and loyalty.  
# 1.3 Retail locations  
The area of retail space in occupation in 2020 in the UK was  
77.1 billion m² \(source\: Cushman & Wakefield, July 2020\). High  
street stores accounted for 36.8 billion m², shopping centres and  
malls for 17.6 billion m² and retail parks for 10.7 billion m². The  
remaining areas are found in transport hubs, stand-alone sites and  
other minor developments.  
Changes in the town planning legislation since 1996 mean that  
the development of new regional malls on greenfield or brownfield  
sites has now ceased. Recent shopping centre developments have  
therefore tended to sit within the existing retail districts of towns  
and cities where they are seen as key components of urban regen-  
eration.  
Transport hubs have become increasingly important to retailers,  
particularly in airports where greater amounts of airside retail space  
have been provided by airport operators.  
The Office for National Statistics defines a high street as a clus-  
ter of 15 or more retail addresses located within 150 metres of one  
another, and calculates that there are almost 7000 high streets in the  
UK. They are the location where the greatest number and variety  
of stores are found, with around one-third of all UK high street  
addresses being occupied by a retailer \(source\: Office for National  
Statistics\).  
# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 General  
Retail outlets comprise buildings, rooms or other spaces from  
which goods and services are sold to the public. Wholesale, or busi-  
ness-to-business sales are usually excluded from the field of retail  
design, as are buildings concerned with the fulfilment of online orders.  
# 1.2 Retail in the United Kingdom  
The proportion of online sales has risen steadily since 2008, when  
it stood at 5 per cent of the total value of sales, to 20 per cent of the  
£378 billion total in 2019 \(source\: Office for National Statistics\).  
In 2020 during the coronavirus pandemic, the proportion of  
online sales exceeded 30 per cent of the total value of retail sales.  
Typically, retail activity contributes around 5 per cent to the UK’s  
GDP and is responsible for around 10 per cent of the UK’s employ-  
ment \(source\: Moody’s Analytics\).  
In the face of the rising cost of maintaining ‘brick and mortar’  
or physical stores, retailers are particularly sensitive to maximising  
sales during the ‘golden quarter’, or the three months leading to  
Christmas and New Year and including Black Friday. The latter is  
now embedded in the UK shoppers’ psyche, having been imported  
as a sales event from the USA in 2013. As commercial pressures  
have increased on retailers, the number of retail outlets has stead-  
ily declined and by the end of 2019, the vacancy rate stood at  
around 10 per cent \(source\: Springboard Research\). In 2020, the  
UK Government announced its intention to change town planning  
legislation to make it easier to change the use of retail premises.  
This is likely to accelerate the irreversible loss of retail sites in the  
UK’s high streets.

# 2 TERMINOLOGY  
# 2.1 Shopping activities  
The majority of retail activity is conducted through physical stores.  
The remaining activity is non-store retail comprising online, mail  
order and teleshopping. Many retailers operate in an omni-channel  
environment where sales are promoted and achieved through both  
actual and virtual marketplaces, social media and other communi-  
cation touch points.  
# 2.2 Retail sub-sectors  
The UK Standard Industrial Classification \(SIC\) categorises  
economic activity into various types as shown in Table I. This clas-  
sification provides a framework for a statistical analysis of retail  
activity which is used for the reporting of indices such as the retail  
price index \(RPI\).  
# 2.3 Locations  
Retailing in the UK exists in a wide variety of locations that are a  
result of historic development over many hundreds of years and  
more recently determined by local and national development poli-  
cies. The main ones are described next.

\*UK SIC 2007 code.  
*High street*  
The majority of all physical retail sites are located in high  
streets. These are found in towns and cities and might include  
the street frontage of shopping centres. High streets contain a  
variety of non-retail uses including, food and beverage outlets,  
professional services offices, residential, leisure and entertain-  
ment venues.  
*Urban fringe*  
This is often brownfield land or land parcels within redevelopment  
zones. Large format stores are typical occupiers, including super-  
markets, DIY stores and discount stores.  
*Out of town*  
These sites are located close to motorway or main road junc-  
tions, allowing easy access to a large population catchment.  
Occupiers include the UK’s major regional malls, shopping  
centres and outlet villages offering food and beverage alongside  
leisure operators.  
Retail locations are analysed and selected against a number of  
criteria.  
*Catchment*  
This is the size of population within a given distance of the site and  
the socio-economic and demographic profile of that population. As  
well as the permanent population, consideration is also given to  
seasonal or tourist shoppers.  
*Accessibility*  
This is the proximity to and availability of public transport, journey  
times and car parking provision.  
*Attractions*  
These are the range of goods, services and other attractions within  
a given location.  
*Deterrents*  
These include development costs and lease conditions.  
*Economic*  
saturation.  
These criteria consider the maturity of the market and market  
# 2.4 Selling methods  
*Personal service*  
This is individual service, typically over counters or desks by sales  
staff in attendance. Examples include watches and jewellery, spe-  
cialist stores, trade counters, delicatessens, food counters.  
*Self-selection*  
In this method, customers handle, compare and select merchandise  
prior to taking them to a point of sale for payment, for example in  
a department store.  
*Self-service*  
In this method, groceries and durables are collected in baskets  
or trolleys and taken to the point of sale for payment. Examples  
include supermarkets and discount stores.  
*Assisted service*  
This involves personal service or self-selection combined with the  
dispatch of goods from stockroom or warehouse for collection or  
home delivery. Examples include white goods stores and furniture  
stores.  
*Fulfilment by store*  
In this click and collect service, merchandise is ordered and paid  
for in advance and collected in store. Examples include department  
stores, home & DIY stores.  
# 2.5 Retail operations  
*Small independent*  
Owner-operated stores with no headquarters or centralised man-  
agement, and usually comprising no more than three separate stores  
or retail outlets. *Large independent*  
Privately owned retail business, but with centralised management  
or under the control of a head office. Usually comprising up to ten  
stores, but can be considerably larger.  
*Multiple*  
Usually publicly-quoted companies under the management of a  
board of directors. Usually comprising ten or more stores and often  
with a nationwide or global presence. These often sell their own  
branded merchandise.  
*Concessions*  
These are retail businesses granted the right to trade from within a  
larger retail operation such as a department store or mall concourse  
in consideration of rent, fees or a percentage of profit.  
*Franchises*  
The brand’s trademark, store design, sales methodology and mer-  
chandise are established by the franchisor, who receives a fee and  
royalties from a franchisee who trades under the brand’s name and  
identity.  
# 2.6 Calculating retail areas  
• Gross leasable area \(GLA\)\: the total area of all floors capable  
of being occupied for exclusive use, excluding public areas,  
lift shafts, service risers but may include shared areas such as  
WC cores. GLA is measured to the inside finished surface of  
the outside walls \(including storefronts\) and to the centreline of  
dividing partitions.  
• Net sales area \(NSA\)\: the total area within the store to which the  
public has access or from where sales are made. This includes  
display windows, other display areas, fitting rooms, serving coun-  
ters, point of sale desks and the areas behind used by serving staff.  
NSA is used to calculate a store’s turnover density \(sales per m²\).  
• In Terms of Zone A \(ITZA\)\: this is a method for calculating the  
rental value of a retail property that acknowledges the higher worth  
of floor space adjacent to the display window where merchandise  
will be more easily seen by passing customers. The floor plan is  
divided into zones, each with a depth of 20 feet \(6.1 m\) with Zone  
A nearest the storefront valued at the highest rate. Zone B is valued  
at half the value of the Zone A, Zone C is valued at half of Zone  
B, and so on. This form of valuation usually applies only to the  
ground floor. For other areas of the store, or space beyond Zone  
D, a generic rate is applied. An example is shown in Figure 34.1.

# 3 ELEMENTS OF RETAIL  
# 3.1 Store planning  
The layout of the store should meet the needs of the retailer’s oper-  
ational requirements while presenting the sales area to customers in  
an enticing and attractive way. The design of the sales area should  
be informed by a clear understanding of the range of merchandise  
offered, and the assortment and the volume of product on display.  
Typically, lower densities of merchandising reflect a higher price  
point. Retailers and store designers often plan the sales area lay-  
out in terms of the customer journey, with carefully structured  
space planning and merchandising to entice customers into making  
impulse purchases. The sales area layout is also a reflection of cus-  
tomer service offered, from the formality of counter service to the  
more relaxed open plan arrangement of self-selection.  
The entrance is usually less densely merchandised to allow cus-  
tomers time and space to make the adjustment between the public  
realm and the sales area. Retailers recognise the importance of  
making the entrance inviting to potential customers, for example  
through the deployment of staff to greet the customer.  
In all but the smallest and simplest of stores, there is a hierarchy  
of aisle widths, reflecting both the foot traffic and the degree of inti-  
macy desired by the retailer. Staircases, escalators and lifts should  
be readily identifiable in the sales space, as travelling to other floors  
is usually a disincentive to browsing. In a small store, the location  
of the point of sale counter is often determined by security consid-  
erations, with good visibility to all parts of the sales area important.  
In larger stores, point of sales counters or checkouts are located to  
suit customer flow or to drive foot traffic in the store.  
# 3.2 Operational and ancillary space  
*Stock rooms*  
These are the areas of the store that support the delivery, handling  
and temporary storage of merchandise prior to its sale. Where  
stock is held on shelves or hanging rails, stock room capacity can  
be increased using rolling racking. Stock rooms should be located  
in close proximity to loading bays and delivery points. If sales staff  
must frequently access the stock room – for example for the sale of  
shoes – good access routes between the stock room and the sales  
floor are essential.  
*Staff welfare*  
Facilities to be provided for the use of staff include toilets, chang-  
ing rooms with lockers, break room and tea kitchen. The scope of  
welfare facilities reflects the size of the store, the nature of the retail  
business and the number of staff employed.  
# 3.3 Ratio of ancillary space  
The proportions of NSA \(also referred to as front of house\) and the  
store’s ancillary space \(also referred to as back of house\) will vary  
according to the type of retail being transacted, Table II. The size  
of stockroom will also be affected by the speed and volume of sales  
and the frequency of stock replenishment. Where a retailer is trad-  
ing as a concession in a department store, or from a mall unit, some  
ancillary space such as staff welfare facilities might be remote from

# 3.4 Display windows  
Retailers are more dependent on attracting passing trade than  
other businesses. A store’s display windows are therefore an  
important element in how the store presents itself to potential  
customers. Because retail display windows contribute much to  
the vibrancy of the traditional street, there may be a town plan-  
ning requirement to maintain display windows, for example in  
conservation areas.  
Following are the three main types of display windows, as  
shown in Figure 34.2.  
*Open windows*  
There is no physical or visual separation between the window dis-  
play and the store’s sales area, although the visual merchandising  
area of the window may be differentiated by a change of level or  
dwarf wall.  
*Enclosed windows*  
The window is separated from the sales area by a partition. On a  
long store front, such as those encountered in department stores,  
the windows may be connected or separated with cross walls.  
The separating wall acts as a backdrop to the window’s visual  
merchandising and should be designed to be readily decorated  
or re-finished to suit the display. Safe access for visual mer-  
chandisers, their tools and installations are a requirement in the  
design.  
*Vitrine windows*  
Where the window is intended to display small or high-value  
pieces such as watches and jewellery, a smaller vitrine with the  
emphasis on a single piece of merchandise is appropriate. These  
should be mounted at a suitable viewing height. Because of the  
value of the merchandise displayed in vitrines, there may be  
additional security measures to be considered such as anti-bandit  
display glass.  
*Pin mounted*  
The letters or logos representing the brand are mounted on pins  
so that they stand out from the fascia. These can be lit from  
light sources concealed by the lettering, so that a halo effect is  
created.  
*Edge lit*  
The letters or logos representing the brand are mounted on acrylic  
sheet, which is lit from light sources concealed by the lettering. The  
light is reflected through the acrylic to create an illuminated edge  
giving a halo effect.  
*Back lit*  
The letters are formed as individual light boxes and finished with  
a semi-opaque material cut to the shape of the individual signage  
characters. The sign therefore comprises illuminated letters against  
a dark background.  
*Lightbox*  
A single lightbox is mounted on the fascia, which is finished with a  
signage panel in a semi-opaque material. The whole fascia can be  
backlit, or areas can be blanked off as unlit.  
Fascia signage is best viewed face-on, and so additional project-  
ing signage may be required if the store is to be seen by potential  
customers approaching from the side, Figure 34.4. The main types  
are described as follows\:  
# 3.5 Signage  
The primary location for the store’s name or brand name is the  
storefront fascia. The signage may be illuminated or backlit,  
although the extent and brightness of the illumination might be  
limited by statutory authorities. Following are the main types of  
signage, as shown in Figure 34.3.  
*Monolithic signage*  
Free-standing backlit structures in the form of totem signage.  
Usually of substantial size \(minimum 1.5 m² face area\), double  
sided and deployed externally. These are typically found in retail  
parks.  
*Flags and banners*  
Roof top flags on vertical flag poles are usually only adopted on  
large buildings where the flag can be seen from a distance. It is  
more usual to have a flag mounted on the façade of the store at a  
lower level, either on a horizontal flagpole or one that projects at  
45 degrees. The later requires a quadrilateral flag to hang to best  
effect.

*Hanging signs*  
These are hung from a wall-mounted bracket, often with the addi-  
tion of picture lights to illuminate the sign during the hours of  
darkness.  
*Blade signs*  
These are projecting signs that cantilever from the façade.  
Illumination options are similar to the back lit and edge lit fascia  
signage types.  
# 3.6 Wayfinding  
Wayfinding is an important consideration to assist customer navi-  
gation within large stores, department stores and shopping centres.  
Wayfinding includes directional signage to indicate the locations  
of store departments, toilets and other customer services. Store  
guides, maps and information points are located at key points such  
as entrances and lifts, at the end of escalators and, in the case of  
malls, the junctions of major branches or walkways.  
# 3.7 Shop fittings  
Shop fittings are pieces of furniture designed for the display of  
merchandise within the store. These must be selected to reflect the  
nature of the retail business, for example, the use of hanging rails  
for garments, or shelves for accessories. Consideration must also be  
# Retail shops and stores 34-5

# Flag Banner  
given to the capacity and density of merchandise to be displayed,  
and the ergonomics of customer selection, Figure 34.5.  
Shop fittings may be manufactured to a bespoke design or  
selected from standard modular units. Whichever method is  
used, the display furniture should be stable, safe from collapse  
or fall, durable and designed to display merchandise to best  
effect.  
Display furniture can be broadly divided into perimeter,  
Figure 34.6, and mid-floor, Figure 34.7. Perimeter furniture is  
designed to be seen from one side while mid-floor is designed to  
be seen in the round.  
Perimeter display can be free-standing or incorporated into wall  
niches. Examples include\:  
• Hanging rails  
• Shelves \(illuminated and non-illuminated\)  
• Cupboards.  
Mid-floor or free-standing units include\:  
• Hanging rail \(mobile\)

# 3.8 Other display  
The display fittings illustrated in section 3.7 allow customer selec-  
tion. Other fittings are intended solely for the display and promotion  
of merchandise and include mannequins, display graphics, screens  
and art pieces. These fittings support the visual merchandising of  
the store.  
# 3.9 Point of sale \(POS\)  
The point of sale usually takes the form of a cash desk or check out,  
although mobile POS using a hand-held device, brought to the cus-  
tomer is increasingly common. Advances in technologies deployed  
by some retailers now allow ‘just walk out’ sales where the store’s  
systems identify a customer and what they purchased, with the cus-  
tomer’s account debited accordingly. Small stores with very low  
sales volumes can process sales through a single till unit. But it  
is more usual, particularly in larger stores, that the cash drawer,  
monitor, printer and processor are separate devices, Figure 34.8.  
# 3.10 Fitting rooms  
Where garments are sold, fitting rooms are required to allow the  
customer to try on clothes for size and fit. In large stores, access to  
fitting rooms is usually managed from a single point where rejected  
clothes are returned to staff who return them to the sales floor.  
Simple fitting rooms may comprise little more than a privacy cur-  
tain and a garment hook, Figure 34.9. Larger fitting rooms, usually  
found where price points and customer service levels are higher,  
include seating, improved lighting and multiple mirrors. An acces-  
sible fitting room suitable for a wheelchair user is shown in Figure  
34.10.  
# 3.11 Security  
Display merchandise is vulnerable to theft or ‘shrinkage’ if meas-  
ures are not taken to prevent or discourage stock loss.  
*Space planning*  
The layout of fixtures in a store can determine how vulnerable  
merchandise is to theft. Avoiding concealed areas of display and  
allowing good sight lines for sales staff to oversee the sales floor  
serve to discourage theft.  
*Electronic article surveillance*  
This is the identification of merchandise that has been tagged and  
is detectable at certain points in the store, usually the entrance area.  
Detectors are located in gates, embedded in the floor or ceiling or a  
combination of all of these. Radio antennae in the detectors register  
the tag when it passes across their field of detection. Hard tags,

**34.10** *Accessible fitting room suitable for wheelchair user*  
using acousto-magnetic frequencies, are removed at the POS and  
are reusable. Radio-frequency tags operating in a wider frequency  
band use flat printed disposable tags that are deactivated at the  
POS. Other tagging methods include ink tags requiring a special  
device for removal. If the tag is forcibly removed, glass vials con-  
taining permanent ink break, spoiling the garment and rendering it  
valueless.  
*Physical security*  
Display windows that are vulnerable to attack can be protected  
with shutters, either closing over the external face of the win-  
dow, or located internally and incorporated into the design of  
the display window. In this case, a brick bond pattern of shutter  
links allows some visibility of the window display when the store  
is closed.  
*Fog systems*  
These can be deployed in the event of a robbery. The system com-  
prises a heated liquid ejected under pressure that vaporises and  
expands as a fog, thereby reducing visibility to hinder the perpe-  
trators.  
*Back of house security*  
These measures include access control locks to rear doors, CCTV  
and in larger stores, security personnel deployed to monitor and  
control access.  
# 3.12 People counters  
The simplest form of people counters are devices that track the  
number of people passing a fixed point in a store, such as the  
entrance threshold. The resulting data provides basic information  
on footfall and customer movement. A variety of technologies may  
be used to track movement.  
*Stereo video cameras*  
The images from two cameras are compared, and from these an  
algorithm determines the presence of a person passing.  
*Thermal*  
passing.  
This device detects body heat to determine the presence of a person  
*Wi-Fi*  
This system detects the presence of any person carrying a Wi-Fi-  
enabled smartphone.  
*CCTV analytics*  
Using existing security camera systems, artificial intelligence is  
used to interpret video feed, not only to determine the presence of  
a customer but to also calculate their age, gender and movement  
patterns through the store.  
# 3.13 Building services  
Because the majority of retail space is internal with limited  
opportunities to benefit from natural light and ventilation, stores  
rely heavily on mechanical ventilation, air conditioning and  
artificial lighting. The design of these systems requires careful  
coordination with the interior fit-out to ensure that they function  
effectively without a disproportionate effect on the store’s aes-  
thetic.  
*Environmental control*  
Retail premises vary widely in form and function but share the  
requirement to create a comfortable environment in which to shop  
and work. Issues to be considered are the risk of heat gain from  
potentially high occupancy levels, UV light damage to merchan-  
dise in display windows, solar gain through large areas of glazing  
and heat gains from lighting and display screens. While small  
stores can rely on natural ventilation and simple heating systems,  
larger stores utilise mechanical cooling and heating systems in  
combination with fresh air supply and extract. These are typically  
refrigerant heat pump systems or self-contained evaporator fan  
coil systems. Typical temperatures for different areas are shown  
in Table III. **34-10 Retail shops and stores**

Large supermarkets contain a wide variety of display types from

Large circulation areas and non-food aisles may require minimal

# 3.14 Spatial requirements  
While it is possible to establish a retail operation from a very small  
footprint such as a stall or a kiosk, the majority of stores are larger and  
found in the locations described in 2.3. The nature of these locations  
tends to impose their own structural and dimension constraints on the  
store. For example, the width of stores occupying the ground floors  
of high street sites is governed by the dimension between party walls  
of adjacent properties, whereas the structural grid adopted for larger,  
modern developments is determined by the efficiency and economy  
of the structural design without necessarily placing the retailer’s needs  
foremost. Structural and spatial requirements are set out in Table VI.

# 4 MARKETS  
# 4.1 Introduction  
The rights granted to municipalities to hold markets date back cen-  
turies and allows control over market trading within a radius of six  
and two-thirds miles \(10.73 km\). Markets are traditionally simple  
but vibrant environments where social interaction is as important as  
the sales made. There are approximately 1000 traditional markets  
in the UK supporting long-standing traders as well as those new to  
retailing who wish to take a low-cost, first step in the world of retail.  
# 4.2 Open markets  
Market stalls might be erected immediately prior to trading or set  
up in a semi-permanent arrangement. The latter is more common  
where a dedicated market square exists. Stalls may be supple-  
mented with fitted-out vans and trailers, Figure 34.11. Where stalls  
are erected on the day of trade, pitches are usually demarcated by  
kerb or pavement markings. Key considerations are\:  
• Vehicle parking and loading \(near stalls\)  
• Traffic control  
• Electrical and water supply to support food vendors  
• Washing facilities  
• Protection and temperature control of fresh food  
• Waste management and street cleaning. Pitch width 3000mm

# 4.3 Covered markets  
Located in market halls and comprising more permanent stalls,  
booths and kiosks. Covered markets offer a similar range of  
merchandise to open markets but may specialise, for example as  
farmers’ markets or craft and antique markets.  
# 4.4 Market halls  
Market halls are usually designed as large-span single-storey buildings  
with good natural light and ventilation. The preferred configuration is a  
single ground floor with good street access, Figure 34.12. Upper floors  
are usually limited to perimeter balcony space served by escalators,  
stairs, goods and accessible lifts. Fish, meat and food stalls are grouped  
in zones with more sophisticated ventilation, drainage and services.  
Key considerations include access to common service areas  
including remote storage, loading and delivery bays. Shared waste  
disposal facilities including the sorting of waste, recycling and com-  
paction. The fire strategy must account for a variety of traders and  
merchandise type, and potentially densely populated common areas.  
# 5 SMALL STORES  
# 5.1 Definition  
It is not sufficient to classify small stores on the basis of floor area  
alone, as they are generally associated with being independent  
stores. The Experian GOAD retail data service defines an ‘inde-  
pendent outlet’ as one with fewer than ten units. The Greater  
London Authority uses this definition, along with a maximum gross  
floor area of 80 m² in their definition of small stores for research  
and planning purposes. For the purposes of fire safety, *The Building*  
*Regulations Approved Document B, Buildings other than dwellings*  
defines a small store as having a maximum of two storeys plus a  
basement and with no single storey greater in area than 280 m².  
# 5.2 Types  
*Convenience*  
These are located in densely populated areas and transport loca-  
tions such as service stations, railway stations and airports.  
# Retail shops and stores 34-11  
Canopy  
Food truck  
Pitch width 8000mm to 9000mm  
*Variety*  
These stores specialise in a chosen category of retail. Stores may  
be located to be close to similar retail operations, or in a particular  
catchment area.  
*Services*  
Typically financial and professional services, these usually have a  
high percentage of office use.  
# 5.3 Store locations  
*High street stores*  
These typically occupy ground and basement floors with another  
use above, such as office or residential.  
*Mall and shopping centre stores*  
These stores are typically single storey with one open-fronted side.  
Back of house access may be from a central service corridor with  
direct links to a common loading bay area.  
*Transport retail*  
These usually occupy a small footprint. Transport hub stores offer  
convenience products \(railway stations\) through to luxury goods  
\(airports\). In airside locations, airport fire regulations may impose  
requirements for fire resistance and smoke control. Stock rooms are  
generally remote due to airside space constraints.  
*Miscellaneous*  
Because of their size and variety of offer, small stores can be found  
throughout the retail world, incorporated into a variety location  
such as visitor centres, academic institutions and hospitals.  
# 5.4 Store space planning  
The majority of small stores can be characterised by their single  
entrance and adjacent display windows. The POS counter is located  
in a position that allows oversight of the retail area. This ensures  
good sales staff visibility and acts as a deterrent to theft. The stock-  
room and other ancillary areas are located to the rear of the store. **34-12 Retail shops and stores**

# 6 DEPARTMENT STORES  
# 6.1 General  
Department stores are large complex stores, extending over sev-  
eral floors and often in landmark buildings in the towns or cities  
where they are located, Figure 34.13. Newer department store sites  
also occupy malls and shopping centres where they act as one of  
the development’s anchor stores, Figure 34.14. Department stores  
sell a wide variety of merchandise, although the primary offer is  
usually clothes, shoes and accessories. Other significant elements  
of a department store’s retail offer include watches and jewellery,  
homewares and household electrical, sporting goods, children’s  
toys, books, stationery, furniture and food and beverages in the  
form of a food hall.  
Department stores vary considerably in size, the largest UK  
stores being Harrods, London \(100000 m² of sales area\) and  
Selfridges, London \(50000 m² sales area\). Most department stores  
offering a reasonably wide range of product have a sales area of  
between 20000 to 50000 m². ‘Junior’ department stores, special-  
ising in luxury goods and fashion have around 5000 to 10000 m²  
sales area.  
# 6.2 Spatial organisation  
A long street frontage is preferred for multiple display windows  
and customer entrances. Because of the large numbers of staff  
employed, a separate staff entrance, changing and locker room  
facilities are provided. A loading bay is required to receive mer-  
chandise of a variety of types, as well as facilities to dispatch **Retail shops and stores 34-13**

deliveries and to collect and sort waste for disposal. Some loading  
bays may be equipped with dock levellers. Where the store’s offer  
includes a food hall, temperature-controlled stock rooms covering  
ambient, chilled and frozen zones are required. In order to manage  
the large amounts of stock held off the retail floor, central stock  
rooms are caged to allow a sub-division of lockable storage. Not all  
stock is located remotely as this is impractical for some merchan-  
dise such as shoes where stock must be quickly available.  
Within the department store, customer footfall varies widely and  
this has traditionally led to high value, high turnover departments such  
as accessories, cosmetics, watches and jewellery being located on the  
ground floor. These departments also benefit from higher ground floor  
ceiling heights. Other typical adjacencies are the food hall located on  
the ground floor or basement, which facilitates servicing and customer  
convenience. Cafes and restaurants may be located on the uppermost  
floor to benefit from city views and drive customer traffic. To encour-  
age customers to visit upper floors, escalators should be sited where  
they are easily located. Directional signage should ensure that nav-  
igation between departments is as clear as possible, and customer  
wayfinding can be supported by good sightlines across departments.  
A clear hierarchy of aisle widths and windows with external views  
also contribute to customer orientation and wayfinding.  
# 6.3 Fire compartmentation  
Maximum sales floor compartments are limited in area to 2,000 m²  
\(*Building Regulations Approved Document B*\), rising to 4,000 m²  
if an automatic sprinkler system is installed. Stock rooms must be  
compartmented if they negatively affect the means of escape, but  
this requirement may be relaxed for stock rooms fitted with either  
automatic fire detection and alarms or with an automatic sprin-  
kler system. Department store floors are characteristically linked  
by escalators in atria. As this increases the risk of fire and smoke  
spread between floors, measures to limit this, such as smoke cur-  
tains and fire shutters, may be required.  
# 6.4 Retail characteristics  
The department store is not simply the collection of separate  
departments in a single building. Department stores seek to offer  
a range of products and services across a wide spectrum of price  
4  
3  
points, blending external brands with the store’s own-bought or  
own-brand offers. Successful department stores are able to host  
external brands without losing their own character and identity.  
# 6.5 Concessions  
External brands that occupy sites within the department store  
are called concessions. The spaces occupied by them might be  
a single counter or corner of a sales floor, through to larger and  
more sophisticated ‘store-in-stores’ with their own interior iden-  
tity. Where groups of brands occupy these spaces \(typically 20 to  
200 m²\), the department store sets design guidelines to ensure a  
harmonious overall design that is in accord with the ambition of the  
department store for the sales room in question.  
# 7 SUPERMARKETS  
# 7.1 General  
Supermarkets primary retail offer is food and household necessities  
from self-service lines. Full-service supermarkets, often located on city  
fringes or out-of-town sites range from 2500 to 8000 m² sales area but  
in recent years supermarket operators have sought to expand through  
smaller, urban ‘express’ stores of 200 to 500 m² gross floor area. These  
offer a smaller product range based on convenience purchases and  
without the necessity for trolleys or pass-through checkouts.  
# 7.2 Planning  
Sales are invariably on one floor and are planned to allow trolley cir-  
culation from car park through the store. A simple rectangular plan  
is preferred with a 30 to 60 m frontage. The position and layout of  
the checkouts govern entrance, exit and circulation plans. Sales areas  
have large unobstructed spaces with structural grids of 9.0 m or more  
to suit display stand spacing and a minimum of 3.5 m clear ceiling  
height, although ceilings are typically open with exposed services.  
In larger stores, delivery and waste disposal is kept apart from cus-  
tomer traffic with loading bays at the rear of the store in a secure  
compound. Express stores may not have this facility and are serviced  
from the street outside of the busiest trading hours. Typical plans for  
full-service and express stores are shown in Figure 34.15.

# 7.3 Layout  
A standard arrangement of parallel shelf racks and cabinets on each  
side of circulation aisles is commonly adopted. In larger stores, the  
main aisles are 2.2 to 2.5 m wide increasing to 2.8 to 3.2 m in front  
of delicatessen counters and fresh meat and fish cabinets. At aisle  
ends, a width of 3.0 m is provided to allow for turning trolleys. At  
the checkout line, a clear width of 2.2 to 3.0 m is allowed either side  
of the checkout. In express stores where trolleys are not available,  
narrower aisles are possible, typically 1.2 to 1.8 m in width.  
Displays are grouped into food, non-food and alcoholic bever-  
ages sections. The delicatessen, bakery and perishables prepared on  
the premises need to be located adjacent to their preparation areas,  
with easy access to store’s refrigerated stores. Refrigerated display  
cabinets are grouped together to facilitate service connections and  
heat recovery. Demand goods \(vegetables, fruit\) are usually placed  
near the entrance to initiate buying, with promotional items dis-  
played in bins and in racks at the end of rows and checkout stations.  
Larger supermarkets may offer customer toilets, baby changing  
facilities and a separate click and collect counter.  
Space has to be allocated for customers to collect and restore bas-  
kets, Figure 34.16 and trolleys, Figure 34.17. Where the majority of

customers arrive by car, trolley parks are normally situated within

Typical checkouts rely on a member of staff scanning items that

These are usually placed in blocks to allow staff oversight. Self-  
scanning technology allowing the customer to scan and pack their  
purchases as they shop is also being introduced by some supermar-  
ket retailers.  
Within larger supermarkets, some sales areas might exist inde-  
pendently of the checkout system, for example a pharmacy, florist  
or café.  
# 8 RETAIL PARKS AND LARGE FORMAT STORES  
# 8.1 Retail parks  
These are developments of at least 4500 m² located on city fringes  
or out-of-town locations, comprising of at least three, single-storey  
units of at least 900 m². In the United Kingdom, there are over  
1200 out-of-town retail parks and so their influence on consumers’  
shopping habits is significant. More substantial retail parks may  
contain large format stores or superstores. These are considerably  
larger, offering 5000 to 10000 m² of selling space, with the requi-  
site increase in car parking and site area.  
Retail parks predominately cover the sales of non-food goods  
such as DIY, furniture, furnishings and consumer durables.  
Buildings are generally of warehouse design, and benefit from the  
combined attraction, shared infrastructure, car parking and supple-  
mentary facilities such as family dining restaurants or fast-food  
outlets. Retail units are simple in form with design emphasis placed **34-16 Retail shops and stores**

Retail parks comprising stores offering imperfect or excess stock  
at discounted prices are known as outlet centres, Figure 34.20. The

Large format stores are constructed as rectangular boxes having  
large-span clearances to allow mainly one-level trading. If required,  
upper storeys are confined to part of the building and used for non-  
food sales, and ancillary services. Compared with supermarkets,

# 9 SHOPPING CENTRES  
# 9.1 Types  
Shopping centres operate under one central management, ensur-  
ing a high degree of overall control. The centre management lease  
retail units to individual retailers and ensure that the store fit-outs  
are carried out to a prescribed standard. As well as ensuring that  
the centre offers a suitable and attractive range of retail offers, the  
centre management are also responsible for the maintenance of  
common areas, security and promotion of the centre.  
Shopping centres are pedestrian spaces and may be\:  
• Open in terraces, squares, piazzas or village-style groupings  
• Partially covered, with canopies, arcades or set-backs  
• Fully covered malls on single or multiple levels.  
# 9.2 Locations  
In the United Kingdom, the development of city shopping centres  
has been driven by urban redevelopment projects, often leading to  
significant schemes of over 20,000 m² located within the existing  
fabric of the city. These include enclosed, stand-alone develop-  
ments such as Westfield Stratford City \(175,000 m² GLA\) as well  
as semi-enclosed centres more closely embedded in the existing  
street pattern such as Trinity Leeds \(72,245 m² GLA\), Figure  
34.21\. These shopping centres are well connected to existing  
adjacent retail sites, car parks and transport infrastructure.

# 9.3 Regional centres  
While town planning policies since the mid-1990s have halted the  
development of new regional out-of-town centres, existing sites  
continue to be redeveloped and improved with major regional cen-  
tres offering sales areas well in excess of 100,000 m². Out-of-town  
malls are located close to major road junctions and include exten-  
sive areas of car parking as well as transport hubs such as local  
bus stations. There are currently 19 regional centres in the United  
Kingdom offering almost 3.9 million m² of retail space. The largest  
are the Metrocentre, Gateshead \(194,000 m² GLA including retail  
park\), Bluewater, Dartford \(155,700 m² GLA\), Westfield, Dudley  
\(154,002 m² GLA\).  
At the time of their development, planning policy encouraged  
the redevelopment of brownfield sites, including exhausted mineral  
workings and discontinued industrial wasteland. Development of  
these sites places extensive demands on technical infrastructures  
and require conservation provisions. These include rainwater recy-  
cling, combined heat and power systems, energy balancing, airflow  
control, fabric insulation and shading, management control sys-  
tems and planned maintenance.  
# 9.4 Planning  
Where practicable, urban shopping centres follow existing street  
patterns and are sensitively integrated into the existing street pat-  
tern and its architecture.  
Commercial and operational considerations include\:  
• Number, size and locations of major stores or anchor tenants  
which will increase the centre’s attractiveness and improve cus-  
tomer footfall  
• Distribution of small stores throughout the centre including an  
attractive mix of independent and brand retailers  
• Entrances and links with parking, public transport and adjacent  
shopping areas  
• Number of levels, changes of level and ease of vertical circulation  
• Leisure attractions such as cinemas, restaurants and entertainment  
venues to draw visitors to the centre  
• Servicing needs and access for deliveries and the removal of waste  
• Environmental control in the mall and in individual stores  
• Fire separation, evacuation and life safety.  
# 9.5 Plan forms  
Typical retail units are single storey of 100 to 1200 m². However,  
larger brand retailers and anchor stores may occupy two storey  
sites with access from both levels of the centre. Malls are usually  
limited to two sales floors because of the difficulty in driving foot-  
fall to the furthest locations, but exceptions exist, notably the three  
floors of retail at Westfield Stratford City.  
Centres are usually planned so that the anchor stores are located  
at the ends of malls or the end of a branch. Anchor stores attracting  
footfall have an effective range of 90 to 120 m. It is not practical  
to extend a mall more than 350 m and large developments call for  
more than one level with concentrated plan forms. These include  
L-form, T-form, pinwheel, figure of eight, loop and other variants,  
Figure 34.22  
# 9.6 Details  
The width of circulation areas in shopping centres varies widely.  
Urban shopping centres, particularly open or semi-enclosed devel-  
opments based on existing street patterns, may include both open  
plazas and narrow corridors of retail units. Face-to-face dimensions  
between stores of 5.4 m upwards are considered suitable to allow  
good pedestrian circulation and visibility of window display. The  
width of circulation routes in enclosed malls has developed over  
time, with most developers working to a rule of thumb dimen-  
sion of 9.13 m \(based on the 30’ width of North American malls\).  
Over the years however, this standard has become less rigid as  
mall planning has evolved from a simple linear plan form to more  
imaginative layouts. This 9.13 m width \(or wider\) allows kiosks,  
seating and other attractions to be located mid-floor in the walk-  
way. Upper galleries around a central court or atrium are typically  
4m wide.  
The preferred display window frontage for small stores is  
5.4 m to 7.3 m with a minimum height of 2.5 m. In open or  
semi-enclosed centres, storefronts are usually similar to high  
street store types, although likely to be designed in compliance  
with centre management guidelines. In enclosed malls, glazed  
storefronts are necessary when the mall remains open to the pub-  
lic at night but otherwise fully or partly open frontages are more  
convenient with shutters or fire barriers \(if required\) to secure  
the store overnight. **Retail shops and stores 34-19**

# 9.7 Food courts  
In malls, large atria and glazed courtyards provide activity spaces  
which are often landscaped and used for restaurants gathered  
around a food court. Features such as water fountains, kiosks,  
planted containers and children’s play centres also create focuses  
for interest.  
# 9.8 Fire precautions  
It is challenging to design large shopping centres on the basis of  
conventional compartmentation and prescriptive regulations.  
Fire safety is therefore usually addressed through bespoke or  
engineered methods. These methods model the behaviour of  
fire and smoke to calculate safe occupancy levels, egress routes  
and evacuation times. Malls must be of non-combustible con-  
struction, with incidental combustible material controlled, and  
have an automatic sprinkler system, detection and fire alarms  
installed. Fire separating walls are required between individ-  
ual retail units and between retail units and internal service  
corridors.  
Smoke control is managed through smoke reservoirs, created  
by downstand beams on fascias at shop frontages and at inter-  
vals along the mall. Smoke detectors activate exhaust fans in the  
reservoirs, and lower level fresh air supply ensures clear escape  
routes.  
Maximum occupancy levels are estimated on the basis of\:  
• Stores, showrooms, supplementary areas – 7.0 m²/person  
• Supermarkets, department store sales floors – 2.0 m²/person.  
No more than 50 per cent of occupants should be assumed to  
escape through the rear of a store, with the rest using the mall.  
Escape routes from the mall must be provided at intervals, with  
exits to open streets directly or via separated structures. Specific  
provision for fire brigade appliances must be made at larger cen-  
tres, with access to hydrants, hoses and extinguishers forming part  
of the fire strategy.  
# 9.9 Circulation and access  
Vertical circulation between storeys requires escalators, feature  
lifts and staircases designed to stimulate interest. These are usually  
located in a spacious central concourse or atrium, at junctions or  
corners and within the larger stores.  
For servicing retail units, vehicular access is required to loading  
docks and waiting bays directly accessible to each of the larger  
stores, with service roads, goods lifts and tunnels extending to the  
rear of smaller units. Service entry is usually at basement or street  
level but may be at an upper level on sloping sites.  
# 9.10 Engineering services  
The shopping centre’s landord is normally responsible for install-  
ing and providing the communal services of the mall, including  
comfort cooling, heating, lighting, cleaning, fire control and secu-  
rity systems. As a rule, individual tenants install remaining plant  
and equipment within their own store to meet their own needs and  
subject to proprietor agreement. Food-preparation areas, public toi-  
lets and plant areas require the installation of specific ventilation,  
drainage and electrical services, and these are installed and main-  
tained by the landlord or mall operator.

# Anthony Langan  
*Anthony Langan is sector lead for education at AHR Architects*.  
*KEY POINTS*  
• *This chapter brings together good practice and recent standards,*  
*but the Department for Education website should be consulted*  
*for the very latest standards and guidelines*  
• *The design of schools is a highly political, and constantly evolv-*  
*ing, field of study*  
• *The current emphasis is on efficient,* *compact forms that are easy*  
*to extend*  
• *Schools should be designed as low carbon environments with*  
*high quality natural lighting and should be naturally ventilated*  
*in all but the most exceptional circumstances*
