# 1 INTRODUCTION  
# 1.1 Definition  
Universities are places of learning and research in a variety of sub-  
jects at the highest level and are often, therefore, described as being  
institutes within the higher education \(HE\) sector. Derived from the  
Latin *universitas magistrorum et scholarium*, which could be trans-  
lated as a ‘corporation of masters and scholars’, the university was  
conceived as a place of academic freedom in contrast to specific  
training for crafts or trades in the medieval period. In time, uni-  
versities were authorised to confer degrees and are now significant  
contributors to national and regional economies all over the world.  
# 1.2 Scope  
Modern universities vary hugely, having differing emphases on  
subjects and research. Their locations and student base are also  
diverse. This section of the *Handbook* seeks to provide broad guid-  
ance for designers of sustainable new university facilities, but this  
guidance could be extended to upgrading or extending existing  
buildings. The range of accommodation examined represents the  
typical core building stock of modern, Western universities and  
may not all be relevant to every building, site or budget. Please note  
that this is written for a temperate UK/Western European climate  
and will not be suitable for other locations. The figures provided  
represent average or recommended dimensions and values and  
would be subject to adjustment for more specific requirements.  
# 1.3 History and types  
*Urban universities*  
The traditional university model has been linked with city life in Europe  
since the Universities of Bologna and Paris were founded in 1088 and  
1150 and later in Oxford \(1167\) and Cambridge \(1209\), Figure 41.1.  
The study of theology was central to university life and consequently  
these early institutes bore a strong relation to monasteries in their  
DOI\: 10.4324/9781003052586-44  
**41.1** *Cambridge town plan\: Cole and Roper map of Cambridge,*  
*1804*  
arrangements, being characterised by cloistered courtyards, chapels  
and refectories. Some would argue that Western universities may have  
been influenced by, or were based on, Islamic *Madrasah* schools in the  
ninth-century Middle East as observed by crusaders.  
*Collegiate universities*  
Many universities evolved into college-based institutes – the ear-  
liest include Paris, Oxford, Cambridge and, later, Durham. In this  
model, formal lectures, governance and administration are provided  
by the university; and the residential, dining, tutorial and pasto-  
ral functions are provided by member ‘colleges’ or ‘houses’. The  
non-college accommodation is normally organised into ‘schools’,  
‘faculties’ or departments and some ceremonial buildings.  
Consequently, the host cities, or city quarters, developed around  
these universities and their colleges over many centuries, and as  
such are largely defined by their presence. Scotland established  
four ‘Ancient’ universities between 1410 and 1582. In London,  
a number of large and almost independent colleges were founded  
from 1826 onwards, each acting as a quasi-university. Some of  
these specialised in subject areas such as science and engineering,  
as in the case of Imperial College London. Their buildings tend to  
**41-1** **41-2 Universities**  
cluster in city-centre sites later referred to as ‘campuses’ after the  
College of New Jersey \(later renamed Princeton University\).  
*Subsequent urban universities*  
There followed an explosion of university creation in major cities across  
the UK and Ireland from 1828 to 1909. Whilst these were not necessarily  
based on the collegiate model, some included colleges and most became  
important parts of inner-city life, often creating distinctive academic city  
‘quarters’. Their physical composition moved away from the monastic  
model, through classic palatial and towards Victorian civic grandeur.  
From 1992, over 70 new universities were created from for-  
mer polytechnics, ‘university colleges’ and HE institutes. Many of  
these occupied urban groupings that were consolidated from dis-  
parate buildings to create urban campuses. In this way, many new  
universities have more in common in urban terms with the ‘Ancient  
Universities’ than those of the Victorian and Edwardian eras.  
*Rural and suburban campus universities*  
Waves of university construction following the World Wars, driven  
by government policy aimed at social mobility, led to a prolifera-  
tion of sylvan campuses across Britain. Their compositions were  
varied and experimental, often laid out in response to masterplans  
by individual architects.  
*Further education*  
Further education \(FE\) is post-compulsory education that is distinct  
from education offered in universities, and has grown significantly  
to become recognised as a separate sector. It provides education,  
from basic training to HND or Foundation Degree. Institutions  
considered part of the FE sector include\:  
• General FE and tertiary colleges  
• Sixth form colleges  
• Specialist colleges \(e.g. land-based colleges\)  
• Adult education institutions.  
FE forms one part of a wider learning and skills sector, alongside  
workplace education and other types of non-school, non-university  
education and training. It provides 14- to 19-year-old learners with  
the opportunity to progress to HE and skilled employment. It also  
provides adult learners with access to basic skills, training for work  
and learning for personal development. FE planning and design  
guidelines and best practice are significantly different from HE and  
are therefore not included in this chapter.  
# 1.4 Site strategy  
The assessment of individual sites should make reference to the  
development masterplan for the campus, drawing together a holis-  
tic understanding of pedestrian routes, servicing strategy, key nodal  
points and public realm strategy. This in turn should inform the  
approach and clear primary entrance points, external/internal way-  
finding, connectivity and the external spaces between buildings.  
Developing ideas for making the campus more inviting by creat-  
ing transparency into student active zones/spaces should also be  
exploited. Understanding how students experience buildings and  
spaces from their own perspective is an important starting point.  
It is desirable to determine the nature and scope of all vehicle  
and pedestrian circulation routes within and around the campus to  
minimise conflict, including movement on/off the site that is sig-  
nificant to the effective operation of campus facilities in order to  
establish proper access and egress arrangements, compliance with  
Equality Act, aggregation of flows of traffic, people and materials,  
and control and security provisions.  
It is also important at the outset of the design process to develop  
clear concepts for maximising the flexibility and quality of the inter-  
nal spaces, focusing on the de-institutionalisation of circulation routes  
via creative impromptu interaction areas for students and staff, together  
with attractive and conducive internal vertical and horizontal circula-  
tion to enhance social contact, for example, atria, galleries, ‘streets’.  
# 1.5 Building form  
There are many matters to consider when designing university  
buildings\:  
• Use narrower, open plan floorplates \(12–13.5 m\) if maximum  
daylighting and natural cross-ventilation are desirable  
• Use the building form to enhance passive/low energy strategies.  
Consider the use of atria, solar chimneys, light wells and wind  
stacks to assist stack ventilation and make use of heat reclaim  
• Extend atria well beyond the roof level to prevent warm, stale air  
build-up affecting the occupants of the upper floors  
• Consider a compact building form with a low ratio of envelope\:  
floor area to reduce heat loss and heat gain  
• Consider high floor to ceiling dimensions to increase daylight pen-  
etration and to prevent warm, stale air build-up at occupant level.  
# 1.6 Orientation  
• Orientate along east/west axis with primary north and south  
elevations  
• Eliminate solar gain as far as possible. South aspect is easier to  
control using screens, louvres and blinds. Also consider ratios of  
glazed\: opaque envelope and translucent insulation  
• East and west elevations get low angled sun, which can cause  
problems with glare. This is very difficult to control using stand-  
ard louvres.  
# 1.7 Energy use  
Potential ideas to minimise energy use could include\:  
• Maximising the integration of passive strategies \(orientation,  
prevailing wind\) to minimise the use of active systems that use  
energy \(e.g. wind/solar assisted ventilation\)  
• Investigating the use of thermal mass to absorb heat during the  
day and purge it at night to provide comfort conditions in the  
morning. This also reduces temperature swings within the space  
• Using natural or mixed-mode ventilation in preference to full air  
conditioning, where possible. Displacement ventilation is prefera-  
ble, as it requires lower energy use for the same cooling capacity.  
However, it also requires larger risers and underfloor voids  
• Optimising daylight whilst being aware of glare and solar gain.  
Consider narrow plan form, use of atria and lightwells, ceiling  
profile, high ceilings, prismatic glass and light-shelves  
• Recovering waste heat for pre-heating winter supply air for heat  
exchanging with hot water supply  
• Ensuring the correct balance of insulation within the façades to  
minimise winter heat loss and reduce summer solar gain \(south  
and west\)  
• Developing a low energy artificial lighting strategy and integrate the  
system with the daylighting. Use low energy light fittings and con-  
sider controls carefully \(occupancy detection, daylight sensors, etc.\)  
• Extracting air through or close to light fittings to extend lamp life  
and reduce heat gains  
• Designing the façades in relation to their specific orientation.  
Each will require a different combination of glazed areas, opaque  
areas, types of glass, blinds, louvres and screens  
• Minimising internal heat gains through specification of low  
heat-emitting appliances and lighting  
• Ensuring that the internal comfort criteria brief is realistic so that  
the services system is not over-designed for heat loads that may  
only occur during a few days of the year. This can lead to inef-  
ficient operation when the plant is running at lower capacities  
• Ensuring that the detail design maximises airtightness in cold  
weather as this is a major contributor to heat loss.  
# 1.8 Water  
• Maximise area of roof and landscaping for rainwater collection  
• Provide a storage tank within the landscape or basement for rain-  
water storage. **Universities 41-3**  
# 1.9 Health and well-being  
• Provide user control of lighting, humidity, heating and ventila-  
tion. This may be arranged by groups and linked to the telephone  
system and/or BMS  
• Provide openable windows where possible, as occupant control  
has psychological health and well-being benefit  
• Pay attention to landscaping and planting inside and out. This  
can be used to temper the environment through natural shading,  
cooling and humidifying. It has been shown that certain plants  
improve air quality within a building  
• Create indoor and outdoor spaces that encourage interaction,  
social exchange and a sense of community  
• Integrate water and planting to improve air quality, natural  
humidity and improve occupants’ sense of well-being.  
# 2 SPACE TYPES  
# 2.1 Introduction  
The UK HE system is becoming increasingly diverse. This increas-  
ing diversity is leading to diverging approaches to the use of space,  
particularly between teaching-led and research-led universities.  
Space will be increasingly subject to remodelling to meet changing  
needs and new standards. With imaginative design, space can be  
deployed flexibly to meet multiple uses.  
‘Learning space’ is seen as one of these new needs, with more  
provision being made for student-led and ‘blended learning’ \(a mix-  
ture of face-to-face plus IT-mediated learning\). This will demand  
more relatively small and adaptable spaces. IT developments are  
enabling more intensive use of space for teaching and learning.  
An educational building is an expensive long-term resource and  
the design of its individual spaces need to be\:  
• Flexible\: to accommodate both current and evolving pedagogies  
• Future-proofed\: to enable space to be re-allocated and reconfigured  
• Bold\: to look beyond tried and tested technologies and pedagogies  
• Creative\: to energise and inspire learners and tutors  
• Supportive\: to develop the potential of all learners  
• Enterprising\: to make each space capable of supporting different  
purposes.  
Learning space should be able to motivate learners and promote  
learning as an activity; support collaborative as well as formal  
practice; provide a personalised and inclusive environment; and be  
flexible in the face of changing needs. Technology plays a key role  
in achieving these aims.  
# 2.2 General teaching and learning space  
The design of most general teaching and learning spaces will  
need to support both tutor-led and learner-led activities. These  
will include presentations, discussion, collaborative project work  
and information retrieval and sharing. Future technological and  
pedagogic developments cannot always be anticipated, but it is  
important that the design can accommodate change.  
Most universities consider general teaching rooms as non-dedi-  
cated space, shared across faculties and the entire campus. As such,  
the rooms should be centrally located providing convenient access  
to all users.  
Centralised online booking systems increase the effectiveness  
of managing space utilisation of general teaching space, and some  
universities have adopted space charging as a measure against block  
booking of rooms. Centralised bookable general teaching rooms typ-  
ically comprise a range of spaces with varying capacities, as follows\:  
• Lecture theatres – large \(250\); medium \(120\); small \(90\)  
• Seminar rooms – large \(60\); medium \(30\); small \(15\)  
• IT rooms – various capacities used \(30+\), although increasingly  
access to IT is via social learning spaces or libraries  
• Tutorial rooms – \(5–6\).  
*Key issues*  
The design of the space should consider the following\:  
• Daylight control  
• Ventilation, including control by room users  
• Registration technology  
• Viewing angles/sightlines  
• Lighting  
• Acoustic performance  
• Reconfiguration  
• Audio visual facilities and controls  
• Signage and booking systems.  
There are no specific standards in the UK for the acoustic  
performance of university teaching spaces. However, *Building*  
*Bulletin 93\: Acoustic design in schools* may be used for guidance.  
# 2.3 Lecture theatres  
Lecture theatres need to be flexible in terms of configuration and  
capacity to meet the demands of varying teaching programmes,  
modes of learning and timetabling. This will allow spaces to adapt  
to evolving pedagogies and future change. However, it is the  
three-dimensional form of the space and the relationship between  
presenter and audience that should be the primary considerations.  
\(See also Chapter 15 Auditoria.\)  
The following should be considered when developing design  
proposals\:  
*Strategic issues*  
• Location within the building  
• Movement of people  
• Wayfinding  
• Foyer space – pre/post lecture milling and cross-over space  
• Access/egress points  
• Occupancy/capacity  
• Refreshments/catering provision  
• WCs and cloakrooms.  
*Uses*  
• Single or multiple speaker presentations  
• Q&A sessions  
• Panel discussions  
• Collaborative working formats  
• Digital presentations  
• Conferences.  
*Layout/configuration*  
• Presentation area – flat or raised platform  
• Seating configuration – straight, angled, curved  
• Fixed rake or retractable bleacher seating  
• Sightlines  
• AV requirements – screen size, repeater screens  
• Means of escape  
• Seat design – tip-up, individual fixed, continuous fixed, with or  
without armrests  
• Writing surface – fixed tablet arm, folding tablet arm, fixed con-  
tinuous writing surface  
• Lectern design  
• Power, data, microphones  
• Inclusive design including wheelchair location, hearing induc-  
tion loop.  
*Supporting facilities*  
• Projection facilities  
• Sound and lighting facilities  
• Translation/interpretation facilities  
• Registration/access control equipment  
• Ticketing/box office  
• Equipment and furniture storage. **41-4 Universities**  
# 2.4 IT rooms  
Although technology is increasingly moving away from dedicated  
computer rooms, for some courses there may still be a requirement  
for intensive, screen-based teaching, which will require a dedicated  
environmental solution.  
# 2.5 Tutorial rooms  
Many universities are removing tutorial space from within academic  
staff offices and providing bookable tutorial rooms that can also be used  
for staff meetings, interviews, confidential work/discussion, private  
study, professional visitors, etc. In some universities, there is a move  
away from individual tutorials to small group tutorials \(5–6 students\).  
# 2.6 Informal and social learning spaces  
The provision of a variety of learning spaces that complement  
timetabled general teaching space is an essential requirement in HE  
buildings. Spaces designed to support learning outside of formal  
teaching spaces, either in groups or individually, have therefore  
become an accepted norm in university space design.  
Well-designed social learning spaces are likely to increase students’  
motivation and positively impacts on their engagement with learning.  
High quality space for informal learning also enhances the profile of  
the university, presenting prospective students with a dynamic learning  
environment. Social spaces should therefore be given a high priority  
in new design proposals. If catering facilities, common rooms, even  
circulation spaces are considered as social meeting and group learning  
environments, universities could improve space efficiency and make a  
statement about their vision for learning as a pervasive and inclusive  
activity based on social interaction, see Figure 41.2.  
The following social learning spaces support the varying needs  
of students throughout the day\:  
*Individual or group informal settings*  
Often located in highly visible settings within buildings, these  
areas support social interaction and blur the lines between social  
and study modes. Key features include\:  
• Soft seating with low tables  
• Proximity to vending or café spaces  
• Local power, potentially within certain zones rather than built  
into all furniture  
• A range of seating options supporting a range of groupings.  
*Individual formal settings*  
The term ‘social learning’ implies conversation and exchange in a  
social setting. However, the need for individual study desks, often,  
but not always, incorporated into libraries, is still extremely impor-  
tant to students. These settings are characterised by\:  
• Generally quiet environments  
• Task lighting  
• Power built into furniture  
• Within an open setting  
• Formal desk arrangements.  
These settings can also include ‘pod’ type spaces to provide  
additional privacy, set within an open plan area.  
*Group formal settings*  
Increasingly valued by students are small rooms for group study  
and work. These rooms are acoustically protected from the sur-  
rounding area\:  
• Single formal central table  
• Screens for presentation  
• Integrated data  
• Formal seating for 4–8 people.  
The mix of these space types within a learning commons, library  
or an academic building will vary from project to project, but it is  
always advisable to offer a range of settings with a range of envi-  
ronmental conditions \(from bright, open spaces to inward-looking  
‘retreat’ type spaces\) to cater for individual preferences.  
The large central learning centre is now a multifunctional facil-  
ity providing social spaces, student services and study support,  
book and laptop loan, access to IT, and different kinds of working  
environments, from comfortable seating for collaborative group  
work, to ‘board rooms’ for practice presentations. Elements of  
teaching may also take place within a learning centre environment.  
These varied purposes demand a clear vision for each area within  
the centre. Zones for different modes of learning are common strat-  
egies. Sound and visual clues, layout and style of furniture, and  
different technologies in different configurations can signal the dif-  
ferent purposes of areas.  
# 2.7 Libraries  
The university library is traditionally the heart of the campus.  
Trends in social learning and information gathering, driven by  
wireless technology and online databases, have resulted in the need  
for libraries to flex and adapt to accommodate a wider variety of  
research methods and spaces. However, regardless of changes to  
learning over recent years, there is still a strong role for the library  
to play on campus as a focus for quiet study and research. More  
intensive use is being seen in longer library opening hours, with  
24-hour opening during the working week becoming more com-  
mon, especially where many students are part-time. \(For further  
guidance, see also Chapter 26 Libraries.\)  
**41.2** *The Brooks Building, Manchester Metropolitan University, designed by Sheppard Robson. The ‘Spanish Steps’ provide valuable*  
*social and informal learning space, complementing traditional seminar rooms* *Key design issues*  
The following should be considered when developing designs for  
university libraries\:  
• Number of volumes on site  
• High demand publications  
• Special collections  
• Categorisation method  
• Roller racking \(if space is at a premium\)  
• Accessibility  
• Community access  
• Line of security  
• Types of study space and social learning provision  
• Furniture  
• Access to online services and other research sources  
• Library catering  
• Library staff offices and support spaces  
• Co-location of recycling facilities with print stations  
• AV to group study spaces, monitors with laptop connectivity and  
write-on surfaces broaden the experience  
• Digital signage for communication with library users  
• Access to drinking water  
• Distribution of WCs  
• Lockers for personal storage  
• Automation of book returns.  
*Environmental factors*  
The environmental quality of a library is critical for the experience  
of the library user. Typical design considerations for libraries are  
as follows\:  
• Acoustic challenges of natural ventilation  
• Maximising natural daylight  
• Control of glare  
• Correct balance between background and task lighting  
• Zoning of acoustically similar activities  
• Acoustic impact of finishes, e.g. hard floor surfaces can disturb  
learners.  
*Library support functions*  
The following types of space are needed to support the library\:  
• Library enquiry/information point – counter, desk, storage \(sat-  
ellite floor-based enquiry desks\)  
• Library administration – offices, workrooms, storage  
• IT administration – offices, workrooms, storage  
• Open stack space – books, periodicals, DVDs, CDs  
• Compact shelving  
• Library support facilities – self issue/return, online public access  
catalogues, printing/photocopying, collection bins  
• Careers section.  
# 2.8 Specialist teaching and research spaces  
These are either\:  
• Teaching spaces that by virtue of particular servicing, fit-out or  
uses need to be dedicated to a particular function or school, but  
which could be accommodated in a standard structural shell  
• Teaching spaces that by virtue of particular dimensional, loading  
or servicing requirements cannot fit into a standard shell.  
Such spaces include science laboratories, music rooms and  
other specialist facilities as detailed in what follows.  
# 2.9 Laboratories  
Undergraduate \(UG\), postgraduate \(PG\) and research laboratory  
requirements are unique to each university. This section focuses on  
# Universities 41-5  
university teaching and research requirements, and should be read  
in conjunction with Chapter 25 Laboratories.  
University laboratories and science learning spaces are  
designed to enthuse and stimulate students through active learning.  
This encourages enquiry-based learning through online platforms  
that involve video clips, interactive simulations, interactive sim-  
ulations, virtual lectures or annotated digital slides to observe,  
understand and practise techniques before attending practical  
laboratory classes. Another recent trend within universities is to  
co-locate disciplines within multidisciplinary accommodation to  
increase collaboration whilst achieving high levels of utilisation.  
University laboratory space needs vary markedly between  
schools and departments, the types of teaching or research being  
undertaken and specific equipment needs. There are a number of  
different types of ‘primary’ university laboratories, including\:  
*Wet laboratory*  
Large capacity labs with ‘wet’ services, with the following key  
features\:  
• Demonstrations shown on repeater screens to the benching bays  
• Benching arrangements will depend on the activity within the  
laboratory  
• Areas for fixed and mobile equipment  
• Student glass storage \(often by a personal lockable cupboard\)  
and all personal items are stored externally to the laboratory  
environment.  
Examples of use include chemistry, chemical engineering,  
microbiology, pharmacy, biochemistry.  
*Dry laboratory*  
Large capacity labs with ‘dry’ electrical services, with the follow-  
ing key features\:  
• Demonstration points/repeater screen technology is often specified  
• Flexibility within the benching arrangements to suit the wider  
range of uses  
• PC workstations to each workspace.  
Examples of use include electrical engineering, geology, earth  
sciences and environmental sciences.  
*E-laboratory*  
The E-lab is a large IT resource that allows students to under-  
take experiments before moving into a potentially hazardous and  
expensive laboratory space, and is now commonplace within many  
universities. E-laboratories enable traditional labs to be used more  
efficiently and is utilised by many scientific disciplines.  
*‘Discovery’ laboratory*  
Within some universities, there is an emphasis on providing a  
laboratory space which allows students to develop within a self-di-  
rected environment; this space is often used for open days, external  
engagement, outreach and display.  
*Specialist spaces*  
Specialist spaces will depend on the disciplines being taught. These  
may consist of spaces which require close control, improved acous-  
tic or vibration performance criteria. Research/post graduate spaces  
are often cellular in nature and are brief specific.  
*Support spaces*  
Supporting spaces should include the following\:  
• Write-up/informal learning  
• Write-up space for post graduates/PhD  
• Preparation rooms **41-6 Universities**  
• Storage  
• Specialist storage – chemicals, solvents and gas can be stored  
either externally or internally; refer to HSE Control of Substances  
Hazardous to Health guidelines  
• Workshops – a small workshop may be required for repairing  
equipment  
• Loading bay/goods handling – laboratories have a high number  
of consumables; adequate space for temporary storage and audit-  
ing of incoming/outgoing goods should be provided.  
# 2.10 Music  
Music can be studied at a university, or at a specialist college, acad-  
emy or conservatoire. The spaces in a music department consist of a  
range of rooms of different sizes, with stringent acoustic requirements.  
Accommodation requirements will vary, but the following is a guide\:  
• Music classrooms \(dedicated\) – large learning and teaching spaces  
• Practice rooms – solo, group, ensemble  
• Music technology \(digital\) and keyboard rooms  
• Instrument and other stores – department/school use, student use  
• Music library and resource area – including music scores, CDs,  
DVDs  
• Rehearsal studios  
• Recital studios  
• Recording/control studios  
• Performance space \(or shared use of a central university facility\)  
• Small breakout spaces associated with music rooms  
• Academic staff rooms and support.  
*Environmental considerations*  
Music rooms are for creating and listening to sound and therefore  
an appropriate acoustic environment is essential. The following  
should be considered\:  
• The aim is to enable people to hear music clearly, without dis-  
traction and with suitable enhancement by the room acoustics  
• The two main acoustic concerns are sound quality and sound  
insulation  
• The main influences on the quality of musical sounds are room  
volume, room geometry and surface finishes  
• Successful sound separation between spaces depends on good  
planning, structure and construction detail \(partitions, doors,  
windows and vents should be appropriately insulated\)  
• The location of the music department/school, relative to other  
department/schools \(or neighbours\), should be carefully considered.  
*Space planning principles*  
Most music departments host a range of activities and events includ-  
ing performances outside the normal teaching day. All these activities  
will involve groups of people \(students, staff, external musicians\)  
arriving and leaving throughout the day. Therefore, the location of the  
departments should make this as easy as possible, whilst maintaining  
security. Important points to consider when planning space are\:  
• Avoiding acoustic disturbance with neighbouring spaces, includ-  
ing external spaces  
• Ensuring music spaces are near to other facilities that will be  
used for musical activities  
• Creating easy access for the movement of musical instruments  
and equipment for performance in spaces outside the depart-  
ment/school  
• Providing a separate dedicated reception that can be used outside  
normal hours without compromising overall security.  
# 2.11 Business schools  
Business studies can be studied at either a business school or  
department within a university, or at an independent international  
graduate school and research institution.  
*University-based business schools*  
UG teaching is usually undertaken in centrally timetabled, general  
teaching accommodation such as lecture theatres, seminar rooms  
and IT rooms. Depending on the university, a dedicated UG work-  
room and lounge may be provided within the school.  
Postgraduate teaching \(PGT\) and research \(PGR\) is usually  
undertaken in dedicated accommodation and can comprise\:  
• Lecture theatres \(small\) \(stepped amphitheatre-style with contin-  
uous writing desks and fixed seating\)  
• Seminar rooms \(small\)  
• Syndicate rooms \(conference style\)  
• PGT group workspace \(drop-in facility, with wireless connec-  
tivity\)  
• PGT computer lab \(learning facility\)  
• PGR group workspace \(café-style linked to syndicate rooms,  
with wireless connectivity\)  
• PGR social space.  
The MBA \(Masters of Business Administration\) accommoda-  
tion is often planned as a dedicated suite of accommodation within  
the business school or department and comprises\:  
• Reception, social/interaction/breakout space, refreshment bar/  
service  
• Lecture theatres \(small\) \(stepped amphitheatre-style with contin-  
uous writing desks in wide rows and mobile/revolving executive  
chairs\)  
• Seminar rooms \(small\) \(café-style with circular tables and  
mobile/revolving executive chairs, with wireless connectivity\)  
• Syndicate rooms \(mobile/revolving executive chairs around con-  
ference tables, with wireless connectivity\)  
• General teaching rooms – sizes to suit the student cohorts  
• IT laboratories – to facilitate use of specialist software linked to  
the taught programme  
• Boardroom pitch room – for practising pitching to potential  
clients  
• Meeting rooms – formal rooms with media walls  
• Informal/social learning spaces in various configurations  
• External partner suite – dedicated suite for industry partners to  
hire/utilise for CPD and/or student engagement  
• Observation rooms – two-way mirror observation suite supported  
by playback facilities  
• One-to-one rooms  
• Multi-faith room – business schools attract a diverse interna-  
tional student intake  
• Catering  
• ‘Executive catering’ – the facility may host functions and CPD  
events; consideration of external partners hospitality spaces may  
be advisable  
• Innovation/incubator space  
• Conferencing facilities – should central conferencing facilities  
not be available a dedicated facility may be required.  
A few schools may incorporate a dedicated Executive Training  
Suite offering custom training to professionals. It will need to be  
easily accessible for evening customers and comprises\:  
• Reception, social/interaction/breakout space, refreshment bar/  
service  
• Executive training room \(small\) \(café-style circular tables with  
mobile/revolving executive chairs\)  
• Reference/resource facilities.  
A dedicated Financial Markets Suite is often included in a busi-  
ness school to provide UG and PG students training in a simulated  
dealing room environment. *Independent graduate business schools*  
These institutions are pre-eminent global graduate business schools  
\(e.g. Harvard, INSEAD, London Business School, see Figure 41.3\)  
that specialise in offering ‘top-class’ MBAs and executive educa-  
tion. They have complete operational independence and separate  
funding. Depending on their vision, aims and objectives they will  
have different approaches and operational areas for the following\:  
• Teaching – MBAs, EMBAs, MiFs, executive education \(open  
and custom programmes\), PhDs  
• Research – faculty working on specialist research initiatives  
based on chosen subject areas  
• External relations – school brand/fundraising, alumni, communi-  
cations, development, events  
• Support departments – finance/accounts, information services,  
careers, facilities, human resources  
• Office accommodation – PG/PhD \(touch down and/or open plan  
office space\); ‘staff office’ \(central space for student enquires  
etc.\); programme support staff spaces \(if not provided centrally  
by institution\)  
• Outreach activities.  
Comprehensive programmes of evening and day events  
will take place throughout the year, such as residential courses,  
conferences, corporate presentations, networking, ceremonies, dis-  
tinguished speaker lectures, recruitment and alumni reunions. Most  
of these events will require good quality residential accommoda-  
tion, conferencing, community networking and catering facilities.  
The planning, design and range of accommodation and the quality  
of the physical space will be characterised by the spirit and ethos of  
the school, and the school’s perceived international brand.  
The range of accommodation for teaching MBAs will be similar  
to university-based schools except the quality and space standards  
will be higher. Similarly, executive education accommodation will  
be of a higher quality, more extensive and include a business cen-  
tre, breakout and refreshment areas for delegates.  
Additional facilities will include\:  
• Conference centre – high quality large theatre/hall with cinema  
style seating, including reception/registration area, foyer/break-  
out space and hospitality service  
• Large community networking space  
• A range of catering facilities – banqueting and hospitality \(break-  
fast/lunch/dinner\), restaurant with service, café, coffee bar/shop  
and dispersed refreshment zones  
**41.3** *The Sammy Ofer Centre at the London Business*  
*School, designed by Sheppard Robson. The renovation and*  
*reconfiguration of the former Marylebone Town Hall and Library*  
*Annexe provide the wide range of learning, social and conference*  
*settings required by the modern business school*  
# Universities 41-7  
• Teaching support – PC labs, library/resource centre and study spaces  
• Student services/support facilities  
• Alumni centre  
• Offices – faculty, support, admin staff  
• School reception area – visitors, information, exhibition.  
Environmental considerations for lecture/conference facilities may  
include\:  
• Naturally lit and air-conditioned  
• Programmable lighting and blackout  
• Sound reinforcement, microphones and high quality acoustics  
• Wireless network, video/filming facilities  
• Interactive whiteboards, projection and LCD screens  
• Control of environment from lecturer’s desk/console.  
# 2.12 Art and design  
Art is studied at a department or school within a university faculty  
of creative arts or at a specialist art college. Art is a practical and  
creative discipline in which students learn through investigation,  
observation, analysis and experimentation. Students work in both  
two and three dimensions and at a range of scales. Typical courses  
that need to be provided may include\:  
• Drawing  
• Graphic design and illustration  
• Painting  
• Screen printing  
• Photography/moving image  
• Textiles/embroidery/fashion/costume design  
• Ceramics/glass  
• Jewellery  
• Sculpture  
• Digital media including desktop publishing, animation and mul-  
ti-media.  
Supplementary and storage spaces may include\:  
• Resource areas  
• Dark rooms and screen processing room for screen prints  
• Editing and production suites  
• Prep/cleaning areas  
• Screening room  
• Clay, damp and plaster stores  
• Kiln rooms  
• Wood, metal and stone equipment stores  
• Secure dye store  
• Media consumables store  
• Laser cutting laboratory  
• 3D and 2D printing and binding  
• Display/exhibition space  
• Student work stores.  
*Primary design considerations*  
The location and orientation of the art department or school can  
affect the accommodation in a number of ways. Some of the main  
considerations are listed in what follows\:  
• Daylight – maximise daylight but control glare and solar gain,  
where fine detail and colour rendering are important  
• Increase ceiling heights and maximise surface reflectance  
• Acoustics – noise disturbance between dissimilar disciplines  
working in the same or adjacent spaces  
• Ventilation – extraction systems needed for specialist activities  
and equipment including removal of heat, noxious gases/fumes,  
dark room chemicals, dust and aerosols/airbrushes  
• Artificial light – an even spread of light without glare. Adopt  
recommended luminance levels and colour rendering of lamps **41-8 Universities**  
• Direct access to sheltered outside areas for external work for  
messy or large scale projects  
• Co-location between departments with shared resources  
• Delivery of bulky or heavy materials  
• Display areas for student work  
• Store rooms directly accessible from the studio spaces.  
Suites of art spaces are sometimes designed as open plan areas  
which can create a sense of light and space, and provide greater  
flexibility. However, noise transmission and dust can be a problem  
in open plan areas such as sculpture and ceramics. Open plan areas  
also need to provide sufficient pin-up space.  
*Other considerations*  
• Folding display walls and mobile display panels for exhibition  
and display  
• A central furniture, fixtures and equipment store or area within  
the workshops/studios  
• Durability and design of fixed partitions in art studios  
• Photo studios as black boxes with no daylight, requiring ‘infinity  
walls’ for fashion and other shoots  
• Flexible social learning areas that could be converted into an  
exhibition space or a catwalk  
• Secure personal storage, dining and kitchenette provision to  
cater for longer hours of operation  
• Water supply in studios and workshops. Heavy duty sinks in art,  
ceramic, sculpture, screen print and dye studios  
• Clay traps to sinks in ceramic studios  
• Overhead power supply.  
# 2.13 Teacher training/education  
Teacher training is provided at a faculty of education or at a school/  
department of education which is part of a larger university faculty.  
General teaching classrooms are required for subjects such as  
maths, English and modern foreign languages, humanities and  
business studies, and for the early years stage. Specialist accom-  
modation is required for all subjects taught in the primary and  
secondary education curriculums, including\:  
• Science \(primary and secondary laboratories, prep rooms, stores,  
greenhouses\)  
• Design & Technology \(D&T classrooms, textile classrooms,  
laser cutting workshops and dedicated stores\)  
• Food technology \(food tech classrooms, dedicated stores and  
prep rooms\)  
• Art \(general studios, ceramic/wet studios, kiln rooms, photogra-  
phy/dark rooms and portfolio display areas\)  
• Music \(large ensemble studios, practice rooms, mixing/digital  
studios and storage\)  
• Drama \(drama studios, costume stores with make-up facilities, light-  
ing/AV control rooms, provision for theory sessions and research\)  
• PE \(sports halls, gyms, changing rooms, storage, dance studios,  
provision for theory sessions\)  
• IT \(IT labs, stores\).  
Relevant school Building Bulletins can be used as a guide for  
designing the specialist accommodation and supporting spaces.  
*Science accommodation*  
Both primary and secondary science laboratories will be required.  
Preparation areas should allow for controlled student access.  
Separate chemical and radioactive stores will also be required.  
The following laboratories will be required\:  
• Primary school labs \(flexible layout with perimeter benching\)  
• Biology and life sciences \(flexible layout with perimeter benching\)  
• General/physics \(flexible layout with perimeter benching or  
fixed pods with sinks\)  
• Chemistry \(with fixed gas and water pods, fume cupboards\).  
*PE accommodation*  
The provision for PE accommodation will depend on the particular  
courses offered by the university, but will typically require\:  
• A small- to medium-sized sports hall \(compliance with national  
standard sports hall sizes and competition standards is not  
required but may be beneficial if the facilities are to be used by  
the wider community\)  
• A gym  
• Adjacent changing facilities  
• An equipment store adjacent to the sports hall.  
Secondary PE courses will be as above but may also include\:  
• A 4–6 court sports hall \(compliance with national standards for  
sports hall sizes and competition standards is recommended\)  
• A dance studio.  
A provision for theory sessions such as a teaching alcove or a  
separate seminar room adjacent to the sports hall will be required.  
Separate student and staff changing facilities may be required.  
Community use and a provision of family changing cubicles should  
be considered where appropriate.  
Teacher training courses incorporate extensive work placement  
as part of the curriculum and place a high demand for one-to-one  
confidential interview rooms. Bookable interview/meeting rooms  
should be provided and are best located in dedicated clusters adja-  
cent to flexible social learning areas.  
# 2.14 Nursing and health professionals  
Nursing may be provided as a course within a faculty of health and/  
or in conjunction with other courses such as midwifery, psychology  
and social care. The core specialist accommodation for the course  
is the provision of nursing laboratories. These are designed as  
mock-up hospital wards intended to replicate the provision within a  
hospital, and include hospital beds with hoists, power, compressed  
air/vacuum supply and facilities to deliver theory sessions \(LED  
screens and flexible seating\). Associated facilities may include\:  
• A facility where students can be trained to use hoists  
• A simulation suite equipped with interactive mannequins, one-  
way mirrors and specialist AV  
• Assisted living teaching facilities to teach carers/health profes-  
sionals how to look after patients in a domestic environment.  
These can be provided within the nursing laboratories or as a sep-  
arate room with domestic furniture and finishes and a mock-up  
bathroom/shower and toilet  
• A facility for external carers. The room will include a variety  
of soft seating including high back support chairs and nursing  
chairs, allowing for meetings and interviews with students  
• A separate breastfeeding teaching room  
• Dedicated equipment storage.  
# 2.15 Engineering  
An engineering facility will consist of many types of accommo-  
dation. The key spaces that will distinguish it from other types of  
education/university spaces will be the\:  
• Laboratories  
• Workshops  
• Teaching and research spaces  
• Ancillary spaces \(including support, stores and material stores\).  
Engineering encompasses a wide range of disciplines and may  
include multidisciplinary/cross-department teaching. Each dis-  
cipline is likely to have unique as well as generic requirements.  
Some of the types of department and the individual requirements  
to consider are\: • Civil and structural\: resilience and robustness testing of items  
and assemblies often to destructive levels, requiring strong  
floors/walls/rooms and temperature-controlled spaces  
• Electrical and electronic\: access to low and high voltage and  
three phase power supplies, soldering and circuit printing  
\(potentially requiring specialist extract and lighting\), anti-static  
and electromagnetic considerations  
• Chemical and nuclear \(use of radioactive and chemical materi-  
als in gas, liquid and powered forms requiring specialist storage,  
containment and distribution requirements, fume cupboards and  
other specialist equipment requiring specialist ventilation and  
piped services, personnel safety and decontamination equipment  
such as showers\)  
• Automotive and aeronautic \(aerodynamic and performance test-  
ing of components and assemblies, potentially wind tunnels,  
rolling roads and jet engine testing spaces – with necessary  
acoustic and temperature controls/containment\)  
• Mechanical \(equipment for the fabrication and testing of compo-  
nents across a range of materials, traditionally metal and timber  
but increasingly making use of new technologies including rapid  
prototyping and water/laser cutting\).  
Design considerations may include\:  
• Large working areas  
• Material/resource stores  
• Specialist extract and ventilation  
• Acoustic controls separation  
• Drainage and water supply  
• Environmental controls  
• Lighting, including specialist requirements \(such as blackout,  
yellow lighting \(for lithography\), etc.\)  
• Vibration  
• Incorporation of digital recording material \(such as sensors to  
primary structure\)  
• Access control and security  
• Remote equipment controls  
• Dangerous substances and explosive atmosphere regulations and  
other regulatory restrictions  
• Provision of pipe services including compressed air and special-  
ist gases  
• Clean rooms and environments.  
*Space planning*  
The space planning for an engineering building should consider  
the following\:  
• A clear legible layout – including zoning, links between front of  
house, clear separation between testing/experiment spaces and  
set-down/write-up areas  
• Safe circulation zones – including protected escape routes in  
high-risk areas  
• Safe/clear marked working zones around equipment  
• Easy access to resources and materials – including teaching  
walls as well as equipment  
• Clear delivery routes and loading areas  
• Clear service strategy – with built-in future flexibility  
• Visibility – to consider visibility from a safety perspective as  
well as cross-departmental interaction/connectivity  
• Storage – both departmental and student such as lockers  
• Clear security line – more secure spaces located deeper into the  
building  
• Areas that may require 24-hour access.  
It is important to design in flexibility to the building and indi-  
vidual spaces to ensure future adaptability to incorporate new  
technologies, working methods and services. The key to designing  
for engineering is an understanding of the requirements early on.  
# Universities 41-9  
Due consideration needs to be given to the aforementioned criteria  
in light of specific requirements and look to maximise flexibility  
for future developments.  
# 2.16 Incubators  
An incubator is a term given to a facility that fosters and encour-  
ages entrepreneurship and minimises obstacles to new business  
formation and growth. It provides the opportunity for ‘start-ups’  
and ‘spin-offs’.  
*Start-ups and spin-offs*  
The incentive confronting an individual or group that discovers  
a significant invention is a choice between start-up and spin-off.  
‘Start-up’ is the term given to the choice that keeps the intellec-  
tual property rights \(knowledge\) of the invention, acquires start-up  
capital or ‘seed’ funding and forms a new company to develop the  
invention. ‘Spin-off’ is the term given to the choice that transfers  
the knowledge of the invention to an existing company to gain  
substantial benefit via compensation, profits or shares from devel-  
opment of the invention.  
*University incubators*  
University incubators aim to\:  
• Create a bridge between education and the economy  
• Accelerate technology transfer between the university and com-  
panies  
• Sponsor ‘spin-offs’ from academia and create ‘start-ups’.  
Originally, incubators were located in abandoned or underused  
university buildings, but have since grown rapidly and developed  
into new, high quality purpose-built ‘centres’ affiliated to univer-  
sities. These ‘centres’ will vary in the facilities provided reflecting  
and influenced by the research focus \(science, technology, busi-  
ness\) of the affiliated university. Many UK universities have  
new-build ‘centres’ and their growth continues. Within these cen-  
tres, incubator units will be planned on a modular basis and can  
vary in size from 10 m2 to 500 m2, with a mix of office, science  
or technology-type units, together with all the supporting facilities  
and services.  
Types of accommodation will vary but may include\:  
• Modular labs \(200 m2\) fitted out with write-up and wet lab areas  
• Flexi-labs \(500 m2\) either wet lab, office or combination  
• Offices \(10 to 200 m2\) for SMEs  
• Workshop facilities  
• Meeting rooms, conferencing and exhibition space  
• Reception and visitor areas  
• Mailing, faxing and copying services  
• Computer services, including secure internet connections  
• Cleaning and security facilities  
• Kitchen facilities, local catering  
• Business support links – finance, legal, public funding, banking,  
accountancy, patent agents.  
To protect the confidential and novel nature of the research  
and development work being undertaken, 24/7 high-level access  
and security control to the building is important, with additional  
dedicated access and security control to each of the inner modular  
incubator units.  
# 2.17 Student support facilities  
The provision of student support facilities may be allocated on  
a university wide basis, site/campus basis or faculty basis. The  
content and location will primarily be determined by the univer-  
sity’s estate strategy, and secondly by the needs of each faculty.  
Accommodation requirements will vary, but the following is a  
guide\: **41-10 Universities**  
*Student union*  
• Student union and association offices  
• Club activities and social rooms  
• Large multi-function events space  
• Bar and café areas  
• Storage \(records, stationery, equipment\).  
*Student services*  
• Student information centre \(including reception and waiting area\)  
• Admissions and funding/finance  
• Counselling, advice and guidance  
• Careers and employment  
• Student/learning support  
• Health services \(outsourced\), welfare and first aid  
• Nursery  
• Chaplaincy and multi-faith prayer rooms.  
*Other student support facilities*  
• UG student common room \(including refreshments\)  
• UG student society office  
• UG student group workroom  
• UG student individual/quiet study room  
• UG student computing labs  
• PGT student study room  
• PGT student computing lab  
• PGR workrooms.  
Similar functions, such as the student union and student services  
could be co-located to form a central focus for students on campus –  
namely a ‘student centre’ – provided that security and confidentially  
are not compromised.  
# 2.18 Staff facilities  
The provision of staff facilities may be allocated either on a site/  
campus-wide or faculty basis. The content and location will primar-  
ily be determined by the university’s estate strategy and secondly  
by the needs of each faculty. Accommodation requirements will  
vary, but the following is a guide\:  
• Staff common room \(including refreshments\)  
• Staff meeting and interview rooms  
• Storage \(archives, records, stationery, equipment\)  
• Staff print and post room  
• Porter’s room  
• Computer systems manager’s office  
• Technician’s office/workspace/help desk  
• Faculty-based staff resource centre  
• Faculty-based externally funded research institute space \(includ-  
ing reception\).  
# 2.19 Public facilities  
It is important that the main entrance to a university should be wel-  
coming and appeal to visitors as well as its regular users. Facilities  
available for public use should be easily accessible from the main  
entrance without compromising security or user movement.  
Accommodation requirements will vary, but the following is a guide\:  
• Main reception desk area  
• Visitors waiting and collection area  
• Information and exhibition area \(including displays of student  
output and future events\)  
• External affairs office \(college/school liaison\)  
• Security control point  
• Security control office.  
# 2.20 Conference facilities  
Many universities aspire to have world-class conference facilities  
to host corporate and distinguished speaker events, presentations,  
symposia and conferences. Conference facilities are expensive if  
underutilised and therefore the auditoria should also be considered for  
formal teaching of large and medium size cohort lecture groups. The  
accommodation requirements will vary, but the following is a guide\:  
• Auditoria \(300 seat and 150 seat\), consider flexible usage, poten-  
tial sub-division  
• Foyer/break-out/interaction/display space  
• Hospitality service room  
• Equipment/store room  
• Control room  
• Green room  
• Cloakrooms  
• Flexible exhibition space at or near the entrance  
• Potential for retractable seating within auditorium spaces  
• Furniture storage  
• Breakout areas  
• Back of house areas for the delivery and temporary installation of  
goods and equipment, including lighting and audio equipment.  
# 2.21 Catering facilities  
Catering facilities may be allocated on a university wide basis or  
site/campus basis. The provision will generally include a central  
facility supplemented by dispersed satellite refreshment facilities  
located in various academic buildings. The content and location  
will be determined by the university’s estate strategy and generally  
franchised to outside catering specialists. Under this arrangement,  
the university provides the built space with the catering specialist  
providing the supply and service of food/drinks, equipment and  
staff. The accommodation requirements will vary, but the follow-  
ing is a guide for a central facility.  
*Informal and formal dining*  
• Food court – buffet style \(including seating, servery, self-service  
islands and ‘back of house facilities’\)  
• Deli bar \(including seating, servery, self-service gondolas and  
‘back of house’ facilities\)  
• Coffee bar \(including seating, servery, self-service dispensers  
and ‘back of house facilities’\)  
• Formal dining area \(including seating area and finishing kitchen\).  
*Main kitchen and catering support*  
• Prep, cooking and plating areas  
• Wash-up area  
• Utensils, cutlery and crockery stores  
• Dry, cold and deep freeze stores  
• Goods reception  
• Catering office  
• Staff toilets, changing and lockers  
• Cleaners’ store  
• Bin storage area \(external\).  
*Other issues to be considered include*  
• Waste and recycling strategy  
• Delivery strategy  
• Security strategy, especially if the catering facilities are accessi-  
ble to the public  
• Other uses of the dining areas when not serving food, for exam-  
ple for social learning and collaborative working  
• Signage, branding and lighting design  
• Wi-Fi coverage and AV provision  
• Data points for tills and vending machines.  
Additional refreshments areas may include vending machines with  
cold drinks and snacks. Hot drink machines are becoming less  
popular as the provision of branded coffee bars becomes more  
common. Dedicated external dining areas \(decks, terraces, etc.\)  
should also be considered as part of amenities. **2.22 Retail facilities**  
The provision of retail facilities may be allocated on a university  
wide basis or site/campus basis. The content and location will  
primarily be determined by the university’s estate strategy and  
generally franchised to outside retail outlets. Under this arrange-  
ment, the university provides the built space with the retail outlets  
providing the supply and service of goods, equipment and staff.  
The accommodation requirements will vary, but the following is  
a guide\:  
• Bookshop  
• University memorabilia/giftware  
• Banking \(including ATMs\)  
• News agency/refreshments/stationery \(‘one stop shop’\)  
• Post office \(or incorporated in ‘one stop shop’\)  
• Whole foods store  
• Travel agency  
• Pharmacy  
• Hairdresser.  
# 2.23 Sport and recreation  
*Indoor facilities*  
Indoor sport and recreation facilities may include\:  
• Sports hall – 8-court badminton hall with lines for badminton,  
basketball, volleyball, handball, netball and tennis, provision for  
segregating the hall with net partitions  
• Fitness suite – comprising cardio-vascular and resistance stations,  
small reception and dedicated storage  
• Aerobics studio – used for dance, yoga and Pilates  
• Martial arts room  
• Swimming pool – 6-lane 25 m pool and seating area  
• Squash courts – with seating area to one/two courts  
• Staff office – permanent and part-time staff  
• Indoor sports \(dry\) changing/showers/toilets – separate male/  
female, number of private cubicles and lockers  
• Pool \(wet\) changing/showers/toilets – separate male and female,  
private cubicles and lockers  
• Equipment store – to accommodate sports hall equipment  
• Mat store – fire resistant room  
• Kitchen – small with storage, work surface and sink  
• Treatment room – treatment bench and desk, may double as first  
aid room  
• Store room\(s\) for sports clubs  
• Bar, lounge, catering – optional  
• Cleaner’s room – close to sports hall, sink and storage.  
*Outdoor facilities*  
Outdoor sport and recreation facilities may include\:  
• Sports pitches – rugby, football, cricket, hockey  
• Sports courts – 5-a-side football, hockey, netball, tennis \(All  
Weather Pitches\)  
• Outdoor sports changing/showers/toilets – separate male/female,  
including lockers  
• External referees’ changing/showers/toilets – separate male/  
female, including lockers  
• Equipment store – posts, nets, etc.  
*Other considerations*  
The following should be taken into account\:  
• Operational and management aspects of the sports facilities  
• Community and club use  
• Graduation, examination and exhibition use  
• Car parking requirements  
• Compliance with Sport England/Northern Ireland/Scotland/Wales  
competition standards.  
# Universities 41-11  
Refer to Chapter 37 for detailed planning and design guidelines for  
sports and recreation facilities.  
# 2.22 Academic offices  
The provision of academic office accommodation is a sensitive topic  
in many universities. Individual academic offices were originally  
provided on the assumption that they would be used for private study,  
conducting tutorials with two to four students, small staff meetings  
and for receiving professional visitors. As such, the academic office  
is a complex environment used for a number of different settings.  
*Individual or shared offices*  
In many universities, the need for all academic staff to have their  
own office is viewed as an important aspect of academic life.  
However, some universities consider that the offices are too large  
for one member of staff and as a result, the individual offices are  
being replaced with larger shared offices, supported by an appropri-  
ate number of small group rooms for meetings and tutorials. This  
arrangement may be particularly appropriate for those staff with  
high class contact hours, those regularly conducting visits to stu-  
dents on work placements, those in professional practice, or those  
involved in specialist facility-based research work, and as a result  
do not spend many hours in an office. Other facilities required  
to support the ‘shared office’ approach might include a common  
room, kitchenette, reception area with secretarial staff, printing and  
general reprographic stations with recycling facilities, and other  
support service facilities.  
*A balanced approach*  
A model of provision promoted by one university and accepted by  
staff involved a compromise between individual and shared offices  
for full time staff\: 25 per cent of the offices were allocated for indi-  
vidual academic staff \(Dean 20 m2, HOD 15 m2, other 10 m2\) with  
the remaining 75 per cent allocated to shared offices split equally  
between offices for two academic staff \(16 m2\) and offices for four  
academic staff \(32 m2\). The faculty could decide how to allocate  
their offices to academic staff. A set of small, bookable rooms were  
provided for tutorials, meetings, etc. Open plan shared ‘hot-desk-  
ing’ offices were provided for part-time staff \(4 m2/50 per cent of  
part-time staff\).  
# 2.24 Administrative offices  
Demand for administrative space in HE is expanding, reflecting  
the growth in certain areas of work such as quality assurance,  
marketing, central fundraising and widening participation work,  
along with services in established areas such as finance, research  
administration and student support. A typical list of university  
administration and central departments includes\:  
• University management  
• Finance  
• Human resources  
• Marketing  
• Quality assurance  
• Business development  
• IT systems support  
• Registry, admissions and exams  
• Student and academic services  
• Estates and facilities.  
New buildings offer the opportunity to co-locate administrative  
departments, improving efficiency, enhancing student/staff ser-  
vices and saving space. Space savings can be achieved by arranging  
administrative departments in suites of large, open plan offices  
with small-embedded offices or ‘pods’ for privacy, confidentiality  
or breakout time. Creatively designed open plan offices can provide  
flexibility, as well as a conducive and effective environment for  
team working, interaction and communication. **41-12 Universities**

# 2.26 The virtual campus  
The concept of a virtual campus refers to a specific format of dis-  
tance education and online learning in which students, teaching  
staff and even university administrative and technical staff mainly  
‘meet’ or communicate through technical links. A virtual campus  
can also refer to the online offerings of a university where course  
work is completed either partially or wholly online, often with  
assistance from a tutor, teacher or teaching assistant. Although the  
phrase ‘virtual campus’ is an important concept in education, there  
is no theoretical framework for it. There is no consensus over the  
optimum concept for e-learning and the rapid development of tech-  
nologies is continually changing the landscape.  
*e-university*  
In 2003, the e-university was launched as a single vehicle of  
UK universities’ HE programmes over the internet. Following  
its launch, it attracted just 900 students against a target of 5600.  
In effect, it failed and Higher Education Funding Council for  
England \(HEFCE\) decided to switch to support the development  
of e-learning in universities that provided coherent progress.  
However, it is expected that e-learning will increase in popularity  
as a response to improvements in the learning interface and high  
fee levels.  
*Embedded e-learning*  
The failure of the e-university has impacted on e-learning and  
shown the importance of holding a narrowly skewed focus or  
definition of e-learning. A learner-centred approach not a technol-  
ogy-driven approach is now considered the way forward. This is  
known as ‘embedded e-learning’.  
*Information communications technology*  
Technologies used in learning, such as interactive whiteboards,  
personal learning environments, wireless networks and mobile  
devices, plus the internet and high quality digital learning  
resources, and the ability to access many of these from home  
and the workplace, are altering the experience and aspirations of  
learners.  
*Mobile and wireless technologies*  
Mobile and wireless technologies have increasingly widespread  
use in HE and the current trend is towards planning innovative  
methods in which to incorporate these technologies into e-learning.  
Key benefits in their use are seen as\:  
• Portability and anytime, anyplace connectivity  
• Flexibility and timeless access to e-learning resources  
• Immediacy of communication  
• Empowerment and engagement of learners  
• Active learning experiences. *Mobile and wireless learning*  
‘Mobile and wireless learning’ is an adopted term for the broad  
concept involving many of the same technologies and facilities as  
e-learning, but with access via mobile devices or wireless networks  
rather than cable networks. Mobile and wireless devices have sup-  
ported presentational, interactive and creative forms of learning,  
and when combined with e-learning, multi-media opportunities  
have resulted. Current best practice has been with the most well-  
known technologies\: USB storage devices, PDAs, laptops, tablet  
PCs, mobile phones and electronic voting. The reason for adoption  
of these is\:  
• Wider availability  
• Ability to support a range of functions  
• Desktop functionality  
• Ease of use  
• Acceptance by learners  
• Potential to support pedagogical aims.  
The easier the mobile device can become the property of the learner,  
the more it is used. However, provision needs to be made for equip-  
ment booking, battery charging, induction and IT support systems.  
*Online exams and assessments*  
Technology is also being used for regulated online computer-as-  
sisted assessments and exams replacing paper-based methods at  
many universities. This is proving very successful with students.  
It will require supervised and controlled environments within the  
university in the form of dedicated secure rooms.  
*Campus-based e-learning*  
As mentioned earlier, across the sector the general expectation  
is that e-learning at a distance will not wholly supplant face-to-  
face teaching. However, campus-based e-learning will continue  
to develop and allow students to work more flexibly, on and off  
campus. At any one time, students will be able to work elsewhere  
on their projects, using their laptops or mobile devices linked to the  
campus wireless network.  
*Distance learning*  
Distance learning, sometimes called e-learning, is a teaching and  
learning system designed to be carried out remotely using elec-  
tronic communication. It offers opportunities in situations where  
traditional education has difficulty in operating. It is more flexi-  
ble in time and can be delivered anywhere. Popular technologies  
are CDs, MP3, web-casts, DVDs, video conferencing and inter-  
net. There is student-teacher interaction with feedback. The Open  
University, other universities and distance learning centres spe-  
cialise in supplying distance learning courses, home study courses,  
online training and courses in a variety of subjects to gain nation-  
ally recognised qualifications.  
*Distributed learning*  
Distributed learning, also called IT-mediated instruction, is an  
instructional model that involves using various information tech-  
nologies to help students learn. It encompasses technologies such  
as video or audio conferencing, satellite broadcasting and web-  
based multi-media formats. It can be implemented in various forms  
and scales, for example\:  
• Course enhancement – instructional technologies embedded in  
traditional classroom settings can be made available for students  
to consult before or after class sessions via the website making  
learning less dependent on time and location  
• Hybrid delivery – a web-based multi-media lecture made avail-  
able to students to view online before attending a class session,  
and also made available for use in other courses multiplying  
their usefulness  
# Universities 41-13  
• Virtual classroom – ‘any time, any place, at any pace’ of learning.  
A course can be packaged on a CD-ROM, including prerequisite  
online lectures and the PowerPoint presentations coupled with  
audio for distance learners.  
# 2.26 Other modes of learning  
*Work-based learning*  
Workplace-based learning is expected to increase although the  
expectation is that it will remain a minor aspect of HE activity.  
Some institutions are likely to become more involved in this work,  
particularly at foundation degree level and with tailor-made mas-  
ters’ courses delivered on organisations’ premises. There will be a  
saving on teaching space, but not support space.  
*Partnerships*  
In some fields, notably creative arts, staff and students are becom-  
ing more itinerant, using cities’ cultural infrastructures and  
practitioner workplaces. Partnership arrangements of this kind are  
often involved and unlikely to lead to a saving on teaching space.  
# 3 SPACE PLANNING  
Environmental, economic and social issues form an integral part of  
the decision process in planning new educational facilities.  
# 3.1 Key issues  
The following are some key approaches to consider when planning  
new educational facilities\:  
• Adopt a modular planning system that is clear and simple to  
use; that has the ability to maximise a range of alternative plans  
needed by the university; and that will meet the objectives of  
functionality, cost effectiveness and adaptability. Modular sys-  
tems can offer practical and economic advantages during design,  
construction and throughout the life of a building  
• Distinguish between those parts of the building that will be fixed  
or unchanging, such as the structure, primary circulation and  
services cores; and those parts that need to be flexible or allow  
change, such as teaching spaces, local servicing systems, inter-  
nal partitions, flooring and ceiling systems  
• Use non-cellular construction techniques, incorporate large span  
framed structures where appropriate, and create column-free  
flexible space  
• Plan space in terms of broad categories of use, with provision  
not only suitable for its briefed purpose, but which is also easily  
adaptable  
• Make greater use of general purpose teaching space; adopt  
appropriate ranges of room sizes; and use partitions between  
rooms that can be moved without major disruption  
• Locate general teaching rooms in a common pool for timetabling  
and sharing between departments/schools  
• Locate accommodation used by large numbers of students at the  
lower levels of a building; and locate accommodation that is to  
be used by smaller numbers of students at upper levels  
• Organise accommodation such that discrete academic depart-  
ments can expand and contract without major adaptation;  
boundaries between departments should be flexible.  
# 3.2 Sustainability  
Applying sustainable solutions where appropriate to education  
projects that reduce environmental impact is an important consid-  
eration. Some of the issues to be considered are\:  
• Zoning of space to minimise mechanical and cooling require-  
ments  
• Creation of open plan, flexible and adaptable environments to  
reduce churn **41-14 Universities**  
• Façades that significantly reduce incident solar gains, moderate  
external noise, provide opportunities for natural ventilation, and  
allow user control to provide satisfactory comfort conditions  
• Façade U-values that exceed building regulations  
• Material specifications that select recycled materials and prod-  
ucts from sustainable sources  
• Robust materials requiring low maintenance  
• Low energy artificial lighting and controls, via presence detec-  
tors and daylight linking, to maximise the use of daylight and  
provide a visually comfortable space  
• Low energy cooling and mechanical ventilation systems, via dis-  
placement air systems, with heat recovery to reduce energy use  
• Low maintenance requirements during the operational life of  
systems  
• Introducing measures to reduce water use such as dual flush  
WCs, low-pressure water systems and aerating taps  
• Rainwater recycling to reduce consumption of potable water  
• Integrating photovoltaic arrays to reduce energy consumption  
• Providing cycle and subsidised public transport networks to dis-  
courage private vehicle use and reduce carbon emissions  
• Using local suppliers and contractors to support local economy  
and minimise carbon emission  
• Using fuel cell powered site vehicles.  
# 3.3 Space norms  
Space norms used to be published by the University Grants  
Committee \(UGC\) and the Polytechnics and Colleges Funding  
Council \(PCFC\). They were based on observations and assumptions  
about how students in different disciplines were taught – number  
of hours, type of teaching activity, staff/student ratio and area per  
workplace. They were widely used by institutions and the UK HE  
Funding Councils to inform the size of new building projects, but  
there have been no new or updated norms published for decades.  
Although there has been a shift away from using space norms,  
many institutes still use them as a guide for space weightings often  
with modifications.  
*UGC space norms*  
UGC space norms were expressed as an ‘allowance’ of net usable  
area per full-time equivalent \(FTE\) student for ‘departmental aca-  
demic areas’. The allowance comprised the following space types\:  
• General teaching space \(excluding lecture theatres\)  
• Academic offices and research labs  
• Non-academic offices and stores  
• Teaching and PG research labs  
• Lab ancillaries.  
There were also space norms for ‘non-departmental academic  
areas’ expressed as an ‘allowance’ of net usable area per FTE stu-  
dent for the following space types\:  
• Lecture theatres  
• Library  
• Administration \(including maintenance\)  
• Social, dining, health centres  
• Sports facilities \(building\) – indoor and outdoor.  
The norm varied according to academic discipline and was a  
guide to quantifying overall space requirements as a basis for pro-  
ject briefs. The UK HE Space Management Group \(SMG\) updated  
UGC norms in 2006. These are listed in Table I.  
*PCFC space norms*  
The PCFC introduced a new system of space norms for PCFC  
institutions \(Polytechnics and Colleges\) in 1990 with reduced  
area allowances to reflect the practice at the time. The norms were  
around 15 per cent less than previously used methods of calculation  
and included the following\:  
• Specialist and non-specialist areas  
• General teaching spaces  
• Libraries  
• Staff, administration  
• Sports and catering facilities.  
The SMG updated PCFC norms in 2006. These are listed in

# 3.4 Space standards

# 3.5 Area definitions  
Five definitions of floor area are used in construction projects in  
higher educational institutions, Figure 41.4. It is imperative that  
any area stated is qualified as being one of the following five  
definitions\:  
*Gross external area – for planning applications*\: the area of  
the building measured externally at each floor level, including  
all spaces within the building, and perimeter wall thicknesses,  
external projections, loading bays and garages. It excludes open  
balconies, canopies and roof terraces.  
# Universities 41-15
