*Gross internal area – for building costs estimation*\: the area of a  
building measured to the internal face of the perimeter walls at  
each floor level. It includes all spaces within the building, inter-  
nal structure, walls and partitions, loading bays and garages. It  
excludes voids over atria.  
*Net internal area – equivalent of net lettable area*\: the area within  
a building that comprises usable areas \(including built-in fixtures  
that occupy usable space\) and primary horizontal circulation. It  
excludes common entrance halls, atria, landings and balconies,  
toilets, bathrooms, cleaners’ rooms, plant spaces \(rooms, ducts  
and stores\), vertical circulation, internal structure \(walls, col-  
umns, piers, etc.\), loading bays and garages.  
*Net usable area – area available in rooms for people to use*\: the  
area within a building available for people to use. It excludes  
primary horizontal circulation in addition to all of the aforemen-  
tioned.  
*Balance area – area to enable the building to function*\: the floor  
area planned to enable the building to function. It includes pri-  
mary horizontal and vertical circulation, entrance lobbies, atria,  
foyers, lifts, toilets, cloakrooms, cleaners’ rooms and stores,  
plant spaces \(rooms, ducts, stores\), loading bays and garages,  
internal structure \(wall, columns, piers, etc.\).  
However, it should be noted that definition conventions may  
change in the future with the wider introduction of the International  
Property Measurement Standards \(see Chapter 5, Section 4.3\).  
*Gross Floor Space \(GIA\) area breakdown*  
Guidance now recommends that new-build projects should target  
the following GIA floor space area breakdown\:  
• Net usable area 70 per cent  
• Balance area 30 per cent  
• Total \(GIA\) 100 per cent.  
# 4 BRIEFING  
# 4.1 The brief  
In its broadest sense, the brief is a ‘model’ of the functional com-  
ponents of an organisation that needs to be accommodated in the  
design proposals. It needs to identify the qualitative and quanti-  
tative aspects of the client’s requirements that are essential to the  
project.  
However, the successful outcome of a project will depend upon  
the design team gaining a comprehensive understanding of the  
client’s values, ethos, aspirations and objectives; all stakeholder  
functional requirements; and the wider project parameters. This  
understanding can only be established by implementing a thorough  
and methodical briefing process. **41-16 Universities**  
**41.4** *Diagram illustrating area definitions\: RICS Code of measuring practice \(6th ed.\)*  
The following points are true of a ‘good’ brief\:  
• The more comprehensive the guidance, and the more certain the  
criteria identified in the brief, the greater is the probability that  
the design solution will provide an appropriate and satisfactory  
framework for the client  
• Each stage of briefing must establish criteria that are salient to  
the progress of the design to a higher level of certainty and detail  
• A brief must precede design, but the sequence of events and  
interaction between briefing and design must accommodate  
widely varying preferences, working methods and levels of  
expertise in different user groups and clients.  
# 4.2 Briefing stages  
Briefing is an iterative process and an integral part of design. It  
takes place in clearly defined stages that establish approved guid-  
ance and criteria for the corresponding design stage. The various  
stages are shown in the following\:  
• Strategic brief\: strategic plan, master plan, feasibility study  
• Concept brief\: concept design, preliminary design  
• Scheme brief\: scheme design, final design  
• Detail brief\: detail design, production information.  
A preliminary version of each brief – strategic, concept, scheme  
or detail – should be approved before work is started on the corre-  
sponding design stage.  
# 4.3 Briefing process  
Briefing requires the full engagement of a client. The stages in the  
process are summarised in what follows and in Figure 41.5.  
*Project sponsor and project steering group*  
• At the outset, it is essential that a ‘project sponsor’ from within  
the university be identified to ‘champion’ the project  
• Under the direction of the project sponsor, a project steering  
group comprising key university personnel should be established  
to represent the views of all ‘user groups’ and ‘stakeholders’  
involved in the project.  
*Vision statement and background*  
• A vision statement identifying the aims and objectives of the  
project should be prepared by the university and presented by  
the project sponsor  
• Alongside the vision statement, a basic statement of need and  
the operational and delivery requirements of the project should  
be provided  
• All relevant background information and any documentation of  
previous work undertaken, that may assist in the briefing pro-  
cess, should be made available.  
*Interview meetings*  
• The project sponsor or steering group should identify key per-  
sonnel within the university to be interviewed in the first step of  
collecting data to develop the project brief  
• In advance of the meetings, all interviewees should prepare an  
outline statement of need and complete a questionnaire pro-  
forma, prepared by the briefing team, which will seek to obtain  
essential data sufficient to inform preliminary space planning  
• During the interview process, all existing accommodation should  
be visited and assessed as to whether it meets the functional and  
operational requirements of each user group.  
*Data analysis*  
• Data gathered at the interview meetings should be analysed and  
collated to form the basis of the preliminary space need, space  
relationships and space modelling options.  
*Benchmarking*  
• Benchmarking is an invaluable activity that should be under-  
taken in the early stages of briefing. Together with the client,  
appropriate projects should be identified and visited to show var-  
ying design solutions that are relevant to the project  
• To manage client expectations, it is essential that the budget for  
all benchmark visits is declared and fully understood  
• The benefits of benchmarking are far-reaching, as it takes stake-  
holders out of an everyday environment to unfamiliar places  
where previously unconsidered possibilities and solutions can be  
witnessed first-hand  
• In the absence of any space standards provided by the university,  
a review of the HEFCE/DELNI/SFC/HEFCW space planning  
and design guidelines could be undertaken \(even though these  
have not been updated for some years\).  
*Preliminary briefing document*  
• A complete record of all briefing meetings, the vision state-  
ment, functional and operational requirements, structure charts,  
population schedules, accommodation schedules \(assuming **Universities 41-17**  
**41.5** *Briefing process diagram*  
shared/non-shared facilities\), preliminary activity space data,  
significant/desirable functional relationships and process flow  
diagrams, should be incorporated into a preliminary briefing  
document for review and discussion with the project steering  
group, and for approval by the project sponsor.  
*Briefing development*  
• Following approval of the preliminary briefing document, design  
concept options can be developed for review with the project  
sponsor and project steering group  
• The concept options should be tested against the preliminary  
brief to determine the most appropriate or preferred option for  
the project  
• The briefing process should continue in parallel with the design  
process and further meetings held with staff, as required, to  
develop detailed schedules of accommodation and room data  
sheets  
• All data collected should be incorporated into subsequent brief-  
ing documents for discussion with the project steering group and  
for client comment and approval.
